('30', 0, 1, 2, 44) 1. SPEECH AT ALL INDIA STUDENTS CONFERENCE, BELGAUM
('30', 0, 2, 3, 96) December 27, 1924
('30', 0, 3, 4, 114) Mahatma Gandhi arrived at the pandal and was accorded a warm welcome.
('30', 0, 3, 5, 184) In compliance with the request of the president and the audience, the Mahatma spoke most feelingly for about 10 minutes.
('30', 0, 3, 6, 305) He exhorted the students to practise swadeshi and wear khaddar.
('30', 0, 3, 7, 369) He explained as to how the salvation of India was bound up with the spread of the spinning wheel.
('30', 0, 3, 8, 467) He told the audience that he was not prepared to admit the plea of want of time.
('30', 0, 3, 9, 548) They could do the work provided they had the will to do it.
('30', 0, 3, 10, 608) Finally he declared that khaddar was not the symbol of hatred of anybody but that it was the symbol of love and self dependence.
('30', 0, 3, 11, 737) The Mahatma was then garlanded amidst loud applause.
('30', 0, 3, 12, 790) The president thanked him for blessing the Conference after which the Mahatma left the pandal.
('30', 0, 4, 13, 885) The Bombay Chronicle, 2 1 1924
('30', 0, 5, 14, 916) 2. SPEECH ON CONDOLENCE RESOLUTION, BELGAUM CONGRESS
('30', 0, 6, 15, 969) December 27, 1924
('30', 0, 7, 16, 987) It was 11.20 a.m.
('30', 0, 7, 17, 1005) when the President moved the following resolution: The Congress records with sorrow the death of Mr. G. M. Bhurgari and tenders its respectful sympathy to the bereaved family.
('30', 0, 8, 18, 1181) Before putting the resolution to vote the President remarked 1:
('30', 0, 9, 19, 1245) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, I am ashamed to have to say that there was an omission when we passed the first resolution.
('30', 0, 9, 20, 1359) A friend from Sind has brought it to my notice that in the resolution mourning the loss of our departed leaders a name was left out—that of Mr. Bhurgari.
('30', 0, 9, 21, 1513) I think you know it and will agree when I say that I could not have deliberately left out this name.
('30', 0, 9, 22, 1614) But I am in such a pitiable state that I tend to forget things when I am engrossed in work.
('30', 0, 9, 23, 1706) It was with great difficulty that I wrote down the names that I did—it was in the address I had prepared—and since I myself wrote the address I was not aware of the omission.
('30', 0, 9, 24, 1881) I would have written Mr. Bhurgari’s
('30', 0, 10, 25, 1917) 1 In Hindi
('30', 1, 0, 1, 1928) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 1, 1, 2, 1968) name most respectfully.
('30', 1, 1, 3, 1992) In my heart also I had the greatest respect for him.
('30', 1, 1, 4, 2045) I have committed an ommission and I apologize for this to his relatives.
('30', 1, 1, 5, 2118) The fact is I had a great regard for him.
('30', 1, 1, 6, 2160) He was a Sindi Mussalman and he loved Hindus.
('30', 1, 1, 7, 2206) When I go to Sind people there say that Mr. Bhurgari was a true son of India.
('30', 1, 1, 8, 2284) Why should we not mourn his loss?
('30', 1, 1, 9, 2318) I request you, brothers and sisters, to rise from your seats and stand respectfully for one minute.
('30', 1, 1, 10, 2418) Let no one keep sitting; all must stand up.
('30', 1, 1, 11, 2462) Now all of you should maintain silence.
('30', 1, 1, 12, 2502) Do not talk.
('30', 1, 1, 13, 2515) We have to finish our programme, if possible by 5 o’clock.
('30', 1, 1, 14, 2574) In this I seek the help of all the delegates.
('30', 1, 1, 15, 2620) Concerning the first resolution that will be moved today, no discussion is necessary and so no lengthy explanation is called for.

('30', 1, 1, 17, 2788) I also want to say that no copies have been distributed amongst you of the resolutions that will be moved today.
('30', 1, 1, 18, 2901) The Reception Committee was not able to do this; there is no press in Belgaum so that all the resolutions that the Reception Committee wanted to print could be printed.
('30', 1, 1, 19, 3070) The Subjects Committee can continue its sittings for two or three days and the resolutions that it drafts can be printed.
('30', 1, 1, 20, 3192) But there is no resolution which makes it necessary to distribute its copies amongst you.
('30', 1, 1, 21, 3282) You will forgive me as well as the Reception Committee for this, and pass the resolutions as they are read out to you.

('30', 2, 4, 7, 4481) 4. SPEECH ON RESOLUTION ON KOHAT AND GULBURGA RIOTS, BELGAUM CONGRESS
('30', 2, 5, 8, 4551) December 27, 1924
('30', 2, 6, 9, 4569) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, You have heard many speeches concerning this resolutions 1. I have received intimations that some more friends are anxious to take part in the discussion.
('30', 2, 6, 10, 4746) But I have told them to excuse me I do not feel anything more needs to be known about the resolution.
('30', 2, 6, 11, 4848) A friend refers to the Board mentioned in the resolution and wants to know the names of the personnel.
('30', 2, 6, 12, 4951) There are two things mentioned.
('30', 2, 6, 13, 4983) If the Board appointed by the Unity Conference does not do its work, it can be replaced by another Board.
('30', 2, 6, 14, 5089) I forget all the names that comprise the Board of the Unity Committee; you will see them in the newspapers.
('30', 2, 6, 15, 5197) I am there, Shaukat Ali is there and some other Muslim brethren.
('30', 2, 6, 16, 5262) I do not want to leave it either.
('30', 2, 6, 17, 5296) I think the Board that has been appointed will collect testimony in regard to the happenings at Kohat.
('30', 2, 6, 18, 5399) Only when it arrives in Rawalpindi can it be known as to what it is possible to do and what it is not.
('30', 2, 6, 19, 5502) Whatever can be done will of course be done.
('30', 2, 6, 20, 5547) Those of you who support the resolution may duly raise their hands.
('30', 2, 7, 21, 5615) [From Hindi]
('30', 2, 8, 22, 5628) Report of the Thirty ninth Indian National Congress, 1924, p.
('30', 2, 9, 23, 5690) 1 The resolution moved by Motilal Nehru deplored the riots, the exodus of Hindus from Kohat and the failure of the local authority to give them protection.
('30', 2, 9, 24, 5846) It also advised the people not to accept the finding of the Government of India but to suspend judgment till the Board appointed by the Unity Conference or some other representative body had enquired into the event and come to decision.
('30', 2, 9, 25, 6083) The resolution expressed sympathy for the sufferers in Gulburga riots.
('30', 2, 9, 26, 6154) 2 The resolution was carried.

('30', 3, 1, 2, 6224) 5. SPEECH ON RESOLUTION ON UNTOUCHABILITY, BELGAUM CONGRESS
('30', 3, 2, 3, 6284) December 27, 1924
('30', 3, 3, 4, 6302) I call upon Mr. Bhopatkar to move the resolution on untoucha bility .
('30', 3, 3, 5, 6372) Before doing so, let me inform you that some Tamil friends have written to me asking that the resolutions might also be translated into Tamil.
('30', 3, 3, 6, 6515) I am extremely sorry that I cannot possibly do that.
('30', 3, 3, 7, 6568) There are 21 provinces to deal with and if we are to render each resolution into so many languages, it would really be not possible to get on.
('30', 3, 3, 8, 6711) Up to now we have been adopting three languages: One is Hindi which everyone is expected to know ; the second is English; and the third is the vernacular of the province.
('30', 3, 3, 9, 6882) We have not been able to reach that common medium, Hindustani, through which we can know each other, because we have always the South to obstruct the way.
('30', 3, 3, 10, 7037) That is why we are using the vernacular of this province as well as English.
('30', 3, 3, 11, 7114) But I would suggest for such cases that those who know English or Hindustani in the said province should take the trouble of explaining the resolutions passed here to their friends who do not know any of the languages here spoken..
('30', 3, 4, 12, 7346) BROTHERS, I am sorry to say that Panditji is not here at the moment.
('30', 3, 4, 13, 7415) I had been asked—and I requested him to say something.
('30', 3, 4, 14, 7470) He said, he did not want to say anything.
('30', 3, 4, 15, 7512) Then again I was told that he would say a few words.
('30', 3, 4, 16, 7565) But at this time he is not here.
('30', 3, 4, 17, 7598) Before I put this resolution to vote I must answer note that I have received.
('30', 3, 4, 18, 7676) A friend asks if the resolution on removal of untoucha bility implies inter dining and inter marriage with the untouchables.
('30', 3, 4, 19, 7801) There is nothing in the resolution suggesting this, but if this friend wants to know what I myself feel in the matter I will say that I have expressed my views in Navajivan and Young India —namely, that we should behave with those we consider untouchable as we behave with other castes.
('30', 3, 5, 20, 8088) 1 After some speakers had supported the resolution, the President called upon Madan Mohan Malaviya to speak.
('30', 3, 5, 21, 8197) As he was absent, the President put the resolution to vote speaking in Hindi.
('30', 4, 0, 1, 8275) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 5
('30', 4, 1, 2, 8319) There was one hand raised against the resolution.
('30', 4, 1, 3, 8369) The President declared it carried.
('30', 4, 1, 4, 8404) [From Hindi]
('30', 4, 2, 5, 8417) Report of the Thirty ninth Indian National Congress, 1924, pp.

('30', 4, 3, 7, 8488) 6. SPEECH AT CONGRESS SESSION BELGAUM 1
('30', 4, 4, 8, 8528) December 27, 1924
('30', 4, 5, 9, 8546) BROTHERS, Before I move the next resolution I have an atonement to make.
('30', 4, 5, 10, 8619) When the resolution on removal of untouchability was being moved, I had it in mind to present an untouchable brother before you.
('30', 4, 5, 11, 8748) I had received a note saying an untouchable brother who was not a delegate wanted to say a few words.
('30', 4, 5, 12, 8850) I had felt that even though he was not a delegate it would be good to permit him to speak as he was an untouchable.
('30', 4, 5, 13, 8966) And so I had wanted to call him.
('30', 4, 5, 14, 8999) But I forgot.
('30', 4, 5, 15, 9013) The only way I now can atone for it is to apologize to him.
('30', 4, 5, 16, 9073) Anyway, it is good that I remembered in time.

('30', 4, 7, 19, 9195) 7. SPEECH ON ANNIE BESANT’S STATEMENT, BELGAUM CONGRESS
('30', 4, 8, 20, 9251) December 27, 1924
('30', 4, 9, 21, 9269) Now, before I proceed to the other resolutions I have to announce to you that Dr. Besant feels that she must make a statement before this House in connection with the resolution 2 we passed yesterday.
('30', 4, 9, 22, 9470) I do not wish to anticipate what the illustrious lady has got to say.
('30', 4, 9, 23, 9540) But I think I voice the feelings of this House when I tender my congratulations to her for gracing this pandal with her presence.
('30', 4, 9, 24, 9670) Whether she and her devoted followers are able to remain in the Congress or not, I may hope that we will always have her sympathy and moral support with us.
('30', 4, 9, 25, 9827) I now request Dr. Besant to make her statement .
('30', 4, 10, 26, 9876) 1 Before permitting a Panchama boy to speak for two minutes 2Vide “Resolution on Calcutta Agreement and Spinning Franchise, Belgaum Congress, 26 12 1924.
('30', 5, 0, 1, 10030) 6 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 5, 1, 2, 10070) FRIENDS, You have heard the statement that Dr. Besant has made.
('30', 5, 1, 3, 10134) You will not expect me to make any remarks upon that statement.
('30', 5, 1, 4, 10198) Dr. Besant has not made the statement, as I know, in order that she may have reply just now.
('30', 5, 1, 5, 10291) She has made that statement from a sense of duty so that her silence might not be construed into meaning that we had her assent to the resolution that we passed yesterday.
('30', 5, 1, 6, 10463) But I hope I may give her the assurance of this Congress that all that she has said will command our respectful attention and that no stone will be left unturned by this Congress or Congressmen and Congresswomen to open the door wide, as wide as is humanly possible, for the entrance of every party that has the interest of India at heart and every party whose goal is swaraj for India.
('30', 5, 1, 7, 10850) With these words I close this incident, repeating my request to Dr. Besant that whether she and other parties are able to join the Congress or not, the Congress will always expect her and every party’s sympathy and support in anything and everything that may commend itself to their attention.
('30', 5, 2, 8, 11144) Report of the Thirty ninth Indian National Congress, 1924, pp.
('30', 5, 2, 9, 11207) 105 & 107 8
('30', 5, 3, 10, 11219) 8. RESOLUTIONS MOVED FROM THE CHAIR, BELGAUM CONGRESS
('30', 5, 4, 11, 11273) December 27, 1924
('30', 5, 5, 12, 11291) The President next moved the following resolutions one by one and put each to vote and declared each carried.
('30', 5, 5, 13, 11401) The resolutions were read by Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru in English, by Sjt.
('30', 5, 5, 14, 11474) Mudvedkar in Kanarese, and by Pandit Sundar Lal in Hindi.
('30', 5, 6, 15, 11532) RESOLUTION X: NATIONAL EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTIONS
('30', 5, 7, 16, 11580) The Congress is strongly of opinion that the hope of the future of the country lies in its youth and therefore trusts that the Provincial Committees will strive more vigorously than they have done to keep alive all national educational institutions.
('30', 5, 7, 17, 11830) But whilst the Congress is of opinion that existing national educational institutions should be maintained and new ones opened, the Congress does not regard any such institution to be national which does not employ some Indian language as the medium of instruction, and which does not actively encourage Hindu Muslim unity, education among untouchables and removal of untouchability; which does not make hand spinning,
('30', 6, 0, 1, 12249) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 7
('30', 6, 1, 2, 12293) carding and training in physical culture and self defence obligatory; and in which teachers and students over the age of 12 years do not spin for at least half an hour per working day and in which students and teachers do not habitually wear khaddar.
('30', 6, 2, 3, 12544) RESOLUTION XI: PAID NATIONAL SERVICE
('30', 6, 3, 4, 12581) Whereas it has been discovered that many otherwise deserving men are unobtainable for national service because of the reluctance to accept remuneration for service, the Congress places on record its opinion that there is not only nothing derogatory to one’s dignity in accepting remuneration for national service, but the Congress hopes that patriotic young men and women will regard it as an honour to accept maintenance for service faithfully rendered and that those needing or those willing to service will prefer national to any other service.
('30', 6, 4, 5, 13129) RESOLUTION XII: CHANGES IN THE CONSTITUTION
('30', 6, 5, 6, 13173) In Article Xl “Rs. 10” to be altered to “Re.
('30', 6, 5, 7, 13218) In Article XXIII, add, after the first sentence ending with the word “Congress”: “The treasurers shall be in charge of the funds of the Congress and shall keep proper accounts of them.
('30', 6, 5, 8, 13403) The general secretaries shall be in charge of the office of the All India Congress Committee and shall be responsible for the publication of the report of the proceedings of the preceding session of the Congress and of any special session held in the course of the year, in co operation with the Reception Committee.
('30', 6, 5, 9, 13720) Such report shall be published as soon as possible and not later than four months after the session, and shall be offered for sale.” Add at the end of article XXIII: “and published along with the next Congress report.”
('30', 6, 6, 10, 13939) RESOLUTION XIII: DRINK AND OPIUM TRAFFIC
('30', 6, 7, 11, 13980) The Congress notes with satisfaction that notwithstanding the set back suffered by the campaign against the use of intoxicating drinks and drugs initiated in 1921, Congress workers in several parts of the country have continued it with vigour and determination.
('30', 6, 7, 12, 14242) The Congr ess hopes that the peaceful endeavours of workers to wean those who are addicted to the drink or the opium habit from the curse will receive further and greater strength and encouragement than hitherto.
('30', 7, 0, 1, 14455) 8 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 7, 1, 2, 14495) The Congress is of opinion that the policy of the Government of India in using the drink and drug habit of the people as a source of revenue is detrimental to the moral welfare of the people of India and would therefore welcome its abolition.
('30', 7, 1, 3, 14738) The Congress is further of opinion that the regulation by the Government of India of the opium traffic is detrimental not only to the moral welfare of India but of the whole world, and that the cultivation of opium in India which is out of all proportion to medical and scientific requirements should be restricted to such requirements.
('30', 7, 2, 4, 15075) Report of the Thirty ninth Indian National Congress, 1924, pp.
('30', 7, 2, 5, 15138) 115 6 & 118
('30', 7, 3, 6, 15150) 9. SPEECH ON RESOLUTION ON OFFICE BEARERS, 1 BELGAUM CONGRESS
('30', 7, 4, 7, 15212) December 27, 1924
('30', 7, 5, 8, 15230) There are now only two things remaining—things that we always have to do, namely, the election of general secretaries and a treasurer and deciding on the venue for the next Congress.
('30', 7, 5, 9, 15413) It will he desirable to leave this to the All India Congress Committee, as was done last year.
('30', 7, 5, 10, 15508) The treasurer is the same.
('30', 7, 5, 11, 15535) The general secretaries will be: first, Pandit Jawaharlal; second, Qureshi; and third, Mr. Bharucha.
('30', 7, 5, 12, 15636) Previ ously Dr. Kitchlew was there and Babu Rajendra Prasad was appro ached.
('30', 7, 5, 13, 15713) Babu Rajendra Prasad has to attend to many kinds of activities and he cannot give all his time to our work.
('30', 7, 5, 14, 15821) So the question of two new secretaries has come up.
('30', 7, 5, 15, 15873) There was a great deal of discussion in the Subjects Committee on the matter yesterday and I had talks with the delegates.
('30', 7, 5, 16, 15996) It was decided in the end that since I shall be the President of the Congress for this year and the next year, secretaries should be appointed from among the people who can help me in my work.
('30', 7, 5, 17, 16189) A number of Swarajists and No changers are there.
('30', 7, 5, 18, 16239) How would it be to take them into the Working Committee?
('30', 7, 5, 19, 16296) I also liked the idea— and I am willing to take into the Working Committee not one but all of them, but on one condition, namely, that they understand it clearly that there is only one national programme, that removal of untoucha bility, charkha, prohibition form one single programme.
('30', 7, 5, 20, 16582) I had said that if there be any Swarajist as staunchly believing in khadi as I do I
('30', 7, 6, 21, 16666) 1 The resolution was later put to vote and carried.
('30', 8, 0, 1, 16718) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 9
('30', 8, 1, 2, 16762) should like to take him, for through him I should reform all the Swarajists.
('30', 8, 1, 3, 16839) The moment they come and work with me we become united, that is if we wish to unite.
('30', 8, 1, 4, 16924) Thus the discussion went on.
('30', 8, 1, 5, 16953) No one came in view.
('30', 8, 1, 6, 16974) The two persons suggested are not necessarily No changers.
('30', 8, 1, 7, 17033) I know a little bit about them which I should like to tell you.
('30', 8, 1, 8, 17097) I know Shwaib Qureshi.
('30', 8, 1, 9, 17120) He is an orthodox Muslim.
('30', 8, 1, 10, 17146) But I have not taken him because of that.
('30', 8, 1, 11, 17188) I want to take full time work from secretaries.
('30', 8, 1, 12, 17236) I therefore told Maulana Shaukat Ali that if Shwaib Sahib would be willing to give me all his time I would like to have him.
('30', 8, 1, 13, 17361) He agreed.
('30', 8, 1, 14, 17372) He is the kind of man who, once he makes a promise, carries out that promise.
('30', 8, 1, 15, 17450) He has a love for khadi, this also I know.
('30', 8, 1, 16, 17493) Bharucha is a crank.
('30', 8, 1, 17, 17514) I am a crank too.
('30', 8, 1, 18, 17532) So we shall get on splendidly.
('30', 8, 1, 19, 17563) I shall have to learn from him to carry bundles of khadi on my shoulder and go hawking.
('30', 8, 1, 20, 17651) He has become a specialist in this.
('30', 8, 1, 21, 17687) It is his wish to see khadi reach every part of the country.
('30', 8, 1, 22, 17748) Not one but hundreds of Bharuchas are required thus to sell khadi.
('30', 8, 1, 23, 17815) Bharucha went to Lala Harkishen Lal, he went to others, and gave them khadi.
('30', 8, 1, 24, 17892) Even if people swear at him, he does not mind it.
('30', 8, 1, 25, 17942) The secretaries we need today should be such that they will sell khadi even if they are abused.
('30', 8, 1, 26, 18038) They should be able to put up with any kind of insult for the sake of khadi.
('30', 8, 1, 27, 18115) I have therefore selected these two.
('30', 8, 1, 28, 18152) But though I have done my selection the final say is yours.
('30', 8, 1, 29, 18212) The Subjects Committee has of course agreed.
('30', 8, 1, 30, 18257) But the constitution of the Congress requires that you express your opinion.
('30', 8, 1, 31, 18334) Those of you who accept these names should come out with their opinion.
('30', 8, 1, 32, 18406) About the treasurer nothing needs to be said.
('30', 8, 1, 33, 18452) You say if you like the man.

('30', 8, 5, 39, 18696) There is something to be announced.
('30', 8, 5, 40, 18732) You know there has been a spinning competition.
('30', 8, 5, 41, 18780) Some friends gave gold medals to be awarded, some silver medals.
('30', 8, 5, 42, 18845) In all, eleven such medals have been awarded.
('30', 8, 5, 43, 18891) I am going to explain to you who gave these eleven medals and to whom

('30', 9, 1, 6, 19209) It is a matter of great credit.

('30', 9, 1, 14, 19743) But we also notice that out of eleven medals, four have gone to our sisters and the rest to our brothers.

('30', 9, 1, 21, 20243) It seems he did not die so recently.
('30', 9, 1, 22, 20280) He died on the eve of the Cocanada Congress—just a day earlier.
('30', 9, 1, 23, 20344) It is the duty of all present to mourn for him.
('30', 9, 1, 24, 20392) And now we are through.

('30', 9, 3, 27, 20491) 11. CONCLUDING SPEECH AT BELGAUM CONGRESS
('30', 9, 4, 28, 20533) December 27, 1924
('30', 9, 5, 29, 20551) In bringing the proceedings of the session to a close, the President delivered a most impassioned address, first in Hindi and then in English .
('30', 9, 6, 30, 20695) BROTHERS, I now wish to tell you that whatever gratitude I may feel for you will be wholly inadequate.
('30', 9, 6, 31, 20798) I do not think any president can expect a greater amount of love than you have shown me.
('30', 9, 6, 32, 20887) You willingly did all the work that I wanted you to do for me.
('30', 9, 6, 33, 20950) When I bid you observe silence, you observed silence.
('30', 9, 6, 34, 21004) You listened to any speech I wanted to
('30', 9, 7, 35, 21043) 1 The fifth name is missing in the source.

('30', 10, 1, 2, 21131) You wanted me to deliver a written oration.
('30', 10, 1, 3, 21175) When I wanted to be excused, you did not press.
('30', 10, 1, 4, 21223) And just as you expressed your opinions here quietly, without being noisy, in the Subjects Committee also there was no disturbance.
('30', 10, 1, 5, 21355) In fact there might have been disturbance when the bomb of the charkha was dropped in your midst, but you raised no objection and in the Subjects Committee also behaved with perfect decorum.
('30', 10, 1, 6, 21546) I feel this kindness of my brethren to me must be the result of some good deed I may have done in an earlier life.
('30', 10, 1, 7, 21661) It is my wish that the kindness you have shown towards me, you should show towards India, for if I wish to live it is only for India and if I wish to die, it is also only for India.
('30', 10, 1, 8, 21843) Not a leaf stirs without God’s will.
('30', 10, 1, 9, 21880) But every man has a right to ask of God just as a child asks of his father what he wants.
('30', 10, 1, 10, 21970) I have seen that He even grants what I ask Him.
('30', 10, 1, 11, 22018) What God has willed cannot be otherwise.
('30', 10, 1, 12, 22059) I therefore appeal to you, brothers, to gird up your loins for the service of India and stick to the pledge you have taken.
('30', 10, 1, 13, 22183) I know I took the chair here as President and all of you gave me your love.
('30', 10, 1, 14, 22259) I desire, naturally, that everyone should praise me, but it does not lead to any achievement.
('30', 10, 1, 15, 22353) The achievement will come when all of you act as you have pledged.
('30', 10, 1, 16, 22420) I do not believe that all these tasks are beyond our strength—the third task or the fourth or fifth— none of them.
('30', 10, 1, 17, 22535) Listening to the speech of Bhopatkar gave me a pleasant surprise.
('30', 10, 1, 18, 22601) He demanded if we wanted the destruction of Hinduism that we treat men as untouchables.
('30', 10, 1, 19, 22689) I was very pleased.
('30', 10, 1, 20, 22709) And three shastris have just told you that there is no sanction in Hinduism for untoucha bility as it is practised.
('30', 10, 1, 21, 22825) Is it the same thing as when we say that Hindus and Muslims should not treat one another as enemies but as brothers?
('30', 10, 1, 22, 22942) Did you not hear what Shaukat Ali said?
('30', 10, 1, 23, 22982) What did Lajpat Rai say?
('30', 10, 1, 24, 23007) Zafar Ali Khan raised an objection.
('30', 10, 1, 25, 23043) I do not see anything to object to, but he is not an enemy of India.
('30', 10, 1, 26, 23112) You should treat no one as enemy.
('30', 10, 1, 27, 23146) The urge in your heart should be to make a brother of an enemy.
('30', 10, 1, 28, 23210) Lalaji has invoked a principle, namely, that the question is of the human species as a whole.
('30', 10, 1, 29, 23304) It is not confined to any particular religion.
('30', 10, 1, 30, 23351) He said if a Hindu became mad, should not a Mussalman swear at him?
('30', 10, 1, 31, 23419) If Mussalmans abused Ramachandra and Krishna should not Hindus abuse the Prophet?
('30', 10, 1, 32, 23501) If you cannot decide this matter by forgiving, go to a court or a panchayat.
('30', 10, 1, 33, 23578) I am a non co operator, but if a Mussalman abuses Lord Krishna I will say, “Go to a court, but do not fight.
('30', 10, 1, 34, 23687) There is nothing in this to fight over.” It does not require
('30', 11, 0, 1, 23748) 12 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 11, 1, 2, 23789) much time to accept this principle.
('30', 11, 1, 3, 23825) There should be a fever in us for swaraj, our hearts should burn for it.
('30', 11, 1, 4, 23898) When Bhopatkar was speaking I thought of Lokamanya.
('30', 11, 1, 5, 23950) He was the genius of swaraj.
('30', 11, 1, 6, 23979) A remarkable thing I heard about him is that when his wife lay dying he was busy in his work for swaraj.
('30', 11, 1, 7, 24084) If such volcanoes are created in our hearts we can do the third thing, the fourth thing and everything else.
('30', 11, 1, 8, 24193) That you should wear khadi when you come to Congress is nothing big.
('30', 11, 1, 9, 24262) That we should give up wearing foreign cloth is nothing big.
('30', 11, 1, 10, 24323) Today I do not talk about burning foreign cloth.
('30', 11, 1, 11, 24372) I am today not the man who in 1921 had caused foreign cloth to be burnt.
('30', 11, 1, 12, 24445) But we have left peaceful ways.
('30', 11, 1, 13, 24477) If even today we can bring about complete peace I can again take up what we did in 1921. Under the pretext of burning foreign cloth we heaped stones to throw at people.
('30', 11, 1, 14, 24646) I know we cannot simultaneously do both: invoke truth and practise untruth.
('30', 11, 1, 15, 24722) If we invoke truth we must not practise untruth, or our bodies will burn up.
('30', 11, 1, 16, 24799) It burns my heart certainly.
('30', 11, 1, 17, 24828) I cannot bear it if someone falsely swears by God or takes false pledges.
('30', 11, 1, 18, 24902) Abuse me by all means, beat me, kick me with shoes, spit at me, I give you my word that I shall not get angry.
('30', 11, 1, 19, 25013) But take a pledge and not act on it and anger will burn away my whole body.
('30', 11, 1, 20, 25089) I should wish to die if a woman who is unchaste should parade her chastity in front of me.
('30', 11, 1, 21, 25180) I should wish to die, again, if a man who is impure should parade his purity in front of me.
('30', 11, 1, 22, 25273) I should not wish to witness it.
('30', 11, 1, 23, 25306) If you want that the love you have shown me, the kindness you have done me in placing the mantle of responsibility on me, should continue, you should understand this well; keep me in this position if you want to.
('30', 11, 1, 24, 25519) But it will be even better if the Swarajists and No changers should walk in unison, As Dr. Besant said, one single stick, by itself, easily breaks, but in a bundle it is very strong.
('30', 11, 1, 25, 25702) Let us not think that the Swarajists are bad people.
('30', 11, 1, 26, 25755) To a pure heart all hearts are pure.
('30', 11, 1, 27, 25792) What are the qualities of the soul?
('30', 11, 1, 28, 25828) The soul is like marble.
('30', 11, 1, 29, 25853) Shankaracharya has said that blemishes are not native to it.
('30', 11, 1, 30, 25914) Blemishes are maya 1. If your heart acquires strength, you will be able to remove blemishes from others without thinking evil of them.
('30', 11, 1, 31, 26049) If treachery is the reward of trust, will the man who trusts come to harm?
('30', 11, 1, 32, 26124) Only the one who commits treachery will come to harm.
('30', 11, 1, 33, 26178) If I say to Jawaharlal that he is more than a son to me and if I say it only to take some work from him, it is deception.
('30', 11, 1, 34, 26300) Who am I to venerate
('30', 11, 2, 35, 26321) 1 Cosmic illusion
('30', 12, 0, 1, 26339) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 13
('30', 12, 1, 2, 26384) Jawaharlal?
('30', 12, 1, 3, 26396) The world will venerate him, shower flowers on him.
('30', 12, 1, 4, 26448) Today I have to say—not to the one alone or the other alone but to both: During this one year work so hard that our strength should be increased and we should be able to feel that swaraj is at last within our reach.
('30', 12, 2, 5, 26664) Addressing next in English the President said I have just poured out my heart to you in my Hindi speech.
('30', 12, 2, 6, 26769) It is impossible for me to reproduce what I have said in Hindi.
('30', 12, 2, 7, 26833) One thing however I want to say.
('30', 12, 2, 8, 26866) I do not think that any chairman, any president, could possibly claim greater courtesy, greater attention and greater affection than you the delegates have extended to me.
('30', 12, 2, 9, 27038) I assure you that it has been the greatest delight to me to preside over your deliberations here in the Congress and in the Subjects Committee.
('30', 12, 2, 10, 27182) Every one of you have readily responded to every call that I have made upon you.
('30', 12, 2, 11, 27263) I know that I have put a heavy strain upon you.
('30', 12, 2, 12, 27311) I have not walked you.
('30', 12, 2, 13, 27334) I know I have run you.
('30', 12, 2, 14, 27357) But what can I do?
('30', 12, 2, 15, 27376) You are impatient and I am impatient.
('30', 12, 2, 16, 27414) We want to march towards swaraj and our march for swaraj has got to be, not at a snail’s pace, but a double quick march; and if we do want to work and march forward, I cannot afford to waste a single minute of your time and my time.
('30', 12, 2, 17, 27647) Therefore, I have put on speed to the best of my ability and it has been a wonder to me—it has given to me the greatest satisfaction that you have so readily responded to me, so nobly!
('30', 12, 2, 18, 27832) And you have not done this thing charity but with a magnificent generosity.
('30', 12, 2, 19, 27908) No one could have possibly claimed more, asked for more, and got more.
('30', 12, 2, 20, 27979) You have given me all that I could possibly ask of you.
('30', 12, 2, 21, 28035) But what I now want to ask you for, is something more, some thing better, something richer, and that is this: Transfer all this noble affection, all this generosity that you have shown to me to the thing that you and I hold dear, to the thing that alone binds you and me together and that is swaraj.
('30', 12, 2, 22, 28335) If we want swaraj, we must know the conditions of swaraj.
('30', 12, 2, 23, 28393) You have endorsed the conditions in the resolu tions.
('30', 12, 2, 24, 28447) Every one of you known those conditions.
('30', 12, 2, 25, 28488) Do not leave these conditions here.
('30', 12, 2, 26, 28524) Take them away with you and fulfil them to the letter and to the spirit and insist upon others to fulfil those conditions, not by force but by love.
('30', 12, 2, 27, 28673) Exert all the influence and all the pressure which love can exert, upon everyone that surrounds you and upon your neighbours.
('30', 12, 2, 28, 28799) Go throughout your district and spread this message of khaddar, spread this message of Hindu Muslim unity and spread this
('30', 13, 0, 1, 28921) 14 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 13, 1, 2, 28962) message against 1 untouchability.
('30', 13, 1, 3, 28996) Go hand in hand with the youngsters of the country and make them the real soldiers of swaraj.
('30', 13, 1, 4, 29090) But you will not do it if the Swarajists and No changers still bear malice against each other, if they still have jealousies against one another.
('30', 13, 1, 5, 29236) It will be possible only if you bury hatred, leave all the jealousies and anger, all those bad influences here.
('30', 13, 1, 6, 29348) I ask you to bury the hatchet.
('30', 13, 1, 7, 29379) Bury the jealousies underground and cremate them wherever you like.
('30', 13, 1, 8, 29447) But take away the sacred resolution that you have passed and say, “Let the heavens fall, but the bond that binds us today, the tie that has bound the Swarajists and the No changers, shall never snap.” My work is finished.
('30', 13, 2, 9, 29669) Scarcely had the President got down the rostrum when he was reminded of the duty of the Congress to thank the Reception Committee, and he re entered the rostrum and said: I would not have forgiven myself if I had not tendered my thanks to the noble volunteers trained by Dr. Hardikar and to the members of the Reception Committee.
('30', 13, 2, 10, 30000) But in the mad passion for swaraj I forgot all about the volunteers and the members of the Reception Committee.
('30', 13, 2, 11, 30112) I know that they have not served in order to receive thanks.
('30', 13, 2, 12, 30173) The noble service that they have rendered is its own reward.
('30', 13, 2, 13, 30234) But it was due from me and I would have been guilty of a breach of duty to you if I had not returned thanks to all of you.
('30', 13, 2, 14, 30357) May God bless all the volunteers and the members of the Reception Committee.

('30', 13, 4, 16, 30497) 12. SPEECH AT UNTOUCHABILITY CONFERENCE, BELGAUM
('30', 13, 5, 17, 30546) [December 27, 1924]
('30', 13, 6, 18, 30566) The following is a free rendering of Mr. Gandhi’s speech at the Untouchability Conference held at Belgaum during the Congress week:
('30', 13, 7, 19, 30698) FRIENDS, It was hardly necessary to ask me to express my views on the subject of untouchability.
('30', 13, 7, 20, 30795) I have declared times without number from various public platforms that it is the prayer of my heart that if I
('30', 13, 8, 21, 30906) 1 The source has “of”.
('30', 14, 0, 1, 30929) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 15
('30', 14, 1, 2, 30974) should fail to obtain moksha in this very birth I might be born a Bhangi in my next.
('30', 14, 1, 3, 31059) I believe in varnashrama both according to birth and to karma.
('30', 14, 1, 4, 31122) But I do not regard Bhangis as in any sense a low order.
('30', 14, 1, 5, 31179) On the contrary I know many Bhangis who are worthy of reverence.
('30', 14, 1, 6, 31244) On the other hand there are Brahmins going about whom it would be very difficult to regard with any reverence.
('30', 14, 1, 7, 31355) Holding these views, therefore, if there is a rebirth in store for me, I wish to be born a pariah in the midst of pariahs, because thereby I would be able to render more effective service to them and also be in a better position to plead with other communities on their behalf.
('30', 14, 1, 8, 31633) But just as I do not want the so called touchables to despise the untouchables, so also I do not want the latter to entertain any feeling of hatred and ill will towards the former.
('30', 14, 1, 9, 31814) I do not want them to wrest their rights by violence as is done in the West.
('30', 14, 1, 10, 31891) The trend of world opinion is against such violence.
('30', 14, 1, 11, 31944) I can clearly see a time coming in the world when it will be impossible to secure rights by arbitrament of force, so I tell my untouchable brethren today as I tell the Government, that if they resort to force for the attainment of their purpose, they shall certainly fail.
('30', 14, 1, 12, 32217) I want to uplift Hinduism.
('30', 14, 1, 13, 32244) I regard the untouchables as an integral part of the Hindu community.
('30', 14, 1, 14, 32314) I am pained when I see a single Bhangi driven out of the fold of Hinduism.
('30', 14, 1, 15, 32389) But do not believe that all class distinctions can be obliterated.
('30', 14, 1, 16, 32456) I believe in the doctrine of equality as taught by Lord Krishna in the Gita.
('30', 14, 1, 17, 32533) The Gita teaches us that members of all the four castes should be treated on an equal basis.
('30', 14, 1, 18, 32626) It does not prescribe the same dharma for the Brahmin as for the Bhangi.
('30', 14, 1, 19, 32699) But it insists that the latter shall be entitled to the same measure of consideration and esteem as the former with all his superior learning.
('30', 14, 1, 20, 32842) It is therefore our duty to see that the untouchables do not feel that they are despised or looked down upon.
('30', 14, 1, 21, 32952) Let them not be offered leavings from our plates for their subsistence.
('30', 14, 1, 22, 33024) How can I accord differential treatment to any person, be he Brahmin or Bhangi, who worships the same God and keeps his body and soul pure and clean?
('30', 14, 1, 23, 33174) I for one would regard myself as having sinned if I gave to a Bhangi unclean food from the leavings from the kitchen or failed to render him personal assistance when he was in need.
('30', 14, 1, 24, 33356) Let me make my position absolutely clear.
('30', 14, 1, 25, 33398) While I do hold that the institution of untouchability as it stands today has no sanction in Hinduism, Hinduism does recognize “untouchability” in a limited
('30', 15, 0, 1, 33555) 16 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 15, 1, 2, 33596) sense and under certain circumstances.
('30', 15, 1, 3, 33635) For instance, every time that my mother handled unclean things she became untouchable for the time being and had to cleanse herself by bathing.
('30', 15, 1, 4, 33779) As a Vaishnava I refuse to believe that anyone can be regarded untouchable by reason of his or her birth, and such untouchability as is recognized by religion is by its very nature transitory, easily removable and referable to the deed not the doer.
('30', 15, 1, 5, 34029) Not only that.
('30', 15, 1, 6, 34044) Just as we revere our mother for the sanitary service that she renders us when we are infants, and the greater her service the greater is our reverence for her, similarly the Bhangis are entitled to our highest reverence for the sanitary service they perform for society.
('30', 15, 1, 7, 34316) Now anoter point.
('30', 15, 1, 8, 34334) I do not regard inter dining and inter marriage as essential to the removal of untouchability.
('30', 15, 1, 9, 34429) I believe in varnashrama dharma.
('30', 15, 1, 10, 34462) But I eat with Bhangis.
('30', 15, 1, 11, 34486) I do not know whether I am a sannyasi, for it seriously doubt whether in this Kaliyuga it is at all possible for anyone to fulfil the conditions prescribed for a sannyasi.
('30', 15, 1, 12, 34658) But I am moving deliberately in the direction of sannyasa.
('30', 15, 1, 13, 34717) It is, therefore, not only not necessary for me to observe these restrictions but their observance may be even harmful for me.
('30', 15, 1, 14, 34844) As regards the question of inter marriage, it does not arise in cases like mine.
('30', 15, 1, 15, 34925) Sufficient for me to say that my scheme does not include inter marriage.
('30', 15, 1, 16, 34998) Let me tell you that in my own clan all the members do not inter dine.
('30', 15, 1, 17, 35069) In certain cases among our Vaishnava families they do not use each other’s utensils or even cook food on fire fetched from others’ kitchens.
('30', 15, 1, 18, 35210) You may call this practice superstitious, but I do not regard it as such.
('30', 15, 1, 19, 35284) It certainly does no harm to Hinduism.
('30', 15, 1, 20, 35323) In my Ashram, Dudhabhai, one of the untouchable inmates, dines with the rest without any distinction.
('30', 15, 1, 21, 35425) But I do not recommend anybody outside the Ashram to follow this example.
('30', 15, 1, 22, 35499) Again, you know the esteem in which I hold Malaviyaji.
('30', 15, 1, 23, 35554) I would wash his feet.
('30', 15, 1, 24, 35577) But he would not take food touched by me.
('30', 15, 1, 25, 35619) Am I to resent it as a mark of contempt?
('30', 15, 1, 26, 35660) Certainly not, because I know that no contempt is meant.
('30', 15, 1, 27, 35717) The religion to which I belong prescribes for our observance maryada 1 dharma.
('30', 15, 1, 28, 35796) The rishis of old carried on exhaustive researches through meditation, and as a result of the researches they discovered some great truths, such as have no parallel perhaps in any other religion.
('30', 15, 1, 29, 35992) One of these was that they regarded certain kinds of foods as injurious for the spiritual well being of man.
('30', 15, 1, 30, 36101) So they interdicted their
('30', 15, 2, 31, 36127) 1 Bounds or limits.
('30', 16, 0, 1, 36147) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 17
('30', 16, 1, 2, 36192) Now suppose someone had to travel abroad and live among strange people with different customs and standards as regard their diet.
('30', 16, 1, 3, 36322) Knowing as they did how compelling sometimes the force of social customs of the people among whom men lived was, they promulgated maryada dharma to help one in such emergencies.
('30', 16, 1, 4, 36500) Though, however, I believe in maryada dharma, I do not regard it as an essential part of Hinduism.
('30', 16, 1, 5, 36599) I can even conceive a time when these restrictions might be abolished with impunity.
('30', 16, 1, 6, 36684) But the reform contemplated in the untouchability movement does not obliterate the restriction as to inter dining and inter marriage.
('30', 16, 1, 7, 36818) I cannot recommend wholesale abolition of these restrictions to the public, even at the risk of being charged with hypocrisy and inconsistency.
('30', 16, 1, 8, 36962) For instance, I let my son dine freely in Mussalman households because I believe he can take sufficient care as to what to take and what not to take.
('30', 16, 1, 9, 37112) I myself have no scruples in taking my food in Mussalman house holds because I have my own strict rules about my diet.
('30', 16, 1, 10, 37231) Let me tell you of an incident that happened at Aligarh.
('30', 16, 1, 11, 37288) Swami Satyadev and I were Khawaja Sahib’s guests.
('30', 16, 1, 12, 37338) Swami Satyadev did not share my views.
('30', 16, 1, 13, 37377) We argued about them.
('30', 16, 1, 14, 37399) I told him that holding the views I did, it would be as wrong of me to refuse to partake of the food offered by a Mussalman as it would be on his part to transgress his maryada.
('30', 16, 1, 15, 37577) So Swami Satyadev was provided with separate cooking arrangements.
('30', 16, 1, 16, 37644) Similarly when I was Bari Sahib’s guest he provided us with a Brahmin cook with strict instructions to obtain all the rations for us fresh from the bazaar.
('30', 16, 1, 17, 37800) When asked why he put himself to such inconvenience he explained that he did so because he wanted to avoid the slightest possibility of suspicion on the part of the public that he entertained any secret designs of proselytization against me or my companions.
('30', 16, 1, 18, 38059) That single incident raised Bari Sahib in my esteem.
('30', 16, 1, 19, 38112) He sometimes commits mistakes, but he is as simple and innocent as a child.
('30', 16, 1, 20, 38188) And although sometimes people complain of him to me bitterly, my first impression of him still remains.
('30', 16, 1, 21, 38292) I have dwelt on this point at such great length, because I want to be absolutely plain with you (untouchables).
('30', 16, 1, 22, 38404) I do not want to employ diplomacy in my dealings with you or for that matter with anyone.
('30', 16, 1, 23, 38494) I do not want to keep you under any false illusion or win your support by holding out temptations.
('30', 16, 1, 24, 38593) I want to remove untouchability because its removal is essential for swaraj and I want swaraj.
('30', 16, 1, 25, 38688) But I would not exploit you for gaining any political ends of mine.
('30', 16, 1, 26, 38756) The issue with me is bigger even than swaraj.
('30', 16, 1, 27, 38802) I am anxious to see an end put to
('30', 17, 0, 1, 38836) 18 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 17, 1, 2, 38877) untouchability because for me it is an expiation and a penance.
('30', 17, 1, 3, 38941) It is not the untouchables whose shuddhi I effect—the thing would be absurd—but my own and that of the Hindu religion.
('30', 17, 1, 4, 39060) Hinduism has committed a great sin in giving sanction to this evil and I am anxious— if such a thing as vicarious penance is possible—to purify it of that sin by expiating for it in my own person.
('30', 17, 1, 5, 39257) That being so, it follows that the only means open to me for my purpose are those of ahimsa and truth.
('30', 17, 1, 6, 39360) I have adopted an untouchable child as my own.
('30', 17, 1, 7, 39407) I confess I have not been able to convert my wife completely to my view.
('30', 17, 1, 8, 39480) She cannot bring hereself to love her as I do.
('30', 17, 1, 9, 39527) But I cannot convert my wife by anger; I can do so only by love.
('30', 17, 1, 10, 39592) If any of my people have done you any wrong, I ask your forgiveness for it.
('30', 17, 1, 11, 39668) Some members of the untouchable class said when I was at Poona that they would resort to force if the Hindus did not alter their attitude towards them.
('30', 17, 1, 12, 39820) Can untouchability be removed by force?
('30', 17, 1, 13, 39860) Can the amelioration of the untouchables come through these methods?
('30', 17, 1, 14, 39929) The only way by which you and I can wean orthodox Hindus from their bigotry is by patient argument and correct conduct.
('30', 17, 1, 15, 40049) So long as they are not converted, I can only ask you to put up with your lot with patience.
('30', 17, 1, 16, 40142) I am willing to stand by you and share your sufferings with you.
('30', 17, 1, 17, 40207) You must have the right of worship in any temple in which members of other castes are admitted.
('30', 17, 1, 18, 40303) You must have admission to schools along with the children of other castes without any distinction.
('30', 17, 1, 19, 40403) You must be eligible to the highest office in the land not excluding even that of the Viceroy’s.
('30', 17, 1, 20, 40500) That is my definition of the removal of untouchability.
('30', 17, 1, 21, 40556) But I can help you in this only by following the way indicated by my religion and not by following Western methods.
('30', 17, 1, 22, 40672) For that way I cannot save Hinduism.
('30', 17, 1, 23, 40709) Yours is a sacred cause.
('30', 17, 1, 24, 40734) Can one serve a sacred cause by adopting Satan’s methods?
('30', 17, 1, 25, 40792) I pray you, therefore, to dismiss from your mind the idea of ameliorating your condition by brute force.
('30', 17, 1, 26, 40897) The Gita tells us that by sincerely meditating on the Lord in one’s heart, one can attain moksha.
('30', 17, 1, 27, 40995) Meditation is waiting on God.
('30', 17, 1, 28, 41025) If waiting on God brings the highest bliss of salvation, how much quicker must it bring removal of untouchability?
('30', 17, 1, 29, 41140) Waiting on God means increasing purity.
('30', 17, 1, 30, 41180) Let us by prayer purify ourselves and we shall not only remove untouchability but shall also hasten the advent of swaraj.

('30', 18, 1, 2, 41370) 13. PRESIDENTIAL ADDRESS AT COW PROTECTION CONFERENCE, BELGAUM
('30', 18, 2, 3, 41433) [December 28, 1924]
('30', 18, 3, 4, 41453) The following is the substance of Mr. Gandhi’s presidential speech at the Cow Protection Conference held during the congress week at Belgaum: I hold the question of cow protection to be not less momentous but in certain respects even of far greater moment than that of swaraj.
('30', 18, 3, 5, 41730) I would even go so far as to say that just as so long as Hindu Muslim unity is not effected, Hinduism not purged of the taint of untoucha bility and the wearing of hand spun and hand woven khaddar does not become universal, swaraj would be impossible of attainment; even so, the term “swaraj” would be devoid of all meaning so long as we have not found out a way of saving the cow, for that is the touchstone on which Hinduism must be tested and proved before there can be any real swaraj in India.
('30', 18, 3, 6, 42229) I claim to be a sanatani Hindu.
('30', 18, 3, 7, 42261) People may laugh and say that to call myself a sanatani Hindu when I eat and drink from the hands of Mussalmans and Christians, keep an untouchable girl in my house as my daughter and do not even hesitate to quote the Bible, is nothing short of doing violence to language.
('30', 18, 3, 8, 42534) But I would still adhere to my claim, for I have faith in me which tells me that a day would come—may be most probably after I am dead and no longer present in this world in the flesh to bear witness—when my critics would recognize their error and admit the justness of my claim.
('30', 18, 3, 9, 42814) Pretty long while ago, I once wrote in Young India an article on Hinduism, 1 which I consider to be one of my most thoughtful writings on the subject.
('30', 18, 3, 10, 42965) The definition of Hinduism which I gave in it is probably the clearest that I have ever given.
('30', 18, 3, 11, 43060) After defining a Hindu as one who believed in the Vedas and Upanishads, recited the Gayatri and subscribed to the doctrine of rebirth and transmigration, etc., I added that so far as the popular notion of Hinduism was concerned, its distinguishing feature was belief in cow protection and reverence for the cow.
('30', 18, 3, 12, 43372) I do not grant to be told as to what Hindus ten thousand years ago did.
('30', 18, 3, 13, 43444) I know there are scholars who tell us that cow sacrifice is mentioned in the Vedas.
('30', 18, 3, 14, 43528) I remember when I was a high school student we read a sentence in our Sanskrit text book to the effect that the Brahmins of old used to eat beef.
('30', 18, 3, 15, 43674) That exercised my mind greatly and I used to wonder and ask myself whether what was written could
('30', 18, 4, 16, 43772) 1Vide “Hinduism”, October 6, 1921.
('30', 19, 0, 1, 43807) 20 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 19, 1, 2, 43848) be after all true.
('30', 19, 1, 3, 43867) But as I grew up the conviction slowly forced itself upon me that even if the text on which these statements were based was actually part of the Vedas, the interpretation put upon it could not be correct.
('30', 19, 1, 4, 44072) I had conceived of another way out of the difficulty.
('30', 19, 1, 5, 44126) This was purely for personal satisfaction.“If the Vedic text under reference was incapable of bearing any other interpretation than the literal”, I said to myself, “the Brahmins who there alleged to be eating beef had the power to bring the slaughtered animals back to life again.” But that is neither here nor there.
('30', 19, 1, 6, 44444) The speculation does not concern the general mass of the Hindus.
('30', 19, 1, 7, 44509) I do not claim to be a Vedic scholar.
('30', 19, 1, 8, 44547) I have read Sanskrit scriptures largely in translation.
('30', 19, 1, 9, 44603) A layman like myself, therefore, can hardly have any locus standi in a controversy like this.
('30', 19, 1, 10, 44697) But l have confidence in myself.
('30', 19, 1, 11, 44730) Therefore I do not hesitate to freely express to others my opinions based on my inner experience.
('30', 19, 1, 12, 44828) It may be that we may not be all able to agree as to the exact meaning and significance of cow protection.
('30', 19, 1, 13, 44935) For Hinduism does not rest on the authority of one book or one prophet; nor does it possess a common creed—like the Kalma 1 of Islam—acceptable to all.
('30', 19, 1, 14, 45087) That renders a common definition of Hinduism a bit difficult, but therein lies its strength also.
('30', 19, 1, 15, 45185) For, it is this special feature that has given to Hinduism its inclusive and assimilative character and made its grad ual, silent evolution possible.
('30', 19, 1, 16, 45335) Go to any Hindu child and he would tell you that cow protection is the supreme duty of every Hindu and that anyone who does not believe in it hardly deserves the name of a Hindu.
('30', 19, 2, 17, 45514) But while I am a firm believer in the necessity and importance of cow protection, I do not at all endorse the current methods adopted for that purpose.
('30', 19, 2, 18, 45666) Some of the practices followed in the name of cow protection cause me extreme anguish.
('30', 19, 2, 19, 45753) My heart aches within me.
('30', 19, 2, 20, 45779) Several year ago I wrote in Hind Swaraj that our cow protection societies were in fact so many cow killing societies.
('30', 19, 2, 21, 45897) 2 Since then and after my return to India in 1915, that conviction of mine has grown stronger and firmer every day.
('30', 19, 2, 22, 46013) Holding the views that I do, therefore, I have naturally fit a great hesitation in accepting the Presidentship of this Conference.
('30', 19, 2, 23, 46144) Would it be proper for me to preside over this
('30', 19, 3, 24, 46191) 1 The creed of Islam as expressed in the verse from The Koran: “There is no God but Allah and Mohammed is His apostle.” 2 Vide “Hind Swaraj Chapter X : The Condition of India (Continued) : The Hindus and the Mahomedans”, November 22, 1909.
('30', 20, 0, 1, 46431) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 21
('30', 20, 1, 2, 46476) Conference under these circumstances?
('30', 20, 1, 3, 46514) Would I at all succeed in convincing you of the soundness of my views—radically different as they are from the commonly accepted notions on this subject?
('30', 20, 1, 4, 46668) These were the questions that filled my mind.
('30', 20, 1, 5, 46714) But Mr. Gangadharrao Deshpande wired to me that I might preside over the Conference on my terms, that Sjt.
('30', 20, 1, 6, 46821) Chikodi was familiar with my views on the matter and was at one with me to a very large extent.
('30', 20, 1, 7, 46917) So much by way of personal explanation.
('30', 20, 2, 8, 46957) Once, while in Champaran, I was asked to expound my views regarding cow protection.
('30', 20, 2, 9, 47041) I told my Champaran friends then that if anybody was really anxious to save the cow, he ought once for all to disabuse his mind of the notion that he had to make the Christians and Mussalmans to desist from cow killing.
('30', 20, 2, 10, 47261) Unfortunately today we seem to believe that the problem of cow protection consists merely in preventing non Hindus, especially Mussalmans from beef eating and cow killing.
('30', 20, 2, 11, 47433) That seems to me to be absurd.
('30', 20, 2, 12, 47464) Let no one, however, conclude from this that I am indifferent when a non Hindu kills a cow or that I can bear the practice of cow killing.
('30', 20, 2, 13, 47603) On the contrary, no one probably experiences a greater agony of the soul when a cow is killed.
('30', 20, 2, 14, 47698) But what am I to do?
('30', 20, 2, 15, 47719) Am I to fulfil my dharma myself or am I to get it fulfilled by proxy?
('30', 20, 2, 16, 47789) Of what avail would be my preaching brahmacharya to others if I am at the same time steeped in vice myself?
('30', 20, 2, 17, 47897) How can I ask Mussalmans to desist from eating beef when I eat it myself?
('30', 20, 2, 18, 47971) But supposing even that I myself do not kill the cow, is it any part of my duty to make the Mussalman, against his will, to do likewise?
('30', 20, 2, 19, 48108) Mussalmans claim that Islam permits them to kill the cow.
('30', 20, 2, 20, 48166) To make a Mussalman, therefore, to abstain from cow killing under compulsion would amount in my opinion to converting him to Hinduism by force.
('30', 20, 2, 21, 48310) Even in India under swaraj, in my opinion, it would be for a Hindu majority unwise and improper to coerce by legislation a Mussalman minority into submission to statutory prohibition of cow slaughter.
('30', 20, 2, 22, 48511) When I pledge myself to save the cow, I do not mean merely the Indian cow, but the cow all the world over.
('30', 20, 2, 23, 48618) My religion teaches me that I should by my personal conduct instill into the minds of those who might hold different views, the conviction that cow killing is a sin and that therefore it ought to be abandoned.
('30', 20, 2, 24, 48828) My ambition is no less than to see the principle of cow protection established throughout the world.
('30', 20, 2, 25, 48929) But that requires that I should set my own house thoroughly in order first.
('30', 21, 0, 1, 49005) 22 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 21, 1, 2, 49046) Let alone other provinces.
('30', 21, 1, 3, 49073) Would you believe me if I told you that the Hindus of Gujarat practice cow killing?
('30', 21, 1, 4, 49157) You will wonder but let me tell you that in Gujarat the bullocks employed for drawing carts are goaded with spiked rods till blood oozes from their bruised backs.
('30', 21, 1, 5, 49320) You may say that this is not cow killing but bullock killing.
('30', 21, 1, 6, 49382) But I see no difference between the two, the killing of the cow and killing her male progeny.
('30', 21, 1, 7, 49476) Again you may say that this practice may be abominable and worthy of condemnation but it hardly amounts to killing.
('30', 21, 1, 8, 49592) But here, again, I beg to differ.
('30', 21, 1, 9, 49626) If the bullock in question had a tongue to speak and were asked which fate he prepared—instanta neous death under the butcher’s knife or the long drawn agony to which he is subjected, he would undoubtedly prefer the former.
('30', 21, 1, 10, 49850) At Calcutta a Sindhi gentleman used to meet me often.
('30', 21, 1, 11, 49904) He used always to tell me stories about the cruelty that was practised by milk men on cows in Calcutta.
('30', 21, 1, 12, 50008) He asked me to see for myself the process of milking the cows as carried on in the dairies.
('30', 21, 1, 13, 50100) The practice of blowing is loathsome.
('30', 21, 1, 14, 50138) The people who do this are Hindus.
('30', 21, 1, 15, 50173) Again, nowhere in the world is the condition of cattle so poor as in India.
('30', 21, 1, 16, 50249) Nowhere in the world would you find such skeletons of cows and bullocks as you do in our cow worshipping India.
('30', 21, 1, 17, 50361) Nowhere are bullocks worked so beyond their capacity as here.
('30', 21, 1, 18, 50423) I contend that so long as these things continue, we have no right to ask anybody to stop cow killing.
('30', 21, 1, 19, 50525) In Bhagavata, in one place the illustrious author describes the various things which have been the cause of India’s downfall.
('30', 21, 1, 20, 50651) One of the causes mentioned is that we have given up cow protection.
('30', 21, 1, 21, 50720) Today I want to bring home to you if I can the close relation which exists between the present poverty stricken condition of India and our failure to protect the cow.
('30', 21, 1, 22, 50887) We, who live in cities, probably can have no idea of the extent of the poverty of our poor folk.
('30', 21, 1, 23, 50984) Millions upon millions cannot afford to have two full meals per day.
('30', 21, 1, 24, 51053) Some live on rotten rice only.
('30', 21, 1, 25, 51084) There are others for whom salt and chillies are the only table luxuries.
('30', 21, 1, 26, 51157) Is it not a just nemesis for our belying of our religion?
('30', 21, 1, 27, 51215) Then in India we have the system of pinjrapoles 1. The way in which most of these are managed is far from satisfactory.
('30', 21, 1, 28, 51335) And yet, I am sorry to observe that the people who are mostly responsible for them are Jains, who are out and out believers in ahimsa.
('30', 21, 1, 29, 51470) Well organized, these pinjrapoles ought to be flourishing dairies supplying
('30', 21, 2, 30, 51546) 1 Shelters for crippled and aged cattle
('30', 22, 0, 1, 51586) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 23
('30', 22, 1, 2, 51631) pure good milk at a cheap rate to the poor.
('30', 22, 1, 3, 51675) I am told however that even in a rich city like Ahmedabad there are cases of the wives of labourers feeding their babies on flour dissolved in water.
('30', 22, 1, 4, 51825) There cannot be a sadder commentary on the way in which we protect the cow than that in a country which has such an extensive system of pinjrapoles, the poor should experience a famine of pure, good milk.
('30', 22, 1, 5, 52030) That I hope will serve to explain to you how our failure to protect the cow at one end of the chain results in our skin and bone starvelings at the other.
('30', 22, 1, 6, 52185) If, therefore, I am asked how to save the cow, my first advice will be: “Dismiss from your minds the Mussalmans and Christians altogether and mind your duty first.” I have been telling Maulana Shaukat Ali all along that I was helping him to save his cow, i.e., the Khilafat, because I hoped to save my cow thereby.
('30', 22, 1, 7, 52500) I am prepared to place my life in the hands of the Mussalmans, to live merely on their sufferance.
('30', 22, 1, 8, 52599) Simply that I might be able to protect the cow.
('30', 22, 1, 9, 52647) I hope to achieve the end not by entering into a bargain with the Mussalmans but by bringing about a change of heart in them.
('30', 22, 1, 10, 52773) So long as this is not done I hold my soul in patience.
('30', 22, 1, 11, 52829) For I have not a shadow of doubt in my mind that such a change of heart can be brought about only by our own correct conduct towards them and by our personal example.
('30', 22, 1, 12, 52996) Cow slaughter and man slaughter are in my opinion the two sides of the same coin.
('30', 22, 1, 13, 53078) And the remedy for both is identical, i.e., that we develop the ahimsa principle and endeavour to win over our opponents by love.
('30', 22, 1, 14, 53208) The test of love is tapasya and tapasya means suffering.
('30', 22, 1, 15, 53265) I offered to share with the Mussalmans their suffering to the best of my capacity not merely because I wanted their co operation for winning swaraj but also because I had in mind the object of saving the cow.
('30', 22, 1, 16, 53474) The Koran, so far as I have been able to understand it, declares it to be a sin to take the life of any living being without cause.
('30', 22, 1, 17, 53606) I want to develop the capacity to convince the Mussalmans that to kill the cow is practically to kill their fellow countrymen and friends—the Hindus.
('30', 22, 1, 18, 53756) The Koran says that there can be no heaven for one who sheds the blood of an innocent neighbour.
('30', 22, 1, 19, 53853) Therefore I am anxious to establish the best neighbourly relations with the Mussalmans.
('30', 22, 1, 20, 53941) I scrupulously avoid doing anything that might hurt their feelings.
('30', 22, 1, 21, 54009) I even try to respect their prejudices.
('30', 22, 1, 22, 54049) But I do this not in a spirit of bargain, I ask them for no reward.
('30', 22, 1, 23, 54117) For that I look to God only.
('30', 22, 1, 24, 54146) My Gita tells me that evil can never result from a good action.
('30', 22, 1, 25, 54210) Therefore I
('30', 23, 0, 1, 54222) 24 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 23, 1, 2, 54263) must help the Mussalmans from a pure sense of duty—without making any terms with them.
('30', 23, 1, 3, 54350) For more cows are killed today for the sake of Englishmen in India than for the Mussalmans.
('30', 23, 1, 4, 54442) I want to convert the former also.
('30', 23, 1, 5, 54477) I would like to convince them that whilst they are in our midst their duty lies in getting rid of their Western culture to the extent that it comes in conflict with ours.
('30', 23, 1, 6, 54648) You will thus see that even our self interest requires us to observe ahimsa.
('30', 23, 1, 7, 54725) By ahimsa we will be able to save the cow and also to win the friendship of the English.
('30', 23, 1, 8, 54814) I want to purchase the friendship of all by sacrifice.
('30', 23, 1, 9, 54869) But if I do not approach the English on bent knees, as I do the Mussalmans, that is because the former are intoxicated with power.
('30', 23, 1, 10, 55000) The Mussalman is a fellow sufferer in slavery.
('30', 23, 1, 11, 55047) We can therefore speak to him as a friend and a comrade.
('30', 23, 1, 12, 55104) The Englishman on the contrary is unable to appreciate our friendly advances.
('30', 23, 1, 13, 55182) He would spurn them.
('30', 23, 1, 14, 55203) He does not care for our friendship, he wants to patronize us.
('30', 23, 1, 15, 55266) We want neither his insults nor his patronage.
('30', 23, 1, 16, 55313) We therefore let him alone.
('30', 23, 1, 17, 55341) Our Shastras have laid down that charity should be given only to a deserving person, that knowledge should be imparted only to one who is desirous of having it.
('30', 23, 1, 18, 55502) So we content ourselves with non co operating with our rulers—not out of hatred but in a spirit of love.
('30', 23, 1, 19, 55607) It was because love was the motive force behind non co operation that I advised suspension of civil disobedience when violence broke out in Bombay and Chauri Chaura.
('30', 23, 1, 20, 55773) I wanted to make it clear to Englishmen that I wanted to win swaraj not by shedding their blood but by making them feel absolutely at ease as regards the safety of their persons.
('30', 23, 1, 21, 55952) What profit would it be if I succeed in saving a few cows from death by using force against persons who do not regard cow killing as sinful?
('30', 23, 1, 22, 56093) Cow protection then can only be secured by cultivating universal friendliness, i.e., ahimsa.
('30', 23, 1, 23, 56186) Now you will understand why I regard the question of cow protection as greater even than that of swaraj.
('30', 23, 1, 24, 56291) The fact is that the capacity to achieve the former will suffice for the latter purpose as well.
('30', 23, 1, 25, 56388) So far I have confined myself to the grosser or material aspect of cow protection, i.e., the aspect that refers to the animal cow only.
('30', 23, 1, 26, 56524) In its finer or spiritual sense the term cow protection means the protection of every living creature.
('30', 23, 1, 27, 56627) Today the world does not fully realize the force and possibilities that lie hidden in ahimsa.
('30', 23, 1, 28, 56721) The scriptures of Christians, Mussalmans and Hindus are all replete with the teaching of ahimsa.
('30', 23, 1, 29, 56818) But we do not know its full import.
('30', 23, 1, 30, 56854) The rishis of old performed terrible penances and austerities to discover the right
('30', 24, 0, 1, 56938) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 25
('30', 24, 1, 2, 56983) meaning of sacred texts.
('30', 24, 1, 3, 57008) Today we have at least two interpretations of the Gayatri.
('30', 24, 1, 4, 57067) Which one of them is correct, that of the sanatanis or that of the Arya Samajists?
('30', 24, 1, 5, 57150) Who can say?
('30', 24, 1, 6, 57163) But our rishis made the startling discovery (and every day I feel more and more convinced of its truth) that sacred texts and inspired writings yield their truth only in proportion as one has advanced in the practice of ahimsa and truth.
('30', 24, 1, 7, 57401) The greater the realization of truth and ahimsa, the greater the illumination.
('30', 24, 1, 8, 57480) These same rishis declared that cow protection was the supreme duty of a Hindu and that its performance brought one moksha, i.e., salvation.
('30', 24, 1, 9, 57621) Now I am not ready to believe that by merely protecting the animal cow, one can attain moksha.
('30', 24, 1, 10, 57716) For moksha one must completely get rid of one’s lower feelings like attachment, hatred, anger, jealousy, etc.
('30', 24, 1, 11, 57826) It follows, therefore, that the meaning of cow protection in terms of moksha must be much wider and far more comprehensive than is commonly supposed.
('30', 24, 1, 12, 57976) The cow protection which can bring one moksha must, from its very nature, include the protection of everything that feels.
('30', 24, 1, 13, 58099) Therefore in my opinion, every little breach of the ahimsa principle, like causing hurt by harsh speech to anyone, man, woman or child, to cause pain to the weakest and the most insignificant creature on earth would be a breach of the principle of cow protection, would be tantamount to the sin of beef eating— differing from it in degree, if at all, rather than in kind.
('30', 24, 1, 14, 58471) That being so, I hold that with all our passions let loose we cannot today claim to be following the principle of cow protection.
('30', 24, 1, 15, 58601) At Lahore I met Lala Dhanpatrai, somewhat of a crank like myself.
('30', 24, 1, 16, 58667) He told me that if I wanted to save the cow I should wean the Hindus from their false notions.
('30', 24, 1, 17, 58762) He said, it was Hindus who sold cows to the Mussalman butcher and but for them the latter would have no cows to kill.
('30', 24, 1, 18, 58880) The reason for this practice he told me was economical.
('30', 24, 1, 19, 58936) The village commons that served as grazing grounds for the cattle had been enclosed by the Government and so people could not afford to keep cows.
('30', 24, 1, 20, 59083) He suggested a way out of the difficulty.
('30', 24, 1, 21, 59125) It was no longer necessary, he told me to sell cows that had ceased to give milk.
('30', 24, 1, 22, 59207) He himself, he said, had tried the experiment of buying such cows.
('30', 24, 1, 23, 59274) He then put them to the plough.
('30', 24, 1, 24, 59306) After some time, if proper care was taken, they put on flesh and became fit to bear again.
('30', 24, 1, 25, 59397) I cannot vouch for the truth of this statement.
('30', 24, 1, 26, 59445) But I see no reason why this practice should not be generally adopted if the facts are as stated by Lala Dhanpatrai.
('30', 24, 1, 27, 59562) Our Shastras certainly have nowhere said that under no circumstances should the cow not be used for draught purposes.
('30', 25, 0, 1, 59680) 26 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 25, 1, 2, 59721) feed the cow properly, tend it carefully and then use her for drawing carts or working the ploughs always taking care not to tax her beyond her capacity, there can be nothing wrong in it.
('30', 25, 1, 3, 59909) I therefore commend the suggestion for consideration and adoption if it is found to be workable.
('30', 25, 1, 4, 60006) We may not look down upon a person if he tries to protect the cow in this manner.

('30', 25, 3, 6, 60111) 14. SPEECH AT ALL INDIA STATES CONFERENCE, BELGAUM 1
('30', 25, 4, 7, 60164) [December 30, 1924]
('30', 25, 5, 8, 60184) I am overwhelmed with the affection which is shown to me by all during the past few days.
('30', 25, 5, 9, 60274) Today the president of your Conference in adjourning the address to give me an opportunity to speak a few words to you has given further proof of it.
('30', 25, 5, 10, 60424) You may know that I was born in an Indian village.
('30', 25, 5, 11, 60475) I know Kathiawar States.
('30', 25, 5, 12, 60500) My relations with them are cordial.
('30', 25, 5, 13, 60536) Though I say little I am always watching the activities in the Indian States.
('30', 25, 5, 14, 60614) In my Presidential Address I have made a reference to the Indian States.
('30', 25, 5, 15, 60687) The All Parties Conference that met recently in Bombay has appointed a committee to draft a scheme of swaraj and in my address I have outlined my ideas of the coming swaraj.
('30', 25, 5, 16, 60861) I had to condense my ideas in the shortest space possible and so I could give very few sentences to the Indian States.
('30', 25, 5, 17, 60980) There are some vakil friends of mine who have something to say about this reference of mine to the Indian States.
('30', 25, 5, 18, 61094) They are saying that I have spoken about the status of Indian princes and chiefs and nothing about their obligations towards their subjects.
('30', 25, 5, 19, 61235) But I need not remind these friends of mine that rights always carry with them corresponding obligations.
('30', 25, 5, 20, 61341) In my scheme of Indian swaraj there is no idea of destroying the States.
('30', 25, 5, 21, 61414) I wanted to bring out this view prominently before the public.
('30', 25, 5, 22, 61477) If, however, subjects from Indian States migrated to British Indian territory owing to the oppression of any Indian Prince, the swaraj government will on no account hand over these people to the mercies of the Prince concerned.
('30', 25, 5, 23, 61705) This guarantee to the subject and the guarantee to the Princes about their status postulate good government
('30', 25, 6, 24, 61813) 1 President over by N. C. Kelkar.
('30', 25, 6, 25, 61847) As Gandhiji hat to leave immediately, the president requested him to say a few words.
('30', 26, 0, 1, 61933) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 27
('30', 26, 1, 2, 61978) in the Indian States.
('30', 26, 1, 3, 62000) In geometry there are certain postulates.
('30', 26, 1, 4, 62042) So also there are some in the political science.
('30', 26, 1, 5, 62091) When the Princes are guaranteed their status it is presumed that they will also guarantee progressive and enlightened government to their subjects.
('30', 26, 1, 6, 62239) I am shortly to preside over the Kathia war States Conference at Bhavnagar and I have reserved all my detailed say about the Indian States for this occasion.
('30', 26, 1, 7, 62397) I was invited to preside over this Conference long ago.
('30', 26, 1, 8, 62453) But before my incarceration I had unfurled the banner of satyagraha and I thought that my acceptance of the presidentship of any of these conferences might jeopardize the position of the Chiefs.
('30', 26, 1, 9, 62648) I did not wish to put them in an awkward position and thus to mar the harmonious relations which existed between them and me.
('30', 26, 1, 10, 62774) You know that I am an out and out believer in non violence.
('30', 26, 1, 11, 62834) To embitter the sweet relations between Princes and their subjects would be contrary to my principles.
('30', 26, 1, 12, 62937) But I need not assure you that I can never forget the people of these States and their legitimate claims.
('30', 26, 1, 13, 63043) My desire is to maintain sweet reasonableness in my handling the question of Indian States and I do not wish to prejudice any party.
('30', 26, 1, 14, 63176) My sole desire is that the status of Princes and the rights of their subjects should be respected.
('30', 26, 1, 15, 63275) I earnestly wish to enlist the sympathies of the Princes in this propaganda of khadi and the Charkha.
('30', 26, 1, 16, 63377) I have pinned my faith to the spinning wheel.
('30', 26, 1, 17, 63423) On it I believe the salvation of this country depends.
('30', 26, 2, 18, 63478) After the Mahatma left, Mr. Kelkar gave a summary of his speech in Marathi .
