('30', 27, 4, 5, 64251) 16. SPEECH AT ALL INDIA MUSLIM LEAGUE, BOMBAY 1
('30', 27, 5, 6, 64299) December 31, 1924
('30', 27, 6, 7, 64317) Mrs. Naidu has come from Africa and she has told you all about it.
('30', 27, 6, 8, 64384) Whatever I was to say I said in the Congress.
('30', 27, 6, 9, 64430) I do not know whether by asking the Government we can get help.
('30', 27, 6, 10, 64494) I think as long as we have no strength, we will have to bear whatever is going on in Kenya.
('30', 27, 6, 11, 64586) There was a time when satyagraha was going on in South Africa and the Government was also saying that the Indians had become disloyal.
('30', 27, 6, 12, 64721) At the same time Lord Hardinge made a pronouncement in Madras and that did considerable good to Indians.
('30', 27, 6, 13, 64826) The reason of this was that the people in South Africa were offering satyagraha.
('30', 27, 6, 14, 64907) If you want to help them then you should first help yourselves.
('30', 27, 6, 15, 64971) I have painfully heard that Indians in East Africa have decided to go in Councils and have left the outside work.
('30', 27, 6, 16, 65085) I do [not] know whether it is right or wrong for I cannot form a judgment from so long a distance.
('30', 27, 6, 17, 65184) The time for us now is to gather our strength and then Lord Reading, you will see, following the same course as Lord Hardinge.
('30', 27, 6, 18, 65311) Hindu Muslim unity is very necessary and at the same time to wear khaddar is also essential, but I do not know whether I should tell it here or not.
('30', 27, 6, 19, 65460) I wish that all Government appointments should go to Mussalmans, Parsis and Christians because they are small in number; if there remains any, they should be filled by Hindus.
('30', 27, 6, 20, 65636) I have come to know about the khadi work in Bengal from a
('30', 27, 7, 21, 65694) 1 At its 16th annual session supporting the resolution condemning the Natal Boroughs Ordinance which deprived Indian of municipal franchise in Natal
('30', 28, 0, 1, 65843) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 29
('30', 28, 1, 2, 65888) co worker, Mr. Roy (Satish Babu).
('30', 28, 1, 3, 65922) There the work is chiefly carried on by Muslim women.
('30', 28, 1, 4, 65976) They earn their living by charkha.
('30', 28, 1, 5, 66011) So if you want to benefit them, wear khadi.
('30', 28, 1, 6, 66055) If you want to help Egypt and as I also have told Maulana Mahomed Ali, the only course is to get swaraj first.
('30', 28, 1, 7, 66166) Then and only then you can help in real sense Turkey, Egypt and Arabia.
('30', 28, 1, 8, 66238) If Hindus and Muslims are united not by paper pacts and resolutions but by heart then and then only you can protect Islam in India and abroad and you please do these for one year and see the results yourselves.
('30', 28, 2, 9, 66449) The Bombay Chronicle, 1 1 1925
('30', 28, 3, 10, 66480) 17. BELGAUM IMPRESSIONS [ I]
('30', 28, 4, 11, 66509) When there are too many impressions all clamouring for expres sion, the registrar’s task becomes unenviable.
('30', 28, 4, 12, 66618) Such is my position as I take up the pencil to register my impressions of Belgaum.
('30', 28, 4, 13, 66701) I can but try.
('30', 28, 4, 14, 66716) Gangadharrao Deshpande and his band of workers rose to the highest height.
('30', 28, 4, 15, 66791) His Vijayanagar was a triumph—not yet of swaraj— but certainly of organisation.
('30', 28, 4, 16, 66871) Every detail was well thought out.
('30', 28, 4, 17, 66906) Dr. Hardikar’s volunteers were smart and attentive.
('30', 28, 4, 18, 66958) The roads were broad and well kept.
('30', 28, 4, 19, 66994) They could easily be broader for the conven ience of the temporary shops and the easy movement of thousands of sight seers.
('30', 28, 4, 20, 67118) The lighting arrangement was perfect.
('30', 28, 4, 21, 67156) The huge pavilion with a marble fountain in front of it seemed to invite all who would enter it.
('30', 28, 4, 22, 67253) The capacity of the pavilion could not be less than seventeen thousand.
('30', 28, 4, 23, 67325) The sanitary arrangements though quite good needed still more scientific treatment than what they had.
('30', 28, 4, 24, 67428) The method of the disposal of used water was very primitive.
('30', 28, 4, 25, 67489) I invite the Cawnpore people who are to have the honour of holding the Congress session of 1925 to study the most effective methods of camp sanitation now and not leave this very important part to the eleventh hour.
('30', 28, 4, 26, 67705) Whilst I am able to give ungrudging praise for the almost perfect organization that one could see in the Congress camp, I cannot help remarking that Gangadharrao could not escape the temptation of making the outside look lavish and in following the traditional custom of going in for extravagant luxuries for the “people at the top”.
('30', 28, 4, 27, 68039) Take the presidential “hut”.
('30', 28, 4, 28, 68068) I had bargained for a khaddar hut; but I was insulted with a khaddar palace.
('30', 28, 4, 29, 68145) The floor space reserved for the
('30', 29, 0, 1, 68178) 30 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 29, 1, 2, 68219) President was certainly quite necessary The fence round the “palace” was an absolute necessity for my protection from embarrassingly admiring crowds.
('30', 29, 1, 3, 68369) But I am sure that, had I been contractor, I would have given the same space and the same comfort to the President at half the expense.
('30', 29, 1, 4, 68505) This however is only one instance of the many I can quote of lavish expenditure.
('30', 29, 1, 5, 68586) The refreshments supplied to the members of the Subjects Committee and others were unnecessarily lavish.
('30', 29, 1, 6, 68691) There was no sense of proportion observed as to the quantities served.
('30', 29, 1, 7, 68762) I am finding fault with nobody.
('30', 29, 1, 8, 68794) The extravagance came from a generous heart.
('30', 29, 1, 9, 68839) It was all well meant.
('30', 29, 1, 10, 68862) Forty years’ tradition cannot be undone in a day, especially if no one likely to gain a hearing will repeatedly criticize it.
('30', 29, 1, 11, 68988) I know, when I suggested to Vallabhbhai in 1921 that he should make a beginning, he retorted by saying that whilst he would try to attain simplicity and avoid extravagance, he would not allow his pet Gujarat to be considered miserly.
('30', 29, 1, 12, 69222) I could not persuade him that if he did not have a temporary fountain costing several thousand rupees he would not be considered miserly.
('30', 29, 1, 13, 69360) I told him too that whatever he did was bound to be copied by his successors.
('30', 29, 1, 14, 69438) Vallabhbhai would not take the odium of being considered miserly.
('30', 29, 1, 15, 69504) I advise Cawnpore to lead the way.
('30', 29, 1, 16, 69539) The miser liness of Cawnpore may be considered the extravagance of tomorrow.
('30', 29, 1, 17, 69616) There were many things Vallabhbhai did discard.
('30', 29, 1, 18, 69664) I did not hear any remarks about the disappearance of the things that were really not a felt want.
('30', 29, 1, 19, 69763) Let us remember that the Congress is intended to represent the poorest toilers who are the salt of India.
('30', 29, 1, 20, 69869) Our scale must be so far as possible adjusted to theirs.
('30', 29, 1, 21, 69926) We must therefore be progressively econo mical without being inefficient and stingy.
('30', 29, 1, 22, 70011) In my opinion the charges for accommodation and food are much too heavy, We may do worse than take a lesson from the book of Swami Shraddhanandji.
('30', 29, 1, 23, 70158) I remember the sheds he built for his guests who came for the Gurukul anniversary in 1916. He built grass sheds for them at a cost (I think) of about Rs. 2,000. He invited contractors to open restaurants on the ground and made no charge for the accommodation.
('30', 29, 1, 24, 70418) No one could complain of the arrangement.
('30', 29, 1, 25, 70460) They knew what they were to expect.
('30', 29, 1, 26, 70496) Nearly 40,000 people were thus accommodated on the Gurukul ground without the slightest difficulty and with practically no expense.
('30', 29, 1, 27, 70628) And what is more each visitor received what he wanted and was at liberty to live cheaply or
('30', 30, 0, 1, 70720) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 31
('30', 30, 1, 2, 70765) extravagantly.
('30', 30, 1, 3, 70780) I do not say that the Swami’s plan should be copied in its entirety.
('30', 30, 1, 4, 70849) But I do suggest that better and cheaper plans are impera tively necessary.
('30', 30, 1, 5, 70925) The reduction of the delegate’s fees from Rs. 10 to 1 was universally acclaimed.
('30', 30, 1, 6, 71006) 1 The reduction of lodging and dining charges would be I am sure still more appreciated.
('30', 30, 1, 7, 71095) The source of income should be a small entrance fee levied from every spectator.
('30', 30, 1, 8, 71176) The Congress must be an annual fair where visitors may come and get instruction with amusement.
('30', 30, 1, 9, 71272) The deliber ative part should be an item round which the demonstrative progr amme should turn.
('30', 30, 1, 10, 71367) It therefore should take place in decent time, as this year, and the appointments must be religiously observed.
('30', 30, 1, 11, 71479) I am not sure that the packing of all other conferences into one week serves any national purpose.
('30', 30, 1, 12, 71578) In my opinion only those conferences should take place during the Congress week that aid and strengthen the Congress.
('30', 30, 1, 13, 71696) The President and his “ Cabinet” must not be expected to give their attention to anything but Congress work.
('30', 30, 1, 14, 71805) I know that, if there had been no other call upon my time, I could have better attended to the charge entrusted to me.
('30', 30, 1, 15, 71924) I had not a moment left to me for contemplation.
('30', 30, 1, 16, 71973) I was unable to frame the necessary recommendations for making the franchise a success.
('30', 30, 1, 17, 72061) The fact is that the organizers of various conferences do not take their tasks seriously.
('30', 30, 1, 18, 72151) They hold them because it has become the fashion to do so.
('30', 30, 1, 19, 72210) I would urge workers in various directions to avoid the annual dissipation of energy.
('30', 30, 1, 20, 72296) The exhibition of indigenous arts and industries is an institution that should grow from year to year.
('30', 30, 1, 21, 72399) The musical concert was a treat that thousands must have enjoyed.
('30', 30, 1, 22, 72465) The lantern lectures tracing the tragic history of the ruin of the greatest national industry and the possibilities of its revival were apposite, instructive and amusing.
('30', 30, 1, 23, 72636) I tender my congratulations to Satish Babu upon the thoughtful and thorough manner in which he organized these lectures.
('30', 30, 1, 24, 72757) The spinning competition 2 must also be a permanent feature.
('30', 30, 1, 25, 72818) Its popularity is evinced by the number of competitors, the brilliance of results and the number of donors.
('30', 30, 1, 26, 72926) This spinning movement is bringing out women from their seclusion as nothing else could have done.
('30', 30, 1, 27, 73025) Of the 11 prize
('30', 30, 2, 28, 73041) 1 Vide “Resolutions Moved from the Chair, Belgaum Congress”, 27 12 1924. 2Vide “Speech Announcing Results of Spinning Competition, Belgaum Congress”, 27 12 1924.

('30', 31, 1, 2, 73244) winners, 4 belonged to the gentle sex.
('30', 31, 1, 3, 73283) It has given them a dignity and self confidence which no university degree could give them.
('30', 31, 1, 4, 73375) They are realizing that their active assistance is just as indispensable as that of men and, what is more, such assistance can be as easily rendered by them as, if not more easily than, by men.
('30', 31, 1, 5, 73569) One thing I must not omit before I close these impressions.
('30', 31, 1, 6, 73629) There were nearly seventy five volunteers, mostly Brahmins, who were engaged in conservancy work in the Congress camp.
('30', 31, 1, 7, 73748) The municipal Bhangis were indeed taken, but it was thought necessary to have the volunteers also.
('30', 31, 1, 8, 73847) Kaka Kalelkar who was in charge of this corps tells me that this part of the work would not have been done as satisfactorily as it was, if the corps had not been formed.
('30', 31, 1, 9, 74017) He tells me too that the volunteers worked most willingly.
('30', 31, 1, 10, 74076) Not one of them shirked the work which ordinarily very few would be prepared to undertake.
('30', 31, 1, 11, 74167) And yet it is the noblest of all from one point of view.
('30', 31, 1, 12, 74224) Indeed sanitary work must be regarded as the foundation of all volunteer training.
('30', 31, 2, 13, 74307) Young India, 1 1 1925
('30', 31, 3, 14, 74329) 18. HOW TO DO IT?
('30', 31, 4, 15, 74347) The Congress has taken a tremendous forward step or as some say committed a tremendous folly at the instance of a mad man.
('30', 31, 4, 16, 74470) Congressmen, whether willing spinners or unwilling, have to justify the step taken by working the spinning franchise That work which some were doing is now transferred to everyone who wishes to belong to the Congress.
('30', 31, 4, 17, 74688) It is methodical labour that the Congress requires from every Congressman.
('30', 31, 4, 18, 74763) If he is unwilling to do that labour, he has to hire it.
('30', 31, 4, 19, 74820) The task is obviously difficult.
('30', 31, 4, 20, 74853) If it were easy, it would not be possible to expect the grand result one expects from its successful working.
('30', 31, 4, 21, 74963) Even when it was a mere matter of collecting four annas per year, the task was found to be difficult.
('30', 31, 4, 22, 75065) And today we have not, on the Congress register, in all the provinces fifty thousand such members.
('30', 31, 4, 23, 75164) Now the Congress expects everyone to spin 2,000 yards per month or to get that quantity spun for him by another.
('30', 31, 4, 24, 75277) Thus the workers have to keep in continuous touch with the spinners.
('30', 31, 4, 25, 75346) Therein lies in my opinion the strength of the franchise.
('30', 31, 4, 26, 75404) It gives the people political education of a high type.
('30', 32, 0, 1, 75460) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 33
('30', 32, 1, 2, 75505) The way to ensure success for every province is to fix the minimum of voters it expects to secure and not to rest till that number is secured.
('30', 32, 1, 3, 75648) Now throughout India at the lowest computation there are at least five million wheels working.
('30', 32, 1, 4, 75743) These spinners can all easily belong to the Congress.
('30', 32, 1, 5, 75797) Those who are taking work from them can now invite them to devote half an hour of their time to the nation by spinning at the wheel for that time.
('30', 32, 1, 6, 75944) This does not require new organizing.
('30', 32, 1, 7, 75982) Cotton slivers, etc., are there.
('30', 32, 1, 8, 76015) All that is necessary is for the organization to make a gift to the Congress of the slivers required to be supplied to the spinners for voluntary or franchise spinning.
('30', 32, 1, 9, 76184) All that is required of spinners is to give the Congress free labour needed to spin 2,000 yards of yarn.
('30', 32, 1, 10, 76289) Then there is the voluntary spinning by non professional spinners.
('30', 32, 1, 11, 76356) Those who are now spinning have to ask their friends and neighbour to do likewise and become Congress members.
('30', 32, 1, 12, 76467) This can be best done by each worker founding spinning clubs of twenty.
('30', 32, 1, 13, 76539) To be efficient these clubs must be small and compact.
('30', 32, 1, 14, 76594) The first member must be a proficient carder and spinner.
('30', 32, 1, 15, 76652) For on him, in the first instance, will fall the burden of collecting cotton, carding it, slivering it and distributing the slivers among the members of the club.
('30', 32, 1, 16, 76815) The third class of work is to provide for the unwilling spinners.
('30', 32, 1, 17, 76881) The honest unwilling spinner will naturally seek out a member of his own family to do the spinning for him.
('30', 32, 1, 18, 76989) He then ensures the contribution of good and true hand spun yarn.
('30', 32, 1, 19, 77055) The next class of unwilling member will himself engage a professional spinner to spin for him.
('30', 32, 1, 20, 77150) And the last class is that which will buy its yarn from the market and run the risk of having spurious yarn sold for genuine.
('30', 32, 1, 21, 77276) For the sake of the common cause I would warn the Congressmen who are unwilling against the last method.
('30', 32, 1, 22, 77381) Registration of membership for the last class is easy and, if many avail themselves of it, the practice will open the floodgates of fraud and may cause an injury to a cottage industry that is struggling to make headway against enormous odds.
('30', 32, 1, 23, 77623) My hope is that there will be very few men and women who will be unwilling to spin for the sake of the Congress and the country.
('30', 32, 1, 24, 77752) The word “unwilling” has found place in the franchise for the sake of meeting the difficulties of those who are old Congressmen and whom I would not like to leave the Congress, even if they were willing to do so.
('30', 32, 1, 25, 77965) But I shall hope that unwillingness will not be encouraged.
('30', 32, 1, 26, 78025) Mere production of hand spun yarn will not make the idle and the starving work.
('30', 32, 1, 27, 78105) It is the atmosphere of manual work, and that too consisting of hand spinning, that is required to make the millions retake to the wheel.
('30', 32, 1, 28, 78243) And that atmosphere can best be produced by all Congressmen regarding it as an honour for themselves personally to spin.
('30', 32, 2, 29, 78364) Young India, 1 1 1925

('30', 33, 1, 2, 78427) 19. NOTES
('30', 33, 2, 3, 78437) TWO PROMISES
('30', 33, 3, 4, 78450) Here is one promise made by a Tamil delegate:
('30', 33, 4, 5, 78496) I promise to introduce ten thousand charkhas in the city of Madura before 30th April 1926.
('30', 33, 5, 6, 78587) Yours ever devoted, L. K. TULSIRAM
('30', 33, 6, 7, 78622) The note containing the promise was passed to me by Sjt.
('30', 33, 6, 8, 78679) Tulsiram at a meeting of the Tamil delegates.
('30', 33, 6, 9, 78725) The introduction of ten thousand charkhas means, of course, as many members.
('30', 33, 6, 10, 78802) If the city of Madura can give ten thousand members, how many should the whole of the Tamilnad?
('30', 33, 6, 11, 78898) Another promise still more important is made by Maulana Zafar Ali Khan.
('30', 33, 6, 12, 78970) He has solemnly promised that he will have got twenty five thousand Mussalman spinners as members by the end of my term of office.
('30', 33, 6, 13, 79101) The Maulana will deserve the highest congratulations, if he succeeds.
('30', 33, 6, 14, 79171) Not that twenty five thousand Mussalman members from the Punjab is by any means a large number, if the thing catches.
('30', 33, 6, 15, 79289) But, when so many are prognosticating a catastrophe, for the Maulana to make the solemn promise is in my opinion a wonderful thing.
('30', 33, 6, 16, 79421) I have told the Maulana that, if he breaks the promise, I shall have to fast against him.
('30', 33, 6, 17, 79511) He retorted by saying, he did not want me to commit suicide and that he would not have made the promise, if he had not meant it or its fulfilment was impossible.
('30', 33, 6, 18, 79673) I invite such promises from every province.
('30', 33, 6, 19, 79717) But no one need make them in a fit of enthusiasm.
('30', 33, 6, 20, 79767) Mere promises mean nothing if there is not an unalterable resolution behind them.
('30', 33, 6, 21, 79849) I know that during the War the authorities used to apportion work for each province, and the provinces had to supply the quota of men or money as the case might be.
('30', 33, 6, 22, 80014) In that case the supply was fixed for them and default carried penalties of a kind with it.
('30', 33, 6, 23, 80106) Should the provinces do less because they are called upon to fix their own quota and because breach of promise will carry no penalty with it?

('30', 34, 3, 6, 80675) 20. MEANING OF BOLSHEVISM
('30', 34, 4, 7, 80701) The following 1 has been received from Mr. M. N. Roy in reply to my article 2 on Bolshevism.
('30', 34, 4, 8, 80794) I gladly publish it, but I cannot help saying that, if Mr. Roy’s article is a correct representation of Bolshevism, it is a poor thing.
('30', 34, 4, 9, 80930) I can no more tolerate the yoke of Bolshevism as described by Mr. Roy than of capitalism.
('30', 34, 4, 10, 81020) I believe in conversion of mankind, not its destruction, and for a very obvious reason.
('30', 34, 4, 11, 81108) We are all very imperfect and weak things and, if we are to destroy all whose ways we do not like, there will be not a man left alive.
('30', 34, 4, 12, 81243) Mobocracy is autocracy multiplied million times.
('30', 34, 4, 13, 81292) But I hope, I am almost sure, that real Bolshevism is much better than Mr. M. N. Roy’s.
('30', 34, 4, 14, 81380) Young India, 1 1 1925
('30', 34, 5, 15, 81402) 21. LETTER TO N. C. KELKAR
('30', 34, 6, 16, 81429) ON THE WAY TO SABARMATI, January 2, 1925
('30', 34, 7, 17, 81470) DEAR MR. KELKAR, It has always been my desire and policy never to write anything to wound the feelings of others.
('30', 34, 7, 18, 81584) But during the current year when I am out for winning you over I would like to be still more cautious.
('30', 34, 7, 19, 81687) I know that without wishing it, I may write things which may not please you, i.e., the party.
('30', 34, 7, 20, 81781) Will you please therefore draw my attention to anything that may appear in Young India or Navajivan and that may not be quite the proper thing?
('30', 34, 7, 21, 81925) I shall try to mend wherever it is possible for me.
('30', 34, 8, 22, 81977) Your sincerely, M. K. GANDHI

('30', 35, 2, 3, 82237) January 2, 1925
('30', 35, 3, 4, 82253) I do not want any Gujarati to take advantage of the freedom to unwilling persons given in the resolution on spinning.
('30', 35, 3, 5, 82371) I see some divine purpose in my release from Yeravda Prison on account of my illness.
('30', 35, 3, 6, 82457) Providence, it seems, has set me free that I might move through the length and breadth of the country speaking about Annapoorna 1, the spinning wheel, and taking it everywhere.
('30', 35, 3, 7, 82634) If India would still not respond to the call of spinning, her privations would multiply.
('30', 35, 3, 8, 82723) It will be no pleasure to me to find Dohad converted into Bombay and half a dozen of its people become millionaires.
('30', 35, 3, 9, 82840) Everyone has the right to earn food and clothing.
('30', 35, 3, 10, 82890) But no one has a right to accumulate wealth and be rich.
('30', 35, 3, 11, 82947) I would not have a handful of you become money lenders.
('30', 35, 3, 12, 83003) I would, however, wish that khadi should be sold as easily as ghee and made current everywhere like coins and postal stamps.
('30', 35, 3, 13, 83128) For those who cannot themselves spin there is a provision to get others to do it for them and thus become eligible for membership But I would urge that no one from Gujarat may take advantage of this provision.
('30', 35, 3, 14, 83338) Sukhdev tells me he has discontinued spinning.
('30', 35, 3, 15, 83385) I did not know it.
('30', 35, 3, 16, 83404) He might be otherwise busy but his discontinuation of spinning is intolerable.
('30', 35, 3, 17, 83483) It would be a miserable plight if our workers themselves do not spin.
('30', 35, 3, 18, 83553) It is not as if Sukhdev does not approve of spinning, it is only his laziness.
('30', 35, 3, 19, 83632) I won’t have this excuse from any Gujarati.

('30', 35, 6, 22, 83713) 23. SPEECH AT ANTYAJA ASHRAM, GODHRA
('30', 35, 7, 23, 83750) January 2, 1925
('30', 35, 8, 24, 83766) You have heard a number of dialogues and bhajans.
('30', 35, 8, 25, 83816) Who would say that these dialogues were by Antyaja children or that it was they who sang the bhanjans in devotion to God?

('30', 41, 3, 8, 97125) 26. WILLING AND UNWILLING
('30', 41, 4, 9, 97151) The Congress session has concluded without a hitch.
('30', 41, 4, 10, 97203) There was a solitary item on the agenda, it may be said, namely, adoption of spinning as an essential duty of every Indian.

('30', 45, 6, 7, 103291) 34. THE WORKING COMMITTEE
('30', 45, 7, 8, 103317) The selection of the Working Committee was ultimately left by the A.I.C.C. to Deshbandhu Das, Pandit Motilal Nehru and me.
('30', 45, 7, 9, 103440) I have been charged with having yielded everything to the Swarajists.
('30', 45, 7, 10, 103510) If I have done so, I pride myself on the fact.
('30', 45, 7, 11, 103557) Full surrender must be full.
('30', 45, 7, 12, 103586) The fact however is that no pressure whatsoever was put upon me to withdraw a single No changer’s name.
('30', 45, 7, 13, 103690) I deliberately withdrew C. Rajagopalachari’s, Vallabhbhai’s and Shankerlal Banker’s names.
('30', 45, 7, 14, 103781) It was a matter of honour to have Sarojini Devi and Sardar Mangal Singh on the Committee.
('30', 45, 7, 15, 103871) Mr. Kelkar was anxious to retire in favour of Mr. Aney.
('30', 45, 7, 16, 103927) I would not listen to it.
('30', 45, 7, 17, 103953) And I was anxious to have Mr. Aney as soon as his name was mentioned.
('30', 45, 7, 18, 104023) Let the reader rest assured that the whole selection was made in a spirit of perfect comradeship.
('30', 45, 7, 19, 104121) Assume honesty (and it must be assumed) on the part of both the groups and the task of either is difficult enough.
('30', 45, 7, 20, 104236) Although the degree of faith and therefore the emphasis is different, both have to strive to find a common method of working the common programme.
('30', 45, 7, 21, 104383) In a Working Committee with a decided majority of No changers strong resolutions can no doubt be carried for khaddar work but they cannot carry much weight with those who have only reluctantly accepted the khaddar franchise.
('30', 45, 7, 22, 104608) Whereas resolutions of a working Committee in which the predominant voice is that of the Swarajists, though they may be mild are sure to carry far greater weight with the Swarajists.
('30', 45, 7, 23, 104791) And my business is to carry the latter with me whole heartely.
('30', 45, 7, 24, 104854) I want to act upon them and I want them to act upon me.
('30', 45, 7, 25, 104910) Nothing, therefore, can be better than that the Swarajist leaders and among them the ablest and most uncompromising opponents of the spinning franchise and I should be thrown together in an atmosphere in which we must pull together.
('30', 45, 7, 26, 105143) I do not need that kind of contact with the enthusiasts.
('30', 45, 7, 27, 105200) They are expected to work away with all the strength that conviction must
('30', 45, 8, 28, 105274) 1 Devchand Parekh; barrister; social worker of Kathiawar
('30', 46, 0, 1, 105331) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 47
('30', 46, 1, 2, 105376) give them.
('30', 46, 1, 3, 105387) They do not need resolutions or instructions as spur to action.
('30', 46, 1, 4, 105451) If, therefore, we mean in the course of the year to achieve an unbreakable unity between the two wings, the selection of the Working Committee is, I hold, ideal.
('30', 46, 1, 5, 105613) Anyway, it must produce an atmosphere the most favourable for the purpose.
('30', 46, 1, 6, 105688) I shall leave no stone unturned to achieve the end.
('30', 46, 1, 7, 105740) Hence I propose during the year to carry no motion or proposal that might be of a party character.
('30', 46, 1, 8, 105839) Neither the spinning wheel nor the boycott of foreign cloth can be expeditiously worked in the teeth of opposition from within the Congress ranks indeed we must strive to gain the support of non Congressmen for the national constructive progra mme.
('30', 46, 1, 9, 106088) They may not like spinning or wearing khaddar as part of the franchise, but I have not met many Liberals who have any objection to hand spinning as a cottage industry or to the use of khaddar as such and apart from the franchise.
('30', 46, 1, 10, 106318) It may be constitutionally impos sible for all parties to accept the existing Congress creed or the new franchise, and therefore to become Congressmen.
('30', 46, 1, 11, 106470) But I hope that the existence of the creed or the new franchise will not be a bar against joint work wherever it is possible.

('30', 46, 3, 13, 106618) 35. BELGAUM IMPRESSIONS [ II]
('30', 46, 4, 14, 106648) NAMDHARIS
('30', 46, 5, 15, 106658) I had a hard time of it meeting all and sundry and trying to give them satisfaction.
('30', 46, 5, 16, 106743) The Namdhari Sikhs brought me a bundle of papers and expected me to attend to their grievance against the Akalis.
('30', 46, 5, 17, 106857) Their patience and courtesy disarmed all unwillingness on my part.
('30', 46, 5, 18, 106924) But my inability to attend to their cause was much greater than my unwillingness.
('30', 46, 5, 19, 107006) Time would not wait even for their courtesy.
('30', 46, 5, 20, 107051) They were themselves able to see that I was perfectly helpless.
('30', 46, 5, 21, 107115) The only comfort I was able to give them was that when I next visited Lahore, I would certainly go through their papers and see to it that the Congress did them no injustice.
('30', 46, 5, 22, 107290) I told them that although I was partial to the cause of the brave Akalis, I would be no party to any injustice or oppression being committed by them.
('30', 46, 5, 23, 107440) Sardar Mangal Singh re echoed my sentiment and said that he was always ready to show that the Akalis wanted nothing but reform of the gurdwaras on a strictly moral basis.
('30', 47, 0, 1, 107611) 48 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 47, 1, 2, 107652) PLEA FOR BUDDHISTS
('30', 47, 2, 3, 107671) Mr. Pereira of.
('30', 47, 2, 4, 107687) Ceylon wanted me to interest the Congress in the Buddha Gaya Temple.
('30', 47, 2, 5, 107756) The reader will remember that a movement has been in progress for some years for the restoration to Buddhists of the great and historic temple at Buddha Gaya.
('30', 47, 2, 6, 107915) But it seems to have made no tangible headway.
('30', 47, 2, 7, 107962) At the Cocanada Congress Babu Rajendra Prasad was appointed to inquire into the matter and report.
('30', 47, 2, 8, 108061) He had not been able to do so up to the time of the meeting.
('30', 47, 2, 9, 108122) A Buddhist deput ation came from Ceylon to Belgaum during the Congress week to plead the Buddhist cause personally before the Congress.
('30', 47, 2, 10, 108258) Mr. Pereira had seen several leaders and then saw me.
('30', 47, 2, 11, 108312) He really did not need to plead his cause before me.
('30', 47, 2, 12, 108365) I was already a convert.
('30', 47, 2, 13, 108390) But here again what was I to do?
('30', 47, 2, 14, 108423) I had no time for anything else beyond what I had already undertaken.
('30', 47, 2, 15, 108493) But Mr. Pereira was irresistible.
('30', 47, 2, 16, 108527) I told him that I believed in his cause as much as he did, but the Congress might not be able to help him much.
('30', 47, 2, 17, 108639) He was persistent and took away from me the promise that I should at least let him address the Subjects Committee and let him take the chance of being rejected.
('30', 47, 2, 18, 108800) Mr. Pereira had confidence in himself.
('30', 47, 2, 19, 108839) His pleasing manners and his brief but eloquent speech made an impression upon the Committee which decided to consider the question there and then.
('30', 47, 2, 20, 108987) But alas!
('30', 47, 2, 21, 108997) Upon discussion the Committee discovered that it could not materially assist Mr. Pereira; it had not the report of its own deputy; it had exhaustively discussed the subject at the previous session and owing to sharp differences was obliged to drop it.
('30', 47, 2, 22, 109249) The only thing, therefore, the Committee was able to do was to ask Rajendra Babu to hasten his inquiry and let the Working Committee have his report on or before the end of the present month.
('30', 47, 2, 23, 109441) There is no doubt that the possession of the temple should vest in the Buddhists.
('30', 47, 2, 24, 109523) There may be legal difficulties.
('30', 47, 2, 25, 109556) They must be overcome.
('30', 47, 2, 26, 109579) If the report is true that animal sacrifice is offered in the temple, it is a sacrilege.
('30', 47, 2, 27, 109668) It is equally a sacrilege if the worship is offered, as it is alleged, in a way calculated to wound the susceptibilities of Buddhists.
('30', 47, 2, 28, 109803) We should take pride in helping the restoration of the temple to the rightful trustees.
('30', 47, 2, 29, 109891) I hope Rajendra Babu will secure all the literature on the subject and produce a report which can serve as a guide for all who wish to advance the cause of the Buddhist claimants.
('30', 47, 2, 30, 110071) Let me hope also that Mr. Pereira has remained in India and is assisting Rajendra Babu.
('30', 48, 0, 1, 110159) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 49
('30', 48, 1, 2, 110204) TEACHERS IN CONFERENCE The national teachers met in informal conference and came to definite conclusions.
('30', 48, 1, 3, 110310) The debate was interesting.
('30', 48, 1, 4, 110338) It centred round the charkha.
('30', 48, 1, 5, 110368) Learned pandits attended the conference.
('30', 48, 1, 6, 110409) I hope that the teachers will carry out to the letter and in the spirit the resolutions addressed to themselves.
('30', 48, 1, 7, 110522) It has been the bane of the national life to pass resolutions and never to enforce them.
('30', 48, 1, 8, 110611) The teachers should be the last persons in the world to make vain promises.
('30', 48, 1, 9, 110687) They have in their hands the moulding of the youth of the country.
('30', 48, 1, 10, 110754) Let them know that the students are sure to copy their bad example of breach of their own word in preference to their lofty sermons on the sacredness of resolutions and promises.
('30', 48, 1, 11, 110933) This year is a year of trial and test for the nation.
('30', 48, 1, 12, 110987) The Congress has staked its all practically on a single issue, i.e., the production and sale of khaddar and the boycott of foreign cloth.
('30', 48, 1, 13, 111125) The national schools to be national have to assist this national work by the teachers and boys and girls learning the various processes incidental to the production of khaddar, by wearing it themselves and by spinning as much yarn as they can.
('30', 48, 1, 14, 111369) Their other studies need not be neglected but they dare not omit the things that are required for the vital needs of the nation.
('30', 48, 1, 15, 111498) The teachers have by an overwhelming majority accepted the position.
('30', 48, 1, 16, 111567) I hope they will make it good by acting up to their promise.
('30', 48, 2, 17, 111628) STUDENTS
('30', 48, 3, 18, 111637) The students too met in conference.
('30', 48, 3, 19, 111673) These were not merely of the national schools and colleges but they were principally from Government schools.
('30', 48, 3, 20, 111783) Mr. Reddy, the President, had a scheme for utilizing the vacation and other leisure hours of students.
('30', 48, 3, 21, 111886) His scheme was to commit the students (he would include the vakils also) to giving the nation at least 28 evenings every year, each volunteer to take up four villages in his neighbourhood as his field of work.
('30', 48, 3, 22, 112096) Mr. Reddy proposed a course of lectures on a variety of subjects.
('30', 48, 3, 23, 112162) For the time being I would occupy the leisure hours of these volunteers for the spread of khaddar.
('30', 48, 3, 24, 112261) But this service is not the only way the students and practising vakils can help.
('30', 48, 3, 25, 112343) Surely the least they can do is to use khaddar themselves and spin half an hour per day.
('30', 48, 3, 26, 112432) The vakils and students over 21 years should become members of the Congress and those who are under age should send their yarn as donation either to their own committee or to the A.I.K.B.

('30', 49, 1, 2, 112683) 36. NOTES
('30', 49, 2, 3, 112693) FOR PROVINCIAL COMMITTEE
('30', 49, 3, 4, 112718) I hope that provincial Congress committees will lose no time in organizing the new franchise.
('30', 49, 3, 5, 112812) I know that some Congressmen are waiting for instructions from the Working Committee as to the method of work before commencing enrolment.
('30', 49, 3, 6, 112951) Such waiting is, however, wholly unnecessary.
('30', 49, 3, 7, 112997) It is not the Working Committee that has to organize the work under the new franchise.
('30', 49, 3, 8, 113084) The burden rests with every province, and the sooner they commence the better it is for the purpose for which the new franchise has been introduced.
('30', 49, 3, 9, 113233) Congres smen should remember that at the end of February the existing list of members falls into desuetude.
('30', 49, 3, 10, 113341) If provincial committees wait till then for enrolment, they will find that they have not even a quorum to go on with.
('30', 49, 3, 11, 113459) Membership should, therefore, be actively canvassed from now.
('30', 49, 3, 12, 113521) I had hoped to publish some valuable information supplied to me by Sjt.
('30', 49, 3, 13, 113593) Satish Chandra Das Gupta as to the method of organiz ation.
('30', 49, 3, 14, 113653) I have also before me two illuminating volumes on khaddar work written by Satish Babu and published by Khadi Pratisthan.
('30', 49, 3, 15, 113774) The first volume deals with the manner of organizing spinning and weaving and the second volume collects all the available information about cotton.
('30', 49, 3, 16, 113923) The volumes are seasonable.
('30', 49, 3, 17, 113951) I hope to condense some of the information made available to the public by their industrious author.
('30', 49, 3, 18, 114052) Those who can afford to buy the volumes should possess them.
('30', 49, 3, 19, 114113) They should write to the Khadi Pratisthan, 15, College Square, Calcutta, for them.
('30', 49, 3, 20, 114196) The price of the first volume is two rupees and that of the second is one rupee.
('30', 49, 4, 21, 114277) TO SPINNERS
('30', 49, 5, 22, 114289) Several spinners, who have been sending their yarn either to the A.I.K.B. or to me, inquire what they are to do now.
('30', 49, 5, 23, 114406) They are to send in their yarn as usual for the month of December.
('30', 49, 5, 24, 114473) All that the adults may spin from the beginning of the year should naturally be retained and sent in to the respective provincial committees as their monthly subscription for membership.
('30', 49, 5, 25, 114660) Hitherto spinners have sent in what they have spun and many have sent in even less than 2,000 yards.
('30', 49, 5, 26, 114761) Now they are bound, to be entitled to a living membership, to send not less than 2,000 yards per month.
('30', 49, 5, 27, 114865) They may send more if they choose.
('30', 49, 5, 28, 114900) They should take care to have a receipt for the exact quantity sent.
('30', 49, 5, 29, 114969) They will get credit for the balance over 2,000 yards for the next
('30', 50, 0, 1, 115036) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 51
('30', 50, 1, 2, 115081) month’s quota.
('30', 50, 1, 3, 115096) Minors may send yarn to the provincial Congress committees as donations.
('30', 50, 1, 4, 115169) They cannot claim membership.
('30', 50, 1, 5, 115199) There are however many such who, I am told, would send their yarn only to me.
('30', 50, 1, 6, 115277) I would advise them to send their yarn to their respective committees; but if they will not do so, I would be glad as usual to receive their yarn and turn it to good account.
('30', 50, 2, 7, 115452) PRIZE ESSAY
('30', 50, 3, 8, 115464) The terms of the prize essay on the message of the spinning wheel and khaddar are: 1. The essay should be in English in four parts: the first part to contain the history of hand spinning and the khaddar (meaning hand spun, including the celebrated shubnum 1 of Dacca), trade of India before the British advent; the second part should trace the history of the ruin of hand spinning and the khaddar trade; the third part should be an examination of the possibilities of hand spinning and khaddar and a comparison between the Indian mill industry and hand spinning and hand weaving; the fourth part should examine the possibilities of achieving boycott of foreign cloth through the spinning wheel.
('30', 50, 3, 9, 116159) The essay should be supported by authoritative statistics and should have an appendix containing a list of all the reference books and authorities used by the author in support of his argument.
('30', 50, 3, 10, 116353) 2. The essay may be as brief as the competitors wish to make it, consistently with the giving of a full record of facts and figures.
('30', 50, 3, 11, 116486) 3. The essay should be sent to the office of Young India by registered book post with the author’s name on a separate sheet and should reach the office of Young India not later than 15th March next.
('30', 50, 3, 12, 116685) The judges will be Messrs Shankerlal Banker, Maganlal K. Gandhi and myself.
('30', 50, 3, 13, 116761) The result will be announced not later than 31st March 1925. The judges will reserve to themselves the right of rejecting all the essays if they fall below a certain standard.
('30', 50, 3, 14, 116937) The prize will be paid to the winner on the announcement thereof.
('30', 50, 3, 15, 117003) The right of publication will vest in the All India Khadi Board in accordance with the donor’s wishes.
('30', 50, 3, 16, 117106) I hope that those scholars who are interested in the great spinning movement and who have studied the subject will consider it worth their while to enter into the competition.
('30', 50, 4, 17, 117282) 1 Literally dew; here a name for the fine muslin formerly woven in Dacca
('30', 51, 0, 1, 117355) 52 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 51, 1, 2, 117396) POVERTY A CAUSE
('30', 51, 2, 3, 117412) A Bengali friend writing about unity says:
('30', 51, 3, 4, 117455) In Bengal, perhaps in other provinces also, the economic distress of the educated middle classes hinders the growth of public spirit and patriotism.
('30', 51, 3, 5, 117604) The young men crowd the meetings and applaud the speeches.
('30', 51, 3, 6, 117663) When they go out of schools and colleges, they begin to feel the struggle for existence.
('30', 51, 3, 7, 117752) It damps their youthful vigour and enthusiasm and they cease to take any practical interest in national work.
('30', 51, 3, 8, 117862) The evil, as the writer rightly judges, is more or less common to all the provinces.
('30', 51, 3, 9, 117947) The remedy is clear.
('30', 51, 3, 10, 117968) No Government can find employment for the increasing number of students year after year.
('30', 51, 3, 11, 118057) The only way to solve the puzzle is to revise the common idea about education, that it is a means of finding a career in life.
('30', 51, 3, 12, 118184) Education should be taken for our mental and moral development.
('30', 51, 3, 13, 118248) Secondly, the army of unemployed young men should realize the dignity of labour and qualify themselves for taking up the organisation of the charkha industry.
('30', 51, 3, 14, 118407) It can take in an unlimited number of young men if they were willing to take the necessary training and to go to the villages and to be satisfied with a modest income.

('30', 52, 5, 23, 121232) 38. PRESIDENTIAL ADDRESS AT KATHIAWAR POLITICAL CONFERENCE, BHAVANAGAR
('30', 52, 6, 24, 121303) January 8, 1925
('30', 52, 7, 25, 121319) The following is an English translation 4 of Mr. Gandhi’s Presidential Address at the Third Kathiawar Political Conference held at Bhavnagar on the 8th instant:
('30', 52, 8, 26, 121480) 1 Ruler 2 Mull 3 Mill clods 4 For the Gujarati report vide Navajivan Supplement, 18 1 1925.
('30', 53, 0, 1, 121572) 54 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 53, 1, 2, 121613) FRIENDS, The Presidentship of the Kathiawar Political Conference had been offered to me before I went to jail but I had then refused to shoulder the responsibility attaching to that honourable position.
('30', 53, 1, 3, 121816) As the reasons which then prompted my refusal do not exist any longer, I have accepted the honour now, though not without trepidation— trepidation because there is a wide divergence between my own views and the views held by many on political questions.
('30', 53, 1, 4, 122070) Again the fact that I am President of the National Congress for the current year makes things rather awkward for me.
('30', 53, 1, 5, 122187) That single burden is more than I can fairly discharge, and it would be almost too much for me during the year to undertake to guide the activities of this Conference in addition.
('30', 53, 1, 6, 122367) If therefore presiding over your deliberations today implies any such responsibility, I may say that I am not at all in a position to do it justice.

('30', 78, 3, 9, 183941) 41. SPEECH AT SAMALDAS COLLEGE, BHAVNAGAR 1
('30', 78, 4, 10, 183985) January 9, 1925
('30', 78, 5, 11, 184001) I have to speak today on the dharma or duty of students.
('30', 78, 5, 12, 184058) That dharma is as easy as it is difficult.
('30', 78, 5, 13, 184101) According to Hinduism, the student is a brahmachari, and brahmacharyashrama is the student state.
('30', 78, 5, 14, 184199) Celibacy is a narrow interpretation of brahmacharya.
('30', 78, 5, 15, 184252) The original meaning is the life or the state of a student.
('30', 78, 5, 16, 184312) That means control of the senses, but the whole period of study or acquirement of knowledge by means of control of the senses came to be regarded as brahma charyashrarma.
('30', 78, 5, 17, 184483) This period of life necessarily means very much taking and very little giving.
('30', 78, 5, 18, 184562) We are mainly recipients in this state— taking whatever we can get from parents, teachers and from the world.
('30', 78, 5, 19, 184672) But the taking, if it carries—as it did—no obligation of simultaneous repayment, it necessarily carried an obligation to repay the whole debt, with compound interest, at the proper time.
('30', 78, 5, 20, 184859) That is why the Hindus maintain brahmacharyashrama as a matter of religious duty.
('30', 78, 5, 21, 184941) The [lives] of a brahmachari and a sannyasi are regarded as spiritually similar.
('30', 78, 5, 22, 185022) The brahmachari must needs be a sannyasi if he is to be a brahmachari.
('30', 78, 5, 23, 185093) For the sannyasi, it is a matter of choice.
('30', 78, 5, 24, 185137) The four ashramas of Hinduism have nowadays lost their sacred character, and exist, if at all, in name.
('30', 78, 5, 25, 185241) The life of the student brahmachari is poisoned at the very spring.

('30', 79, 0, 1, 185655) 80 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 79, 1, 2, 185696) How can we understand the duty of students today?
('30', 79, 1, 3, 185746) We have fallen so much from the ideal.
('30', 79, 1, 4, 185785) The parents take the lead in giving the wrong direction.
('30', 79, 1, 5, 185842) They feel that their children should be educated only in order that they may earn wealth and position.
('30', 79, 1, 6, 185945) Education and knowledge are thus being prostituted, and we look in vain for the peace, innocence and bliss that the life of a student ought to be.
('30', 79, 1, 7, 186092) Our students are weighed down with cares and worries when they should really be “careful for nothing”.
('30', 79, 1, 8, 186195) They have simply to receive and to assimilate.
('30', 79, 1, 9, 186242) They should know only to discriminate between what should be received and what rejected.
('30', 79, 1, 10, 186331) It is the duty of the teacher to teach his pupils discrimination.
('30', 79, 1, 11, 186397) If we go on talking in indiscrimin ately, we would be no better.
('30', 79, 1, 12, 186462) than machines.
('30', 79, 1, 13, 186477) We are thinking, knowing beings and we must in this period distinguish truth from untruth, sweet from bitter language, clean from unclean things and so on.
('30', 79, 1, 14, 186633) But the student’s path today is strewn with more difficulties than the one of distinguishing good from bad things.
('30', 79, 1, 15, 186748) He has to fight the hostile atmosphere around him.
('30', 79, 1, 16, 186799) Instead of the sacred surroundings of a rishi guru’s ashram and his paternal care, he has the atmosphere of a broken down home, and the artificial surroundings created by the modern system of education.
('30', 79, 1, 17, 187002) The rishis taught their pupils without books.
('30', 79, 1, 18, 187048) They only gave them a few mantras which the pupils treasured in their memories and translated in practical life.
('30', 79, 1, 19, 187161) The present day student has to live in the midst of heaps of books, sufficient to choke him.
('30', 79, 1, 20, 187254) In my own days Reynolds was much in vogue among students and I escaped him only because I was far from being a brilliant student and never cared to peep out of the school text books.
('30', 79, 1, 21, 187437) When I went to England, however, I saw that the novels were tabooed in decent circles and that I had lost nothing by having never read them.
('30', 79, 1, 22, 187578) Similarly there are many other things which a student might do worse than reject.
('30', 79, 1, 23, 187660) One such thing is the craze for earning a career.
('30', 79, 1, 24, 187710) Only the grihastha—householder—has to think of it, it is none of the brahmachari student’s dharma.
('30', 79, 1, 25, 187809) He has to acquaint himself with the condition of things in his own country, try to realize the magnitude of the crisis with which it is faced and the work that it requires of him.
('30', 79, 1, 26, 187989) I dare say many amongst you read newspapers.
('30', 79, 1, 27, 188034) I do not think I can ask you to eschew them altogether.
('30', 79, 1, 28, 188090) But I would ask you to eschew everything of ephemeral interest, and I can tell you that newspapers afford nothing of permanent interest.
('30', 79, 1, 29, 188227) They offer nothing to help the formation of character.
('30', 79, 1, 30, 188282) And yet I know the craze for newspapers.
('30', 79, 1, 31, 188323) It is pitiable, terrible.
('30', 79, 1, 32, 188349) I am talking in this strain as I have myself made

('30', 80, 1, 2, 188444) some experiments in education.

('30', 80, 1, 5, 188760) I have ventured to place them even before students.

('30', 80, 1, 12, 189161) The loser would be Lord Reading if he chose to reject it.

('30', 80, 1, 15, 189382) Maddock, and when Mrs. Maddock sailed for England I presented her with a khaddar towel as a memento, and asked her to carry the message from house to house.

('30', 80, 1, 17, 189687) It may not be relishing, but no health giving food has the relish of spicy foods so detrimental to health, And so the Gita in a memorable text asks all thinking people to take things of which the first taste is bitter, but which are ultimately conducive to immortality.
('30', 80, 1, 18, 189957) Such a thing today is the spinning wheel and its product.
('30', 80, 1, 19, 190015) There is no yajna (Sacrifice) greater than spinning, calculated to bring peace to the troubled spirit, to soothe the distracted student’s mind, to spiritualize his life.

('30', 80, 1, 22, 190494) An English friend wrote saying his English common sense told him that spinning was an excellent hobby.

('30', 80, 1, 24, 190783) Their “hobby” is a thing full of meaning.

('30', 80, 1, 26, 190943) Two hours he had set apart for his hobby which was gardening and it was this gardening that lent zest and savour to his life

('30', 84, 3, 11, 197726) On the whole 74 members promised to spin, three promised to give yarn spun by others, and the total number of members promised to be collected was 1,700. Mr. Gandhi then suggested that over and above these members who would spin or give yarn, there might be many more who would spin for half an hour daily if they were given cotton.

('30', 94, 2, 8, 222678) SIR PRABHASHANKER TO SPIN
('30', 94, 3, 9, 222704) The most startling event of the session perhaps was the solemn resolution taken by Sir Prabhashanker Pattani to spin daily for at least half an hour before taking his principal meal so long as he was not too ill to turn the wheel.
('30', 94, 3, 10, 222935) He has made no exception for travels, for he contends, and rightly, that as he travels always first class, he should have no difficulty about carrying the wheel with him and spinning during his travels.

('30', 94, 3, 20, 223904) The effect of the addition on individuals might be imperceptible, but on the people as a whole it must be most marked.

('30', 95, 5, 15, 225833) 52. THE REVOLVING WHEEL
('30', 95, 6, 16, 225857) Baro Dada Dwijendranath Tagore as the reader knows has a weakness for me.
('30', 95, 6, 17, 225931) Almost everything I say or do appeals to him with an irresistible force.
('30', 95, 6, 18, 226004) The reader is therefore entitled to discount his approval of my ideas and schemes.
('30', 95, 6, 19, 226087) But he cannot but admire Baro Dada’s zeal and devotion for his country which make him keep in touch with the current thought in our politics.
('30', 95, 6, 20, 226229) Here is his latest on the spinning wheel:
('30', 95, 7, 21, 226271) In practice, though not in theory, most self important people fondly believe that what seems improbable to them is impossible and what seems probable to them is alone possible.
('30', 95, 7, 22, 226448) The enemies of Napoleon once thought that it was as impossible for an army to cross the Alps during the winter season as it would be to take a flight to the moon by means of a balloon; but Napoleon thought otherwise.
('30', 95, 7, 23, 226665) To his penetrating view, crossing the Alps was the only means possible by which he could gain entrance into Italy.
('30', 95, 8, 24, 226780) In like manner most of our countrymen think it utterly impossible
('30', 96, 0, 1, 226846) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 97
('30', 96, 1, 2, 226891) that the cause of our economical, if not political, freedom can advance a single step by such a simple thing as plying the charkha; while on the other hand Mahatmaji thinks that that is the only means possible by adopting which we can hope to reach the goal of our endeavour.
('30', 96, 1, 3, 227167) Baro Dada adds in a footnote that a charkha is philologically equivalent to a circle and metaphorically to the revolving wheel of the universe—samsara.
('30', 96, 1, 4, 227319) One of Kabir’s songs is based on this imagery.
('30', 96, 1, 5, 227366) But the most important part of Baro Dada’s letter is his emphasis on the stern fact that howsoever impossible the charkha may appear to the worldly wise, it is the only possible thing for the country’s real advance.
('30', 96, 1, 6, 227582) It is the only thing that can give substance to any big political move that the country may make.

('30', 96, 3, 8, 227703) 53. NON BRAHMINS
('30', 96, 4, 9, 227720) The Chronicle invites me to explain my action or inaction in connection with the Non Brahmin Conference at Belgaum.
('30', 96, 4, 10, 227836) It surprises me to hear complaints of indifference on the part of the Congress leaders regarding the Conference.
('30', 96, 4, 11, 227949) Speaking for myself I was trying to attend all the conferences consistently with the work I had gone to Belgaum to do.
('30', 96, 4, 12, 228068) The Non Brahmin Conference that was held was not held, so I was told, in response to Maulana Mahomed Ali’s invitation.
('30', 96, 4, 13, 228187) It was not held on the Congress ground.
('30', 96, 4, 14, 228227) It was not held in consultation with any Congressman so far as I am aware.
('30', 96, 4, 15, 228302) I knew nothing of the time or the place of the meeting except through the admission card that was delivered to me in common with numerous such cards.
('30', 96, 4, 16, 228452) Nevertheless I was anxious to attend it and was trying to fit in my visit there with my other appointments.
('30', 96, 4, 17, 228560) Unfortunately I was attending to business.
('30', 96, 4, 18, 228603) I could not leave, whilst the Conference was proceeding.
('30', 96, 4, 19, 228660) When I finished my work and inquired I found that the Conference was already dissolved.
('30', 96, 4, 20, 228748) I state these facts merely to show that there was neither disinclination nor discourtesy shown regarding the Conference.
('30', 96, 4, 21, 228869) What applies to me applies to most leaders.
('30', 96, 4, 22, 228913) In my opinion it was the duty of the organizers to consult me as to the time of the Conference so as to ensure my attendance.
('30', 96, 4, 23, 229039) And I would then have made it possible for the other Congress leaders, too, to go.
('30', 96, 4, 24, 229122) Maulana Mahomed Ali’s invitation was not meant for a mechanical act of holding others conferences during the Congress week.
('30', 96, 4, 25, 229246) It was to
('30', 97, 0, 1, 229256) 98 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 97, 1, 2, 229297) bring the parties together in hearty contact.
('30', 97, 1, 3, 229343) I find no fault with the organizers of the Non Brahmin Conference; I am simply endeavour ing to show that the Congress leaders would have gladly gone if they could have and if they had been given an opportunity.
('30', 97, 1, 4, 229555) Since writing the foregoing I have seen Sjt.
('30', 97, 1, 5, 229600) Gangadharrao’s explanation which makes the position clearer.

('30', 101, 2, 3, 234872) In those provinces in which there are a considerable number of self spinners and the khadi activity is of importance, it will not be difficult to enrol members on yarn franchise at once and work the existing charkhas.
('30', 101, 2, 4, 235090) But in those provinces where spinning has not made much headway, the P.C.C. will have to make very special arrangements for enrolling members.
('30', 101, 2, 5, 235233) Up to now the Congress Committees were handling cash only, but with the introduction of the yarn franchise, yarn and khadi will have to be handled.
('30', 101, 2, 6, 235381) The Congress office shall have a yarn and khadi section.
('30', 101, 2, 7, 235438) Scales and weights for weighing and all the necessary items for the storing, packing, despatch and sale of khadi and yarn will have to be attended to.
('30', 101, 2, 8, 235589) A full set of books shall have to be kept.

('30', 101, 2, 10, 235713) Arrangements shall have to be made for making charkhas easily available to the members.
('30', 101, 2, 11, 235801) Every Congress Committee will require a training section to be attached with it.
('30', 101, 2, 12, 235882) The worker in charge of spinning section must learn to card and use the carding bow as an expert and also be a good spinner.

('30', 110, 3, 27, 257356) It is with this Ravishankar as a witness that you have taken an oath; so if you break your pledge you will force him to fast.
('30', 110, 3, 28, 257482) I am of Ravishankar’s fraternity and know how to follow him.
('30', 110, 3, 29, 257543) I know not how to kill, but how to die.

('30', 116, 5, 12, 270421) As the resolution regarding spinning drops the clauses opposed to it, the question arose whether life members did or did not retain their rights.
('30', 116, 5, 13, 270567) According to the resolution, clauses which opposed spinning were automatically dropped.
('30', 116, 5, 14, 270655) The question was a complicated one; however, there was no alternative for me but to give a verdict.

('30', 116, 5, 16, 270874) I have not given the decision whether or not the Conference has the legal authority to do away with such rights.
('30', 116, 5, 17, 270987) It was necessary for me only to decide whether the resolution of the Conference made any difference to the rights of the life members and, as mentioned above, I have given that decision in favour of the life members.
('30', 116, 6, 18, 271204) REQUEST TO THEM

('30', 116, 7, 23, 271699) This is my humble opinion.

('30', 117, 1, 2, 271768) SIR PRABHASHANKAR PATTANI 1
('30', 117, 2, 3, 271796) In some respects I regard Sir Prabhashankar Pattani’s pledge to spin as a major achievement of the Conference.
('30', 117, 2, 4, 271907) The words with which he announced his pledge were very solemn.
('30', 117, 2, 5, 271970) They left a very deep impression on the members.
('30', 117, 2, 6, 272019) That pledge originated in the following manner.
('30', 117, 2, 7, 272067) After the final session of the Congress at Belgaum, 2 many persons had come to the decision that they would enrol a certain number of spinning members before the first of March.
('30', 117, 2, 8, 272245) I had personally undertaken to try and enrol a hundred names in this venture, and I had also said I would try to persuade two additional persons who were thought to be unwilling to spin.
('30', 117, 2, 9, 272432) As I had to come to Kathiawar in any case, I had hoped to find these persons here.
('30', 117, 2, 10, 272515) I counted Pattani Saheb among those averse to spinning.
('30', 117, 2, 11, 272571) When the Subjects Committee accepted the resolution on spinning, I asked for a hundred names and also promised to try and persuade Pattani Saheb to spin.
('30', 117, 2, 12, 272725) No sooner had these words escaped my lips than pattani Saheb stood up and took the pledge that as long as he was in good health, he would spin regularly for half an hour before his meal.
('30', 117, 2, 13, 272912) He then laid down the condition that I should teach him how to spin.
('30', 117, 2, 14, 272981) I got what I wanted.
('30', 117, 2, 15, 273002) At the close of the Confere nce I was to be his guest.
('30', 117, 2, 16, 273057) The very day after the Conference, I taught him for half an hour.
('30', 117, 2, 17, 273123) Within that very half hour, he learnt how to take out threads from the sliver.
('30', 117, 2, 18, 273202) On the second day, within two hours, he spun 48 yards of fine eight count yarn and on the third day he spun 27 yards within an hour.
('30', 117, 2, 19, 273335) On both the days he had his meal only after taking a bath and spinning the yarn.
('30', 117, 2, 20, 273416) In this manner, if other well known officials and members of princely families set an example in spinning, it would make a good impression on the poorer sections of the people in the country and make them industrious.
('30', 117, 2, 21, 273634) I hope that Pattani Saheb’s pledge will be fulfilled in all respects.
('30', 117, 2, 22, 273704) I should inform you that he will not become a member of the Congress or the Kathiawar Political Conference.
('30', 117, 2, 23, 273812) Nor did I want or wish him to do so.
('30', 117, 2, 24, 273849) In my opinion, spinning is related to politics.
('30', 117, 2, 25, 273897) However, spinning can be undertaken even without political motives.
('30', 117, 2, 26, 273965) Compassion for the poor, the religious sentiment underlying spinning and its economic implications are acceptable to all.
('30', 117, 2, 27, 274087) I even wish that

('30', 129, 2, 3, 300040) NOT 25,000 Maulana Zafar Ali Khan 1 wires as follows:
('30', 129, 3, 4, 300094) On my return to Lahore I have seen it announced in local papers on authority of Young India that I promised you twenty five thousand spinning Muslim Congress workers by end of this year.
('30', 129, 3, 5, 300281) I am afraid there is a misunderstanding somewhere.
('30', 129, 3, 6, 300332) Perhaps my language was not sufficiently clear.
('30', 129, 3, 7, 300380) All I promised was that I would strain every nerve to place the services of ten thousand Muslim volunteers at your disposal before your term of office expires and I stick to this offer.
('30', 129, 3, 8, 300566) I gladly print this wire.
('30', 129, 3, 9, 300592) There was no misunderstanding, so far as I am concerned.
('30', 129, 3, 10, 300649) The offer was so striking that I warned the Maulana against being over sanguine.
('30', 129, 3, 11, 300730) He stuck to his guns.
('30', 129, 3, 12, 300752) The promise was too good to be withheld from the public.
('30', 129, 3, 13, 300809) But the offer was a free gift.
('30', 129, 3, 14, 300840) And no prudent man will look a gift horse in the mouth.
('30', 129, 3, 15, 300896) As things go even ten thousand volunteers is a good and encouraging number.
('30', 129, 3, 16, 300972) Let me remind Maulana Saheb that one must be a spinner to be a volunteer.
('30', 129, 3, 17, 301046) That is an old Delhi resolution stiffened at Ahmedabad Congress in 1921. I shall therefore be satisfied with ten thousand Mussalman volunteer spinners spinning every month two thousand yards of good yarn with clock work regularity.
('30', 129, 3, 18, 301278) I do not doubt that if the Maulana secures ten thousand spinners, he will have no difficulty about getting even twenty five thousand.

('30', 132, 2, 19, 308540) THEIR TWO VOWS

('30', 133, 3, 22, 311381) “RAMANAMA” It is easy enough to take a vow under a stimulating influence.

('30', 140, 1, 2, 325324) 72. SPEECH AT ALL PARTY CONFERENCE COMMITTEE MEETING, DELHI
('30', 140, 2, 3, 325384) January 23, 1925
('30', 140, 3, 4, 325401) The All Party Conference Committee convened 1 as the result of the discussions held at Bombay in November last met here last evening (Friday) at the Western Hostel, Raisina.
('30', 140, 3, 5, 325575) Mr. Gandhi presided.
('30', 140, 3, 6, 325596) A lively discussion took place on the proposal of Mr. Gandhi to appoint a sub committee to suggest lines of agreement between Hindus and Mussalmans and among all the political parties and also to draw up a scheme of swaraj.
('30', 140, 3, 7, 325820) Speeches were made by the representatives of the various communities and parties who explained their respective positions and the Conference eventually adjourned till Saturday afternoon.
('30', 140, 4, 8, 326007) The Conference was attended by a large number of members and also by several Indian members of the Central Legislature.
('30', 140, 5, 9, 326127) Mr. Gandhi explained that the objects of the Conference were to explore the avenues of communal and political unity and formulate a scheme of swaraj.
('30', 140, 5, 10, 326277) He suggested the appointment of a sub committee to suggest the lines of an agreement.
('30', 140, 6, 11, 326363) Mrs. Besant 2 thought it would be impertinent, nay, anarchical, on the part of the Conference suddenly to make new resolutions which might run counter to those passed by the Belgaum Congress and thereby unseat Mr. Gandhi from his presidentship.
('30', 140, 7, 12, 326608) Mr. Gandhi said his suggestion for a Committee did not go so far as Dr. Besant feared and that the suggestion was made to show that Congressmen were not hidebound to anything but the new franchise or the creed of the Congress.
('30', 140, 7, 13, 326835) Those could not be lightly altered merely because the proposed sub committee might come to certain conclusions.
('30', 140, 7, 14, 326947) The Congressmen knew their mind and they would prosecute their programme but if the non Congressmen joined the Congress and convinced them of the error of their ways and of the propriety of altering the creed or the franchise then they could undertake to call a special session of the Congress.
('30', 140, 7, 15, 327242) Personally he did not think any alteration was called for.
('30', 140, 8, 16, 327301) Mr. Gandhi, at the request of Mr. Dalvi, read the Liberal Federation’s reso lution that the Liberal Party would rejoin the Congress only, (1) if the object of the Congress, defined as Dominion Self government, was to be attained by constitutional methods; (2) If non co operation and civil disobedience were
('30', 140, 9, 17, 327609) 1 Vide “Speech at All Party Conference, Bombay”, November 21, 1924. 2 1847 1933; Leader of the Theosophical movement; founded the Home Rule League in 1916; President, Indian National Congress, 1917
('30', 141, 0, 1, 327807) 142 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 141, 1, 2, 327849) definitely abandoned as also the yarn franchise; and (3) if the Swaraj Party were not constituted as the only accredited representatives of the Congress in the legislatures.
('30', 141, 2, 3, 328023) Mr. Gandhi added that the suggestions from other political bodies were almost along the same lines.
('30', 141, 2, 4, 328123) The Bombay Chronicle, 26 1 1925
('30', 141, 3, 5, 328155) 73. DRAFT CONSTITUTION OF ALL INDIA COW PROTECTION SABHA 1
('30', 141, 4, 6, 328214) [January 24, 1925] 2
('30', 141, 5, 7, 328235) ALL INDIA COW PROTECTION SABHA
('30', 141, 6, 8, 328266) OBJECT Whereas the Hindus have failed in cow protection which is an obligation imposed on them by their religion, and whereas the cows in India and their progeny are deteriorating day by day: The All India Cow protection Sabha is formed for the proper fulfilment of the religious obligation of cow protection.
('30', 141, 6, 9, 328576) The object of the Sabha shall be to protect the cow and her progeny by all moral means.
('30', 141, 6, 10, 328664) “Cow protection” shall mean the protection of the cow and her progeny from cruelty and slaughter.
('30', 141, 6, 11, 328762) Note: It will be against the fundamental policy of the Sabha to bring physical force or pressure to bear on those communities whose religion does not prohibit, or regard as obligatory, cow slaughter.
('30', 141, 8, 12, 328962) The Sabha shall carry on its work by the following means:
('30', 141, 9, 13, 329020) 1. By pleading with those who may be ill treating cows, bullo cks, etc., and by carrying on propaganda against such ill treatment by means of leaflets, lectures, etc.; 2. By taking charge of diseased and disabled cows and oxen from their owners wherever the latter cannot afford to maintain them; 3. By superintending and inspecting the administration of
('30', 141, 10, 14, 329375) 1 Prepared by Gandhiji; vide Mahadev Desai’s :“Delhi Letter” in Navajivan, 8 2 1925. 2 Vide “All India Cow protection Sabha”, 15 3 1925 and “Cow protection”, 9 4 1925.
('30', 142, 0, 1, 329543) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 143
('30', 142, 1, 2, 329589) existing pinjarapoles 1 and cow protection institutions, and by helping in their better organization and management, as also by establishing fresh institutions; 4. By breeding model cows and draught cattle by means of cattle farms, etc., and by providing clean and cheap milk through properly kept dairies; 5. By opening tanneries for tanning hides of dead cattle and thereby stopping or reducing the export abroad of disabled cattle; 6. By enlisting men of character and education in the cause, and founding scholarships, etc., for training them in the work; 7. By holding an inquiry into the causes of the disappearance of grazing lands and into the advantages or disadvantages thereof; 8. By investigating into the necessity or otherwise of the practice of castrating bulls, and if found necessary and useful, investigating into the possibilities of discovering a harmless method of castration or a wholesome modification in the present method; 9. By collecting funds; and 10. By taking whatever other steps may be necessary for the work of cow protection.
('30', 142, 2, 3, 330649) MEMBERSHIP Any person of the age of eighteen years, who subscribes to the object of the Sabha, and 1. who pays to the Sabha an annual subscription of five rupees; or 2. who gives to the Sabha enough time and labour to enable him or her to spin and send 2,000 yards per month of even and well spun yarn to the Sabha; or 3. who devotes one hour daily to any work that may be prescribed by the Sabha shall be a member of the Sabha.
('30', 142, 2, 4, 331078) Note: In respect of (2), slivers, if necessary, will be supplied by the Sabha.
('30', 142, 3, 5, 331157) ADMINISTRATION The members of the Sabha shall annually elect their president by a majority vote and he shall nominate the secretary and the treasurer.
('30', 142, 4, 6, 331308) 1 Institutions for the care of disabled and useless cattle
('30', 143, 0, 1, 331367) 144 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 143, 1, 2, 331409) A Working Committee consisting of not less than five members of the Sabha shall be elected annually at a general meeting to be convened by the president.
('30', 143, 1, 3, 331563) The treasurer shall be responsible for the accounts of all the receipts and disbursements, all amounts exceeding one thousand rupees to be kept deposited in a bank of his approval.
('30', 143, 1, 4, 331744) Young India, 9 4 1925

('30', 148, 1, 9, 343228) Ordinarily a field is chosen as the site of the Conference.
('30', 148, 1, 10, 343288) Our artists looked around and chose a spot which was filled with natural beauty.
('30', 148, 1, 11, 343369) A river named Valmiki flows near Vedchhi.
('30', 148, 1, 12, 343411) It dances along between rows of hills adorned by trees.
('30', 148, 1, 13, 343467) The organizers of the Conference chose this spot.
('30', 148, 1, 14, 343517) The main rostrum was placed in the flowing water and, just as branches spring out of a tree, the seats for the delegates were arranged in front of the main rostrum.
('30', 148, 1, 15, 343682) As it was winter, and, moreover, as the water was cool, this artistic expert argued that not only did the delegates did not require any shade but the afternoon sun at 2.00 p.m.
('30', 148, 1, 16, 343859) would be welcome to them, hence the golden sky provided the dome of the pavilion and the river sand, the seats.

('30', 148, 1, 18, 344098) There is no mud on the river bank but only sand.

('30', 149, 1, 15, 346245) They themselves grow cotton.

('30', 149, 1, 18, 346381) If khadi is available at low price, they would certainly wear it.

('30', 149, 1, 20, 346549) Hence, the spinning wheel and the propaganda for khadi seem to be popular among these people.
('30', 149, 1, 21, 346643) A sixty year old peasant, even though he looks after his field, regularly spins till late at night and at dawn.
('30', 149, 1, 22, 346755) He had his own clothes made out of the yarn and he wishes to give what remains to his children.
('30', 149, 1, 23, 346851) In this manner the goal is for one family after another to spin and weave for themselves.

('30', 149, 1, 25, 347043) He saved Rs.10/ which was his annual expense on clothes.

('30', 154, 1, 2, 355072) Ordinance and inquired whether in view of Lord Lytton's speech 1 before the Bengal Council and the Viceroy's speech 2 in the Assembly he had altered his opinion.
('30', 154, 1, 3, 355234) Mahatma Gandhi said he had seen nothing to change his opinion.
('30', 154, 1, 4, 355297) On the contrary, he held that both the speeches were irrelevant to the issue before the nation, because he held that the powers taken under the Ordinance should not be granted except on an extraordinary occasion and then never without the sanction of the duly elected representatives of the people.
('30', 154, 1, 5, 355596) In matters where the questions of life and death were concerned and where the liberty of the subject was involved the opinions of functionaries, however highly placed they may be, were of no consequence.
('30', 154, 2, 6, 355800) In fact, Mahatma Gandhi went further and said: India had been used to such emphatic declarations before now.
('30', 154, 2, 7, 355909) Did not Sir M. O’Dwyer 3 and even Lord Chelmsford 4 practically swear that treason and conspiracy were rampant in the Punjab, and did not Sir M. O’Dwyer claim to be able to prove the existence of general rebellion in the Punjab?
('30', 154, 2, 8, 356138) We knew now that there was very little warrant for these statements.
('30', 154, 3, 9, 356207) Mahatma Gandhi, therefore, was glad that so far at any rate as the Ordinance was concerned Indian opinion was unanimous in condemnation and hoped that the agitation against it would grow in strength day after day such that it would become irresistible.
