('30', 155, 1, 2, 357972) 82. INTERROGATORIES ANSWERED
('30', 155, 2, 3, 358001) During last month I had a hearty discussion with an English friend who takes deep interest in matters Indian and who is anxious to serve India to the best of his ability.
('30', 155, 2, 4, 358172) He asked me whether I would publish the gist of our conversation.
('30', 155, 2, 5, 358238) I readily agreed but asked him to jot down the points he raised which he gladly did.
('30', 155, 2, 6, 358323) I do not disclose the friend’s name as the name does not matter.
('30', 155, 2, 7, 358388) It is my views that matter because they are exciting some interest at the present moment.
('30', 155, 2, 8, 358478) If I am a friend of Englishmen, as I claim to be, I must patiently answer all the doubts that may arise in their minds.
('30', 155, 2, 9, 358598) The English friend put the questions not all on his own behalf but mostly on behalf of those Englishmen who had originally raised them.
('30', 155, 3, 10, 358734) Here are the questions with answers.
('30', 155, 4, 11, 358771) What is the real purpose of your insistence upon the khaddar programme as a means of obtaining swaraj?
('30', 155, 4, 12, 358874) I am interested in the attainment of swaraj only by non violent and truthful means.
('30', 155, 4, 13, 358958) This is possible only through a diligent and successful prosecution of the khaddar programme.
('30', 155, 4, 14, 359052) Swaraj can be peacefully attained only if the whole Indian mass work as with one will, be it on ever so little a constructive and useful thing for ever so little a time.
('30', 155, 4, 15, 359222) Such an effort presupposes national consciousness.
('30', 155, 4, 16, 359273) This is possible only through the spinning wheel.
('30', 155, 4, 17, 359323) It is not remunerative enough for individuals.
('30', 155, 4, 18, 359370) It is therefore not enough incentive for an individual selfishly inclined.
('30', 155, 4, 19, 359445) It is however enough to raise at a bound the national prosperity in an appreciable manner.
('30', 155, 4, 20, 359536) An increase of one rupee per head per year may mean nothing to the individual.
('30', 155, 4, 21, 359615) But Rs. 5,000/ in a village containing a population of as many would mean the payment of land revenue or other dues.
('30', 155, 4, 22, 359732) Thus the spinning wheel means national consciousness and a contribution by every individual to a definite constructive national work.
('30', 155, 4, 23, 359866) If India can demonstrate her capacity for such an achievement by voluntary effort she is ready for political swaraj.
('30', 155, 4, 24, 359983) Any lawful demand of a nation with a will of its own must prove irresistible.
('30', 155, 4, 25, 360061) I have hitherto said nothing of the immense economic value of the wheel and its product khaddar.
('30', 155, 4, 26, 360158) For it is obvious.
('30', 155, 4, 27, 360177) The economic prosperity of India must indirectly affect the course of her political history—even using the word “political” in its narrow sense.
('30', 155, 4, 28, 360322) Lastly, when the exploitation of India by Lancashire ceases by reason of the ability of India through the wheel to clothe
('30', 156, 0, 1, 360444) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 157
('30', 156, 1, 2, 360490) herself and consequently to exclude foreign cloth and therefore also Lancashire cloth, England will have lost the feverish anxiety at any cost to hold India under subjection.
('30', 156, 2, 3, 360665) This means revolutionizing the national taste?
('30', 156, 2, 4, 360712) Do you expect to persuade your countrymen to give up the use of foreign cloth?
('30', 156, 2, 5, 360791) After all I am asking for very little.
('30', 156, 2, 6, 360830) Millions are indifferent as to what they wear.
('30', 156, 2, 7, 360877) They merely look to the cheapness of the articles they buy.
('30', 156, 2, 8, 360937) It is the middle class whose taste has to be revised.
('30', 156, 2, 9, 360991) I do not think that the substitution of foreign cloth by khaddar is an impos sible task for them.
('30', 156, 2, 10, 361089) Moreover it should be remembered that nowadays it is possible for khaddar to suit a large variety of tastes.
('30', 156, 2, 11, 361198) And improvement in fineness is making steady progress.
('30', 156, 2, 12, 361253) I am therefore of opinion that if any constructive work is capable of success, it is the khaddar programme.
('30', 156, 3, 13, 361361) What do you mean by swaraj and what are its limitations, if any?
('30', 156, 3, 14, 361426) By swaraj I mean the Government of India by the consent of the people ascertained by the vote of the largest number of the adult population, male or female, native born or domiciled who have contributed by manual labour to the service of the State and who have taken the trouble of having their names registered as voters.
('30', 156, 3, 15, 361749) This Government should be quite consistent with the British connection on absolutely honourable and equal terms.
('30', 156, 3, 16, 361862) Personally I have not despaired of the substitution for the present servile condition of equal partnership or association.
('30', 156, 3, 17, 361985) But I would not for one moment hesitate to countenance or bring about complete severance if it became necessary, i.e., if the connection impeded India's full growth.
('30', 156, 4, 18, 362151) To what extent are you committed to the programme and methods of the Swaraj Party?
('30', 156, 4, 19, 362234) I am personally committed neither to the programme nor to the methods of the Swaraj Party.
('30', 156, 4, 20, 362325) As a Congressman I recognize its undoubted influence in the country and therefore its right to represent the Congress—a right which it now enjoys by arrangement but which it otherwise might have secured by a party vote.
('30', 156, 5, 21, 362545) What are the relations between you and the leaders of that party?
('30', 156, 5, 22, 362611) They are of a most cordial character.
('30', 156, 5, 23, 362649) I give them the same credit for patriotic service and sacrifice that I would like to claim for myself.
('30', 156, 6, 24, 362752) It has been stated that you have surrendered to Mr. Das?
('30', 157, 0, 1, 362809) 158 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 157, 1, 2, 362851) The statment is true in the sense that I have avoided a quarrel among Congressmen.
('30', 157, 1, 3, 362934) But it is not true if it is intended to convey the meaning that I have surrendered an iota of my principles.
('30', 157, 2, 4, 363043) Was not your attitude on the Saha resolution 1 different from the one you have now adopted?
('30', 157, 2, 5, 363135) Not in the least.
('30', 157, 2, 6, 363153) At the time of the Saha resolution I was opposing an internal error.
('30', 157, 2, 7, 363222) At the present moment I am resisting external oppression based on erroneous assumptions.
('30', 157, 2, 8, 363311) Moreover, my attempt then to secure consistency of conduct and control of the Congress executive by one party must not be confused with my action on the Saha resolution.
('30', 157, 2, 9, 363481) The two things were totally different and were not even inter related.
('30', 157, 2, 10, 363552) As soon as I discovered that the attempt to secure unity of control led to bad blood, I retraced my steps and declared complete surrender to the Swaraj Party.
('30', 157, 3, 11, 363711) It has been stated that you have lost your moral authority by your surrender—?
('30', 157, 3, 12, 363790) Moral authority is never retained by any attempt to hold on to it.
('30', 157, 3, 13, 363857) It comes without seeking and is retained without effort.
('30', 157, 3, 14, 363914) I am not conscious of loss of moral authority, for I am utterly unconscious of being guilty of any single act compromising my moral conduct.
('30', 157, 3, 15, 364055) What I have undoubtedly lost is the intellectual co operation of a large number of educated men in my presentation of the means of attaining swaraj, e.
('30', 157, 3, 16, 364207) g., the spinning wheel.
('30', 157, 4, 17, 364231) Why do you insist upon non co operation while every one of the activities has failed?
('30', 157, 4, 18, 364317) What is the purpose in speaking of its suspension?
('30', 157, 4, 19, 364368) I do not insist now.
('30', 157, 4, 20, 364389) But I do not admit that every one of the activities has failed.
('30', 157, 4, 21, 364453) On the contrary, every activity of non co operation succeeded to an extent.
('30', 157, 4, 22, 364529) I can speak only of its suspension because to me non co operation is a vital principle of life and because in my opinion it had done India and, if you will, the world an amount of good of which, at present, we have not adequate conception and also because, if I found an atmosphere of substantial non violence and real co operation among the people and if the end remained still unattained, I should not hesitate to advise its resumption by the nation.
('30', 157, 5, 23, 364982) How do you propose to solve the Hindu Muslim problem?
('30', 157, 5, 24, 365036) By constantly insisting upon both the communities cultivating
('30', 157, 6, 25, 365098) 1 Passed by the Bengal Provincial Conference, paying homage to the “patriotism” of Gopinath Saha who had murdered Ernest Day; vide “Interview to The Times of India”, June 5, 1924.
('30', 158, 0, 1, 365278) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 159
('30', 158, 1, 2, 365324) mutual respect and trust and by insisting upon Hindus surrendering out of strength to the Mussalman in every mundane matter and by showing that those who claim to be nationalists and are in an overwhelming majority should stand out in any unseemly competition for legislative or administrative control.
('30', 158, 1, 3, 365627) I hope also to achieve the end by demonstrating that real swaraj will come not by the acquisition of authority by a few but by the acquisition of the capacity by all to resist authority when it is abused.
('30', 158, 1, 4, 365832) In other words; swaraj is to be attained by educating the masses to a sense of their capacity to regulate and control authority.
('30', 158, 2, 5, 365961) What is your own real attitude towards the English and your hope about England?
('30', 158, 2, 6, 366041) My attitude towards the English is one of utter friendliness and respect.
('30', 158, 2, 7, 366115) I claim to be their friend, because it is contrary to my nature to distrust a single human being or to believe that any nation on earth is incapable of redemption.
('30', 158, 2, 8, 366279) I have respect for Englishmen, because I recognise their bravery, their spirit of sacrifice for what they believe to be good for themselves, their cohesion and their powers of vast organization.
('30', 158, 2, 9, 366474) My hope about them is that they will at no distant date retrace their steps, revise their policy of exploitation of undisciplined and ill organized races and give tangible proof that India is an equal friend and partner in the British Commonwealth to come.
('30', 158, 2, 10, 366731) Whether such as event will ever come to pass will largely depend upon our own conduct.
('30', 158, 2, 11, 366818) That is to say I have hope of England because I have hope of India.
('30', 158, 2, 12, 366886) We will not for ever remain disorganised and imitative.
('30', 158, 2, 13, 366942) Beneath the present disorganization, demoralization and lack of initiative I can discover organization, moral strength and initiative forming themselves.
('30', 158, 2, 14, 367096) A time is coming when England will be glad of India’s friendship and India will disdain to reject the proffered hand because it has once despoiled her.
('30', 158, 2, 15, 367248) I know that I have nothing to offer in proof of my hope.
('30', 158, 2, 16, 367305) It is based on an immutable faith.
('30', 158, 2, 17, 367340) And it is a poor faith that is based on proof commonly [so] called.

('30', 159, 1, 2, 367473) 83. NOTES
('30', 159, 2, 3, 367483) HOW NOT TO DO IT
('30', 159, 3, 4, 367500) Jamiet al Tabligh Islam has favoured me with the following translation of a resolution recently passed by it:
('30', 159, 4, 5, 367610) Resolved that the responsibility for the entire series of deplorable events which took place during the recent disturbances at Kohat 1 and which resulted in great loss of life and property to the residents of that place, lies with the person or persons who published at Kohat the offensive and provoking pamphlet which contained vile attacks on Islam and deeply wounded the religious feelings of Mussalmans.
('30', 159, 4, 6, 368018) The Hindus who fired shots and killed Mussalmans are also responsible for aggravating the delicate situation still further.
('30', 159, 4, 7, 368142) This Jamiet expresses sympathy with all those residents of Kohat, irrespective of creed and caste, who suffered loss of life or property in the course of these disturbances.
('30', 159, 4, 8, 368316) As a religious society, this Jamiet feels bound to point out to Mahatma Gandhi and other political leaders that unless scurrilous attacks, in writing or by speech, on religion and founders and leaders of religious movements are absolutely stopped, the creation and maintenance of Hindu Muslim unity in India will always be found impossible.
('30', 159, 4, 9, 368657) I am unable to congratulate the Jamiet on its resolution.
('30', 159, 4, 10, 368715) It seems that both the parties have made up their minds on the main fact although no impartial inquiry has yet been held.
('30', 159, 4, 11, 368837) Is it an established fact that the responsibility for “the entire series of deplorable events” lies with “the person or persons who published at Kohat the offensive and provoking pamphlet”?
('30', 159, 4, 12, 369027) Is it also an established fact that “the Hindus who fired shots and killed Mussalmans are also responsible for aggravating the delicate situation still further”?
('30', 159, 4, 13, 369189) If the two facts above mentioned are clearly established the Hindus at least are not entitled to any sympathy which the Jamiet shows for the loss in life and property suffered by them.
('30', 159, 4, 14, 369374) For they have reaped what they have sown.
('30', 159, 4, 15, 369416) The Jamiet is therefore inconsistent in showing sympathy to the Hindus.
('30', 159, 4, 16, 369488) And what is the point in the Jamiet telling me and other political leaders that “unless scurrilous attacks on religion and founders of religious movements are absolutely stopped the creation and
('30', 159, 5, 17, 369683) 1 As a result of strained relations between the Hindu and the Mussalman communities, riots had broken out on the 9th and 10th September, 1924, in the city of Kohat in the North West Frontier Province.
('30', 160, 0, 1, 369884) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 161
('30', 160, 1, 2, 369930) maintenance of Hindu Muslim unity in India will always be found impossible”?
('30', 160, 1, 3, 370007) If what the Jamiet contends is true, is not the impos sibility of unity a fact for the Jamiet to note as well as the political leaders?
('30', 160, 1, 4, 370143) And must Hindu Muslim unity be impossible because some person delivers attacks on religion?
('30', 160, 1, 5, 370235) According to the Jamiet one insane Hindu or one insane Mussalman is enough to make Hindu Muslim unity impossible.
('30', 160, 1, 6, 370349) Fortunately Hindu Muslim unity does not finally depend upon religious or political leaders.
('30', 160, 1, 7, 370441) It depends upon the enlightened selfishness of the masses belonging to both the communities.
('30', 160, 1, 8, 370534) They cannot be misled for all time.
('30', 160, 1, 9, 370570) But I hope that the original resolution of the Jamiet does not read as bad as the translation before me.
('30', 160, 2, 10, 370675) IAN AZL I USSAIN 1
('30', 160, 3, 11, 370694) A correspondent asks me to give my impressions of the interview I had with Mian Fazl i Hussain during my last visit to Lahore.
('30', 160, 3, 12, 370821) I gladly comply.
('30', 160, 3, 13, 370838) I had a very pleasant time with the Mian Saheb.
('30', 160, 3, 14, 370886) His manners were most charming.
('30', 160, 3, 15, 370918) He was reasonable and plausible in his conversation.
('30', 160, 3, 16, 370971) He protested against the charge of partiality brought against him by Hindus.
('30', 160, 3, 17, 371048) He said that he was trying to do tardy justice and that too in an incomplete manner to the Mussalmans.
('30', 160, 3, 18, 371151) He was accessible to all and was anxious to explain his own position to anybody who cared to study the question.
('30', 160, 3, 19, 371264) More than this, no man had a right to expect.
('30', 160, 3, 20, 371310) Whether as a matter of fact there is anything to be said against the Mian Saheb’s policy, I do not know.
('30', 160, 3, 21, 371415) I have not been able to study the question on either side.
('30', 160, 3, 22, 371474) When I am able to do so I shall gladly publish my opinion of Mian Fazl i Hussain’s claim that he has done less than justice to the Mussalmans.
('30', 160, 3, 23, 371617) Sufficient in the meantime for me to feel that in Mian Fazl i Hussain one has a gentleman, calm, cool, dignified and reasonable to deal with.
('30', 160, 4, 24, 371759) UR ELPLESSNESS
('30', 160, 5, 25, 371774) Orders are pouring in at the Ashram at Sabarmati for spin ning wheels, spindles, slivers, etc.
('30', 160, 5, 26, 371869) If we were well organized, such helplessness should be impossible.
('30', 160, 5, 27, 371936) Time was when every village carpenter could make a spinning wheel.
('30', 160, 5, 28, 372003) Today city carpenters often do not know what a spinning wheel is like, and they equally often refuse to make one from a model.
('30', 160, 5, 29, 372130) Similarly, whereas formerly every carder knew how to make slivers, today they shrug their shoulders or
('30', 160, 6, 30, 372233) 1 A Muslim leader; member of the Viceroy’s Executive Council
('30', 161, 0, 1, 372294) 162 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 161, 1, 2, 372336) want to charge exorbitant prices.
('30', 161, 1, 3, 372370) But the success of hand spinning depends upon our resourcefulness and upon the co operation of the artisans of India.
('30', 161, 1, 4, 372488) No single institution can meet the growing demand for the wheel and its accessories.
('30', 161, 1, 5, 372573) Fortunately things are improving but not as fast as they ought.
('30', 161, 1, 6, 372637) Those who are in need should make a desperate effort to get these things made in their own cities or districts before ordering things from the Ashram.
('30', 161, 1, 7, 372788) No doubt it is better to get them even from the Ashram than wait for an indefinite period of time for them.
('30', 161, 1, 8, 372896) So far as slivers are concerned, I agree with Mr. K. Santhanam 1 who showed in his admirable essay that every spinner should make his own slivers.
('30', 161, 1, 9, 373043) Carding with a small bow is an incredibly simple and easy performance.
('30', 161, 1, 10, 373114) It is learnt much more quickly than spinning.
('30', 161, 1, 11, 373160) And good carding invariably adds to the output of yarn and facilitates its evenness.
('30', 161, 1, 12, 373245) For those who spin for wages carding adds to their earnings.
('30', 161, 1, 13, 373306) There are carders all over India who can make a full living out of carding.
('30', 161, 1, 14, 373382) A good carder can earn twelve annas per day— not so a good spinner.
('30', 161, 1, 15, 373450) Every Congress Committee worth the name must have a depot for making and supplying wheels and the accessories.
('30', 161, 2, 16, 373561) N ASE F ISAPPROPRIATION An Andhra friend writes:
('30', 161, 3, 17, 373610) Many people are taking undue advantage and not paying the amounts due to Congress Committees and Khaddar Boards knowing it for certain that they would not proceed against them in British courts.
('30', 161, 3, 18, 373805) This of course amounts to misappropriation and cheating if not worse.
('30', 161, 3, 19, 373875) In view of what you have written already regarding misappropriation of funds, and now the removal of ban on courts, I am quite sure that the Congress Committees can proceed in courts under these circumstances.
('30', 161, 3, 20, 374085) I have already given my opinion in such cases.
('30', 161, 3, 21, 374132) I have no doubt that even when the boycott of courts was on foot it was the duty of Congress Committees to proceed against fraudulent and defaulting debtors.
('30', 161, 3, 22, 374290) The boycott was not meant for the Congress to commit suicide.
('30', 161, 3, 23, 374352) It presupposed honesty on the part of those who dealt with the Congress.
('30', 161, 4, 24, 374425) A. I. K. B.’ ESOLUTIONS I invite the attention of all concerned to the following
('30', 161, 5, 25, 374506) 1895; Lawyer, journalist and politician; then Secretary, Tamil Nad Congress Khaddar Board
('30', 162, 0, 1, 374596) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 163
('30', 162, 1, 2, 374642) resolutions of the A.I.K.B. regarding the working of the Congress Franchise:
('30', 162, 2, 3, 374719) In view of the Congress having made hand spinning part of the franchise and in order to enable the provincial Committees to receive facilities in the matter, the All India Khadi Board resolves that it will be prepared to give the following assistance directly as well as through the Provincial Khadi Boards.
('30', 162, 3, 4, 375027) 1. The Board will be prepared to supply cotton to any province where cotton is not easily available.
('30', 162, 4, 5, 375128) 2. The Board will be prepared to consider applications for cotton loans on terms to be arranged.
('30', 162, 5, 6, 375225) 3. This Board advises the Provincial Khadi Boards to render every possible assistance to enable members to get models for making good charkhas and carding bows and supply all necessary accessories as also to assist in the matter of getting carded slivers until members make their own arrangements.
('30', 162, 6, 7, 375523) 4. The Board will, so far as possible, arrange for experts to give the necessary tuition in carding, spinning, etc., under arrangements to be made with the Board.
('30', 162, 7, 8, 375686) 5. The Board will be prepared to buy yarn from any provincial Congress Committee at bazaar rates or to get it woven for the Committees.
('30', 162, 8, 9, 375822) 6. The Board will be prepared, if so desired, to supply hand spun yarn at reasonable rates in connection with the yarn required for satisfying the franchise.
('30', 162, 9, 10, 375980) 7. The Board warns individuals and committees against buying hand spun yarn from the bazaar for the purpose of the yarn franchise as the bazaar yarn is likely to be mill yarn or spun from mill slivers and not to be even and well twisted.
('30', 162, 9, 11, 376218) (It is possible only for experts to distinguish between mill spun and hand spun yarn or to say when yarn is well twisted; even experts will be unable to say when hand spun yarn is spun from mill made slivers.)
('30', 162, 10, 12, 376428) 8. Lastly, the Board will be prepared to give any further information or help to individuals or committees which it is in its power to give.
('30', 162, 10, 13, 376569) Time is running against us.
('30', 162, 10, 14, 376597) I hope therefore that the Provincial Committees are organizing themselves under the new franchise.
('30', 162, 10, 15, 376696) Prop erly worked, its possibilities are immense.
('30', 162, 10, 16, 376745) But the working requires attention to the minutest details.
('30', 162, 10, 17, 376805) And when once the organization is in working order, it must grow from day to day in geometrical progr ession and make the Congress a self supporting, wealth producing institution.

('30', 164, 10, 20, 379178) 87. A SHAME
('30', 164, 11, 21, 379190) A friend from Tanganyika writes: 1
('30', 164, 12, 22, 379225) It is likely that the picture is completely true.
('30', 164, 12, 23, 379275) I have personally observed such things happening in the Portuguese territory, i.e., in Delagoa Bay.
('30', 164, 12, 24, 379375) The Muslims there have opened an orphanage for their children and thus made some provision for them.
('30', 164, 12, 25, 379476) Hindus hand over their children to the care of Muslims.
('30', 164, 12, 26, 379532) All these children are brought up as Muslims.
('30', 164, 12, 27, 379578) This is one way out.
('30', 164, 12, 28, 379599) I, however, do not approve of this
('30', 164, 13, 29, 379634) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('30', 164, 13, 30, 379671) The correspondent has described the plight of children born to Negro women secretly married to Hindus who afterwards abandoned them and left for India.
('30', 165, 0, 1, 379823) 166 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 165, 1, 2, 379865) solution.
('30', 165, 1, 3, 379875) To my mind, the action of both deserves condemnation.
('30', 165, 1, 4, 379929) In the first place, it is wrong to treat a union of this kind as a marriage.
('30', 165, 1, 5, 380006) I, for one, regard it merely as a means of sensual gratification.
('30', 165, 1, 6, 380072) Moral restrictions tend to become lax in a foreign country, since the fear of social opinion disappears.
('30', 165, 1, 7, 380177) But there is a difference of degree between the guilt of the two parties.
('30', 165, 1, 8, 380251) The Muslims accept and rear the children of love and bring them up in their faith.
('30', 165, 1, 9, 380334) If the provision made by the Muslims were not available for the children of the Hindus, the latter would simply starve to death.
('30', 165, 1, 10, 380463) Since the children are the fruit of mere sensual gratification, their Hindu fathers do not care in what religious faith they are brought up.
('30', 165, 1, 11, 380604) In my view, a man so blinded by lust has forsaken his religion.
('30', 165, 1, 12, 380668) It is difficult for me to regard anyone who obeys no moral principle in his conduct to be a religious man.
('30', 165, 1, 13, 380775) For purposes of census persons born into a certain religion may be regarded as belonging to that religion, but really speaking they have renounced religion.
('30', 165, 1, 14, 380932) There is nothing apart from conduct which may be defined as religion.
('30', 165, 1, 15, 381002) It is not the one who repeats the Gayatri mantra 1 every day or studies the Vedas that truly belongs to the Vedic religion, but the one who lives according to the teachings of the Vedas is a true follower of the Vedic religion.
('30', 165, 1, 16, 381230) Some Christians make a deep study of the Vedas and other scriptures, but that along does not render them true followers of the Vedic religion.
('30', 165, 1, 17, 381373) In other words, those who recite the Gayatri and other mantras hypocritically or because they are ruled by superstition, are not followers of the Vedas.
('30', 165, 1, 18, 381526) Their claim of belonging to any religion can be accepted only if they understand the teachings of that religion and follow them in practice to the best of their ability.
('30', 165, 1, 19, 381696) Judged from this point of view, the Hindus of Tanganyika should be considered to have forsaken their religion.
('30', 165, 1, 20, 381807) This is only an abstract solution.
('30', 165, 1, 21, 381842) In practice, these Hindu or Muslim fathers are regarded as Hindus or Muslims, as the case may be, and so we should find a solution which will work in practice.
('30', 165, 1, 22, 382002) The Hindu fathers should convert such union into regular marriage and take their children under their loving care and make necessary provision for their education, etc.
('30', 165, 1, 23, 382171) This is a solution to the problem of the children already born.
('30', 165, 1, 24, 382235) In future, however, everyone intending to go and live in a foreign country should take his family along with him.
('30', 165, 1, 25, 382349) For those children, however, whose fathers are altogether heartless, there is no other solution except opening orphanages.
('30', 165, 2, 26, 382472) 1 Prayer to sun god
('30', 166, 0, 1, 382492) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 167
('30', 166, 1, 2, 382538) orphanages should best be opened in the countries in question.
('30', 166, 1, 3, 382601) We may assume that the mothers of the children will stay with them in the orphanages.
('30', 166, 1, 4, 382687) These mothers had sacrificed themselves to earn their livelihood.
('30', 166, 1, 5, 382753) They are, however, not aware of the sinful aspect of their conduct.
('30', 166, 1, 6, 382821) For, though Negroes have the institution of marriage among them, it is not considered immoral for a woman to offer her body for money.
('30', 166, 1, 7, 382956) Such women, nevertheless, do feel the mother’s love in their heart.
('30', 166, 1, 8, 383024) We should tend it and encourage them to do their duty as mothers.
('30', 166, 1, 9, 383090) In these pitiable cases, the child’s mother tongue is different from its father tongue.
('30', 166, 1, 10, 383178) Which language should it be taught?
('30', 166, 1, 11, 383214) The father generally feels little attachment for his children born in this manner and so the latter learn the mother’s language.
('30', 166, 1, 12, 383343) Hence, those in charge of the orphanages should teach these children their mother tongue.
('30', 166, 1, 13, 383433) If they are taught both the [father’s and the mother’s] languages, they will be better equipped to earn their livelihood in future.
('30', 166, 1, 14, 383565) The problem of their religion is more intriguing.
('30', 166, 1, 15, 383615) It does not arise, as we have seen, as far as the Muslim fathers are concerned.
('30', 166, 1, 16, 383695) But it is the general rule that the children of a Hindu father should be treated as Hindus.
('30', 166, 1, 17, 383787) I have no doubt in my mind that, following this rule, the children of Hindu fathers should receive instruction in Hindu religion.
('30', 166, 1, 18, 383917) The children themselves are helpless in this matter.
('30', 166, 1, 19, 383970) They will assimilate the atmosphere in the orphanages where they are brought up.
('30', 166, 1, 20, 384051) If these are run by men imbued with a religious spirit, they can instil it in the children.
('30', 166, 1, 21, 384143) I hope that the Hindus living in Tanganyika and such other territories will think and consider what their duty is, and do it.
('30', 166, 1, 22, 384269) Their first duty is to overcome their lust.
('30', 166, 1, 23, 384313) This refers to the future.
('30', 166, 1, 24, 384340) To bring up properly the children already born, to provide for their religious instruction and in every way to do their duty as fathers—this is their duty at all times.
('30', 166, 1, 25, 384509) Those who can should take their wives with them.
('30', 166, 1, 26, 384558) A man should judge a woman’s condition by his own.
('30', 166, 1, 27, 384609) If a man cannot endure separation for a long time, neither can a woman.
('30', 166, 1, 28, 384681) That men and women married at a proper age should not remain separated for a long time needs no proof.
('30', 166, 1, 29, 384784) In not remaining so lies the guarantee of the purity of their character.
('30', 166, 1, 30, 384857) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 1 2 1925
('30', 167, 0, 1, 384893) 168 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 167, 1, 2, 384935) 88. MY NOTES
('30', 167, 2, 3, 384948) WORTHY OF EMULATION I reproduce the following relevant extract from a reader's letter from Palitana: 1
('30', 167, 3, 4, 385051) What a great advance in reform can be brought about if other [public] servants emulate this example!
('30', 167, 3, 5, 385152) Through such work one serves both the Ruler and the people, and one’s own interest as well.
('30', 167, 3, 6, 385244) This couple will, by and by, have all their cotton and woollen garments made from yarn and wool spun by themselves.
('30', 167, 3, 7, 385360) We have noted that among the Kaliparaj tribals the annual expenditure on clothes amounts to Rs. 10 for every person.
('30', 167, 3, 8, 385477) The expenditure in the family of this correspondent must be even higher.
('30', 167, 3, 9, 385550) He will save considerably on that expenditure and, in the bargain, will have acquired a skill, earned the blessings of the poor and learnt something about the varieties of cotton and wool and how to improve their quality.
('30', 167, 3, 10, 385772) At this time when spinning and allied activities are making good progress in Kathiawar, I wish that officials of all grades who come into frequent contacts with the public in the course of their work should teach the people, as this correspondent does, to spin and do other work relating to khadi.
('30', 167, 3, 11, 386070) This friend wants a portable spinning wheel which can be carried on horse back.
('30', 167, 3, 12, 386150) Others, too, are likely to ask for such a wheel.
('30', 167, 3, 13, 386199) But the right solution is that people in every village should have spinning wheels in their homes.
('30', 167, 3, 14, 386298) Whether in Kathiawar or elsewhere, there ought to be no village without at least one spinning wheel.
('30', 167, 3, 15, 386399) If in a village there is none, arrangements must be made to instal them, so that officials can borrow them and do their spinning.
('30', 167, 3, 16, 386529) If all the people take up spinning, there should be in the central meeting place in every village two or three spinning wheels which may be used by the patels 2 as also by the poor people and the officials on their visits.
('30', 167, 3, 17, 386752) Meanwhile, however, the idea of having a portable spinning wheel which can be carried on horse back is an excellent one.
('30', 167, 4, 18, 386873) KHADI STORE
('30', 167, 5, 19, 386885) I frequently receive letters about the closure of the khadi store
('30', 167, 6, 20, 386951) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('30', 167, 6, 21, 386988) The correspondent, who was an employee in the Palitana State service, had said that he and his wife devoted their spare time to spinning cotton and wool and that the State authorities, far from objecting to his activities, encouraged him.
('30', 167, 6, 22, 387227) 2 Village headmen
('30', 168, 0, 1, 387245) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 169
('30', 168, 1, 2, 387291) run by the Gujarat Provincial Congress Committee.
('30', 168, 1, 3, 387341) One such letter is lying before me just now.
('30', 168, 1, 4, 387386) I notice from it that there is some misunderstanding about this matter.
('30', 168, 1, 5, 387458) I have never advised that the Provincial Committee should run no khadi store.
('30', 168, 1, 6, 387536) What indeed I have suggested is that a khadi store which runs at a great loss or in which the loss is increasing, instead of diminishing, should be closed down, and that buying khadi for a store from outside Gujarat should be stopped.
('30', 168, 1, 7, 387771) This advice is inspired by nothing else but a careful calculation and some knowledge of economics.
('30', 168, 1, 8, 387870) I cannot, even in my dream, wish ill of other provinces and well to Gujarat.
('30', 168, 1, 9, 387947) It is, however, of the very essence of the principle of swadeshi that one should serve one’s neighbours first.
('30', 168, 1, 10, 388058) This principle is violated when wheat from the south is preferred to the wheat produced in Gujarat and the procedure, therefore, is detrimental to Gujarat, to the south and to the whole country.
('30', 168, 1, 11, 388253) The philosophy of khadi had its origin in this principle.
('30', 168, 1, 12, 388311) Let us now examine the aims we hope to serve through khadi.
('30', 168, 1, 13, 388371) The first is that it will revive Indian villages.
('30', 168, 1, 14, 388421) This can happen only when every village produces its own khadi.
('30', 168, 1, 15, 388485) This in its turn is possible only if every province produces its own khadi and uses what it produces.
('30', 168, 1, 16, 388587) The second aim behind khadi is to bring about a boycott of foreign cloth through it.
('30', 168, 1, 17, 388672) This can be achieved only if India manufactures all the cloth its population requires.
('30', 168, 1, 18, 388759) If Indians demand cloth similar to the foreign product, India cannot meet that demand.
('30', 168, 1, 19, 388846) Indians, therefore, should accustom themselves to wear, with pleasure, such cloth as the country produces.
('30', 168, 1, 20, 388953) If all the people insist on wearing only khadi manufactured in Andhra, Andhra cannot meet all that demand and the boycott of foreign cloth can never be achieved.
('30', 168, 1, 21, 389115) Every province, therefore, should try to produce fine khadi.
('30', 168, 1, 22, 389176) For the same reason, every province should produce its own khadi.
('30', 168, 1, 23, 389242) As a general rule it is observed that, so long as there is no demand for a commodity, no effort is made to produce it.
('30', 168, 1, 24, 389361) This certainly does not mean that no one should wear or order Andhra khadi.
('30', 168, 1, 25, 389437) My only point is that the Congress at any rate should always adopt the ideal course.
('30', 168, 1, 26, 389522) If it wishes, the public will adopt the second best course.
('30', 168, 1, 27, 389582) If, because the ideal course is difficult, even the Congress does not adopt it, no one else is likely to do, and without such efforts success is impossible.
('30', 168, 1, 28, 389739) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 1 2 1925
('30', 169, 0, 1, 389775) 170 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 169, 1, 2, 389817) 89. SHORTAGE OF SPINNING WHEELS
('30', 169, 2, 3, 389849) I notice that spinning has now spread considerably and, in consequence, there is a great demand for supply of spinning wheels by the Ashram.
('30', 169, 2, 4, 389990) The latter cannot provide all the spinning wheels demanded.
('30', 169, 2, 5, 390050) Nor can the movement progress in this manner.
('30', 169, 2, 6, 390096) Each province, each district, each taluk and, finally, each village should be able to boast of a carpenter who can make spinning wheels.
('30', 169, 2, 7, 390233) The spindle holders are now made of string or coir.
('30', 169, 2, 8, 390285) The benefits of the spinning wheel movement are not confined to the spinners and weavers.
('30', 169, 2, 9, 390375) It provides work to carpenters and blacksmiths, too.
('30', 169, 2, 10, 390428) There will be no section of society which will not share in the benefits.
('30', 169, 3, 11, 390502) NEED FOR VOLUNTEERS It is but natural that at this time when a determined effort is made to spread the khadi movement in Maha Gujarat we should require a large number of volunteers.
('30', 169, 3, 12, 390684) We need both part time volunteers and full time volunteers.
('30', 169, 3, 13, 390744) It is essential that every volunteer should know all the processes connected with spinning.
('30', 169, 3, 14, 390836) Any persons who wish to offer their services as such volunteers may send their names to me, so that as and when the need arises their services may be utilized.
('30', 169, 3, 15, 390996) This request for names is not addressed to those who are already working some where or other.
('30', 169, 3, 16, 391090) I invite, however, the names of persons who are able and willing to serve but who have had no opportunity till now.
('30', 169, 3, 17, 391206) Those who send their names should also give particulars of their age, aptitude for work, etc.

('30', 172, 6, 13, 394409) 95. PERTINENT QUESTIONS
('30', 172, 7, 14, 394433) I printed sometime ago a thoughtful letter 3 from Bengal on the question of untouchability.
('30', 172, 7, 15, 394525) The writer is still pursuing his diligent search.
('30', 172, 7, 16, 394575) Now I have a similar search from a Madras correspondent in the form of questions.
('30', 172, 7, 17, 394657) It is a healthy sign that the orthodox Hindus are moved to an inquiry into this thorny question.
('30', 172, 7, 18, 394754) There is no denying the earnestness of the framer of the questions.
('30', 172, 7, 19, 394822) They are typical because there is hardly one among the long list that has not been put to me in my rambles.
('30', 172, 7, 20, 394930) In the hope, therefore, that my answers may guide the path of the correspondent who claims to be a worker and an earnest seeker, and such other workers and seekers, I make an attempt to solve the many riddles presented by my correspondent.
('30', 172, 8, 21, 395170) 1. What are the practical steps to be taken to remove untouchability?
('30', 172, 8, 22, 395240) (a) To open to untouchables all public schools, temples and roads that are open to non Brahmins and are not exclusively devoted to any particular caste.
('30', 172, 8, 23, 395393) (b) For caste Hindus to open schools for their children, to dig wells
('30', 172, 9, 24, 395463) 1 The postmark bears the date February 6, 1925, in which year Maha Sud 11 corresponded to February 4. 2 Vithalbhai Patel 3 Vide “Can Untouchability be Defended?”, December 5, 1924.
('30', 173, 0, 1, 395644) 174 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 173, 1, 2, 395686) for them where they are in need and to render them all personal service that they may need, e.g., to carry on temperance and hygienic reform among them and to provide them with medical aid.
('30', 173, 2, 3, 395876) 2. What would be the religious status of the untouchables when the ban of untouchability is completely removed?
('30', 173, 2, 4, 395988) The religious status would be the same as that of the caste Hindus.
('30', 173, 2, 5, 396056) They will therefore be classed as Sudras instead of Atisudras.
('30', 173, 3, 6, 396119) 3. What would be the relation between the untouchable and the high caste orthodox, Brahmin, when untouchability is removed?
('30', 173, 3, 7, 396243) The same as with non Brahmin Hindus.
('30', 173, 4, 8, 396280) 4. Do you advocate inter mingling of castes?
('30', 173, 4, 9, 396325) I would abolish all castes and would keep the four divisions.
('30', 173, 5, 10, 396387) 5. Why should not the untouchables build temples for their own worship, without interfering with the existing temples?
('30', 173, 5, 11, 396506) The “higher” castes have not left them much capacity for such enterprise.
('30', 173, 5, 12, 396580) It is the wrong way of looking at the question to say that they interfere with our temples.
('30', 173, 5, 13, 396672) We, the so called higher caste men, have to do our duty by admitting them to the temples common to all Hindus.
('30', 173, 6, 14, 396783) 6. Are you an advocate of communal representation, and do you hold that the untouchables must have representation in all administrative bodies?
('30', 173, 6, 15, 396927) I am not.
('30', 173, 6, 16, 396937) But if the untouchables are purposely shut out by the influential classes, it would be an improper exclusion barring the road to swaraj.
('30', 173, 6, 17, 397074) My disapproval of communal representation does not mean exclusion of any community from representation but, on the contrary, it lays the burden on the represented communities to see to the proper representation of the unrepresented or inadequately represented communities.
('30', 173, 7, 18, 397347) 7. Are you a believer in the efficacy of varnashrama dharma?
('30', 173, 7, 19, 397408) But there is today a travesty of varna, no trace of ashram and a misrepresentation of dharma.
('30', 173, 7, 20, 397502) The whole system needs to be revised and brought in unison with the latest discoveries in the field of religion.
('30', 173, 8, 21, 397615) 8. Don’t you believe that India is Karmabhumi, and that everybody born here is endowed with wealth and intelligence, social status and religious aspirations
('30', 173, 9, 22, 397772) 1 Antyajas
('30', 174, 0, 1, 397783) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 175
('30', 174, 1, 2, 397829) according to his good or ill deeds in his previous birth?
('30', 174, 1, 3, 397887) Not in the sense the correspondent means.
('30', 174, 1, 4, 397929) For everybody everywhere reaps as he sows.
('30', 174, 1, 5, 397972) But India is essentially karmabhumi (land of duty) in contradistinction to bhogabhumi (land of enjoyment).
('30', 174, 2, 6, 398079) 9. Is not education and reform among the untouchables a primary condition to be fulfilled are one can begin to talk of the removal of untouchability?
('30', 174, 2, 7, 398229) There can be no reform or education among the untouchables without the removal of untouchability.
('30', 174, 3, 8, 398327) 10. Is it not natural, and just as it should be, that non drunkards avoid drunkards, and that vegetarians avoid non vegetarians?
('30', 174, 3, 9, 398456) Not necessarily.
('30', 174, 3, 10, 398473) A teetotaller would regard it as his duty to associate with his drunkard brother for the purpose of weaning him from the evil habit.
('30', 174, 3, 11, 398606) So may a vegetarian seek out a non vegetarian.
('30', 174, 4, 12, 398653) 11. Is it not true that a pure man (in the sense that he is a teetotaller, and vegetarian) easily becomes an impure man (in the sense that he becomes a drunkard, and non vegetarian) when he is made to single with men who drink, and kill, and eat animals?
('30', 174, 4, 13, 398908) A man who being unconscious of the wrong, drinks wine and eats flesh foods, is not necessarily an impure man.
('30', 174, 4, 14, 399018) But I can understand the possibility of evil resulting from one being made to mingle with a corrupt person.
('30', 174, 4, 15, 399126) In our case, however, there is no case of making anyone associate with untouchables.
('30', 174, 5, 16, 399211) 12. Is it not owing to the above fact that a certain class of orthodox Brahmins do not mingle with the other castes (including the untouchables), but constitute themselves into a separate class, and live together or their spiritual uplift?
('30', 174, 5, 17, 399451) It must be a poor spirituality that requires to be locked up in a safe.
('30', 174, 5, 18, 399523) Moreover, days are gone when men used to guard their virtue by permanent isolation.
('30', 174, 6, 19, 399607) 13. Would you not be interfering with the religions and caste system (varnashrama dharma) of India, whatever may be the bad or good points of the above systems and religions, if you advocate the removal of untouchability?
('30', 174, 6, 20, 399829) How do I interfere with anything or anybody by mere advocacy of a reform?
('30', 174, 6, 21, 399903) Interference there would be, if I were to advocate removal of untouchability by the use of force against those who retain untouchability.
('30', 174, 7, 22, 400041) 14. Would you not be guilty of doing himsa 1 to the orthodox Brahmins, if you
('30', 174, 8, 23, 400119) 1 Violence
('30', 175, 0, 1, 400130) 176 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 175, 1, 2, 400172) interefere with their religious beliefs without convincing them in the first instance?
('30', 175, 1, 3, 400259) I cannot be guilty of himsa to the orthodox Brahmins as I do not interfere with their religious belief except through conviction.
('30', 175, 2, 4, 400389) 15. Are not the Brahmins guilty of untouchability, when they do not touch, dine with or marry the various other castes leaving along the untouchables?
('30', 175, 2, 5, 400540) Brahmins are guilty of the sin if they refuse to “touch” the other castes.
('30', 175, 3, 6, 400615) 16. Does it satisfy the hunger of the untouchable when he is made to parade Brahmin agraharams 1 in the exercise of his right as a man?
('30', 175, 3, 7, 400751) Man does not live by bread alone.
('30', 175, 3, 8, 400785) Many prefer self respect to food.
('30', 175, 4, 9, 400819) 17. Does not satyagraha in this direction lead to violence, seeing that the untouchables are not so well educated as to understand the full doctrine of non violence non co operation, and also seeing that the Brahmin cares more for his religion than or politics?
('30', 175, 4, 10, 401081) If reference is to Vykom, experience shows that the “untouch able” has shown amazing self restraint.
('30', 175, 4, 11, 401182) The latter part of the question suggests the possibility of violence by the Brahmins concerned.
('30', 175, 4, 12, 401278) I should be sorry if they resort to violence.
('30', 175, 4, 13, 401324) They would then have shown, in my opinion, not regard for religion but ignorance of and contempt for religion.
('30', 175, 5, 14, 401435) 18. Do you advocate that all should become equal, without any distinction of caste, race, creed or avocation?
('30', 175, 5, 15, 401545) Such should be the case in the eye of the law in the matter of elementary human rights, even as, irrespective of caste, race, creed or colour, we have certain things in common, e.g., hunger, thirst, etc.
('30', 175, 6, 16, 401749) 19. Would that supreme philosophical truth be of any use in the field of practical politics, to the average grihastha or householder, seeing that only great souls, who have come to the end of their cycle of karma, could realize are practise that supreme philosophical truth, and not the ordinary grihastha, who has only to follow what the rishis 2 have ordained, and in that following, get discipline which consequently leads to release from birth and death?
('30', 175, 6, 17, 402208) Not much “supreme philosophical truth” is involved in the recognition of the simple truth that no human being is to be regarded as untouchable by reason of his birth.
('30', 175, 6, 18, 402375) The truth is so simple that it is
('30', 175, 7, 19, 402409) 1 Streets occupied by Brahmins 2 Sages
('30', 176, 0, 1, 402448) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 177
('30', 176, 1, 2, 402494) recognized all over the world except by orthodox Hindus.
('30', 176, 1, 3, 402551) I have questioned the statement that the rishis taught the doctrine of untouchability as we practise it.
('30', 176, 1, 4, 402656) Young India, 5 2 1925
('30', 176, 2, 5, 402678) 96. ON ANOTHER’S LAND
('30', 176, 3, 6, 402700) A friend says :
('30', 176, 4, 7, 402716) You ask us at every turn to yield to Mussalmans, you ask us to resort to law courts on any account.
('30', 176, 4, 8, 402816) Have you fully considered the consequences of what you are saying?
('30', 176, 4, 9, 402883) Have you taken into the account human nature?
('30', 176, 4, 10, 402929) What are we to do when mosques are being put up on our ground without our permission?
('30', 176, 4, 11, 403015) What are we to do when unscrupulous men bring suits against us for monies we do not owe or when they actually rob us of our possessions.
('30', 176, 4, 12, 403152) In giving your answers you must take our poor selves into consideration.
('30', 176, 4, 13, 403225) You dare not say you do not know us.
('30', 176, 4, 14, 403262) Or if you give your fatwas 1 in utter obliviousness of us, you must not blame us if we do not respond to your counsels of perfection.
('30', 176, 4, 15, 403396) Let me tell you that you are sometimes impossible.
('30', 176, 4, 16, 403447) I sympathize with the friends who talk to me in this strain.
('30', 176, 4, 17, 403508) I am prepared to recognize the limitations of human nature for the very simple reason that I recognise my own.
('30', 176, 4, 18, 403619) But precisely as recognizing my own limitations, I do not decieve myself by refusing to distignuish between what I ought to do and what I fail to do.
('30', 176, 4, 19, 403769) I must not deceive others by refusing to notice the same distinction and telling them that what they propose to do is not only perhaps defensible but also right.
('30', 176, 4, 20, 403931) Many things are impossible and yet are the only things right.
('30', 176, 4, 21, 403993) A reformer’s business is to make the impossible possible by giving an ocular demonstration of the possibility in his own conduct.
('30', 176, 4, 22, 404123) Whoever thought it possible before Edison to speak to people hundreds of miles away from us.
('30', 176, 4, 23, 404216) Marconi went a step further and made wireless communication possible.
('30', 176, 4, 24, 404286) We are daily witnessing the phenomenon of the impossible of yesterday becoming the possible of today.
('30', 176, 4, 25, 404388) As in physical science so in psychological.

('30', 181, 2, 3, 414572) IS A SWARAJIST A ONGRESSMAN ?
('30', 181, 3, 4, 414602) I have before me a curious letter in which the writer says, a distinction is being made by Congressmen in Sind between Swarajists and Congressmen, and the former are obstructed by the latter.
('30', 181, 3, 5, 414794) I should have hoped that such a thing would be impossible after the Belgaum Congress which recognizes the Swaraj Party as an integral party of the Congress and which suspends the non co operation programme.
('30', 181, 3, 6, 415001) Every Swarajist who subscribes to the Congress creed and conforms to the new franchise is as much a Congressman as the one who is not a Swarajist, that is to say, who does not believe in Council entry.
('30', 181, 3, 7, 415203) Let it be also remembered that the Swaraj Party has itself altered its constitution to make it obligatory on every member of that party to accept the Congress franchise.
('30', 181, 3, 8, 415373) There should therefore not only be no obstruction by one of the other but each should help the other wherever the help is not inconsistent with one’s conscience.

('30', 183, 2, 3, 419423) WASTE OF YARN A friend from Kumbakonam writes:
('30', 183, 3, 4, 419470) Perhaps you are aware of a custom, now prevalent in the country, to honour political leaders with hand spun yarn garlands.
('30', 183, 3, 5, 419593) Such garlands are invariably used on every political occasion and I may add that an enormous quantity of hand spun yarn is wasted since none takes care of it.
('30', 183, 3, 6, 419752) As an example of such waste, I have sent per separate post, a parcel of yarn which I was able to pick up at the Tamil Nadu Khilafat Conference held recently at Kumbakonam under the Presidency of Maulana Shaukat Ali 1. But for my interest in the yarn 960 yards of yarn would have gone to waste.
('30', 183, 3, 7, 420046) I am sure that at the said Conference alone, much larger quantity of yarn had been wasted.
('30', 183, 3, 8, 420137) Hence I would like to suggest to you to instruct our countrymen through Young India to prepare garlands in hanks of uniform length, say 2,000 yards, so that at every meeting garlands of 2,000 yards may be collected and utilized according as the garlanded leaders propose.
('30', 183, 3, 9, 420409) I can endorse the correspondent’s complaint as to waste.
('30', 183, 3, 10, 420466) It is a good custom to present leaders with yarn garlands but they should be prettily made and not much yarn should be used in them.
('30', 183, 3, 11, 420599) If the idea be to present yarn to leaders and not to garland them, the correspondent’s suggestion should be adopted and uniform size hanks should be given.
('30', 183, 3, 12, 420755) For, if the habit of presenting yarn garlands becomes universal and care is not taken, there might be an enormous waste of good yarn which might otherwise have been utilized for making cheap khaddar for poor people.
('30', 183, 3, 13, 420971) “HABITUAL WEARING” A Bengal school teacher writes:
('30', 183, 4, 14, 421022) I am a teacher of a national school.
('30', 183, 4, 15, 421059) The resolution about national schools passed at Belgaum has given rise to considerable stir amongst the teachers and students of national schools.
('30', 183, 4, 16, 421206) Some are trying to interpret the resolution as it suits their own interest.
('30', 183, 4, 17, 421282) The words “habitual wearing of khaddar by students” is being interpreted by some as not meaning compulsory wearing and hence they say that those, who are attending school without khadi on, need not be debarred.
('30', 183, 4, 18, 421493) All that the teachers should do is always to ask them to put on khadi and gradually initiate them into wearing it.
('30', 183, 4, 19, 421608) They say, even if they have to wait indefinitely to see their students clad in khadi they can continue calling their

('30', 184, 0, 1, 421840) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 185
('30', 184, 1, 2, 421886) institutions “national” without transgressing the resolution of Belgaum.
('30', 184, 1, 3, 421959) They say, even if 60 p.c.
('30', 184, 1, 4, 421985) of the students come to school with mill cloth they can claim to call their schools national if only the school teachers continued teaching the utility and propriety of using khaddar, hoping that they would take to it in due course which may be six months, one year or even more.
('30', 184, 2, 5, 422265) In our opinion the resolution does not admit of this interpretation.
('30', 184, 2, 6, 422334) It means that the schools should not tolerate anybody’s coming to school without khaddar but in cases of emergency or helplessness resulting from unavoidable causes over which one has no control a student may be allowed to join school on rare occasions.
('30', 184, 2, 7, 422588) We think the resolution debars everybody from attending who systematically comes to school without khaddar.
('30', 184, 2, 8, 422696) We have been trying to run the institutions in our area on this line.
('30', 184, 3, 9, 422766) I therefore appeal to you to write to me, and in the pages of Young India if you think it necessary, the real meaning and sense of the resolution in clear unequivocal language so that your idea about the point may be known to all concerned.
('30', 184, 3, 10, 423007) I have no doubt about the meaning of the word “habitual”.
('30', 184, 3, 11, 423065) My correspondent’s meaning is the only possible meaning.
('30', 184, 3, 12, 423122) A school cannot be called national, in terms of the Congress resolu tion, whose scholars do not wear khaddar as a rule.
('30', 184, 3, 13, 423242) But in seek ing to know the meaning of words, the safest rule is “go to the dictionary”.
('30', 184, 3, 14, 423331) Here is the meaning given in the Concise Oxford Dictio nary of the word “habitual”: “customary, constant, continual”.
('30', 184, 4, 15, 423449) SHOULD THEY AFFILIATE The question then arises: are the schools which cannot fulfil the test then to become affiliated as Government institutions?
('30', 184, 4, 16, 423596) Surely such is not the only alternative or for that matter any, for a school that has non co operated.
('30', 184, 4, 17, 423699) There is room enough for schools independent both of the Congress and the Government.
('30', 184, 4, 18, 423785) There may be schools whose conductors do not believe in Government patronage, control or interference and yet may not believe for instance in khadi or in teaching the vernacular or Hindustani.
('30', 184, 4, 19, 423978) There is no reason why such schools should not continue if they receive public support or the conductors are themselves rich enough to carry them on themselves.
('30', 184, 4, 20, 424139) All that the Congress has done is to prescribe the limits within which it can recognize or support educational institutions.
('30', 184, 4, 21, 424264) And what can be more natural than that the Congress should insist on Congress institutions conforming to conditions which in the opinion of Congressmen promote the interest of the country?

('30', 185, 1, 2, 424495) TILAK MAHARASHTRA UNIVERSITY Mr. Gharpure, the Registrar of the Tilak Maharashtra University, writes:
('30', 185, 2, 3, 424597) Many friends and colleagues have drawn my attention to a sentence in your presidential address on page 25, last two lines.
('30', 185, 2, 4, 424720) “Many provinces have their national schools and colleges.
('30', 185, 2, 5, 424778) Gujarat alone has a National University maintained at an annual cost of Rs. 1,00,000/ and having control of three colleges and 70 schools wih 9,000 pupils.”
('30', 185, 3, 6, 424935) This gives rise to a misunderstanding.
('30', 185, 3, 7, 424974) You are right if you mean that no other Province has a University maintained at an annual cost of one lakh.
('30', 185, 3, 8, 425082) But people are liable to interpret it in another way, viz., that no other Province has a University.
('30', 185, 3, 9, 425183) The cost is regarded only as an adjectival clause.
('30', 185, 4, 10, 425234) I shall be glad if you will be kind enough to remove this misunders tanding through the pages of Young India as early as you can.
('30', 185, 5, 11, 425364) The Tilak Maharashtra University is maintained at an annual cost of Rs. 6,000, with three colleges, 30 schools and 2,000 students.
('30', 185, 5, 12, 425495) The annual cost is less simply because each college and school takes care of its own self and no charges are made to the University.
('30', 185, 5, 13, 425628) The National Medical College is not yet recognized though it is on the way to it.
('30', 185, 5, 14, 425710) Still the Tilak Mahavidyalaya maintains 75 students with an annual cost of Rs. 15,000. I had thought that I knew English fairly well and that read in its context the sentence, referred to by Mr. Gharpure, was capable of bearing only one meaning, i.e., that not to mention the other provinces, Gujarat alone underwent so much expense and trained so many scholars.
('30', 185, 5, 15, 426073) But I see that friends at least as conversant with English as myself have put a different construction upon the sentence.
('30', 185, 5, 16, 426195) My only consolation is that both they and I are judging the meaning of a sentence written in a language foreign to us.
('30', 185, 5, 17, 426314) I therefore derive the very poor consolation from the thought that they are as likely to be wrong in their interpretation as I in mine.

('30', 185, 5, 19, 426638) The emphasis was not meant for the University as distinguished from schools and colleges.

('30', 186, 2, 5, 427249) VOLUNTEERS I have been asked to give my impressions of the volunteers’ work at Belgaum during the Congress week.
('30', 186, 2, 6, 427362) I thought that I had already dealt with it in my Belgaum impressions.
('30', 186, 2, 7, 427432) But I gladly respond.
('30', 186, 2, 8, 427454) Their work will bear a fuller and separate treatment.
('30', 186, 2, 9, 427508) In my opinion the volunteers reached at Belgaum comparatively the highest watermark in efficiency within my experience of four Congresses.
('30', 186, 2, 10, 427647) They were hardworking, efficient and willing.
('30', 186, 2, 11, 427693) I heard no complaint from the delegates about them.
('30', 186, 2, 12, 427745) Physically too they appeared to me to be fit.
('30', 186, 2, 13, 427791) Dr. Hardikar 1 was good enough to take me through their camp which had a businesslike appearance and was fairly tidy.
('30', 186, 2, 14, 427909) I say fairly tidy for in my opinion a volunteer camp must be a model of tidiness, not a thing being out of its place and everything being not only in its own place but being in its place in a neat manner.
('30', 186, 2, 15, 428114) For instance, a volunteer may have his bedding in its place and yet may have put it in a heap instead of having properly and neatly folded it in the prescribed manner.
('30', 186, 2, 16, 428282) In point of sanitation too a volunteer camp must be perfect, not a scrap of paper or dirt should be found anywhere.
('30', 186, 2, 17, 428398) I understand that Dr. Hardikar specially restricted the number of volunteers.
('30', 186, 2, 18, 428476) They had therefore more than a fair share of work to do.
('30', 186, 2, 19, 428533) During the time that the Congress was in session they had to work over sixteen hours per day, being on their legs practically the whole of that time.
('30', 186, 2, 20, 428683) I must not omit to mention the lady volunteers.
('30', 186, 2, 21, 428731) They were most helpful and attentive.
('30', 186, 2, 22, 428769) They too had undergone previous training.
('30', 186, 2, 23, 428811) Though we cannot manage a Congress session without the efficient help of volunteers, let me say that work is the least part of a volunteer’s training.
('30', 186, 2, 24, 428962) Volunteers must be our greatest asset in winning swaraj.
('30', 186, 2, 25, 429019) This they can only be, if in addition to having a spotless character and the necessary training in drilling, sanitation and first aid to the injured, they know how to organize the nation for swaraj.
('30', 186, 2, 26, 429218) For this purpose therefore every volunteer must be an expert carder and spinner, and must be able in addition to doing his share of spinning, necessary for the franchise, to organize carding and spinning in his own district.
('30', 186, 2, 27, 429443) It should be remembered that hand spinning has been

('30', 189, 1, 2, 432558) 100. SPEECH AT RAWALPINDI 1
('30', 189, 2, 3, 432586) February 5, 1925 I was present here last December and held some talks with you.
('30', 189, 3, 4, 432666) At that time I assured you that if you all had not returned to Kohat, I would come back and would talk to you; and if some Muslim brothers came by then from Kohat, I would make some inquiries also.
('30', 189, 3, 5, 432864) Some Muslim brothers have come from Kohat and I am talking things over with them.
('30', 189, 3, 6, 432946) As a result of these discussions I am in no position to advise you to go back to Kohat.
('30', 189, 3, 7, 433034) I was hoping that by holding talks with them something good might turn up.
('30', 189, 3, 8, 433109) I am not without hope but today I do not have a single reason for asking you to return to Kohat.
('30', 189, 3, 9, 433206) In fact I feel like advising you to the contrary.
('30', 189, 3, 10, 433256) It is possible that I may not succeed in my task with the Muslim brethren.
('30', 189, 3, 11, 433331) Moreover those Muslims who have got a hold over Kohat have not come here.
('30', 189, 3, 12, 433405) On the other hand they have sent a telegram saying, “A compromise has already been reached here and the Hindus are returning to Kohat.
('30', 189, 3, 13, 433540) Why do you call us then?
('30', 189, 3, 14, 433565) Why do you again throw all people into panic?
('30', 189, 3, 15, 433611) The implication is that Shaukat Ali and myself should not interfere in this matter.
('30', 189, 3, 16, 433695) But while talking to the Muslims who have come here I asked them, “Do you take the responsibility of taking Hindus to Kohat?” One of the gentlemen frankly replied, “If the Hindus want to return to Kohat, let them do so but we can take no responsibility.
('30', 189, 3, 17, 433949) We are not even in a position to invite them, the reason being that those who are there at present are hated.” So I cannot advise you to go back to Kohat.
('30', 189, 3, 18, 434104) There is yet another matter.
('30', 189, 3, 19, 434133) If you want to return there relying on the strength of the Government and if the talks with the Government have inspired some faith in you, you are free to go back.
('30', 189, 3, 20, 434298) But even now I hold firm to the belief that we are not going to benefit by working with or through the Government .
('30', 189, 3, 21, 434414) And therefore I do not advise you to go there under the protection of the Government.
('30', 189, 3, 22, 434500) Wherever you stay you have to rely on your own strength.

('30', 194, 4, 9, 445134) 101. EXAMINATION OF KAMAL JAILANE ON KOHAT RIOT 1
('30', 194, 5, 10, 445184) [RAWALPINDI] February 6, 1925
('30', 194, 6, 11, 445214) Q. Do you live near Kohat?
('30', 194, 7, 12, 445241) A. I live quite close by.
('30', 194, 8, 13, 445267) Q. Are you a zamindar?
('30', 194, 9, 14, 445290) A. I am a zamindar.
('30', 194, 9, 15, 445310) I own several villages in.
('30', 194, 9, 16, 445337) 2 Besides these our ancestors were given shares in lands in almost all the villages (here).
('30', 194, 10, 17, 445429) Q. Are you on good terms with the Hindus?

('30', 201, 8, 14, 460045) A few months ago, dispute between the Hindus and Mussalmans had arisen over this Gurdwara.
('30', 201, 8, 15, 460136) The Hindus claimed it as a temple of theirs while the Sikhs contended that it was a Gurdwara and belonged to them.
('30', 201, 8, 16, 460251) Some Hindu sadhus used to sit in this Gurdwara and smoke charas to which the Sikhs took strong objection.
('30', 201, 8, 17, 460357) The Sikhs then came to the Gurdwara in force and ejected the sadhus from that place and took possession of it.
('30', 201, 8, 18, 460468) As a result, a Sub Inspector of Police with some sergeants and a full body of police remained camped there for several weeks to prevent a disturbance as the Gurdwara was situated outside the city.
('30', 201, 9, 19, 460665) Respectable leaders of both the communities were also made to deposit securities and bound over for peace and good behaviour.
('30', 201, 9, 20, 460791) I myself gave a piece of land belonging to me opposite our cemetery to that sadhu.
('30', 201, 9, 21, 460874) This sadhu declared that he would not leave that place till he had burnt that Gurdwara.
('30', 201, 9, 22, 460962) During the riots this sadhu along with two respectable Hindu leaders who had taken refuge with him remained there for two days and besides risking his own life, protected the lives of two other Hindus.
('30', 201, 9, 23, 461164) Afterwards I learnt that some Sikh gentlemen had reported to the police that the burning of the Gurdwara had been instigated by that sadhu.
('30', 201, 9, 24, 461304) So the police expelled him from that place and sent him out of the district.

('30', 202, 10, 18, 463193) Q. The Hindus state that between 9th and 10th September several Hindus were forcibly converted to Islam.
('30', 202, 10, 19, 463298) Do you know anything about it ?
('30', 202, 11, 20, 463330) A. I think no Hindu was forcibly converted to Islam.
('30', 202, 11, 21, 463383) But some Hindus who had taken shelter with the Mussalmans, feeling that their lives were in danger, themselves requested that their tuft of hair, etc., might be removed and their protectors, feeling that the lives of Hindus were really in danger, removed their choti 1
('30', 202, 12, 22, 463652) & c., and gave out that they had become Mussalmans.
('30', 202, 13, 23, 463704) Q. You had mentioned another procedure also ?
('30', 202, 14, 24, 463750) A. Something like that might have happened.
('30', 202, 14, 25, 463794) Only I have no knowledge of any case when a Mussalman in order to save the life of a Hindu advised him to become a Mussalman and removed his choti.
('30', 202, 14, 26, 463942) I can, however, believe an incident like this taking place.
('30', 202, 15, 27, 464002) Q. Why do you believe it to be possible that some Mussalmans might have advised some Hindus to become Mussalmans to save their lives ?
('30', 202, 16, 28, 464137) 1 Tuft of hair
('30', 203, 0, 1, 464152) 204 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 203, 1, 2, 464194) A. Simply because the people from the villages were uneducated and protection of life was a serious matter.
('30', 203, 2, 3, 464302) Q. Would you regard a person who has been converted to Islam in this manner as a Mussalman ?
('30', 203, 3, 4, 464395) A. So long as such a person does not of his own free will declare himself to be a Mussalman in circumstances of peace, he cannot be regarded as a Mussalman.

('30', 203, 5, 6, 464597) 102. EXAMINATION OF AHMAD GUL ON KOHAT RIOT 1
('30', 203, 6, 7, 464643) [ RAWALPINDI] February 6, 1925
('30', 203, 7, 8, 464674) Q. Your name, Maulvi Saheb?
('30', 203, 8, 9, 464702) A. My name is Ahmad Gul.
('30', 203, 9, 10, 464727) Q. What work are you employed in?
('30', 203, 10, 11, 464761) A. I am a dentist.
('30', 203, 11, 12, 464780) Q. Since when are you the Secretary of Khilafat?
('30', 203, 12, 13, 464829) A. Since 1922.
('30', 203, 13, 14, 464844) Q. Since when do you live in Kohat?
('30', 203, 14, 15, 464880) A. I was born there.
('30', 203, 15, 16, 464901) Q. In your opinion what is the cause of the Kohat troubles?
('30', 203, 16, 17, 464961) A. In some respects I agree with Pir Kamal Saheb, but in others I differ.
('30', 203, 16, 18, 465035) In my opinion the cause of the disturbances was the pamphlet.
('30', 203, 17, 19, 465097) Q. Any other cause, apart from the pamphlet?
('30', 203, 18, 20, 465142) A. There was another incident.
('30', 203, 18, 21, 465173) In my life there were only two such occasions when the Mohammedans went to the Government in large numbers.
('30', 203, 18, 22, 465281) One was the case of S. Makhan Singh’s son and the other of the pamphlet.
('30', 203, 18, 23, 465354) Besides these occasions never has such excitement prevailed.
('30', 203, 18, 24, 465415) Neither they collected nor was there any such disturbance.
('30', 203, 19, 25, 465474) Q. Do you take only these two incidents as the cause of disturbances?
('30', 203, 20, 26, 465544) A. There were some mutual dissensions also.
('30', 203, 21, 27, 465588) Q. What was the matter regarding S. Makhan Singh’s son?
('30', 203, 22, 28, 465644) A. There was a general rumour among the people that S. Makhan Singh's son had
('30', 203, 23, 29, 465722) 1 The source was defective and has been slightly edited, where absolutely necessary.
('30', 204, 0, 1, 465807) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 205
('30', 204, 1, 2, 465853) illegitimate connection with the wife of his gardener.
('30', 204, 1, 3, 465908) He went away to Lahore and the malan 1 also followed him and this was followed with a great stir among the people.
('30', 204, 1, 4, 466023) The Pathans as a community look upon this kind of action with hatred even if it is done by a Mussalman.
('30', 204, 1, 5, 466127) Therefore the Government also treats the accused severely and the people are disturbed thereby even if the case is between two Mussalmans.
('30', 204, 1, 6, 466266) In the case of S. Makhan Singh's son the Government did not pay heed although a deputation waited.
('30', 204, 1, 7, 466365) I mean to say that the Sardar’s son was not convicted and the gardener did not get justice.
('30', 204, 1, 8, 466457) It was a great shock to the Mussal mans when a Hindu or a Sikh dared to do so.
('30', 204, 1, 9, 466536) It was also rumoured that S. Makhan Singh pacified the gardener by giving some money.
('30', 204, 1, 10, 466622) It was also broadcast that S. Makhan Singh saved himself on other occasion also by payments.
('30', 204, 2, 11, 466715) Q. When did this occur?
('30', 204, 3, 12, 466739) A. It was about one year ago, i.e., one year before the pamphlet incident.
('30', 204, 3, 13, 466814) When Jivandas was arrested and put into lock up, S. Makhan Singh went to the jail in the capacity of a non official visitor.
('30', 204, 3, 14, 466939) The Jail Superintendent also complained against his conduct as a visitor as he interfered in jail arrangements.
('30', 204, 3, 15, 467051) The Superintendent kept Jivandas in a solitary cell but the Sardar Saheb asked Jivandas to be taken out of it.
('30', 204, 3, 16, 467162) There was a regular complaint about it as the daughter of Jivandas was betrothed to the Sardar's son.
('30', 204, 3, 17, 467264) This rumour was also going round that Sardar Saheb would get Jivandas released in a few hours.
('30', 204, 3, 18, 467359) After that when the first firing took place, the first thing that was heard was that the boys were killed before the house of Sardar Saheb.
('30', 204, 3, 19, 467499) This was the past incident and again the release of Jivandas and the firing near Sardar Saheb's house excited the Mussalmans and in my opinion this is the reason of the disturbance.
('30', 204, 4, 20, 467681) Q. Who put out the rumour that Sardar Saheb and his son fired?
('30', 204, 5, 21, 467744) A. When I was in court and the crowd was being assured that Jivandas would be prosecuted, we had no complaint against other Hindus.
('30', 204, 5, 22, 467876) The Mussalmans were satisfied when the court decided to proceed against the accused.
('30', 204, 5, 23, 467961) The basis of the charge was being established, when the information reached there that firing took place in the bazaar.
('30', 204, 5, 24, 468081) Ahmad Khan Saheb informed me and, taking me with him in motor car besides three other Mohammedans, proceeded to the scene of the occurrrence.
('30', 204, 5, 25, 468223) We entered the city by the Cantonment gate and were yet fifty paces from Sardar Saheb's place when we met a crowd of fifty or sixty which came to stop us and said that firing was going on and we should not proceed further.
('30', 204, 5, 26, 468446) One boy was lying killed near Sardar Makhan Singh's balakhana 2 and one man was wounded.
('30', 204, 5, 27, 468535) On this the motor car was brought back to Kotwali without being turned as the space was not adequate.
('30', 204, 5, 28, 468637) The Kotwali might be a hundred paces distance from there.

('30', 206, 9, 13, 472007) I translated it before the crowd and also looking to their excitement and intention which I could guess I kept them back from resorting to any kind of disturbance and reminded them of the bad consequences of the riots in Malabar, Multan, Saharanpur and in other places and advised them that in case they could not control themselves they should go to the Government in this case also, as they were doing about other matters.

('30', 219, 6, 10, 500208) If I had gone out then, such people would have entered the field and it would have been more troublesome.

('30', 220, 7, 8, 501737) In a few days I shall be again in Kathiawar, and that, too, in Rajkot this time.
('30', 220, 7, 9, 501818) Shri Bharucha has been so much impressed by Kathiawar that he has asked for permission to prolong his stay there and propagate the spinning wheel movement .
('30', 220, 7, 10, 501975) I hope that the usual remark about our being enthusiastic merely in the beginning will not be proved true in this case.
('30', 220, 7, 11, 502095) If the political leaders of Rajkot decide, they can infuse new life in Rajkot as also in other parts of Kathiawar.
('30', 220, 7, 12, 502210) “In other parts”, because Rajkot is the central place and, as it is the headquarters of the (Political) Agency also, political workers foregather there.
('30', 220, 7, 13, 502363) No one can say that politicians are pressed for time, and they have sufficient influence over the people.
('30', 220, 7, 14, 502469) They can make the whole of Kathiawar khadi minded, revitalize it and check the exodus of Kathiawaris for a few pounds of bajri 2. We shall not understand how the problem will be solved in this way, by asking the question what a person can earn through the spinning wheel; we shall be convinced that it can be, if we calculate how much money the people will save.
('30', 220, 7, 15, 502832) If we only think how much everyone will suffer by the increase of a pie in a rupee in the salt tax, we shall see no reason to be seriously upset.
('30', 220, 7, 16, 502978) But when we calculate the total revenue yielded by this impost, we shall be astounded by the figures.
('30', 220, 7, 17, 503080) Loss of this kind is like a prick by the cobbler’s needle.
('30', 220, 7, 18, 503139) It is felt by the society as a whole.
('30', 220, 7, 19, 503177) We can deduce from this the effect on every individual.
('30', 220, 7, 20, 503233) Similar is the case with the spinning wheel.

('30', 223, 0, 1, 508254) 224 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('30', 223, 1, 4, 508436) The work of spinning will become a golden link binding the Maharaja and his subject.
('30', 223, 1, 5, 508521) This will revive the rule that princes should engage themselves in useful work which is calculated to benefit the subjects, the knowledge that even the work done by the poorest among the subjects has a place in the palace of the Maharaja will always act as an inspiration to the people, and it will be established that in reality there is no distinction of class between the prince and the poor.

('30', 223, 5, 13, 509357) After he has seen them, he passes on to me those needing immediate attention, and I can look into them as and when I find time.
