('30', 224, 1, 2, 510466) The doctor proposes, and rightly, that it should be made a permanent feature and included in the curriculum itself.
('30', 224, 1, 3, 510582) The letter seems to imply that the doctor intends his scheme to be adopted in place of the present scheme of studies.
('30', 224, 1, 4, 510700) Personally, I might like even that; there is, however, no need to completely replace the present scheme, and even if there be, it is not possible to do so.
('30', 224, 1, 5, 510856) We had in mind the students’ inclinations when framing it.
('30', 224, 1, 6, 510915) In comparison with other provinces, Gujarat felt the spirit of service a little late.
('30', 224, 1, 7, 511001) Every student, therefore, will not be eager for a course of studies essential for training in service.
('30', 224, 1, 8, 511104) Moreover, along with the needs of social service we have to pay attention to the problem of livelihood.
('30', 224, 1, 9, 511208) The prevailing idea is that education is intended to equip the student with the means of livelihood.
('30', 224, 1, 10, 511309) If the aim were no more than this, it could be excused, but there is also the idea that education should help the student to make money or to get appointed to a position of authority.
('30', 224, 1, 11, 511493) As long as this attitude does not change, our curriculum is bound to remain defective from a theoretical point of view.
('30', 224, 1, 12, 511613) I think it impossible to change it immediately.
('30', 224, 1, 13, 511661) But it is essential, and quite possible, gradually to reduce the idea of career to secondary importance.
('30', 224, 1, 14, 511766) The Vidyapith also will have to create for the students fields of social service which can offer them means of livelihood.
('30', 224, 1, 15, 511889) Livelihood may not be the aim of education, but the ability to earn it must be one of the fruits of education.
('30', 224, 1, 16, 512000) The aim of education is spiritual development, and where this is achieved, the ability to make a living is bound to follow.
('30', 224, 1, 17, 512124) It is also noted that students are not happy unless they acquire a knowledge of English.
('30', 224, 1, 18, 512213) They also crave for a knowledge of literature.
('30', 224, 1, 19, 512260) There can be no harm at all in either.
('30', 224, 1, 20, 512299) We have only to guard against making a fetish of them, against making the study of English and of literature the sole aims of education and forms of self indulgence.
('30', 224, 1, 21, 512465) In their right place, which they occupy at present, they are of great value.
('30', 224, 1, 22, 512542) It cannot be maintained that the curriculum of the Government colleges is in every respect harmful.
('30', 224, 1, 23, 512642) I do not feel that all of it deserves to be kept out.
('30', 224, 1, 24, 512696) Its features of parrot learning, prohibition of the use of the mother tongue, grand display of the knowledge of English, one sided study of history, almost complete indifference to our ancient culture, absence of training in self control, all these and similar features must be guarded against.

('30', 226, 3, 10, 516507) This is not possible at the present moment.

('30', 231, 1, 2, 524733) 116. LETTER TO SIR PRABHASHANKER PATTANI
('30', 231, 2, 3, 524774) Maha Vad 2 [February 10, 1925]
('30', 231, 3, 4, 524805) SUGNA BHAISHRI, I returned from Rawalpindi yesterday.
('30', 231, 3, 5, 524859) Today I got your letter for which I was waiting.
('30', 231, 3, 6, 524908) I could not resist sending a telegram conveying my thanks.
('30', 231, 3, 7, 524967) Please do not be angry with the person who wrote to me.
('30', 231, 3, 8, 525023) I shall try to let you know his name also.
('30', 231, 3, 9, 525066) On reading that you do not consider any letter as wholly confidential, I have begun to feel more proud of mankind.
('30', 231, 3, 10, 525181) I feel humbled.
('30', 231, 3, 11, 525197) I thought that I was perhaps the only persons who had nothing private of confidential.
('30', 231, 3, 12, 525284) You have surpassed me, because you are living in an environment where it would be difficult to publicize one’s private life.
('30', 231, 3, 13, 525409) Had the writer been a schemer or a wicked man, I would have written nothing to you from his letter, nor would I have allowed it to influence me in the least.
('30', 231, 3, 14, 525567) But he is a gentleman, discrimination, disciplined and learned.
('30', 231, 3, 15, 525631) He cannot possibly have any malice towards you; but I can well understand how he came to commit this mistake.
('30', 231, 3, 16, 525741) I am sending him a copy of your letter.
('30', 231, 3, 17, 525781) It will do him good.
('30', 231, 3, 18, 525802) He is such a pure minded person that I wouldn’t be surprised if he came to you and offered his apology.
('30', 231, 3, 19, 525906) I did well in writing the letter to you.
('30', 231, 3, 20, 525947) You recollect your past lapses; but who is free from these?
('30', 231, 3, 21, 526007) I have been saved thrice from falling.
('30', 231, 3, 22, 526046) It was not owing to my own strength but owing to my unlettered mother.
('30', 231, 3, 23, 526117) She bound her son by the thread of a vow and he was saved.
('30', 231, 3, 24, 526176) I shall reach Rajkot on the 16th.
('30', 231, 3, 25, 526210) Shall we meet there or any where else?

('30', 232, 4, 8, 526821) 118. SPEECH AT SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, SABARMATI
('30', 232, 5, 9, 526865) February 10, 1925 I am in the predicament of a man who having come to know that there is a serpent under his mattress shakes the matters vigoro usly, sweeps the room and washes the floor with water.
('30', 232, 5, 10, 527064) I have come to know what I did not know earlier about the situation in Kohat.
('30', 232, 5, 11, 527142) I talk to you about it because it is a matter concerning religion.
('30', 232, 5, 12, 527209) We all have to take this as a warning.
('30', 232, 5, 13, 527248) It does not mean that we have to do something special and novel; but we have to prepare ourselves mentally and emotionally.
('30', 232, 5, 14, 527372) We have to become purer.
('30', 232, 6, 15, 527397) At this stage Gandhiji referred to the number of conversions in Kohat and said: That number may possibly be considered as small elsewhere.
('30', 232, 6, 16, 527536) In an area were Muslims barely number 15,000, this is terrible.
('30', 232, 6, 17, 527600) The Hindus there work up and the Muslims could not tolerate the awakening; those looking for a chance to wreak vengeance found it in the form of that booklet.
('30', 232, 6, 18, 527759) If that was the only reason, the man concerned could have been arrested, he could have been crushed, and perhaps all those connected with the booklet could have been crushed.
('30', 232, 6, 19, 527934) But here the whole community was persecuted.
('30', 232, 6, 20, 527979) Its cause must be deep seated.
('30', 232, 6, 21, 528010) I found that cause quite by chance.
('30', 232, 6, 22, 528046) The Muslims said many things frankly about proselytization.
('30', 232, 6, 23, 528106) But that activity has hurt me very much.
('30', 232, 6, 24, 528147) I would not mind it at all if 30 crores of Hindus became Muslims as a result of scriptural studies and rational arguments.
('30', 232, 6, 25, 528270) Then I would be the single Hindu left and thereby I would add lustre to Hinduism.
('30', 232, 6, 26, 528352) Or I would adduce proof of the immortality of Hinduism and say that the others became Muslims because they could not bear the brilliance of Hinduism.
('30', 232, 6, 27, 528502) But if people turned Muslims out of greed or fear, as it happened there, I could not endure it.
('30', 232, 6, 28, 528598) I am talking about this matter because I am to make you strong of mind, in order that you may be more attached to dharma.
('30', 232, 6, 29, 528720) Despite this,
('30', 233, 0, 1, 528734) 234 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 233, 1, 2, 528776) there will be no change in my non violent behaviour, my attitude of love and in my behaviour towards Muslims.
('30', 233, 1, 3, 528886) The more I see their weaknesses, the more shall I serve them.
('30', 233, 1, 4, 528948) My love for them will certainly endure.
('30', 233, 1, 5, 528988) But the language of love will change—it has become more firm and will become firmer still—just as my words to Englishmen are becoming stiffer.
('30', 233, 1, 6, 529131) That will be the only difference.
('30', 233, 1, 7, 529165) My sole object is to rouse you this morning and to caution you.
('30', 233, 1, 8, 529229) I want to caution you because you may sometimes face a similar situation.
('30', 233, 1, 9, 529303) If any little boy or girl in the Ashram is kidnapped, you should not just look on, interpreting my non violence in a superficial way.
('30', 233, 1, 10, 529437) The determination to be pure is itself a source of strength.
('30', 233, 1, 11, 529498) A man having a pure and unsullied heart has no need to develop his body.
('30', 233, 1, 12, 529571) His body automatically becomes strong.
('30', 233, 1, 13, 529610) And thereafter mere resolve is enough.
('30', 233, 1, 14, 529649) It is my resolve that I would utter the name of Rama before retiring, so that without chanting the name I can never get sleep.
('30', 233, 1, 15, 529776) And if I do get it, I utter Ramanama while turning on my side and I do see my standing near me.
('30', 233, 1, 16, 529872) The same true of every resolve.
('30', 233, 1, 17, 529904) Even a child in the Ashram is not afraid if he faces danger.
('30', 233, 1, 18, 529965) If he does not have strength of soul, he surely has nails.
('30', 233, 1, 19, 530024) We clip nails becuase dirt accumulates in them.
('30', 233, 1, 20, 530072) When they grow big they get in the way and we clip them.
('30', 233, 1, 21, 530129) In like manner, we should go on removing the dangerous elements in the body one by one.
('30', 233, 1, 22, 530217) [From Gujarati]
('30', 233, 2, 23, 530233) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. VII, pp.

('30', 235, 4, 10, 532559) 122. SPEECH AT BORSAD
('30', 235, 5, 11, 532581) February 11, 1925 Borsad has become a place of pilgrimage, thanks to the satyagraha struggle.
('30', 235, 5, 12, 532675) But the holy places in India are no longer holy, and I hope this has not become the fate of Borsad.
('30', 235, 5, 13, 532775) Your struggle and the success you achieved in it were no ordinary ones.
('30', 235, 5, 14, 532847) But to fight a battle is one thing, and to follow it up with constructive work is another.
('30', 235, 5, 15, 532938) One discovers that to reap happy benefits from one’s success is a difficult matter,and it often seems as if the struggle had never been fought.
('30', 235, 5, 16, 533082) To return to the normal conditions after a struggle is as difficult as after a prolonged fast.
('30', 235, 5, 17, 533177) We discovered this even after the Kheda agitation, and feel it after the present struggle.
('30', 235, 5, 18, 533268) We saw the same thing, on a wider scale in Europe.
('30', 235, 5, 19, 533319) There, a great War was fought between Britain and Germany; colossal sacrifices were made and we had expected to see a new Europe as a result of these, expected to see its people more moral and pure, wiser and more godfearing.
('30', 235, 5, 20, 533545) But the evil ways which prevailed there persist even today, and the people who made the sacrifices are in an unhappy plight.
('30', 235, 5, 21, 533670) Let us hope that the difference in the manner of fighting that War and our struggle will be reflected in thier repsective outcomes.
('30', 235, 5, 22, 533802) In the War in Europe, the two sides fought to destroy each other.
('30', 235, 5, 23, 533868) In a satyagraha struggle, neither side is destroyed, but on the contrary both benefit.
('30', 235, 5, 24, 533955) How does it happen, then, that we do not see the desired result at the end of even such a pure struggle as satyagraha?
('30', 235, 5, 25, 534074) The reason is just this, that we find excitement to be a common feature of the two kinds of fighting.
('30', 235, 5, 26, 534176) We are not able to maintain an atmosphere of peace and show patience, as we should, and so we seem to lose the gain we have made.
('30', 235, 5, 27, 534306) About Borsad, however, the Durbar Saheb had forewarned me that he would not be able to show me Khadinagar, that the struggle had not taught
('30', 236, 0, 1, 534446) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 237
('30', 236, 1, 2, 534492) the people the value of khadi.
('30', 236, 1, 3, 534523) I did not, therefore, come here with any high hopes and so I am not very much disappointed either.
('30', 236, 1, 4, 534622) Even running a school requires considerable ability.
('30', 236, 1, 5, 534675) The aphorism, as in one’s body so in the universe, holds true on all occasions.
('30', 236, 1, 6, 534755) If I can conduct the Satyagraha Ashram well, I can succeed even in Lord Reading’s seat.
('30', 236, 1, 7, 534843) The difficulties I have to face Ashram, the anxious thought I have to bestow and the number of problems I have to solve, I do not have to in a struggle like yours.
('30', 236, 1, 8, 535007) What after all is to be done in running a campaign?
('30', 236, 1, 9, 535059) I have to chalk out a programme and tell you what to do, merely give instructions to people; running an Ashram is much more difficult that this.
('30', 236, 1, 10, 535204) I have no aspiration to be a Viceroy even in this life; I only wish to be a devoted servant of the country.
('30', 236, 1, 11, 535312) But I beg leave to say that running an Ashram taxes one’s spiritual resources more agonizingly than discharging the duties of a Viceroy ever does.
('30', 236, 1, 12, 535459) You, too, I wish, should tax yourselves in like manner in running the Vidya Mandir, or the more one suffers the purer one becomes.

('30', 236, 2, 14, 535627) 123. SPEECH AT BHADRAN 1
('30', 236, 3, 15, 535652) February 11, 1925
('30', 236, 4, 16, 535670) Before I thank you for your love and the address you have presented to me, I have one request to make.
('30', 236, 4, 17, 535773) You have assembled here in such a large number at this late hour of the night.
('30', 236, 4, 18, 535852) I would be guilty of a crime against you if I did not say that this makes me happy.
('30', 236, 4, 19, 535936) But there is also something else which pains me.
('30', 236, 4, 20, 535985) I do not know if the organizers of the meeting deliberately made the arrangements which we find here, but by now everyone who attends such meetings knows my idiosyncrasies.
('30', 236, 4, 21, 536158) One of these is that I am extremely paimed to see at a meeting a separate enclosure for Antyajas, and find it impossible to start my speech.
('30', 236, 4, 22, 536299) But, as you have said, and many others besides you say, non violence is the central creed guiding my life, and I am trying to act every moment in accordance with it.
('30', 236, 4, 23, 536465) If what you have said is true, I can never wish to give you pain.
('30', 236, 4, 24, 536531) I would not like you to do anything without knowing its implications, nor can I get angry with
('30', 236, 5, 25, 536626) 1 A village in Kaira District in Gujarat
('30', 237, 0, 1, 536667) 238 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 237, 1, 2, 536709) you and force you to do anything.
('30', 237, 1, 3, 536743) Whatever I wish you to do, I should persuade you to do by touching your heart and reason.

('30', 249, 3, 6, 566801) 128. SPEECH IN REPLY TO SEVA MANDAL ADDRESS,
('30', 249, 4, 7, 566846) BHADRAN February 12, 1925 I have been asked to say something about brahmacharya 2. This is one of those subjects on which I write in Navajivan from time to time.
('30', 249, 4, 8, 567008) I rarely speak on it, because I think that it is an extremely difficult subject to talk about and one cannot explain one’s ideas about it in a speech.
('30', 249, 4, 9, 567159) You wish to hear my views on ordinary brahmacharya and not on brahmacharya in the extended definition of the term which connotes the control of all organs of sense.
('30', 249, 4, 10, 567324) Even ordinary brahmacharya is said by the Shastras to be very difficult to observe.
('30', 249, 4, 11, 567408) Permit me to say that there is ninety nine per cent truth in this view, but that it falls short of absolute truth by one per cent.
('30', 249, 4, 12, 567539) The observance of this ordinary brahmacharya is felt to be difficult because we do not strive to control the other organs of sense.
('30', 249, 4, 13, 567671) The most important of these is the palate.
('30', 249, 4, 14, 567714) For him who has learnt to control the palate.
('30', 249, 4, 15, 567760) The observance of brahmacharya will be easy enough.
('30', 249, 4, 16, 567812) Students of zoology tell us that lower creatures observe brahmacharya better than man.
('30', 249, 4, 17, 567899) What they say is true, and if we try to know the reason we shall discover that the lower creatures have the completest control over the palate, which is not the result of an effort of will but is instinctive.
('30', 249, 4, 18, 568108) They feed on grass and plants, and eat only as much as would satisfy their hunger.
('30', 249, 4, 19, 568191) They eat to live, and do not live to eat.
('30', 249, 4, 20, 568233) We do quite the opposite of this.
('30', 249, 4, 21, 568267) The mother feeds her child all manner of delicacies, believing that only so can she express her love.
('30', 249, 4, 22, 568369) By acting in this way, we do not make our food more tasty, but rather less so.
('30', 249, 4, 23, 568448) Food is made tasty by appetite.
('30', 249, 4, 24, 568480) A plain rotla 3 is more tasty to a hungry person than ladu 4 can be to a person who has no appetite.
('30', 249, 4, 25, 568581) We actually use all kinds of spices and prepare an endless variety of

('30', 261, 1, 2, 594670) 135. SPEECH AT OPENING OF NATIONAL SCHOOL, RAJKOT
('30', 261, 2, 3, 594720) February 15, 1925 This school, or rather the Vidyapith from which it has sprung, is a part of the great experiment which is at present being conducted in the country.
('30', 261, 2, 4, 594887) Durbars and Indian States rarely undertake an exper iment of this kind.
('30', 261, 2, 5, 594959) Their general inclination is to follow the royal path.
('30', 261, 2, 6, 595014) We shall hardly find any State which would think of abandoning this path and venturing upon experiments.
('30', 261, 2, 7, 595119) It is for the people, not their rulers, to undertake experiments.
('30', 261, 2, 8, 595185) Rulers are the protectors and representatives of their subjects.
('30', 261, 2, 9, 595250) If I may go further, I would say that a real king is the servant of his subjects.
('30', 261, 2, 10, 595332) He cannot, therefore, conduct experiments at their cost.
('30', 261, 2, 11, 595389) From that point of view, the Thakore Saheb was right in what he said regarding teachers, but people like me who have spent their whole lives in making experiments cannot follow any other course.
('30', 261, 2, 12, 595584) I would, therefore, pray to the Thakore Saheb to look kindly on us.
('30', 261, 2, 13, 595652) If the rules intended for the teachers of a country which aspires to be free, that is, to be self controlled, are not very strict, we shall find it difficult to get teachers of even moderate quality for the ordinary schools.
('30', 261, 2, 14, 595877) I would tell the teachers that they should always be ready to face difficulties, and should follow the path of dharma till the very end.
('30', 261, 2, 15, 596014) No matter if the number of students goes down from 150 to 40, they should continue to serve the school.
('30', 261, 2, 16, 596118) It is their faith which will give a magnetic quality to the school and attract more students in the future.
('30', 261, 2, 17, 596226) It is said that we are always brave in the beginning, but, when difficulties come, instead of praying to the God of mercy we abandon the task, the egotists that we are.
('30', 261, 2, 18, 596395) If we examine the history of nations, we shall see that among people who enjoy freedom there have been countless men and women who had remained loyal to their principles at the cost of their lives.
('30', 261, 2, 19, 596593) It does not matter if the school makes no progress, not merely for five years but for twenty years.
('30', 261, 2, 20, 596693) In the history of a school twenty years mean nothing.
('30', 261, 2, 21, 596747) Whether or no we see any tangible results, if the teachers have faith in themselves they should follow what seems to them the most straightforward path; they are bound, in the end, to see the coast.

('30', 263, 3, 10, 600440) The smaller countries of Europe, like Sweden, Norway and Switzerland—countries about which the world has not heard much because they were not involved in the last War—boast a civilization in no way inferior to that of the bigger coun tries; they have carried out many successful experiments in the field of education.
('30', 263, 3, 11, 600758) The problems of big countries are also big.
('30', 263, 3, 12, 600802) I can well understand what difficulties a person in the position of Lord Reading generally has to contend with.
('30', 263, 3, 13, 600914) With so many parties and interests to consider, and the field of work so large, what effective work can be done?
('30', 263, 3, 14, 601027) It is, therefore, only in small countries that promising plans can be easily implemented.
('30', 263, 3, 15, 601117) The Gujarat Vidy apith has been, in a way, doing what the Thakore Saheb explained.
('30', 263, 3, 16, 601200) If we run one model institution with ideal students, many more institu tions of the same kind will grow out of it.
('30', 263, 3, 17, 601315) A zero can produce nothing, for it cannot be multiplied, whereas one can grow into many.
('30', 263, 3, 18, 601404) There is, therefore, no cause for despair.
('30', 263, 3, 19, 601447) The cause of despair generally lies in the man himself.
('30', 263, 3, 20, 601503) The atman is its own friend and its own enemy.
('30', 263, 3, 21, 601550) 1 We may not put any limits to what human effort can achieve.

('30', 263, 3, 23, 601703) For rising the sky is the only limit.
('30', 263, 3, 24, 601741) There is a limit to how low we can fall.
('30', 263, 3, 25, 601782) God Himself has created such limit in the form of land, rock, water, etc.
('30', 263, 3, 26, 601856) Hence we need not despair.
('30', 263, 3, 27, 601883) I advise the people to take the fullest advantage of the Ruler, and should like to say to the latter that he has done much, but much more needs to be done.

('30', 264, 1, 2, 602125) The Ruler and the subjects should develop the completest mutual understanding and confidence.

('30', 264, 12, 20, 603097) 139. VYKOM SATYAGRAHA
('30', 264, 13, 21, 603119) Here is a letter from a Vykom satyagrahi:
('30', 265, 0, 1, 603161) 266 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 265, 1, 2, 603203) Your kind card to hand.
('30', 265, 1, 3, 603227) The Travancore Legislative Council yesterday voted by 22 against 21 against the right of entry to the Vykom temple road for which purpose satyagraha is now being offered.
('30', 265, 1, 4, 603398) Naturally people here are very much agitated and feel aggrieved all the more, because the voting was gained by the direct pressure brought by the Government on the voters.
('30', 265, 1, 5, 603570) I am ashamed to say, one member of the depressed and prohibited classes himself voted against the entry and sided with the Government.
('30', 265, 1, 6, 603705) The situation hereafter is fraught with all kinds of difficulties.
('30', 265, 1, 7, 603772) There is very little enthusiasm now for the peacecful methods of satyagraha.
('30', 265, 1, 8, 603849) Some have already begun to advocate “direct action” and even forcible entry into temples.
('30', 265, 1, 9, 603939) Small pox has broken out in the Satyagraha Camp itself and with the growing heat of the advancing summer it may attack more and more.
('30', 265, 1, 10, 604073) We are carrying the struggle with faith in your leadership and gospel of non violence.
('30', 265, 1, 11, 604160) But I am afraid the Provincial Congress Committee of Kerala is waning in its enthusiasm.
('30', 265, 1, 12, 604249) They have collected very little money during the last many months by their own efforts.
('30', 265, 1, 13, 604337) For everything we depend on your own esteemed help and advice.
('30', 265, 1, 14, 604400) We are hard up for money.
('30', 265, 1, 15, 604426) All satyagrahis are anxiously awaiting your forthcoming visit which would, it is needless to say, be of inestimable help to our cause.
('30', 265, 1, 16, 604561) It is a good letter because it is a frank letter.
('30', 265, 1, 17, 604611) I am unable to congratulate the Travancore Government, if the facts are as stated.
('30', 265, 1, 18, 604694) But I do not know them.
('30', 265, 1, 19, 604718) I therefore suspend my judgment till I know them first hand .
('30', 265, 1, 20, 604780) I am eager to visit Vykom at the earliest possible date.
('30', 265, 1, 21, 604837) I hope that it will not be long.
('30', 265, 1, 22, 604870) Meanwhile, satyagrahis must not be dejected.
('30', 265, 1, 23, 604915) They dare not give way to despair.
('30', 265, 1, 24, 604950) Of all my Tamil lessons one proverb at least abides with me as an evergreen.
('30', 265, 1, 25, 605027) Its literal meaning is, “God is the only Help for the helpless”.
('30', 265, 1, 26, 605092) The grand theory of satyagraha is built upon a belief in that truth.
('30', 265, 1, 27, 605161) Hindu religious literature, indeed all religious literature, is full of illustrations to prove the truth.
('30', 265, 1, 28, 605267) The Travancore Durbar may have failed them.
('30', 265, 1, 29, 605311) I may fail them.
('30', 265, 1, 30, 605328) But God will never fail them, if they have faith in Him.
('30', 265, 1, 31, 605385) Let them know that they are leaning on a broken reed if they are relying on me.
('30', 265, 1, 32, 605465) I am living at a safe distance from them.
('30', 265, 1, 33, 605507) I may wipe their tears, but suffering is their sole privilege.
('30', 265, 1, 34, 605570) And victory will surely come out of their sufferings provided they are pure.
('30', 265, 1, 35, 605647) God tries His votaries through and through, but never beyond endurance.
('30', 265, 1, 36, 605719) He gives them strength enough to go through the ordeal He prescribes for them.
('30', 265, 1, 37, 605798) For the satyagrahis of Vykom their satyagraha is not a mere experiment to be given up if it does not succeed within a prescribed time or after a prescribed force
('30', 266, 0, 1, 605960) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 267
('30', 266, 1, 2, 606006) of suffering.
('30', 266, 1, 3, 606020) There is no time limit for a satyagrahi nor is there a limit to his capacity for suffering.
('30', 266, 1, 4, 606112) Hence there is no such thing as defeat in satyagraha.
('30', 266, 1, 5, 606166) Their so called defeat may be the dawn of victory.
('30', 266, 1, 6, 606217) It may be the agony of birth.
('30', 266, 1, 7, 606247) The Vykom satyagrahis are fighting a battle of no less consequence than that of swaraj.

('30', 267, 1, 2, 608226) 140. HINDU MUSLIM QUESTION
('30', 267, 2, 3, 608253) A correspondent writes:
('30', 267, 3, 4, 608277) You have entertained in the columns of Young India an attempt made by one of your correspondents to show up the shibboleth of the Muslims’ extreme backwardness in education.
('30', 267, 3, 5, 608451) That emboldens me, if you will permit an humble worker in the country’s cause, to put before you one more of these shibboleths which has been ruling our political life for long, but which is palpably more absurd than the one as regards Muslim backwardness to which I am glad your attention has at last been drawn.
('30', 267, 4, 6, 608765) “The Muslims are a minority in India.” How often is such a statement
('30', 267, 5, 7, 608834) made, and how many times more is it tacitly assumed in political argument!
('30', 267, 5, 8, 608909) But are they really a minority?
('30', 267, 5, 9, 608941) Even taking one sect of them, viz., the Sunni Henafi, for comparison, do we not find that it is numerically stronger by far than any single community amongst the Hindus, or even than each of the other religious groups in India, as the Christians, Parsis, Sikhs, Jains, Jews and Buddhists?
('30', 267, 5, 10, 609230) And is it not the case that the Hindus are divided into communities and sects which are in most cases farther apart from one another socially than the Muslims are from the non Muslims?
('30', 267, 5, 11, 609415) Then, what about the Hindu untouchables?
('30', 267, 5, 12, 609456) Is not their number equal to, if not greater than, that of the Muslim “minority”?
('30', 267, 5, 13, 609538) If Muslims as “a minority” in India may claim separate and special treatment, protection and guarantees, how much stronger must the claim of this untouchable section of Hindus be allowed to be, since they not only are by their numbers as important a “minority”—and a claimant one too, since the date of the Lucknow Pact 1, —but have been suffering for ages from actual present disabilities with which no Muslim or any other touchable minority’s apprehensions for the future may possibly bear comparison?
('30', 267, 5, 14, 610042) As witness the Vykom satyagraha, the palghat dispute, the Bombay “lynchers”.
('30', 267, 5, 15, 610119) I leave alone the innumerable backward castes and the aborigines so far reckoned within the Hindu fold.
('30', 267, 5, 16, 610223) Are the Muslims then the minority?
('30', 267, 5, 17, 610258) The italics and the black types are the writer’s.
('30', 267, 5, 18, 610308) I have given the letter for its undoubted earnestness.
('30', 267, 5, 19, 610363) And yet to me, an ob server untouched, I hope, by any bias one way or the other, the reasoning appears to be specious when it is used to demonstrate that the Mussalmans are not a minority in India.
('30', 267, 5, 20, 610561) The writer forgets that the claim is that of all Mussalmans against all Hindus.
('30', 267, 5, 21, 610641) The latter cannot
('30', 267, 6, 22, 610659) 1 The joint scheme of reforms adopted by the Indian National Congress and Muslim League at their sessions in Lucknow in 1916
('30', 268, 0, 1, 610784) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 269
('30', 268, 1, 2, 610830) both have the cake and eat it.
('30', 268, 1, 3, 610861) Though divided among themselves, the Hindus do present a more or less united front not only to the Mus salmans but to all non Hindus, even as the Mussalmans though divided among themselves present naturally a united front to all non Muslims.
('30', 268, 1, 4, 611103) We shall never solve the question by ignoring facts or re arranging them to suit our plans.
('30', 268, 1, 5, 611195) The facts are that the Mussalmans are seven crores against twenty two crores of Hindus.
('30', 268, 1, 6, 611283) The latter have never denied it.
('30', 268, 1, 7, 611316) Let us also know the issues.
('30', 268, 1, 8, 611345) A minority does not always fear a majority be cause it is a majority.
('30', 268, 1, 9, 611415) The Mussalmans fear the Hindu majority because the Hindus, they say, have not always treated them with justice, have not respected their religious prejudices and because, they say, the Hindus are superior to them in education and wealth.
('30', 268, 1, 10, 611653) Whether these are facts or not is irrelevant for our purpose.
('30', 268, 1, 11, 611715) It is enough that Mussalmans believe them and therefore are afraid of the Hindu majority.
('30', 268, 1, 12, 611805) The Mussalmans expect to meet this fear only partially be means of separate electorates and special represen tation even in excess of their number in some cases.
('30', 268, 1, 13, 611967) The Hindus admit the Mussalman minority but deny the Mussalman charge of injustice.
('30', 268, 1, 14, 612051) This must therefore be verifed.
('30', 268, 1, 15, 612083) I have not known Hindus to deny the statement that they are superior to Mussalmans in education and wealth.
('30', 268, 2, 16, 612191) The Hindus on their part fear the Mussalmans because they (the Hindus) say that Mussalmans whenever they have held power have treated them with great harshness and contend that though they were in a majority they were non plussed by a handful of Mussalman invaders, that the danger of a repetition of the experience is ever present before the Hindus, and that in spite of the sincerity of the leading Mussalmans the Mussalman masses are bound to make common cause with any Mussalman adventurer.
('30', 268, 2, 17, 612686) The Hindus therefore reject the plea of weakness on the part of the Mussalmans and refuse to entertain the idea of extending the doctrine of the Lucknow Pact.
('30', 268, 2, 18, 612845) It is again beside the question whether the Hindu fear is justified.
('30', 268, 2, 19, 612914) The fear is a fact to be reckoned with.
('30', 268, 2, 20, 612954) It would be wrong to impute motives to any community or leaders.
('30', 268, 2, 21, 613019) To distrust Malaviyaji or Mian Fazl i Hussain is to postpone a proper solution.
('30', 268, 2, 22, 613099) Both honestly state what they feel.
('30', 268, 2, 23, 613135) Wisdom lies therefore in brushing aside all side issues and facing the situation as it is, not as we would like it to be.
('30', 268, 2, 24, 613257) In my opinion therefore the writer has tried, be it ever so unconsciously, to overprove his case.
('30', 268, 2, 25, 613355) He is right in saying that Hindus
('30', 269, 0, 1, 613389) 270 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 269, 1, 2, 613431) are divided into many antagonistic sects or parties each setting up a claim or separate treatment.

('30', 269, 1, 4, 613653) The writer has made out a case not against the fact of Mussalman minority but against communal representation and separate electorates.
('30', 269, 1, 5, 613789) He has shown that any extension of the doctrine of the Lucknow Pact must inevitably lead to communal representation for innumerable sub castes and other denominations, thus indefinitely postponing the early advent of swaraj.

('30', 269, 1, 9, 614315) Such a solution is not impossible.
('30', 269, 1, 10, 614350) Here is one.
('30', 269, 1, 11, 614363) In my opinion the Mussalman claim for majority in Bengal and the Punjab in accordance with their numbers is irresistible.
('30', 269, 1, 12, 614485) That claim cannot be resisted for the fear from the north or the North West.
('30', 269, 1, 13, 614562) Hindus, if they want swaraj, must take the chance.
('30', 269, 1, 14, 614613) So long as we fear the outside world, we must cease to think of swaraj.
('30', 269, 1, 15, 614685) But swaraj we must have.
('30', 269, 1, 16, 614710) I would therefore rule out the Hindu fear in considering the just claim of the Mussalmans.
('30', 269, 1, 17, 614801) We must dare to do justice even at the cost of future safety.
('30', 269, 1, 18, 614863) What the Mussalmans want is not separate electorate for its own sake but they want their own real representatives to be sent to the legislatures and other elective bodies.
('30', 269, 1, 19, 615035) This can be done by private arrangement rather than legal imposition.
('30', 269, 1, 20, 615105) There is flexibility about private arrangement.
('30', 269, 1, 21, 615153) A legal imposition tends to become more and more rigid.
('30', 269, 1, 22, 615209) Private arrangement will continually test the honour and good faith of each party.
('30', 269, 1, 23, 615292) Legal imposition avoids the necessity of honour or good faith.
('30', 269, 1, 24, 615355) Private arrangement means a domestic settle ment of domestic quarrels and a solid wall of united opposition against a common enemy—the foreign rule.
('30', 269, 1, 25, 615504) I am told that the law prevents the working of the private arrangement I have in view.
('30', 269, 1, 26, 615591) If it is so, we must seek to remove the legal obstacle and not create and add a new one.
('30', 269, 1, 27, 615680) My plan therefore is to do away with separate electorates but secure the elec tion of the desired and agreed number of Mussalman and other candidates in a given constituency under a joint ticket, Mussalman candidates o be nominated by previously known Mussal

('30', 270, 1, 2, 615986) man associations.
('30', 270, 1, 3, 616004) I need not enter into the question of representation in excess of numbers at the present stage.
('30', 270, 1, 4, 616100) It can be considered and all difficulties in that direction can be met when the principle of private arrangement is accepted by all.

('30', 272, 4, 16, 621687) 1. In Bengal the untouchables are not allowed to draw water from the wells, nor are they allowed to enter the room where drinking water is kept.

('30', 272, 5, 20, 622177) What should be done to wean them from the error?

('30', 272, 6, 22, 622380) My answers are: 1. One way of removing the evil is for us to take water from the hands of the untouchables.
('30', 272, 6, 23, 622488) I do not think that digging of separate

('30', 275, 2, 3, 627859) THE LATEST DISCOVERY
('30', 275, 3, 4, 627880) Since my return from Pindi I have visited nearly ten villages of Borsad taluk.
('30', 275, 3, 5, 627959) It is a taluk of the successful and glorious satyagraha of 1923 under Mr. Vallabhbhai Patel’s leadership.
('30', 275, 3, 6, 628065) It contains an intelligent, able and comparatively hard population.
('30', 275, 3, 7, 628133) But even in this taluk I was pained to find in some villages squalor and degradation that were due purely to poverty.
('30', 275, 3, 8, 628251) The crops were damaged by a severe frost.
('30', 275, 3, 9, 628293) In certain villages the people were in constant danger of having their fields raided by cattle lot loose upon them at the instance practically of the principal landowner.
('30', 275, 3, 10, 628464) It was not possible for them to feel settled in life or feel that they had a home of their own which they could take pride in.
('30', 275, 3, 11, 628591) The result was despair and consequent indifference to effort.
('30', 275, 3, 12, 628653) There was nothing but the charkha for such people.
('30', 275, 3, 13, 628704) But even the charkha makes slow headway.
('30', 275, 3, 14, 628745) They do not want to do anything.
('30', 275, 3, 15, 628778) They want merely to eke out a living somehow.
('30', 275, 3, 16, 628824) “We have gone on like this for years, let us close our lives like this”, is the reply written in their blank and incredulous looks.
('30', 275, 3, 17, 628956) It is the same thing to them even if one presented them with some other industry.
('30', 275, 3, 18, 629038) They do not want to work because they have hither to slaved.
('30', 275, 3, 19, 629099) And having only done that, they believe in slaving but not in working.
('30', 275, 3, 20, 629170) This is a sad discovery not made by me for the first time.
('30', 275, 3, 21, 629229) It was the same thing in Champaran, worse in Orissa.
('30', 275, 3, 22, 629282) But it came upon me in Borsad taluk with a strange and overwhelming force.
('30', 275, 3, 23, 629357) I was ill prepared for the discovery in this taluk.
('30', 275, 3, 24, 629409) On the contrary I had expected to find well ordered villages where I would see enthusiasm and brightness and hope.
('30', 275, 3, 25, 629524) Not that all the villages were alike.
('30', 275, 3, 26, 629562) Although they are so near one another, each has problems of its own and each has a distinct individually.
('30', 275, 3, 27, 629668) For the villages I have described, the spinning wheel is the only hope, if there is any.
('30', 275, 3, 28, 629757) Cattle cannot raid it.
('30', 275, 3, 29, 629780) Frost cannot bite it.
('30', 275, 3, 30, 629802) It is man’s protection against cruel nature’s ravages and some protection against man’s depradations.
('30', 275, 3, 31, 629904) Ample work awaits those patriotic young men who do not mind the village life and who can derive pleasure from silent and sustained labour, not too taxing and yet taxing enough for its monotony.
('30', 275, 3, 32, 630098) It requires sufficient application to be able to appreciate the monotony of life giving industry.
('30', 275, 3, 33, 630196) A beginner of music knows the dullness of the initial effort but the very monotony becomes a pleasure as soon as he has mastered the art.
('30', 275, 3, 34, 630334) So it is with the village workers.
('30', 275, 3, 35, 630369) As soon as they
('30', 276, 0, 1, 630385) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 277
('30', 276, 1, 2, 630431) have lived down the excitement of the intoxicating town life and settled down to work, the monotony of labour will give strength and hope because it is productive.
('30', 276, 1, 3, 630595) Who is ever jaded by the monotonous and unfailing regularity with which the solar system works.
('30', 276, 1, 4, 630691) Though as ancient as time, it has never ceased to excite wonder and praise.
('30', 276, 1, 5, 630767) We know, too, that a disturbance in the even tenor of its working means destruction of our race.
('30', 276, 1, 6, 630864) So it is with the village solar system whose centre is the wheel.

('30', 283, 3, 12, 647755) Your help too is needed.
('30', 283, 3, 13, 647780) Many Hindus tell me: “You take their side; but you should see for yourself how these people live.

('30', 285, 6, 14, 651179) Today we feel keenly the absence of Shivlalbhai 1. You have heard about the services he rendered to Kathiawar and to the country.
('30', 285, 6, 15, 651309) It is India’s misfortune that those worthy men who pass away are not replaced.
('30', 285, 6, 16, 651388) Everyone is destined to pass away.
('30', 285, 6, 17, 651423) Life and death form a pair and there should neither be happiness nor sorrow concerning them.
('30', 285, 6, 18, 651516) Nevertheless we grieve when someone dies.
('30', 285, 6, 19, 651558) But I feel that such grief springs from one’s self interest.
('30', 285, 6, 20, 651619) The revered memory of Shivlalbhai reminds me of the extent of our own loss.
('30', 285, 6, 21, 651695) If we want his memory to live for ever, we should take his place.
('30', 285, 6, 22, 651761) We should feel no shame in surpassing him in work.
('30', 285, 6, 23, 651812) One should be ashamed only if one does not add to one’s inheritance.
('30', 285, 6, 24, 651881) One is considered a true descendant only if one adds to one’s inheritance.
('30', 285, 6, 25, 651956) Our duty is to add to Shivlalbhai’s legacy.
('30', 285, 6, 26, 652000) I am sorry that this has not been done.
('30', 285, 6, 27, 652040) It is my ambition that khadi work should become every man’s job and it should enter every village.

('30', 287, 2, 5, 654799) On my returning to India [from Africa], I [first] went to Ahmedabad, consulted the citizens there, placed my views before them and established my Ashram there only after they had agreed to support and help me for one year.
('30', 287, 2, 6, 655022) In my consultations with them I had also spoken of my views on the issue of Antyajas.

('30', 288, 2, 10, 657610) 152. SPEECH AT OPENING OF NURSERY SCHOOL,
('30', 288, 3, 11, 657652) WADHWAN February 21, 1925
('30', 288, 4, 12, 657678) I am supposed to take away with me this lock and key, as also this trowel which has not been soiled with earth at all.
('30', 288, 4, 13, 657797) The gold coins which Shri Dhorajiwala has given to me, I will hand over to Fulchan dbhai.
('30', 288, 4, 14, 657887) Both these things have a meaning.
('30', 288, 4, 15, 657921) A good many activities are going on in the country at present; who can say how many of them are genuine, or what self sacrifice and sincerity of effort lie behind them?
('30', 288, 4, 16, 658090) I, for one, do not know.
('30', 288, 4, 17, 658115) All that I know is that of the innumerable institutions which are being run in the country at present, a few, we can say, have life in them.
('30', 288, 4, 18, 658256) An English poet has said, describing Heaven, that St. Peter stands guard at its gate, and the key with which he opens the gate is of iron and not of gold.
('30', 288, 4, 19, 658411) 1 Explaining this, another poet has said that it is not easy to open the gate of Heaven, that it cannot be opened with a key made of gold since gold is a rather soft metal, whereas iron is supposed to be one of the strongest metals.
('30', 288, 4, 20, 658644) The gate, therefore, can be opened only with a key made of iron.
('30', 288, 4, 21, 658709) Here in Kathiawar we say of a very difficult task that it is as difficult as chewing iron pellets.
('30', 288, 4, 22, 658808) Running an institution like this is a task of that kind.
('30', 288, 4, 23, 658865) For building the walls of a library, a trowel made of silver can be of no use.

('30', 288, 4, 25, 658970) Likewise, we cannot use a silver padlock for locking its doors.
('30', 288, 4, 26, 659034) We must have an iron one.
('30', 288, 4, 27, 659060) There is, thus, an artificiality about the first steps we have taken in doing both these things.

('30', 289, 1, 3, 659515) A library does not mean a building containing books, or the books in it, or idle visitors who do not read the books.

('30', 291, 0, 1, 664805) 292 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('30', 291, 1, 4, 664983) I am told that such a large number of pupils are enrolled in the school at Wankaner because its results at examinations are one hundred per cent.
('30', 291, 1, 5, 665129) This a narrow way of measuring its worth.

('30', 291, 3, 12, 665910) 153. MY NOTES
('30', 291, 4, 13, 665924) KHADI IN UTKAL
('30', 291, 5, 14, 665939) From Calcutta Shri Shankerlal Banker writes about Utkal, i.e., Orissa: 1
('30', 291, 6, 15, 666012) There is no other province as poor as Utkal.
('30', 291, 6, 16, 666057) Khadi work, therefore, could progress better there than anywhere else.
('30', 291, 6, 17, 666128) But the above letter tells us that the work done there is the poorest.
('30', 291, 6, 18, 666199) The reason is well known.
('30', 291, 6, 19, 666225) Where food is scarce, energy and enthusiasm for work disappear.
('30', 291, 6, 20, 666289) If good workers are steadily forthcoming, Utkal can be trusted to overtake all other provinces.
('30', 291, 7, 21, 666385) YARN IN ADDITION TO KHADI
('30', 291, 8, 22, 666411) A gentleman writes: “Will it not be much better if, instead of purchasing hand spun yarn and sending it to you, we send you the requisite amount for khadi and wear it?” There is a misunderstanding behind this question.
('30', 291, 8, 23, 666630) The Congress has demanded not one of the two things, but both of them.
('30', 291, 8, 24, 666701) First, everyone should send 2,000 yards of hand spun yarn every month whether spun by oneself or someone
('30', 291, 9, 25, 666806) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('30', 291, 9, 26, 666843) It gave details of khadi work in Orissa.
('30', 292, 0, 1, 666884) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 293
('30', 292, 1, 2, 666930) Secondly, everyone should wear khadi.
('30', 292, 1, 3, 666968) And so there is no alternative, but the two together are obligatory.
('30', 292, 1, 4, 667037) A mere spinner cannot become a Congress member nor can a mere khadi wearer.
('30', 292, 1, 5, 667113) And this is quite right.
('30', 292, 1, 6, 667138) By making spinning universal we shall increase the production of khadi and by making the use of khadi universal we shall increase the consumption of khadi.
('30', 292, 1, 7, 667294) That along will remove starvation from India.
('30', 292, 2, 8, 667340) A WOMAN’S OBJECTION
('30', 292, 3, 9, 667360) This gentleman further writes: “When I went to persuade a woman to wear khadi, she objected: ‘If I wear khadi, my husband may be attracted by a woman using foreign or mill cloth and thus lose his character.” I cannot expect such a reply from any virtuous woman.
('30', 292, 3, 10, 667622) But since the issue has been raised it should be considered.
('30', 292, 3, 11, 667683) If any husband deviates from his moral course simply because his wife observes simplicity or performs her duty, then the virtuous wife should scarcely care for him.
('30', 292, 3, 12, 667848) A man’s character is not worth anything if he could be tempted merely by another woman’s clothes.
('30', 292, 3, 13, 667946) A husband who is seduced by a change in dress can also be seduced by a more beautiful woman.
('30', 292, 3, 14, 668039) My experience, however, is contrary to the statement of this woman.
('30', 292, 3, 15, 668107) I know hundreds of husbands who have been delighted to find their wives in khadi clothes.
('30', 292, 3, 16, 668197) Their household expenditure has been reduced and their love for their khadi clad wives has grown.
('30', 292, 3, 17, 668295) But it is also possible that this sister had no mind to use khadi and so unawares she might have raised this unworthy objection.
('30', 292, 3, 18, 668424) I appeal to the sisters who think like her to take boldly to khadi and realize that beauty does not consist in dress but in purity of character, and clothes are not meant for adornment but for protecting the body from heat and cold.

('30', 294, 1, 4, 671577) The experiment that His Highness the Thakore Saheb of Rajkot is making with a Representative Assembly he has founded, says Mr. Gandhi, is deeply interesting, though it is yet too early to give any definite opinion about it.
('30', 294, 1, 5, 671801) From what he has come to know of it, however, makes him hopeful of success.
('30', 294, 1, 6, 671877) Wankaner has made primary education compulsory in Wankaner itself and amongst the higher classes.
('30', 294, 1, 7, 671975) Mr. Gandhi remarked: It is sign of the times that in all these places I noticed among the people the keenest desire for total prohibition.
('30', 294, 1, 8, 672114) In Rajkot it is most keen ly felt, because there an unhealthy an ugly competition is going on bet ween the State liquor shops and the Civil Station liquor shops.
('30', 294, 1, 9, 672276) The result is that the prices have considerably gone down and the lower classes are taking to liquor more than ever before.
('30', 294, 1, 10, 672400) Their womenfolk are bitterly complaining about the havoc that is being played in their families owing to men returning day after day in a drunken state.
('30', 294, 1, 11, 672553) People are urging the Thakore Saheb to abolish liquor shops altogether.
('30', 294, 1, 12, 672625) The latter is reluctant to do so on the ground of individual liberty.
('30', 294, 1, 13, 672695) He is of opinion that temperance should be brought about by preaching.
('30', 294, 1, 14, 672766) The State Assembly has unanimously passed a resolution requesting the Darbar to close all licensed liquor shops, and prohibit distillation of liquor except for medicinal purposes, if necessary.
('30', 294, 1, 15, 672960) It will be interesting to learn how the Thakore Saheb deals with this resolution.

('30', 297, 1, 2, 675390) 161. LETTER TO SHAUKAT ALI
('30', 297, 2, 3, 675417) SABARMATI, February 23, 1925
('30', 297, 3, 4, 675446) MY DEAR FRIEND & BROTHER,
('30', 297, 4, 5, 675472) I have read today your commentary on my statement on Kohat.
('30', 297, 4, 6, 675532) I honour you and love you all the more for your out spokenness.
('30', 297, 4, 7, 675596) But your commentary shows how with all the detachment and impartiality in the world sometimes people most closely related as we are can come to opposite conclusions on identical facts.
('30', 297, 4, 8, 675781) It makes me more charitable than ever towards opponents and more distrustful of my judgment even than I am.
('30', 297, 4, 9, 675889) I have twice read your commentary and I see the wide gulf that separates us in the affair.
('30', 297, 4, 10, 675980) I am prepared to strongly condemn the publication of the poem but I am unable to condone the looting and arson.
('30', 297, 4, 11, 676092) I do not endorse your opinion that the pamphlet was the cause of the conflagration.
('30', 297, 4, 12, 676176) The ground was already prepared.
('30', 297, 4, 13, 676209) I cannot treat the conversions as lightly as you seem to do.
('30', 297, 4, 14, 676270) In my opinion the Khilafatists have greatly neglected their duty and Maulvi Ahmed Gul certainly betrayed the trust reposed in him.
('30', 297, 4, 15, 676401) I do not say these things to influence your opinion if there is no cause for it.
('30', 297, 4, 16, 676482) But I do want you to look more deeply into the facts than you have done and see whether there is cause for reconsideration.
('30', 297, 4, 17, 676606) I tremble to publish our statements.
('30', 297, 4, 18, 676643) The publication will give rise to an acrimonious discussion.
('30', 297, 4, 19, 676704) I would therefore even suggest the whole matter being examined by Hakim Saheb or Dr. Ansari.
('30', 297, 4, 20, 676797) I would love to have new light on the question.
('30', 297, 4, 21, 676845) I would like all the friends to look at the facts and try to influence us both.
('30', 297, 4, 22, 676925) But if after we have exhausted all our resources to come to a joint conclusion, we fail, we must dare to let the public know our difference of opinion and know too that we shall still love one another and work together.
('30', 297, 4, 23, 677145) But that very love demands that we take no hasty action.
('30', 297, 4, 24, 677202) Are you coming to Delhi?
('30', 297, 4, 25, 677227) If you are, let us travel together.
('30', 297, 4, 26, 677263) I leave by the metergauge on 27th.
('30', 297, 4, 27, 677298) But if you are coming and you would rather leave by the Punjab Mail I would join you at Baroda.
('30', 297, 4, 28, 677394) It may be advisable to have leisurely discussion between us.
('30', 297, 4, 29, 677455) The train seems to be the best place for such discussion.
('30', 297, 4, 30, 677513) Do let me know what you would like to do.
('30', 297, 4, 31, 677555) Please wire if
('30', 298, 0, 1, 677570) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 299
('30', 298, 1, 2, 677616) possible.
('30', 298, 1, 3, 677626) I am not publishing the statement this week.
('30', 298, 1, 4, 677671) With love,
('30', 298, 2, 5, 677682) Yours, M. K. GANDHI [PS.] I am glad you are taking Kuhne treatment.
('30', 298, 2, 6, 677750) You certainly need plenty of exercise.

('30', 301, 5, 10, 681051) 170. SPEECH AT AHMEDABAD 2
('30', 301, 6, 11, 681078) February 25, 1925
('30', 301, 7, 12, 681096) Prayer time is the best time for words of blessing.
('30', 301, 7, 13, 681148) On two earlier occasions, when young people who grew up in the Ashram were married off, many among us did not appreciate the significance of the occasion.
('30', 301, 7, 14, 681303) Whoever comes to the Ashram, whether children or married men, would like to observe brahmacharya; and, therefore, how can marriage be solemnized in the Ashram where is the aim is to encourage everyone in the observance of brahmacharya ?
('30', 301, 7, 15, 681540) It is natural that the question should arise in the minds of many people; and yet three marriages came to be solemnized here.
('30', 301, 7, 16, 681666) Though the regulations of the Ashram are strict, we are unable to enforce discipline.
('30', 301, 7, 17, 681752) It is not easy to impart training in brahmacharya to young persons.
('30', 301, 7, 18, 681820) Not that older folk are able to observe brahmacharya strictly.
('30', 301, 7, 19, 681883) To fulfil an ideal, one should have ardour in one’s heart.
('30', 301, 7, 20, 681942) The subject is so profound that the more I delve into it, the more aweinspiring it seems and I see its beauty and drink deep of its delights.
('30', 301, 7, 21, 682084) We can’t use force on the young people whom we keep in the Ashram.
('30', 301, 7, 22, 682151) It happens sometimes that marriages cannot be avoided.
('30', 301, 8, 23, 682206) 1 This sentence is in English.
('30', 301, 8, 24, 682237) 2 Blessing the couple on the occasion of the marriage of Dahyabhai Patel.
('30', 301, 8, 25, 682311) Vide also “My Notes”, 29 3 1925.
('30', 302, 0, 1, 682344) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 303
('30', 302, 1, 2, 682390) There were three such cases.
('30', 302, 1, 3, 682419) In order to pacify my mind I took the one way out.
('30', 302, 1, 4, 682470) The ceremonial should be performed outside the precincts of the Ashram.
('30', 302, 1, 5, 682542) One should get married without deceiving the inner self or the outer world.
('30', 302, 1, 6, 682618) And then one should come to the Ashram and receive everyone’s blessings.
('30', 302, 1, 7, 682691) If marry one must, it should not be to indulge the senses but to practise self control—this must be made clear to the married couple as well as the inmates of the Ashram.
('30', 302, 1, 8, 682862) Inmates should not eagerly look forward to wedding occasions.
('30', 302, 1, 9, 682924) It is a different matter if they can’t be avoided.
('30', 302, 1, 10, 682975) That is an event linking the soul and God.
('30', 302, 1, 11, 683018) That is why in English the soul is feminine in gender.
('30', 302, 1, 12, 683073) Jaydev has also descried the soul as a feminine entity sporting with the Supreme Being.
('30', 302, 1, 13, 683161) Little remains to be done in this world after such marriage of spirits.
('30', 302, 1, 14, 683233) If marriages must take place even when this union of souls does not obtain, well, let it be so.
('30', 302, 1, 15, 683329) It is necessary for me to tell you on this, the fourth, occasion that marriage is not meant for greed but for sacrifice.
('30', 302, 1, 16, 683450) Resolve that even if you wish to derive sense pleasure from this relationship, you will do so within limits.
('30', 302, 1, 17, 683559) Among us the rule of fidelity is meant for women only, though the last four morsels given to [the couple] while solemnizing the marriage stand for the union of flesh, spirit and bone.
('30', 302, 1, 18, 683743) It is a pity we did not lay down a similar rule for men.
('30', 302, 1, 19, 683800) Therefore I can only say that you must live in moderation and realize that the pleasures of the body should be only a means of procreation.
('30', 302, 1, 20, 683940) Who has the right to give birth to a child in these terrible times?
('30', 302, 1, 21, 684008) Countless persons in India observe brahmacharya and many in Europe as well.
('30', 302, 1, 22, 684084) Among Roman Catholics, there are many adult men and women who observe brahmacharya throughout their life.
('30', 302, 1, 23, 684190) An eighteen year old girl walks out of worldly life andobserves unbroken brahmacharya.
('30', 302, 1, 24, 684277) They have monastries and nunneries where such men and women live.
('30', 302, 1, 25, 684343) In these hard times no one in India has the right to beget children.
('30', 302, 1, 26, 684412) No one has at any time the right to bear children before one is strong enough.
('30', 302, 1, 27, 684491) I wanted the marriage to be solemnized in the Ashram, because the priest performing the rites would explain their significance and you could thus learn that marriage is not a matter of pleasure but of self control.
('30', 302, 1, 28, 684706) Both of you, therefore, should understand this occasion and remember it.
('30', 302, 1, 29, 684779) I have taken upon myself one responsibility and I will never regret it.
('30', 302, 1, 30, 684851) The result is bound to be beneficent.
('30', 302, 1, 31, 684889) You know my relations with Vallabhbhai.
('30', 302, 1, 32, 684929) He asked me of his own free will that
('30', 303, 0, 1, 684967) 304 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 303, 1, 2, 685009) this marriage be solemnized by me.
('30', 303, 1, 3, 685044) Kashibhai was also favourable to the idea.
('30', 303, 1, 4, 685087) There is no need for spending lots of money on a marriage.
('30', 303, 1, 5, 685146) It is penance that is needed.
('30', 303, 1, 6, 685176) Outside the Ashram a marriage cannot take place without money being spent, for you cannot have only the religious rite, leaving out things like barat 1. That is why the marriage has been solemnized here.
('30', 303, 1, 7, 685380) The seed that is sown will grow into a tree.
('30', 303, 1, 8, 685425) But be worthy of your parents to nurture that seed and eschew worldly pleasures.
('30', 303, 1, 9, 685506) For not spending money, the motive was not stinginess, and it certainly was not greed.
('30', 303, 1, 10, 685593) Such expenditure bears heavily on the Patidar families and our intention was to save them from it altogether.
('30', 303, 1, 11, 685703) I have known Dahyabhai for a long time and Yashoda too.
('30', 303, 1, 12, 685759) I feel confident that they are strong enough through self control to add lustre to this marriage.
('30', 303, 1, 13, 685857) All these things which I say to inmates of the Ashram can not be said too often.
('30', 303, 1, 14, 685938) I do not mean to seek out such occasions, for that is not my vocation.
('30', 303, 1, 15, 686009) But if they arise, I perform the ceremonies in the hope that self control can be strengthened thus.
('30', 303, 1, 16, 686109) This may well be an illu sion.
('30', 303, 1, 17, 686140) I do not wish not to take the chance if it comes.
('30', 303, 1, 18, 686190) But I wish for all of you that you develop more self control through such occasions.
('30', 303, 1, 19, 686275) That is why we are all assembled here.
('30', 303, 1, 20, 686314) Let us pray to God that we may attain our ideals and we may bring up men and women here who do not think about marriage and procreation, but who regard all children as their own, and who spend their lives in serving children who have no sunshine in their lives.
('30', 303, 1, 21, 686576) Dahyabhai and Yashoda must think for themselves and realize how great is their responsibility.
('30', 303, 1, 22, 686671) It seems to me as if they have lost their freedom today.
('30', 303, 1, 23, 686728) But this state too can be beautiful.
('30', 303, 1, 24, 686765) Let them be happy and restrained.
('30', 303, 1, 25, 686799) Let them breathe the spirit of sacrifice and be worthy of their parents and also of us; so that no one may feel like asking why this marriage was celebrated in the Ashram.
('30', 303, 2, 26, 686971) [From Gujarati]

('30', 303, 4, 28, 687022) 171. THE EMBARGO
('30', 303, 5, 29, 687039) I publish the following telegraphic correspondence between the Private Secretary to H.E. the Viceroy and myself.
('30', 303, 6, 30, 687152) 1 Marriage party
('30', 304, 0, 1, 687169) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 305
('30', 304, 1, 2, 687215) TELEGRAM TO THE PRIVATE SECRETARY TO THE VICEROY 1
('30', 304, 2, 3, 687266) REPLY TO THE ABOVE 2
('30', 304, 3, 4, 687287) SECOND TELEGRAM TO PRIVATE SECRETARY TO THE VICEROY 3
('30', 304, 4, 5, 687341) REPLY TO THE ABOVE 4 It is quite true that my going to Kohat is likely to reopen the settlement in so far as it is intrinsically bad.
('30', 304, 4, 6, 687475) It is settlement brought about my coercion, for it has been arrived at under threat of prosecu tions on either side.
('30', 304, 4, 7, 687592) It is not a voluntary settlement that pleases the parties.
('30', 304, 4, 8, 687651) Both the Hindus and the Mussalmans whom Maulana Shaukat Ali and I met at Rawalpindi said as much.
('30', 304, 4, 9, 687749) But my visit to Kohat, whatever else it may or may not bring about, can never mean greater estrangement between the parties.
('30', 304, 4, 10, 687874) If, therefore, I had been permitted together with Mussalman friends to proceed to Kohat it would have meant furtherance of peace which the Viceroy claims to have at heart equally with me.
('30', 304, 4, 11, 688062) Whilst, therefore, I was able somewhat to understand the refusal when the things were still in a ferment, I am unable to understand the prohibition at the present moment.
('30', 304, 4, 12, 688233) Friends were not wanting who suggested that I should have proceeded to Kohat without permission or intimation and taken the risk of a prohibition order.
('30', 304, 4, 13, 688386) I could not do so unless I meant to disobey any such order and court imprisonment.
('30', 304, 4, 14, 688469) And as I hold that there is no atmosphere at the present moment in the country for any such step I could not take the proposed risk.
('30', 304, 4, 15, 688602) I can only hope that the authorities will appreciate the deliberation with which I am avoiding every step that may precipitate civil resistance.
('30', 304, 4, 16, 688747) My purpose so far as it is humanly possible is to avoid taking a single step that may even indirectly precipitate violence on the part of the people.
('30', 304, 4, 17, 688897) But a time must come when non violent resistance on my part may become a duty in total disregard of untoward consequences.
('30', 304, 4, 18, 689020) I do not myself know when such a time can or will come.
('30', 304, 4, 19, 689076) I know that it is a possibility.
('30', 304, 4, 20, 689109) But when that time comes I hope that friends will not find me wanting.
('30', 304, 4, 21, 689180) Till then I must ask them to bear with me.
('30', 304, 4, 22, 689223) Young India, 26 2 1925
