('30', 305, 1, 2, 689424) 172. INHUMAN IF TRUE
('30', 305, 2, 3, 689445) Shiromani Gurdwara Prabandhak Committee sends me the following telegram:
('30', 305, 3, 4, 689518) Reports from Nabha just received give harrowing details of inhuman tortures including wholesale merciless beating to unconsciousness, dragging by keshas (hair) and beards, ducking into water, putting hot iron rods on various parts of body and hanging by their feet heads downward, resulting in several deaths at the spot.
('30', 305, 3, 5, 689840) Many more are in a precarious condition.
('30', 305, 3, 6, 689881) A large number is seriously wounded.
('30', 305, 3, 7, 689918) No ration issued on 13th and 14th to some jathas 1. Great excitement prevails.
('30', 305, 3, 8, 689997) Situation extremely serious.
('30', 305, 3, 9, 690026) Immediate action necessary.
('30', 305, 3, 10, 690054) I print the telegram, but alas!
('30', 305, 3, 11, 690086) what immediate action can be taken?
('30', 305, 3, 12, 690122) Of Public sympathy the prisoners can be sure.
('30', 305, 3, 13, 690168) I have little doubt that there will be questions and usual answers in the Assembly but of what use will they be to the sufferers?
('30', 305, 3, 14, 690298) I can only hope that the picture is overdrawn and that the authorities are not guilty of the inhumanities ascribed to them.
('30', 305, 3, 15, 690422) I trust that the Administrator of Nabha will give a full explanation about the awful charges brought against the prison authorities and court an impartial inquiry into the allegations.
('30', 305, 4, 16, 690607) Young India, 26 2 1925
('30', 305, 5, 17, 690630) 173. MORE ABOUT VYKOM
('30', 305, 6, 18, 690652) The folllowing letter will be bread with painful interest by those Hindus who look upon untouchability as a crime:
('30', 305, 7, 19, 690767) We have seen your article 2 in Young India about us.
('30', 305, 7, 20, 690820) It is our fervent prayer that we do really deserve the high terms in which you have been kind enough to characterize our activities here.
('30', 305, 7, 21, 690958) On reading it we have become to some extent depressed by the sense of our own shortcomings and we are strivings our utmost to come up to the level which will satisfy you when you come here and see things actually for yourself.
('30', 305, 8, 22, 691185) In the meantime the local Legislative Council has thrown out “our resolution” by a majority of 22 to 21 votes.
('30', 305, 8, 23, 691296) The Government majority was made up of 15 officials, 3 nominated members, one Brahmin representative of vested interests and three elected members.
('30', 305, 8, 24, 691444) The constitution of the Council is
('30', 305, 9, 25, 691479) 1 Bands of satyagrahis 2Vide “Vykom Satyagraha”, 19 2 1925.
('30', 306, 0, 1, 691539) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 307
('30', 306, 1, 2, 691585) 15 officials, 7 nominated non officials and 28 elected non officials.
('30', 306, 1, 3, 691655) So of the 35 non officials 21 voted for us, two stood neutral, 7 against us and the rest were absent.
('30', 306, 1, 4, 691757) And of the 7 who voted against us, as already stated three alone were elected from the general electorate.
('30', 306, 1, 5, 691864) It is clear from the facts stated above that the Government, far from taking a neutral attitude, actually went the length of canvassing against the resolution.
('30', 306, 1, 6, 692024) You may remember that, the Regent Maharani in her reply to the caste Hindu jatha expressed a desire to know the attitude of the councils before doing anything in the matter.
('30', 306, 1, 7, 692198) Then we had expected that the Government would at least have kept a neutral attitude.
('30', 306, 1, 8, 692284) But now we find that it is not so.
('30', 306, 1, 9, 692319) It has now become clear that the Government is to a large extent acting as the real opposition where enlightened opinion is in favour of reform.
('30', 306, 1, 10, 692464) But what, however, I wished to bring to your notice is this.
('30', 306, 1, 11, 692525) The result of the resolution in the Council may prove the last straw on the camel’s back.
('30', 306, 1, 12, 692615) There are signs everywhere of an impatience at the gentle and “slow” method of satyagraha.
('30', 306, 1, 13, 692706) Even responsible leaders may fall victims to the general restlessness.
('30', 306, 1, 14, 692777) So if it is absolutely impossible for you to go over here in the near future, it must be at least possible for you to issue an authoritative statement regarding the implications of satyagraha.
('30', 306, 1, 15, 692970) Such a statement coming from you is bound to have the healthiest effect on minds that have begun to waver in the face of the present heavy odds.
('30', 306, 1, 16, 693115) Some people have begun to advocate social ostracism of the high castes, non co operation and so many other methods, all of which are more or less dangerous in the present state of our society.
('30', 306, 2, 17, 693308) Considerable strength of mind and perseverance is required now even to manage the Camp.
('30', 306, 2, 18, 693396) But this is not the real difficulty.
('30', 306, 2, 19, 693433) The matrix in which satyagraha flourished is the general communal consciousness and I only point out that after ten months of satyagraha when people realize that the Travancore Council has thrown out the “Freedom of Road” resolution, there is either a tendency to take to extreme steps or to completely collapse.
('30', 306, 2, 20, 693746) Of these I am only afraid of the first and that is why I request that a message, clearly conveying to them all the implications of satyagraha, how though seemingly dilatory in its working yet it is the quickest agent for success, and how other methods are less useful if not positively harmful, especially in a “communal problem”, etc., is highly necessary.
('30', 306, 2, 21, 694104) I hope you will find time to do so.
('30', 306, 2, 22, 694140) That a State reported to be advanced should work in opposition to progressive opinion is a sad commentary on its “advanced” state.
('30', 306, 2, 23, 694271) The progressives really won the battle from a moral standpoint.
('30', 306, 2, 24, 694335) Whilst it is regrettable that 22 should have voted against the use by the so called untouchables of the public road in question, it is consoling to
('30', 307, 0, 1, 694483) 308 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 307, 1, 2, 694525) find that 21 members vindicated the position taken by the Hindu reformers by voting in favour of their resolution.
('30', 307, 1, 3, 694640) The saddest part of the letter, however, is the fact that the satyagrahis seem to be losing hope.
('30', 307, 1, 4, 694738) I do not wonder.
('30', 307, 1, 5, 694755) Theirs is the first experience of sustained satyagraha.
('30', 307, 1, 6, 694811) Let me, however, assure them that victory is assured.
('30', 307, 1, 7, 694865) For their cause is just, their means non violent.
('30', 307, 1, 8, 694915) Let them realize, too, that by their sufferings they have attracted the attention of the world.
('30', 307, 1, 9, 695011) Whoever knew Vykom before the struggle commenced?
('30', 307, 1, 10, 695061) They should also know that they are fighting an age long superstition.
('30', 307, 1, 11, 695132) What is a year’s suffering on the part of a few reformers in their attempt to break down the iron wall of prejudice?
('30', 307, 1, 12, 695249) To lose patience is to lose the battle.
('30', 307, 1, 13, 695289) They must fight to the finish.
('30', 307, 1, 14, 695320) What is the alternative anyone can have in view?
('30', 307, 1, 15, 695369) The breaking of heads will not serve the purpose.
('30', 307, 1, 16, 695419) Orthodoxy will stiffen its back and will suck nourishment out of the blood of its martyrs.
('30', 307, 1, 17, 695510) For if the orthodox are injured, sympathy will irresistibly be drawn towards them though their cause is wrong.
('30', 307, 1, 18, 695621) To attempt to force the entry will invite stronger barricades.
('30', 307, 1, 19, 695684) And even if force succeeded, it would merely mean mechanical use of a single public road and not change of opinion.
('30', 307, 1, 20, 695800) What, however, the Hindu reformers want is the conversion of the orthodox people who have made of untouchability a religion.
('30', 307, 1, 21, 695925) This they will only do by sufferings such as they are now undergoing.
('30', 307, 1, 22, 695995) Satyagraha is the shortest cut to success.
('30', 307, 1, 23, 696038) All the reforms that have been brought about by violent methods have taken not one year but years.
('30', 307, 1, 24, 696137) The victory of enlightenment over darkness in Europe was a long and torturing process.
('30', 307, 1, 25, 696224) And one is not sure that it was a lasting success.
('30', 307, 1, 26, 696275) There was no conversion of those who opposed and died.
('30', 307, 1, 27, 696330) The others who were converted were attracted by the sufferings of those who died even whilst inflicting death on their opponents.
('30', 307, 1, 28, 696460) The net legacy that age bequeathed the world was a confirmation of belief in methods of violence.
('30', 307, 1, 29, 696558) I hope therefore that the satyagrahis of Vykom will not swerve from their path even though their ranks may be thinned and victory may seem further off than ever.
('30', 307, 1, 30, 696720) Satyagraha is utter self effacement, greatest humiliation, greatest patience and brightest faith.
('30', 307, 1, 31, 696818) It is its own reward.
('30', 307, 1, 32, 696840) Young India, 26 2 1925
('30', 308, 0, 1, 696863) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 309
('30', 308, 1, 2, 696909) 174. NOTES
('30', 308, 2, 3, 696920) 28TH FEBRUARY The Sub Committee appointed by the All Parties Conference Committee is to meet once more on the 28th instant at Delhi.
('30', 308, 2, 4, 697053) No Sub Committee had perhaps a more difficult task before it.
('30', 308, 2, 5, 697115) The Sub Committee redivided itself into two groups, one for drafting a skeleton swaraj scheme and the other for framing a skeleton Hindu Muslim Unity scheme.
('30', 308, 2, 6, 697273) Dr. Besant was Chairman of the Swaraj group of the Sub Committee and she has already presented a report for the consideration of the Sub Committee.
('30', 308, 2, 7, 697421) The adjournment took place for the consideration of the Hindu Muslim question as no agreement could be reached last time, and as the desire was expressed that the members then present should be able to confer with those who were absent and those others who though not members might be able to assist in reaching an agreement.
('30', 308, 2, 8, 697747) It is to be hoped that those who can will attend the forthcoming meeting.
('30', 308, 2, 9, 697821) Lala Lajpat Rai has telegraphed asking me to postpone the meeting to a date after the third week of March.
('30', 308, 2, 10, 697928) Several members have informed him that they will not be able to attend.
('30', 308, 2, 11, 698000) I have informed him 1 saying that I could not postpone without reference to the meeting itself and that the meeting might postpone if it was thought desirable.
('30', 308, 2, 12, 698160) Everybody has by this time made up his mind as to what should be done.
('30', 308, 2, 13, 698231) No new light would possibly be thrown on the question at the forthcoming meeting.
('30', 308, 2, 14, 698313) The only question for consideration would be whether there is a middle course between the two extremes that were discussed at Delhi at the last meeting.
('30', 308, 2, 15, 698466) That leads to another question.
('30', 308, 2, 16, 698498) Is there a will on the part of both the parties to find an immediate solution ?
('30', 308, 2, 17, 698578) The swaraj scheme is also a tremendously important problem.
('30', 308, 2, 18, 698638) Only, the Hindu Muslim question seems to block all progress.
('30', 308, 2, 19, 698699) I do hope that all who are at all able will come and assist the deliberations.
('30', 308, 2, 20, 698778) I would advise the absentees to send in their opinions lest the meeting should decide to continue its deliberations instead of postponing as suggested by Lalaji.
('30', 308, 3, 21, 698940) ACHARYA GIDWANI RELEASED The reader will share with me the joy of reading the following
('30', 308, 4, 22, 699028) 1 Vide “Telegram to Lajpat Rai”, 23 2 1925.
('30', 309, 0, 1, 699072) 310 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 309, 1, 2, 699114) telegram received on Monday morning from Ambala:
('30', 309, 2, 3, 699163) Gidwani released yesterday evening sentence being suspended again.
('30', 309, 2, 4, 699230) Administrator’s order states facts correctly this time.
('30', 309, 2, 5, 699286) Administrator sent word through his brother Alim Gidwani, who went to see him on the 8th instant to ask for appointment for Mrs. Gidwani that if Gidwani did not interfere in Nabha politics he could go away that day.
('30', 309, 2, 6, 699502) Gidwani sent word that if that meant obedience to externment order he had no intention of disobeying it when he came and none in future.
('30', 309, 2, 7, 699639) Mrs. Gidwani brought word on the 11th that that was what Administrator required, when Gidwani sent immediately following letter: “Mrs. Gidwani tells me that you desire some assurance from me that I have no intention of disobeying your externment order.
('30', 309, 2, 8, 699892) I have not the slightest hesitation in giving you that assurance.
('30', 309, 2, 9, 699958) When I started from Amritsar last year I had no intention of disobeying the order when I wrote to you for permission to enter Jaito.
('30', 309, 2, 10, 700091) As I explained in my written statement on 8th March 1924, I had fully intended to abide by your decision; my friends tell me that you did not get that letter in time which perhaps explains the unfortunate misunderstanding.
('30', 309, 2, 11, 700314) The Congress position and Mr. Gandhi’s wishes in the matter which I had ascertained personally before starting required me to obey the order and my future course of action will of course be the same, obeying the order until it is withdrawn.” Administrator left for Delhi on 12th morning returned on 15th and had to go immediately to Jaito returning again on 21st night.
('30', 309, 2, 12, 700684) The suspension order came at 4 a.m.
('30', 309, 2, 13, 700720) on 22nd.
('30', 309, 2, 14, 700729) Gidwani proceeding Delhi tonight staying with Principal, Hindu College, awaiting Mahatmaji’s instructions.
('30', 309, 2, 15, 700836) I rejoice to have the news of Acharya Gidwani’s release because his imprisonment was a gross injustice and because that injustice has been redressed.
('30', 309, 2, 16, 700986) Truly the ways of the Nabha authorities are strange.
('30', 309, 2, 17, 701039) What they have now received from the Acharya they could have had long ago.
('30', 309, 2, 18, 701114) In fact as has been repeatedly pointed out in these columns, Acharya Gidwani never entered the Nabha boundary in order to defy orders.
('30', 309, 2, 19, 701249) He entered purely and simply in order to perform a humanitarian service.
('30', 309, 2, 20, 701322) But neither the nation nor the Acharya has lost by the imprisonment.
('30', 309, 2, 21, 701391) It is the necessary training for swaraj and the price that one must pay for liberty.
('30', 309, 3, 22, 701476) STONING TO DEATH
('30', 309, 4, 23, 701493) I have a long telegram sent to me as President of the National Congress regarding the stoning to death in Afghanistan of two members of the Ahmediya sect.
('30', 309, 4, 24, 701648) I purposely refrained from any comment on the awful penalty imposed on the late Niamatulla Khan
('30', 310, 0, 1, 701744) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 311
('30', 310, 1, 2, 701790) but I dare not ignore the incidents now reported especially when a personal appeal for expression of opinion is made to me.
('30', 310, 1, 3, 701914) I understand that the stoning method is enjoined in the Koran only in certain circumstances which do not cover the cases under observation.
('30', 310, 1, 4, 702054) But as a human being living in the fear of God I should question the morality of the method under any circumstance whatsoever.
('30', 310, 1, 5, 702181) Whatever may have been necessary or permissible during the Prophet’s lifetime and in that age, this particular form of penalty cannot be defended on the mere ground of its mention in the Koran.
('30', 310, 1, 6, 702375) Every formula of every religion has in this age of reason, to submit to the acid test of reason and universal justice if it is to ask for universal assent.
('30', 310, 1, 7, 702531) Error can claim no exemption even if it can be supported by the scriptures of the world.
('30', 310, 1, 8, 702620) I extend my sympathy to the sect in its distress.
('30', 310, 1, 9, 702670) Needless to say I can express no opinion on the merits of the case.
('30', 310, 1, 10, 702738) I do not think the public has any data for forming an opinon on merits.
('30', 310, 1, 11, 702810) It is the form penalty that wounds the human conscience.
('30', 310, 1, 12, 702867) Both reason and heart refuse to reconcile themselves to torture for any crime, no matter how vile the crime may be.
('30', 310, 2, 13, 702983) SOME POSERS
('30', 310, 3, 14, 702995) “A well wisher” sends these lines for my meditation:
('30', 310, 4, 15, 703048) The Bible can be read in 566 languages.
('30', 310, 4, 16, 703088) In how many can the Upanishads and the Gita?
('30', 310, 5, 17, 703133) How many leper asylums and institutions for the depressed and the distressed have the missionaries?
('30', 310, 5, 18, 703233) How many have you?
('30', 310, 5, 19, 703252) It is usual for me to receive such posers.
('30', 310, 5, 20, 703295) “A well wisher” deserves an answer.
('30', 310, 5, 21, 703331) I have great regard for the missionaries for their zeal and self sacrifice.
('30', 310, 5, 22, 703407) But I have not hesitated to point out to them that both are often misplaced.
('30', 310, 5, 23, 703484) What though the Bible were translated in every tongue in the world?
('30', 310, 5, 24, 703552) Is a patent medicine better than the Upanishads for being advertised in more languages than the Upanishads?
('30', 310, 5, 25, 703660) An error does not become truth by reason of multipled propagation, nor does truth become error becase nobody will see it.
('30', 310, 5, 26, 703782) The Bible was a greater power when the early fathers preached it than it is today.
('30', 310, 5, 27, 703865) “A well wisher” has little conception of the way truth works, if he thinks that the translation of the Bible in more languages than the Upanishads is any test of its superiority.
('30', 310, 5, 28, 704044) Truth has to be lived if it is to fructify.
('30', 310, 5, 29, 704088) But if it is any satisfaction to “A well wisher” to have my answer I may gladly tell him that the Upanishads and the Gita have been translated into far fewer languages than the Bible.
('30', 311, 0, 1, 704272) 312 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 311, 1, 2, 704314) have never been curious enough to know in how many languages they are translated.
('30', 311, 1, 3, 704396) As for the second question, too, I must own that the missionaries have founded many leper asylums and the like.
('30', 311, 1, 4, 704508) I have founded none.
('30', 311, 1, 5, 704529) But I stand unmoved.
('30', 311, 1, 6, 704550) I am not competing with the missionaries or anybody else in such matters.
('30', 311, 1, 7, 704624) I am trying humbly to serve humanity as God leads me.
('30', 311, 1, 8, 704678) The founding of leper asylums, etc., is only one of the ways, and perhaps not the best, of serving humanity.
('30', 311, 1, 9, 704787) But even such noble service loses much of its nobility when conversion is the motive behind it.
('30', 311, 1, 10, 704883) That service is the noblest which is rendered for its own sake.
('30', 311, 1, 11, 704947) But let me not be misunderstood.
('30', 311, 1, 12, 704980) The missionaries that selflessly work away in such asylums command my respect.
('30', 311, 1, 13, 705059) I am ashamed to have to confess that Hindus have become so callous as to care little for the waifs and strays of India, let alone the world.
('30', 311, 1, 14, 705200) A SUPERSTITION A Bengal zamindar sends me a long letter dealing with Hindu Muslim unity, untouchability and swaraj.
('30', 311, 1, 15, 705316) The letter is too long for publication and covers no new ground.
('30', 311, 1, 16, 705381) I cull, however, one typical sentence from it.
('30', 311, 1, 17, 705428) It is: For over 500 years the relation between Hindus and Mussalmans was that of foes.
('30', 311, 1, 18, 705515) After the advent of British rule both the Mussalmans and Hindus were compelled out of policy to forget that racial hatred and the acrimony of that bitter enmity is now no more.
('30', 311, 1, 19, 705692) But the permanent difference in the constitution of these two races does even now exist.
('30', 311, 1, 20, 705781) I believe the present cordial relation is due to British rule and not to the catholicity of modern Hinduism.
('30', 311, 1, 21, 705890) I regard this statement as pure superstition.
('30', 311, 1, 22, 705936) The two races lived at peace among themselves during the Mussalman rule.
('30', 311, 1, 23, 706009) Let it be remembered that many Hindus embraced Islam before the advent of Muslim rule in India.
('30', 311, 1, 24, 706105) It is my belief that had there been no Muslim rule, there would still have been Mussalmans in India even as there would have been Christians had there been no British rule.
('30', 311, 1, 25, 706278) There is nothing to prove that Hindus and Mussalmans lived at war with one another before the British rule.
('30', 311, 1, 26, 706386) My belief is that the British policy of “divide and rule” has accentuated our differences and will continue to do so, till we recognize that we must unite in spite of the policy.
('30', 311, 1, 27, 706565) This cannot and will not happen unless we refrain from a scramble for place and power.
('30', 311, 1, 28, 706652) The beginning must be made by the Hindus.

('30', 312, 3, 12, 707627) INDIA’S PLIGHT Mr. Higginbottom of the Agricultural Institute of Allahabad was examined by the Taxation Inquiry Committee on the 6th instant when he gave expression to interesting opinions on several matters of importance.
('30', 312, 3, 13, 707850) I cull the following from theCivil and Military Gazette:
('30', 312, 4, 14, 707907) India, while being poor, is the most extravagant country on the face of the earth in matters of agriculture.
('30', 312, 4, 15, 708016) The extreme poverty in the land is not so much due to want of either land or material for agriculture but want of a scientific system of agriculture.
('30', 312, 4, 16, 708166) The existence of numerous uneconomic cattle and religious mendicants are the source of a fearful economic drain on the country.
('30', 312, 4, 17, 708294) There are far too many cattle for food supply, and there are too many cattle for the work to be done.
('30', 312, 4, 18, 708396) Lack of food reduces the size and value of cattle.
('30', 312, 4, 19, 708447) Lack of food and the refusal to eliminate unfit ones has led to the Indian cow giving the least amount of milk of any cow on the earth.
('30', 312, 4, 20, 708583) Indian milk is most expensive to produce and over 90 per cent of the cattle in this country is an economic loss.
('30', 312, 5, 21, 708696) The most expensive manure, which is difficult to get, is being burnt by the people.
('30', 312, 6, 22, 708780) The potential taxability of India is very great, but her present taxable capacity is very low.
('30', 312, 6, 23, 708875) The burden of the land tax is very much lower than what it ought to be.
('30', 312, 6, 24, 708947) Land revenue in India is burdensome when the holding is smaller than an economic holding.
('30', 312, 7, 25, 709037) Legislation is necessary for abolishing uneconomic holdings.
('30', 312, 7, 26, 709098) The present legislation was putting a premium on small farming.
('30', 312, 7, 27, 709162) The size of a
('30', 313, 0, 1, 709176) 314 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 313, 1, 2, 709218) holding is seldom sufficiently large for the use of labour saving machinery.
('30', 313, 1, 3, 709295) The present state of legislation is making all economic holdings to become a number of uneconomic holdings.
('30', 313, 1, 4, 709403) There is absence of a proper system of village industries to take care of the surplus people.
('30', 313, 1, 5, 709497) Further the land is asked to provide a whole time living for a very large number of men and animals who can work on it only for half the time.
('30', 313, 1, 6, 709640) The remedy is to devise and devlop rural seasonal industries for men, women and oxen so that they can be gainfully occupied for a portion of the time when the land does not require their services.
('30', 313, 2, 7, 709837) The landlord regards his income as personal, and does not consider the improvement of the countryside as his gain.
('30', 313, 2, 8, 709952) Moreover, tenants and landlords are eternally at war.
('30', 313, 2, 9, 710006) These extracts deal with four things.
('30', 313, 2, 10, 710044) Waste of valuable manure, the distressing problem of cattle, uneconomic holdings and want of occupation for the peasantry all the year round.
('30', 313, 2, 11, 710186) All these, apart from the burden of taxation, deepen the poverty of the masses and deserve conside ration at the hands of all patriots.
('30', 313, 2, 12, 710322) Everyone of them is capable of being handled in an effective manner.
('30', 313, 2, 13, 710391) In a country where the cow is an object of worship, there should be no cattle problem at all.
('30', 313, 2, 14, 710485) But our cow worship has resolved itself into an ignorant fanati cism.
('30', 313, 2, 15, 710555) The fact that we have more cattle than we can support is a matter for urgent treatment.
('30', 313, 2, 16, 710643) I have already suggested the taking over of the question by cow protection societies.
('30', 313, 2, 17, 710729) It is their legitimate function.
('30', 313, 2, 18, 710762) The question of uneconomic holdings requires revision of the family system.
('30', 313, 2, 19, 710838) The question of wanton destruction of manure requires a true agricultural education and that of unemployment for half the year for millions of men and women can only be solved by the spinning wheel.
('30', 313, 2, 20, 711037) It is clear that to the fight with the Government we must add a scientific study and handling of the problems discussed by Mr. Sam Higginbottom.
('30', 313, 2, 21, 711182) Young India, 26 2 1925

('30', 317, 5, 12, 715601) 184. LETTER TO SIR PRABHASHANKER PATTANI
('30', 317, 6, 13, 715642) Phagan Sud 6, Samvat 1981 [February 28, 1925]

('30', 319, 8, 21, 718821) 188. REMINISCENCES OF KATHIAWAR 1
('30', 319, 9, 22, 718855) PEOPLE’S REPRESENTATIVE ASSEMBLY
('30', 319, 10, 23, 718888) The memories of my visit to Kathiawar, which lasted from the 15th to 21st , will ever remain fresh in my mind.
('30', 319, 10, 24, 718999) I was delighted to see the independence displayed by the Thakore Saheb of Rajkot.
('30', 319, 10, 25, 719081) I had my misgivings about the usefulness of the People’s Representative Assembly, but my presence during this body’s deliberations for three hours dispelled them.
('30', 319, 10, 26, 719244) The ultimate benefit from this organization would be known only in the future but it can be said that it is useful even in its present form.
('30', 319, 10, 27, 719385) It rests with the representatives to increase its utility.
('30', 319, 10, 28, 719444) The representatives have complete freedom to express themselves and they were seen exercising this to the full.
('30', 319, 10, 29, 719556) Nobody seemed to worry about what views the Thakore Saheb would approve.
('30', 319, 10, 30, 719629) The representatives expressed even such views as were likely to offend the Thakore Saheb.
('30', 320, 0, 1, 719719) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 321
('30', 320, 1, 2, 719765) As the proceedings were conducted in Gujarati, the atmos phere was lively.
('30', 320, 1, 3, 719840) Here was none of the artificiality, snobbery, and so on that one finds in English speeches.
('30', 320, 1, 4, 719932) Some speeches, one could say, were excellent and effective.
('30', 320, 1, 5, 719992) The speeches did not drag on and most of them were to the point.
('30', 320, 1, 6, 720057) I would not consider this council inferior to any other assembly in respect of debating ability, self restraint and orderly procedure.
('30', 320, 1, 7, 720192) Prohibition was the main topic discussed by the Assembly.
('30', 320, 1, 8, 720250) It unanimously passed a resolution to the effect that the Durbar should ban the distillation of liquor.
('30', 320, 1, 9, 720354) The representatives knew that the Thakore Saheb was opposed to this resolution.
('30', 320, 1, 10, 720434) And yet it was passed a second time.
('30', 320, 2, 11, 720471) A FLAW IN ARGUMENT
('30', 320, 3, 12, 720490) The Thakore Saheb had himself argued with the representatives.
('30', 320, 3, 13, 720553) Hence his views on this subject could be known.
('30', 320, 3, 14, 720601) He argued that if drink shops were banned, individual liberty would be curtailed.
('30', 320, 3, 15, 720683) I think that there is a great flaw in this argument.
('30', 320, 3, 16, 720736) It is difficult to understand how individual liberty is curtailed if liquor shops are closed down.
('30', 320, 3, 17, 720835) People did not want drinking to be considered a crime, but they wanted a ban on the preparation and sale of liquor.
('30', 320, 3, 18, 720951) No society or individual is entitled to prepare or sell a thing if it is considered harmful by them.
('30', 320, 3, 19, 721052) Everyone is aware of the harm done by drinking.
('30', 320, 3, 20, 721100) As there can be no liberty for anyone to steal, there can be none to distil or sell liquor.
('30', 320, 3, 21, 721192) Those who cannot do without liquor may transgress the law.
('30', 320, 3, 22, 721251) Many instances of such restrictions are found even in countries where individual liberty is cherished.
('30', 320, 3, 23, 721354) Liberty and license are not the same thing.
('30', 320, 3, 24, 721398) One cannot have the license to act as one pleases.
('30', 320, 3, 25, 721449) If such license exists, then the goddess of liberty can never stay there.
('30', 320, 3, 26, 721523) Everyone has the right to enjoy as much liberty as will not harm others.
('30', 320, 3, 27, 721596) There is a legal maxim 1 in English that one should use one’s property in such a way that others are not injured.
('30', 320, 3, 28, 721710) I have every right to dig up my whole plot of land but I cannot dig it so that the foundation of my neighbour’s house is damaged.
('30', 320, 3, 29, 721840) If a section of the people drinks wine, the evil consequences are not suffered by the drinkers alone but their children and neighbours also suffer.
('30', 320, 3, 30, 721988) America has closed down drink shops and breweries.
('30', 320, 3, 31, 722039) That has not resulted in
('30', 320, 4, 32, 722064) 1 A Latin legal maxim, Sic utere tuo ut alienum non laedars which means: “Use your property in such a way as not to damage that of others.”
('30', 321, 0, 1, 722204) 322 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 321, 1, 2, 722246) the curtailment of individual liberty.
('30', 321, 1, 3, 722285) When the whole world loudly protests against the drink trade, it is regrettable that the Thakore Saheb of Rajkot is defending individual liberty to drink.
('30', 321, 2, 4, 722440) PUBLIC OPINION Assuming that the ban on the drink trade would curtail individual liberty, even then, if the people clearly hold a unanimous view, it is the duty of the ruler to act according to the wishes of the people.
('30', 321, 2, 5, 722660) That is a principle recognized all over the world.
('30', 321, 2, 6, 722711) There was no one in the People’s Representative Assembly who did not desire a ban on the drink trade.
('30', 321, 2, 7, 722813) There is evidence to show that the addicts themselves desire such a ban.
('30', 321, 2, 8, 722886) Their families have suffered.
('30', 321, 2, 9, 722916) It will be regrettable if the Thakore Saheb does not respect the wishes of the people in this matter.
('30', 321, 2, 10, 723018) The ruler has taken the initiative in forming the People’s Representative Assembly, and I would expect that he will not disregard the people’s wish clinging to wrong reasoning and that he will earn the sincere blessings of the poor by banning the drink trade.
('30', 321, 3, 11, 723278) REGULARITY The Thakore Saheb of Rajkot is a stickler for regularity.
('30', 321, 3, 12, 723347) He does all his work at the appointed hour and diligently goes through all his appointments, and makes others do the same.
('30', 321, 3, 13, 723470) He loves discipline.
('30', 321, 3, 14, 723491) He believes that our greatest drawback is lack of discipline.
('30', 321, 3, 15, 723553) That this is very much so cannot be denied.
('30', 321, 3, 16, 723597) The people are not able to fulfil their good intentions for want of rules and discipline.
('30', 321, 3, 17, 723687) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 1 3 1925

('30', 326, 4, 6, 730406) 199. STATEMENT ON ADJOURNMENT OF ALL PARTY CONFERENCE SUB COMMITTEE
('30', 326, 5, 7, 730474) DELHI, March 2, 1925
('30', 326, 6, 8, 730495) Mahatma Gandhi and Pandit Motilal Nehru have issued the following statement explaining the reasons which led to the adjournment of the Sub committee of the All Party Conference over the Hindu Muslim question: It was decided at the meeting 1 of the Sub committee, appointed by the committee of the All Party Conference, to adjourn the proceedings sine die with the provision that the meeting be called on a requisition from a majority of the members of the Sub committee.
('30', 326, 6, 9, 730966) We were also required and authorized by the meeting to give a resume of the position as it stands today.
('30', 326, 6, 10, 731071) The meeting was attended by very few members—14 out of 53. They were Maulana Mahomed Ali, Maulana Shaukat Ali, Swami Shraddhanand, Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, Dr. S. Datta, Mr. Ahmed Ali, M.L.A., Raja Ahmad Ali Khan of Salempur, Nawab Sir Sahibzada Abdul Quiyum, Mr. Mohamed Yakub, Mr. N.M. Joshi, Mr. N.C. Kelkar, besides ourselves Mr. Jinnah came in for a few minutes from another meeting (Independent Party’s meeting) he was attending at that time.
('30', 326, 7, 11, 731520) Lala Lajpat Rai had asked for a postponement by reason of the inability of Messrs Jayakar,Srinivasa Iyengar 2 and Jairamdas to attend.
('30', 326, 7, 12, 731655) We were unable to postpone the meeting on our own responsibility.
('30', 326, 7, 13, 731721) We, therefore, informed Lala Lajpat Rai that the question of postpone ment be placed before the meeting.
('30', 326, 7, 14, 731826) This was consequently done.
('30', 326, 7, 15, 731854) But apart from the absence of Lala Lajpat Rai and of the gentlemen named by him the attendance was otherwise also too meagre for
('30', 326, 8, 16, 731983) 1 Held on March 1. Gandhiji was the President of the Sub committee and Motilal Nehru, its General Secretary.

('30', 328, 6, 9, 734472) 202. NOTES I
('30', 328, 7, 10, 734485) HINDU MUSLIM PROBLEM The reader will see from the statement published in the Press that the Sub committee of the All Party Conference has not been able to come to any decision on the problem of problems.
('30', 328, 7, 11, 734689) But perhaps it was as well that it did not.
('30', 328, 7, 12, 734733) The atmosphere for a reasonable solution is lacking.
('30', 328, 7, 13, 734786) Each distrusts the other.
('30', 328, 7, 14, 734812) In such circumstances there can be no common ground of action.
('30', 328, 7, 15, 734875) Each necessarily wants to surrender as little as possible.
('30', 328, 7, 16, 734934) Nor does one notice a real anxiety on the part of any of the parties for a solution.
('30', 328, 7, 17, 735019) There is, however, no cause for despair.
('30', 328, 7, 18, 735060) The present failure may be a stepping stone to success, if those who can trust and who have no fear of one another will be true to their faith and try to work at a solution.
('30', 328, 7, 19, 735234) Any solution to be national must disregard the Government, i.e., must have inherent working power and must not depend for its proper working upon the goodwill of the Government.
('30', 328, 8, 20, 735412) HELPLESSNESS
('30', 328, 9, 21, 735425) I have a long telegram describing a daring dacoity attempted in Sukkur at 10 p.m.
('30', 328, 9, 22, 735507) on the 22nd near the Police Station and in the heart of the town.
('30', 328, 9, 23, 735573) The telegram adds that the bankers are feeling unsafe and that the dacoits are still uncaught.
('30', 328, 9, 24, 735668) The object of the telegram no doubt is to excite public sympathy and criticism of a Government the most expensive in the world and yet failing to afford simple protection to life and property.
('30', 328, 9, 25, 735861) That sympathy the citizens of Sukkur have.
('30', 328, 9, 26, 735904) Criticism of the Government they may also have by the cartload.
('30', 328, 9, 27, 735968) But the more relevant question is what the bankers were doing when the dacoits came.
('30', 328, 9, 28, 736053) From the telegram it would appear that they more or

('30', 329, 2, 8, 736876) A CRY FROM SYLHET Here is a pathetic appeal from Sylhet in support of the invitation to visit that District:
('30', 329, 3, 9, 736985) Although our present may not justify us in giving you trouble, we have a past which may not fail to draw your sympathy.
('30', 329, 3, 10, 737105) Ours is a peculiar position.
('30', 329, 3, 11, 737134) Politically we are under the administration of the Government of Assam, but we have a close inseparable affinity with Bengal in all matters, linguistic, social, religious and political.
('30', 329, 3, 12, 737320) This District Congress Committee is within the jurisdiction of the Bengal Provincial Congress Committee.
('30', 329, 4, 13, 737425) During the palmy days of non co operation this province of Assam including our district was perhaps a victim of bureaucratic wrath next only to the Punjab.
('30', 329, 5, 14, 737581) Tea garden labour exodus, the incidents of tearing Koran at Maijbhag and lastly the tragedy of Kanaighat had introduced this district to the rest of India.
('30', 329, 6, 15, 737737) The “Law and Order” exacted a punitive tax of two lacs more or less from this district containing about 26 lacs of souls.
('30', 329, 7, 16, 737859) Nearly 200 national workers were imprisoned.
('30', 329, 8, 17, 737904) This ruthless repression dealt a fatal blow to the Congress activities.
('30', 329, 8, 18, 737976) Many went to their respective callings and hence there is a miserable fall in our ranks.
('30', 329, 9, 19, 738065) Out of ten national schools we have only one dragging its weary life.
('30', 329, 9, 20, 738135) About 20,000 handlooms are at work, but, alas, with the exception of a very few, almost all work in foreign yarn.
('30', 329, 9, 21, 738249) Sufficient quantity of cotton is being exported by the foreign capitalist year by year from our hills.
('30', 329, 9, 22, 738352) The past record of Sylhet is undoubtedly brilliant.
('30', 329, 9, 23, 738404) But no nation can live merely upon its past.
('30', 329, 9, 24, 738449) A glorious past may be, ought to be, an inspiration for the present.
('30', 329, 9, 25, 738518) But the future can only be determined by the present conduct.
('30', 329, 9, 26, 738580) It is, therefore, necessary for the people in the Sylhet District to bestir themselves and make the constructive
('30', 330, 0, 1, 738693) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 331
('30', 330, 1, 2, 738739) programme a success so far as their part of the country is concerned.
('30', 330, 1, 3, 738809) It is a sad reflection that all over the country the imprisonment left the people paralysed.
('30', 330, 1, 4, 738902) If we had understood the secret of suffering, they should have invigorated us instead of enervating us as they did in general.
('30', 330, 1, 5, 739029) It ought not to be beyond the ability of the people of Sylhet to intercept some of the cotton that leaves their district nor to persuade the weavers to weave hand spun yarn and to supply them with such yarn spun in their own district.
('30', 330, 1, 6, 739264) Then and not till then will they be entitled to ask me to visit them.
('30', 330, 2, 7, 739334) THE BAR SINISTER
('30', 330, 3, 8, 739351) General Smuts 1 has at last spoken out on the proposed extension of the Colour Bar in South African Legislation.
('30', 330, 3, 9, 739464) The reader will remember the cablegram received sometime ago that the Union Government was seeking to put the ban on Asiatics being employed in the mines.
('30', 330, 3, 10, 739619) Speaking on and against that legislation General Smuts is reported to have said:
('30', 330, 4, 11, 739700) In opposing the Colour Bar Bill in the Union Assembly, General Smuts declared that the Bill sought to give the Government power by regulation to apportion work in mines and works between whites on the one hand, and Natives and Asiatics on the other, which he thought was a very serious matter.
('30', 330, 4, 12, 739994) He felt that the Bill was not honest dealing and it was his deliberate opinion that there was only one guarantee of the security of white civilization namely, honest justice between man and man in this country.
('30', 330, 4, 13, 740205) (“Hear, hear!”) Turning to the Bill, as it affected Asiatics, he said that in the days of his negotiation with Mr. Gandhi the position which the latter took up, and which had been taken up at subsequent conferences in London, was an appeal not to dishonour Indians.
('30', 330, 4, 14, 740471) “We recognize”, said Mr. Gandhi, “there is a difference between you and us and that distinctions must be made, but don’t cast a stigma on us in the laws of your country,” but in this Bill they were doing the very thing they were asked to avoid.
('30', 330, 4, 15, 740716) They were gathering on their heads the hatred of the whole of Asia from one side to the other.
('30', 330, 4, 16, 740811) In conclusion, he suggested that the matter should be seriously considered, whether they should not discharge the order for the second reading of the Bill, and see whether some way out of the difficulty could not be found.
('30', 330, 4, 17, 741034) General Smuts has correctly given the substance of my conversation with him.
('30', 330, 4, 18, 741111) My point was that whilst administrative
('30', 330, 5, 19, 741151) 1 J. C. Smuts (1870 1950); South African general and statesman, late Prime Minister
('30', 331, 0, 1, 741235) 332 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 331, 1, 2, 741277) difference there was bound to be so long as human nature remained what it was and so long as there was a conflict between European culture and the Indian, a legal recognition of the difference in the shape of the introduction of the Bar sinister in the laws of the country was an intolerable burden.
('30', 331, 1, 3, 741577) The settlement of 1914 chiefly consisted in the vindication of the Indian position.
('30', 331, 1, 4, 741661) With General Smuts’ opposition we may hope that the Bill will now be dropped.
('30', 331, 1, 5, 741739) But let us not deceive ourselves.
('30', 331, 1, 6, 741773) The Natal Disfranchising Bill recently passed is an extension of the “Bar Sinister”.
('30', 331, 1, 7, 741858) General Smut’ opposition therefore means only a protest against the bar being introduced even in the matter of employment, not against the bar altogether.
('30', 331, 1, 8, 742013) However I tender my congratulations to General Smuts on his plain speech at the risk of still further weaken ing his political position in his country.
('30', 331, 1, 9, 742165) We may not be satisfied till the South African statute book is purged of all legal inequality as between whites and Asiatics or better still as between white and coloured people.

('30', 334, 2, 9, 749906) Since reference has been made to a booklet 2 of mine on ethics and religion, I must draw the attention of the reader to the fact that what the correspondent refers to is a translation of the original which is in Gujarati.
('30', 334, 2, 10, 750128) But the Gujarati itself as the preface makes it clear is not an original effort but an adaptation from an American publication called Ethical Religion by Mr. Salter.
('30', 334, 2, 11, 750294) The translation came under my notice in Yeravda Jail and I regretted to notice the absence of any mention of the source from which I had borrowed.
('30', 334, 2, 12, 750441) The translator himself I understand did not rely upon the original Gujarati but a Hindi translation.
('30', 334, 2, 13, 750542) The English rendering therefore is a round about thing.
('30', 334, 2, 14, 750598) I owe this explanation to the author of the original book and I am glad that the mention of the work by my correspondent has reminded me of my obligation.

('30', 334, 5, 17, 750789) I gladly print the following from Maulana Zafar Ali Khan written by him in his capacity as President of the Punjab Khilafat Committee:
('30', 334, 6, 18, 750924) I have read with feelings of mingled amazement and pain your pronouncement, in Young India of the 26th instant, on stoning inci dents in Kabul.
('30', 334, 6, 19, 751068) You say that “this particular form of penalty cannotbe defended on the mere ground of its mention in the Koran”.
('30', 334, 6, 20, 751181) 3 You, moreover, declare that “every formula of every religion has in this age of reason to submit to the acid test of reason and universal justice if it is to ask for universal assent”.
('30', 334, 6, 21, 751368) Finally you maintain that error can claim no exemption even if it can be supported by the
('30', 334, 7, 22, 751458) 1 What follows has been appended to the article under Gandhij’s signature.
('30', 334, 7, 23, 751533) 2 Vide “Ethical Religion V”, February 2, 1907. 3 Vide “Notes”, 26 2 1925, sub title,“Stoning to Death”.
('30', 335, 0, 1, 751637) 336 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 335, 1, 2, 751679) scriptures of the world.
('30', 335, 2, 3, 751704) I have always paid unstinted homage to your greatness and have all along looked upon you as one of the few men who are making modern history; but I would be failing in my duty as a Mussalman if I refrained from pointing out to you that by challenging the right of the Koran to regulate the life of its followers in its own way you have shaken the belief of millions of your Muslim admirers in your capacity to lead them.
('30', 335, 3, 4, 752125) You are at perfect liberty to express your opinion one way or the other as to whether renegades can be stoned to death under the law of Islam.
('30', 335, 3, 5, 752268) But to hold that even if the Koran supported such form of penalty, it should be condemned outright as an error, is a form of reasoning which cannot appeal to the Mussalmans.
('30', 335, 4, 6, 752442) Error is after all a relative term and Mussalmans have their own way of interpreting it.
('30', 335, 4, 7, 752531) To them the koran is an unalterable law which transcends the ever changing policies and expendiencies of puny humanity.
('30', 335, 4, 8, 752651) Would to God that to your multifarious activities as leader of India you had not added the rather delicate task of adversely criticizing the teaching of the Holy Koran.
('30', 335, 4, 9, 752820) The Maulana has put an interpretation upon my note which it does not bear.
('30', 335, 4, 10, 752895) I have not adversely (or otherwise) criticized the teachings of the Holy Koran.
('30', 335, 4, 11, 752975) But I have criticised the teachers, that is, the interpreters, in anticipation of their defending the penalty of stoning to death.
('30', 335, 4, 12, 753106) I claim to understand enough of the Koran and the history of Islam to know that a multitude of interpreters have interpreted the Koran to suit their preconceived notions.
('30', 335, 4, 13, 753277) My purpose was to issue a warning against the acceptance of such interpretations.
('30', 335, 4, 14, 753359) But I would like to say that even the teachings themselves of the Koran cannot be exempt from criticism .
('30', 335, 4, 15, 753465) Every true scripture only gains by criticism.
('30', 335, 4, 16, 753511) After all we have no other guide but our reason to tell us what may be regarded as revealed and what may not be.
('30', 335, 4, 17, 753624) The early Mussalmans accepted Islam not because they knew it to be revealed but because it appealed to their virgin reason.
('30', 335, 4, 18, 753748) I fully endorse the Maulana’s statement that error is a relative term.
('30', 335, 4, 19, 753819) But we know as a matter of fact that some things are universally accepted as errors.
('30', 335, 4, 20, 753904) Death by torture is, I expect, such an error.
('30', 335, 4, 21, 753950) In making the three statements the Maulana has quoted, I have simply mentioned three canons of interpretations which I think are incapable of challenge.
('30', 335, 4, 22, 754103) Anyway, I abide by them .
('30', 335, 4, 23, 754129) And if I am at perfect liberty to express my opinion “as to whether renegades can be stoned to death under the law of Islam” why may I not express an opinion as to whether
('30', 336, 0, 1, 754301) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 337
('30', 336, 1, 2, 754347) penalty of stoning to death can be imposed at all under the law of Islam?
('30', 336, 1, 3, 754421) The Maulana has betrayed intolerance of criticism by a non Muslim of anything relating to Islam.
('30', 336, 1, 4, 754518) I suggest to him that intolerance of criticism even of what one may prize as dear as life itself is not conducive to the growth of public corporate life.
('30', 336, 1, 5, 754672) Surely Islam has nothing to fear from criticism even if it be unreasonable.
('30', 336, 1, 6, 754748) I therefore suggest to the Maulana the advisability in the light of my criticism of applying himself to an elucidation of the tremendous issues involved in the incidents reported from Kabul.

('30', 336, 2, 8, 754961) 205. NOTES–II
('30', 336, 3, 9, 754975) AN OASIS IN THE DESERT In the midst of complaints against Bombay in the matter of Khaddar,one is glad to find that a group of ladies are doing silent and effective work in spreading khaddar.
('30', 336, 3, 10, 755166) A letter before me says:
('30', 336, 4, 11, 755191) This month we are selling over Rs. 2,000 worth of khaddar vests for the work guild and schools.
('30', 336, 4, 12, 755287) Moreover we have sent some to Bhavnagar.
('30', 336, 4, 13, 755328) Add to this the usual money sales.
('30', 336, 4, 14, 755363) A new class is being opened in the Seva Sadan 1 on the condition that only those children are to be admitted to it who are prepared to do a certain amount of spinning every day.
('30', 336, 4, 15, 755541) When they have mastered the art, they are to contribute 2,000 yards per month.
('30', 336, 4, 16, 755620) This is impressing the existing classes.
('30', 336, 4, 17, 755661) The girls are to commence hand spinning in some of them.
('30', 336, 4, 18, 755718) Another friend properly remarks that it is not the people that are apathetic.
('30', 336, 4, 19, 755796) It is the workers, the leaders.
('30', 336, 4, 20, 755828) They are doing nothing to spread the gospel.
('30', 336, 4, 21, 755873) The people have not yet developed that liking for khaddar as to make them go out of their way to procure khaddar, but if it is brought to their doors, they would gladly take it.
('30', 336, 4, 22, 756051) The harvest is indeed such but the labourers are few.
('30', 336, 4, 23, 756105) Why will not every worker make it a point to sell a given quantity of khaddar per month?
('30', 336, 4, 24, 756194) I know that we have made sufficient progress in the manufacture of khaddar to be able to supply the most fastidious tastes.
('30', 336, 4, 25, 756318) I was shown the other day a rich bride’s trousers.
('30', 336, 4, 26, 756369) It was all made of khaddar and silver and gold embroidery.
('30', 336, 4, 27, 756428) There was nothing wanting from a rich man’s point of view.
('30', 336, 4, 28, 756487) And the khaddar saris were as fine as one could possibly desire.
('30', 336, 4, 29, 756552) There was the inevitable richly coloured shawl too made of
('30', 336, 5, 30, 756611) 1 Sarasvat Hall; vide “A Correction”, 26 3 1925.
('30', 337, 0, 1, 756660) 338 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 337, 1, 2, 756702) khaddar which the bride has to wear on her being given to the bridegroom.
('30', 337, 1, 3, 756776) Let no one therefore pretend that he or she does not use khaddar because it is not fine enough or coloured according to one’s tastes.
('30', 337, 1, 4, 756910) Will the workers all over India please note and copy the example of the silent sisters whose efforts I have brought to their notice?
('30', 337, 1, 5, 757043) FARIDPUR CONFERENCE
('30', 337, 2, 6, 757063) I have telegrams from Faridpur urging me to attend the Bengal Provincial Conference.
('30', 337, 2, 7, 757148) I am extremely sorry for my inability to attend it, much as I would love to do so.
('30', 337, 2, 8, 757231) I had warned 1 the Faridpur friends not to rely upon my attendance.
('30', 337, 2, 9, 757299) I had told them that my movements were uncertain.
('30', 337, 2, 10, 757349) Mine is not an enviable position.
('30', 337, 2, 11, 757383) I have calls from Bihar, Wardha, Orissa, Andhra and several other places.
('30', 337, 2, 12, 757457) I would like to visit all of them.
('30', 337, 2, 13, 757492) But since I cannot visit all at the same time, I must judge where I can be of the greatest service at a particular moment.
('30', 337, 2, 14, 757615) I feel that my place just now is among the valiant band of satyagrahis at Vykom.
('30', 337, 2, 15, 757696) It is a promise long overdue.
('30', 337, 2, 16, 757726) They are endeavouring to enforce the doctrine of satyagraha in every minute detail.
('30', 337, 2, 17, 757810) They are few in number.
('30', 337, 2, 18, 757834) They are fighting against heavy odds.
('30', 337, 2, 19, 757872) Till now I have interfered with their seeking monetary and other help from outside.
('30', 337, 2, 20, 757956) It is due to them that I should as a professing expert go to them and guide them and hearten them for all that lies in front of them.
('30', 337, 2, 21, 758090) The friends from the other provinces will not grudge me or them this privilege of long deferred communion.
('30', 337, 2, 22, 758197) What is more, whereas I fancy I can be of some assistance to these satyagrahis, I feel sure that I can be of no use in the other provinces except to be on show there.
('30', 337, 2, 23, 758364) My prescription for them is incredibly simple.
('30', 337, 2, 24, 758411) Settle your local differences whether they are between Hindus and Mussalmans or other or whether they are between Brahmins and non Brahmins.
('30', 337, 2, 25, 758552) Spin as much as you can, wear khaddar on all occasions, enrol as many selfspinning members as you can for the Congress.
('30', 337, 2, 26, 758672) And add to these those who will not spin themselves but will gladly furnish 2,000 yards of yarn per month, hand spun for them by others.
('30', 337, 2, 27, 758809) Help the suppressed classes in your district or province in every way you can, rid your place of the drink and the opium evil, and then invite me for further effort.
('30', 337, 2, 28, 758975) If we want an era of hope drawning upon us next year, during this year of grace we shall
('30', 337, 3, 29, 759064) 1 Vide “Telegram to Secretary, Congress Committee, Calcutta”, 23 2 1925.
('30', 338, 0, 1, 759137) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 339
('30', 338, 1, 2, 759183) devote all our energy to the national constructive programme undeterred by anything that the Government may or may not do , the Bengal Ordinance notwithstanding.
('30', 338, 1, 3, 759345) If we want to see the Ordinance removed, we must generate enough strength for the purpose.
('30', 338, 1, 4, 759436) The only way I know of so doing is to work the constructive programme with all our might.
('30', 338, 1, 5, 759526) A CASE FOR RECONSIDERATION Mr. A. V. Thakkar, that friend of the suppressed classes, has sent me a copy of the Report of the Committee appointed by the Bombay Corporation to inquire into the ejection from municipal chawls of certain members belonging to the suppressed classes.
('30', 338, 1, 6, 759804) These poor men and women have been driven out on the grounds that they are not in municipal service, that some of them can afford to pay more and that some others are undesirable persons against whom prosecutions have been proved.
('30', 338, 1, 7, 760035) On behalf of the evicted people it has been contended that they are near relatives of the employees, that they have been living in municipal chawls for years and that the evictions have been brought about at the instance of corrupt municipal servants who could not get bribes from the evicted persons.
('30', 338, 1, 8, 760337) In the Municipal Commissioner’s report it is stated that
('30', 338, 2, 9, 760394) some years ago after visiting the chawls and making enquiries I was satisfied that the evidence and statements made (about corruption) were such that no impartial person could accept them.
('30', 338, 2, 10, 760583) I cannot recall any such statement having been made by me.
('30', 338, 2, 11, 760642) But the question of bribery is irrelevant.
('30', 338, 2, 12, 760685) Even if every Municipal official would be proved to be above corruption, the eviction of the people other than employees is bad in principle so far as the suppressed classes are concerned.
('30', 338, 2, 13, 760874) Theirs is a special case.
('30', 338, 2, 14, 760900) They have nowhere to go to.
('30', 338, 2, 15, 760928) They do not cluster together in municipal chawls for the sake of finding cheap habitation.
('30', 338, 2, 16, 761019) They live there because they can procure no other for love or money.
('30', 338, 2, 17, 761088) I hold that it is the duty of the Corporation not only to let the relatives of the suppressed class employees remain with them but it is also to provide enough and decent additional accommodation for these classes.
('30', 338, 2, 18, 761303) The Corporation will be entitled to charge a reasonable rent for such accommodation.
('30', 338, 2, 19, 761388) I know instances of very respectable members belonging to the suppressed classes having been unable to procure lodgings at any rent whatsoever.
('30', 338, 2, 20, 761532) The owners will not let their houses to these classes.
('30', 338, 2, 21, 761587) The objection of the Committee or the Municipal Commissioner to
('30', 339, 0, 1, 761651) 340 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 339, 1, 2, 761693) persons other than employees occupying municipal chawls would be valid, if it were raised in connection with any other class.
('30', 339, 1, 3, 761819) I hope therefore that the case will be reopened and provision made for every one of the evicted men and women of the suppressed class.

('30', 341, 4, 11, 764513) 212. INTERVIEW TO PRESS ON HINDU MUSLIM PROBLEM
('30', 341, 5, 12, 764561) BOMBAY, March 5, 1925 My views remain the same as hitherto.
('30', 341, 5, 13, 764621) Unity is inevitable.
('30', 341, 5, 14, 764642) It will take longer than I had expected.
('30', 341, 5, 15, 764683) The estrangement is undoubtedly growing.
('30', 341, 5, 16, 764724) Let us hope that even in the midst of the storm, same of us will remain calm I am out for conquest.
('30', 341, 5, 17, 764824) I as a Hindu will not therefore quarrel with the Mussalmans, neither will I yield to threats, such as I see are reported to have been uttered at Peshawar.
('30', 341, 5, 18, 764979) I am in correspon dence 2 both with Maulana Zafar Ali Khan and Dr. Kitchlew 3. I hope that they are incorrectly reported.
('30', 341, 5, 19, 765101) But I must refuse to lose my head even if they have said all that has been reported of them.I do not believe in the efficacy of retaliation.
('30', 341, 5, 20, 765242) I would urge the Hindus not to be angry over such incidents.
('30', 341, 5, 21, 765303) But I see that there is no settlement to be had in the near future.
('30', 341, 5, 22, 765371) No lasting settlement can be had by higgling.
('30', 341, 5, 23, 765417) I cannot be interested in a fight for sharing power with the bureaucracy.
('30', 341, 5, 24, 765491) Such fight can only strengthen British dominance.
('30', 341, 5, 25, 765541) I would prefer anarchy to that dominance.
('30', 341, 5, 26, 765583) As equals I would value co operation of the British, but I would prefer anarchy to their dominance.
('30', 341, 5, 27, 765683) For I know that we can never become one nation through that dominance.
('30', 341, 5, 28, 765754) I can see the chance of reconciliation between Hindu and Mussalmans after
('30', 341, 6, 29, 765828) 1 A physician practising the Ayurvedic system of medicine 2 Vide “My Crime” , 5 3 1925. 3 1887 1963; Barrister and Congress leader of the Punjab
('30', 342, 0, 1, 765973) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 343
('30', 342, 1, 2, 766019) a free and hearty fight, but I see none with British arms restraining us.
('30', 342, 1, 3, 766093) We must learn to restrain ourselves.
('30', 342, 1, 4, 766130) My motto, therefore, is “Unite now, today, if you can; fight if you must.
('30', 342, 1, 5, 766204) But in every case avoid British intervention”.
('30', 342, 1, 6, 766251) I know that the temptation is great.
('30', 342, 1, 7, 766288) But, great or small, I must avoid it at all cost.
('30', 342, 1, 8, 766338) I can see swaraj rising out of the Thermopylae being enacted in every street or village in India, but I can see no swaraj out of the armed neutrality between the two communities.
('30', 342, 1, 9, 766517) There is as much need for a change of heart among the Hindus and Mussalmans, as there is among the British, before a proper settlement is arrived at.
('30', 342, 2, 10, 766667) “But who will follow your advice ?” asked the interviewer.
('30', 342, 2, 11, 766726) The Mahatma replied: I will.
('30', 342, 2, 12, 766755) Is it not enough ?
('30', 342, 2, 13, 766774) Must I surrender my belief because no one will follow it ?
('30', 342, 3, 14, 766833) “Still, that is no answer to my question,” said the interviewer.
('30', 342, 3, 15, 766898) The Mahatma answered: Your complaint is just.
('30', 342, 3, 16, 766944) I cannot however take you any further.
('30', 342, 3, 17, 766983) I know that I am at a discount just now.
('30', 342, 3, 18, 767024) People will rush to the Govern ment and in such circumstances if I were the Government, probably I would do exactly as the British are doing, i.e., try to divide both and rule.
('30', 342, 3, 19, 767201) What can one do with those who want to be ruled?
('30', 342, 3, 20, 767250) The Hindu Muslim problem is therefore just now an insoluble puzzle.
('30', 342, 3, 21, 767318) I propose to keep out of it, holding myself available whenever wanted.
('30', 342, 3, 22, 767389) I believe in God, not as a theory but a fact, more real than that of life itself.
('30', 342, 3, 23, 767471) I must therefore wait upon Him.
('30', 342, 3, 24, 767503) In the hour of my need He will guide my steps on this question as He has done hitherto.
('30', 342, 3, 25, 767591) Meanwhile, in the spinning wheel and untouchability, I have more than enough to occupy my time and that of those who think like me.
('30', 342, 3, 26, 767723) “ But will you not make some concrete suggestion for those who will (not ?)
('30', 342, 4, 27, 767799) follow your advice ?” was the last question.
('30', 342, 4, 28, 767844) I must think about them.
('30', 342, 4, 29, 767869) I do not want to add to the complications by adding a new formula to the many that are current among us, unless I see a chance of its proper working.

('30', 344, 14, 21, 770269) 1 In 1925, Phagan Sud 11 fell on March 6. The postmark, however bears the date March 7, 1925. 2 Gandhiji’s nephew and associate 3 A Tamil Daily
('30', 345, 0, 1, 770413) 346 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 345, 1, 2, 770455) college girls were already there to have the darshan 1 of Mahatmaji.
('30', 345, 2, 3, 770524) Mahatmaji asked the girls: Do you spin on the charkha?
('30', 345, 3, 4, 770579) One of the girls replied that as they were at college, they could not find time for spinning .

('30', 349, 1, 2, 778845) you have been pleased to present to me.
('30', 349, 1, 3, 778885) It is always a matter of embarrassment for me to receive addresses.
('30', 349, 1, 4, 778953) On several occasions I have described myself as a scavenger, and I should be content if I could die also as a scavenger.
('30', 349, 1, 5, 779074) I am a lover of municipal work.
('30', 349, 1, 6, 779106) Fates have decided otherwise There was a time when I was myself thinking seriously of taking to municipal life.
('30', 349, 1, 7, 779218) It is a life in which a great deal of plodding is required.
('30', 349, 1, 8, 779278) I am myself a plodder, and I call myself a scavenger because I believe in sanitation from more than one point of view, that is to say, in outward sanitation, as also inward sanitation.
('30', 349, 1, 9, 779463) I am not a stranger to Madras.
('30', 349, 1, 10, 779494) I have lived off and on several occasions in Madras, sufficiently long to enable me to study and understand the sanitation of your city; and it has always grieved me whenever I have walked through your streets early in the morning to see them disfigured.
('30', 349, 1, 11, 779749) I used to talk when I used to live with Mr. Natesan 1 about the conditions of the streets of Madras.
('30', 349, 1, 12, 779850) I do not wish to single out the streets of Madras as if they are more insanitary than the streets of other cities of India.
('30', 349, 1, 13, 779974) But I cannot help remarking upon the condition of your streets because I think that more than any other city of India, the streets of Madras were at that time disfigured even by grown up elderly men.
('30', 349, 1, 14, 780174) It was a sight to which I must confess I was unused before I came to Madras, and often did I feel like taking a broom myself and cleaning up every nook and corner of the streets through which I passed.
('30', 349, 1, 15, 780376) I still indulge in it as a pastime.
('30', 349, 1, 16, 780412) Whenever I can get a little bit of cleaning work, I assure you, it gives me a pleasure and you could understand my weakness also from municipal addresses.
('30', 349, 1, 17, 780567) If I must receive addresses at all, I always feel that the receipt of the municipal address does give me opportunity to drive this one truth home to the citizens of India.
('30', 349, 1, 18, 780739) I feel that in the matter of outward sanitation we have to learn a great deal from the West.
('30', 349, 1, 19, 780832) It has been my painful duty often to speak against the Western civilization and the methods of the West.
('30', 349, 1, 20, 780937) I, therefore, whenever I get an opportunity, never miss the opportunity of saying what we can legitimately and usefully learn from the West; and I think that for the methods of sanitation in the large cities that we have in India we cannot do better than go to the West for the lessons.
('30', 349, 1, 21, 781224) I wish I could drive the truth home to you that scavenging is an occupation which is a noble occupation although it may not give as much renown and that notoriety which services in other departments of life bring to us.

('30', 353, 1, 12, 790350) So it is with the Hindu Muslim question.
('30', 353, 1, 13, 790391) It has become a hopeless tangle at the present moment.

('30', 354, 1, 4, 791932) I know that even in that direction we have done something.
('30', 354, 1, 5, 791991) But it is sheer laziness and our ignorance that have left khaddar in the position in which it stands today.
('30', 354, 1, 6, 792099) There is no question here of passion and prejudice as there is about the Hindu Muslim problem.

('30', 354, 1, 9, 792423) It is the simplest A B C of economics that millions of the masses of India who have at least four months of idleness on their hands would be able to turn those four months to good use if they had the spinning wheels in their cottages.
('30', 354, 1, 10, 792658) Whilst a few pies per day may be nothing to you and to me, those few pies are a heavensent gift to these masses.
('30', 354, 1, 11, 792771) It must be a matter of ordinary common sense to understand that if we would have our masses to spin the charkha we must first of all learn the art that has all but died out before we would take the message of hope to these cottages.
('30', 354, 1, 12, 793004) You will agree that it will be easy enough for a child to understand that if the masses are to spin the charkha and weave khaddar, the classes and masses together must use and wear khaddar, and I am sorry to have to prophesy that if we have become so soft as not to be able to wear coarse khaddar, remember that there is no swaraj for us in this generation.

('30', 365, 4, 9, 819030) 225. SPEECH IN REPLY TO CORPORATION ADDRESS,
('30', 365, 5, 10, 819075) ERNAKULAM March 8, 1925 I thank you very sincerely for the address and the sentiments expressed in it.
('30', 365, 5, 11, 819178) It is a matter of great sorrow to me that, at the present moment, I have not beside me my friend Maulana Shaukat Ali or Maulana Mahomed Ali.
('30', 365, 5, 12, 819319) As you know we had become almost inseparable in all our travels in India.
('30', 365, 5, 13, 819393) One of the brothers, however, is today immersed in his journalism and the other Big Brother has practically buried himself in and about Bombay.
('30', 365, 5, 14, 819537) As I have arrived in this Presidency purely for the sake of visiting Vykom and entering the zone, where my work chiefly lies, during the present visit, it pleases me to receive this address from you.
('30', 365, 5, 15, 819737) This is an errand of peace and I want all the assistance that I can receive from public opinion throughout the length and breadth of this land.
('30', 365, 5, 16, 819881) Above all, I want the prayers of those who believe in prayers, whether they are HIndus, Mussalmans, Christians, Jews or Parsis.
('30', 365, 5, 17, 820009) Whatever faith they may belong to, if they believe in prayers I want their prayers for the success of my mission.
('30', 365, 5, 18, 820123) There are other things also in which I am interested and in which you should also be interested.
('30', 365, 5, 19, 820220) It makes no difference whatsoever whether you belong to British India proper or to one of the Protected States.
('30', 365, 5, 20, 820332) I refer to Hindu Muslim unity which is a form of unity amongst all the races professing the various religions of India.
('30', 365, 5, 21, 820452) I know that in this State you have no such question, as I understand, as between Hindus and Muslims or between Hindus and other races.
('30', 365, 5, 22, 820587) It is a matter of great pleasure to me to find that in this State all the races are living in peace, amity and brotherhood.
('30', 365, 5, 23, 820711) Let that state of things last
('30', 366, 0, 1, 820741) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 367
('30', 366, 1, 2, 820787) for ever.
('30', 366, 1, 3, 820797) But I am afraid I am unable to pay you the same tribute so far as the spinning wheel is concerned.
('30', 366, 1, 4, 820896) I took the oppor tunity, in replying to the address of the Madras Corporation, of mentioning the fact that no municipality’s work in India can be considered to be complete until that municipality had identified itself with the lowest of its citizens.
('30', 366, 1, 5, 821147) One often learns that the order is really reversed, that is to say, the municipalities give to those who have much and take away much from those who have very little.
('30', 366, 1, 6, 821314) They care more for the rich and the powerful and little or less for the poor and down trodden.
('30', 366, 1, 7, 821409) (“Hear, hear.”) I hope that it is not true of this town and that you are observing the proper order of things.
('30', 366, 1, 8, 821520) I therefore suggest the spinning wheel only by way of addition.
('30', 366, 1, 9, 821584) It is to me a symbol of inseparable connection between the rich and the poor.
('30', 366, 1, 10, 821662) It is the one certain definite solution for the poverty of the masses of India.
('30', 366, 1, 11, 821742) I ask you therefore to introduce the spinning wheel in your schools and also its product, khaddar.
('30', 366, 1, 12, 821841) I ask you to give it a sacred place in your homes as it occupied years and years ago.
('30', 366, 1, 13, 821927) I have not hesitated to call it one of the yajnas of this age and as the great ones do, so do the lower order of beings follow.
('30', 366, 1, 14, 822055) You will not therefore be able success fully to carry the message of the spinning wheel to the humble homes of India, unless you adopt it yourselves.
('30', 366, 1, 15, 822205) May you have the courage and the strength and the goodwill to follow the advice that I have humbly tendered to you!
('30', 366, 1, 16, 822321) The Hindu, 9 3 1925
('30', 366, 2, 17, 822341) 226. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, COCHIN
('30', 366, 3, 18, 822379) March 8, 1925
('30', 366, 4, 19, 822393) FRIENDS, It gives me much pleasure to be able to meet you.
('30', 366, 4, 20, 822452) When I decided to come to Vykom, I little thought that it would be possible and necessary for me to stay here before proceeding there.
('30', 366, 4, 21, 822587) I know that yours is a historic city.
('30', 366, 4, 22, 822625) It is full of all kinds of vivid recollections, not all of them of a pleasant type.
('30', 366, 4, 23, 822709) Living on the seaside you are aware of what adventure can do.
('30', 366, 4, 24, 822771) The sea is an epitome of adventures.
('30', 366, 4, 25, 822808) At the present moment, however, I am not concerned with the adventures that the sea offers.
('30', 366, 4, 26, 822900) What we need is the spirit of adventure in our national life and if we find that we have made but little progress towards our
('30', 367, 0, 1, 823026) 368 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 367, 1, 2, 823068) goal, it is because the spirit of adventure is absent from us.
('30', 367, 1, 3, 823131) It requires for instance an adventurous spirit to find out in the Hindu religion its black spots.
('30', 367, 1, 4, 823229) Those who are not fired with that spirit are satisfied with things as they are.
('30', 367, 1, 5, 823309) They do not stop to enquire whether they are good or bad; but ever since I have been in India, after my sojourn in South Africa for a period of nearly 20 years, I have been telling the Hindus that we have in our religion a black spot which must be removed.
('30', 367, 1, 6, 823566) It is untouchability and here I am sorry to add also unapproachability.
('30', 367, 1, 7, 823638) I have not come in order to argue with the orthodox people.
('30', 367, 1, 8, 823698) I have come with a message of peace.
('30', 367, 1, 9, 823735) I want to plead wisdom and tell them that this untouchability and unapproacha bility cannot be part of Hinduism.
('30', 367, 1, 10, 823848) I have come to tell them that the satyagrahis who are fighting against enormous odds at Vykom are not out to destroy religion, but to reform it.
('30', 367, 1, 11, 823993) I have come to tell them of all the implications of this struggle.
('30', 367, 1, 12, 824060) I have come to tell them also that it is wrong for us to be satisfied with things as they are, if we find that they are bad.
('30', 367, 1, 13, 824185) It, therefore, gives me pleasure that I shall be carrying with me your blessings and your sympathy, for in the address presented to me on your behalf by the municipality I am assured of your sympathy and support.
('30', 367, 1, 14, 824398) I want you also to carry the same spirit a little further and I want you to find with me that one of the most potent causes of the ever deepening poverty of the masses is that they have nothing to do for nearly a third part of the year throughout India.
('30', 367, 1, 15, 824652) I would like you to discover with me that if we give them the spinning wheel which had a place in every home in India only a hundred years ago, they will find enough to occupy themselves during their leisure hours.
('30', 367, 1, 16, 824867) But the introduction of the spinning wheel in the millions of our homes will be a perfectly useless thing if we do not discard the use of foreign cloth or mill made cloth.
('30', 367, 1, 17, 825039) In going about, therefore, from place to place I am pleading with those men and women whom I see that it is their bounden duty to discard the use of foreign cloth and mill made cloth and replace it with hand spun and hand woven khaddar.
('30', 367, 1, 18, 825276) For you in Malabar plenty of clothing is a burden.
('30', 367, 1, 19, 825327) I have no doubt that I am an object of envy with most of you.
('30', 367, 1, 20, 825389) In this weather of ours the least we have in the shape of clothing the better it is from every point of view.
('30', 367, 1, 21, 825499) I wish you will not run away with the idea that dignity or civilization requires multipli 
('30', 368, 0, 1, 825590) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 369
('30', 368, 1, 2, 825636) cation of clothing.
('30', 368, 1, 3, 825656) (Laughter and “hear, hear!”) “Handsome is not who is handsome clothed, but handsome is who handsome does.” The truest test of civilization, culture and dignity is character and not clothing.
('30', 368, 1, 4, 825847) I feel overwhelmed with sorrow whenever I find the people in India telling me that they have outgrown khaddar and that it is impossible for them to return to the savage days when our ancestors were satisfied with khaddar clothing.
('30', 368, 1, 5, 826078) I would like you to answer with me the critics who think in that way, that the best way of ridding India of the curse of poverty and pauperism is for one and all of us to be dressed in khaddar.
('30', 368, 1, 6, 826272) Those of you who will go in for fineries and fineness, it is possible for you to get as fine a hand spun yarn as you wish to.
('30', 368, 1, 7, 826398) I hope therefore that you will tax yourselves, tax your minds and dot every home in Cochin with the spinning wheel and see to it that everyone in Cochin uses khaddar and nothing else.
('30', 368, 1, 8, 826582) I need say nothing about the Hindu Muslim question.
('30', 368, 1, 9, 826634) I know that you miss the presence of one of the Ali Brothers.
('30', 368, 1, 10, 826696) It has been usual for one of them to be touring with me throughout India.
('30', 368, 1, 11, 826770) But it was not possible to do so this time.
('30', 368, 1, 12, 826814) But I wish to congratulate you on the freedom from this taxing problem in your midst.
('30', 368, 1, 13, 826900) It is a matter of great pleasure to me to find that all the communities belonging to the different religions are living in a spirit of goodwill and brother hood in this State.
('30', 368, 1, 14, 827076) I wish that we could in every part of India copy your worthy examples.
('30', 368, 1, 15, 827147) May God give you the strength and the wisdom to introduce khaddar and the spinning wheel in your homes and to rid Hinduism of the curse of untouchability!
('30', 368, 1, 16, 827302) May all the races inhabiting this fair land remain for ever united as they are today!
('30', 368, 2, 17, 827388) The Hindu, 9 3 1925
