('30', 371, 4, 6, 830660) They are reaping the reward of their karma.
('30', 371, 5, 7, 830704) G. No doubt they are suffering for their karma by being born as untouchables.

('30', 371, 5, 9, 830822) Are they worse than even criminals and beasts?

('30', 372, 4, 9, 832888) N. So you think those who introduced the custom were Dyers?
('30', 372, 4, 10, 832948) You would call Shankaracharya a Dyer?
('30', 372, 5, 11, 832986) G. I am calling no Acharya a Dyer.
('30', 372, 5, 12, 833021) But I do characterize your action as Dyerism, and if indeed any Acharya was responsible for introducing this custom his ignorance was as monstrous as that of General Dyer.
('30', 372, 6, 13, 833193) N. But how can we give up an ancient custom?
('30', 372, 6, 14, 833238) You say the satyagrahis are going through suffering.
('30', 372, 6, 15, 833291) Suffering is entirely on our side.
('30', 372, 6, 16, 833326) The satyagrahis sit at the gates of the temples.
('30', 372, 6, 17, 833375) Their shadow would pollute us and so we have to take a long and circuitous way to the temple.
('30', 372, 6, 18, 833469) Is that not a great hardship?
('30', 372, 7, 19, 833499) G. That surely is extraordinary.
('30', 372, 7, 20, 833532) It reminds one of the old story of the wolf and the lamb.
('30', 372, 7, 21, 833590) I beseech you to talk with some reason at least.
('30', 372, 8, 22, 833639) N. Reason is out of place in matters religious.
('30', 372, 9, 23, 833687) G. If this is an ancient sanatani custom it must obtain everywhere in India.
('30', 372, 9, 24, 833764) But I do not find it in any other part of the country.
('30', 372, 10, 25, 833819) N. Surely untouchability is there is every part of India.
('30', 372, 10, 26, 833877) We carry untouchability a little further.
('30', 372, 10, 27, 833919) That is all.
('30', 372, 11, 28, 833932) G. You say these people are worse than criminals.
('30', 372, 11, 29, 833982) Supposing they became Mussalmans or Christians tomorrow.

('30', 372, 12, 31, 834078) (The Nambudiri remained silent.

('30', 374, 1, 2, 836522) 231. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, VYKOM
('30', 374, 2, 3, 836559) March 10, 1925
('30', 374, 3, 4, 836574) FRIENDS,
('30', 374, 4, 5, 836583) I know you will excuse me for not standing up to speak to you, and I hope you will also excuse me for being a few minutes late.
('30', 374, 4, 6, 836711) I can only give you my assurance that my being late was due to no delay on my part.
('30', 374, 4, 7, 836795) I have been occupied the whole day long with the mission that has brought me here.
('30', 374, 4, 8, 836878) It gives me very great pleasure to see such a large assembly here, because it enables me to tell you the purpose of my mission.
('30', 374, 4, 9, 837006) At the outset, however, I wish to thank all those who presented me with addresses yesterday; at the time the address was presented, a letter was delivered into my hands protesting against that address and assuring me that it did not represent the sentiments of all the people in Vykom (“Shame!”).
('30', 374, 4, 10, 837303) I gladly accept that protest and inform you of it.
('30', 374, 4, 11, 837354) The very fact of the letter having been signed by a few gentlemen shows at least that they were not in sympathy with the address or rather the wording of it.
('30', 374, 4, 12, 837512) Nor does it surprise me that the address did not carry the consent of all the people of Vykom.
('30', 374, 4, 13, 837607) I know that you are unfortunately divided here over a very vital question.
('30', 374, 4, 14, 837682) So far as I am concerned, I would be happier without any address whatsoever, but when I do receive addresses, they give me a topic of conversation with the meetings which I address and this address does show that in a most particular manner.
('30', 374, 4, 15, 837924) I thank those who have pres ented me with the address this evening also.
('30', 374, 4, 16, 837997) That too deals with the subject that has brought me here and that is the subject of untouch ability and unapproachability and the method, namely, satyagraha, adopted in Vykom in order to rid this place of unapproachability in a particular way.
('30', 374, 4, 17, 838241) As you are aware, that struggle from its very inception has commanded my deep admiration and sympathy.
('30', 374, 4, 18, 838344) It is possible that the conductors of satyagraha may have made mistakes in the campaign.
('30', 374, 4, 19, 838433) Who is there in the world who is infallible?
('30', 374, 4, 20, 838478) But I am satisfied that the mistakes, if any were committed, were not deliberate.
('30', 374, 4, 21, 838560) Satyagraha, like the name itself, is a somewhat new doctrine, or rather a new presentation of an old doctrine.
('30', 374, 4, 22, 838671) The question of untouchability is one which lends itself to the method of satyagraha in a peculiar manner, for satyagraha is a method of suffering, not suffering imposed upon those who are opposed to you, but suffering imposed upon oneself.
('30', 374, 4, 23, 838912) Now the
('30', 375, 0, 1, 838920) 376 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 375, 1, 2, 838962) position taken up by the satyagrahis at Vykom is that the roads that pass by the great temple should be open to those who are considered to be untouchables or unapproachables.
('30', 375, 1, 3, 839138) The claim is based upon humanity itself.
('30', 375, 1, 4, 839179) Any road which is open to the public, so far as Hindus are concerned, any road that is open to those who are caste Hindus, should and does claim to be open to those who are thrown out of caste and considered untouchables or unapproachables.
('30', 375, 1, 5, 839420) In my humble opinion, it is a natural and just claim.
('30', 375, 1, 6, 839474) As you know, ever since I set my foot on Indian soil after a long exile in South Africa, I have been speaking frankly, fearlessly and freely on the question of untouchability.
('30', 375, 1, 7, 839650) I claim to be a sanatani Hindu.
('30', 375, 1, 8, 839682) I claim to know sufficient of the Shastras for my own purpose and I venture to suggest that untouchability and unapproachability, as they are practised in this holy land of ours, have no place or sanction in the Hindu Shastras.
('30', 375, 1, 9, 839910) (“Hear, hear”, and cheers.) Neither approve nor disapprove, but simply listen to my remarks.
('30', 375, 1, 10, 840003) I venture to suggest to those who are professors of Hinduism, who hold Hinduism as dear as life itself, that Hinduism like every other religion, apart from the sanction of Shastras, has got to submit itself to the test of universal reason.
('30', 375, 1, 11, 840243) In this age of reason, in this age of universal knowledge, in this age of education and comparative theology, any religion which entrenches itself behind Shastric injunctions and authority is, in my own humble opinion, bound to fail.
('30', 375, 1, 12, 840477) In my opinion, untouchability is a blot upon humanity and therefore upon Hinduism.
('30', 375, 1, 13, 840560) It cannot stand the test of reason.
('30', 375, 1, 14, 840596) It is in conflict with the fundamental precepts of Hinduism.
('30', 375, 1, 15, 840657) The first among the three principles I am about to enunciate of Hinduism is Satyannasti paro dharmah, 1 i.e., there is no religion other than or higher than truth.
('30', 375, 1, 16, 840821) The second is Ahimsa paramo dharmah and if ahimsa, meaning love, non violence, is the law of life, is the greatest religion, is the only religion, then I suggest to you that untouchability is in direct conflict with that truth.
('30', 375, 1, 17, 841049) The third is that God alone is Truth and everything else is transitory and illusory.
('30', 375, 1, 18, 841134) If it is so, I suggest to you that it is impossible for us to reconcile untouchability and unapp roachability with the grand doctrine.
('30', 375, 1, 19, 841269) I have come, therefore, to reason with my orthodox friends.
('30', 375, 1, 20, 841329) I have come to plead with them, and by their courtesy and goodwill.
('30', 375, 1, 21, 841397) I was able to wait upon them this afternoon.
('30', 375, 1, 22, 841442) They gave me a patient hearing and listened to me.
('30', 375, 1, 23, 841493) We argued, I appealed to their reason, I appealed to their humanity, I appealed to the Hinduism in them.
('30', 375, 2, 24, 841598) 1 Mahabharata, Shantiparva, Ch. 160
('30', 376, 0, 1, 841634) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 377
('30', 376, 1, 2, 841680) sorry to confess to you that I was not able to produce an impression that I had expected I would be able to do.
('30', 376, 1, 3, 841792) But “despair” is a term which does not occur in my dictionary.
('30', 376, 1, 4, 841855) (Laughter.) I shall despair when I despair of myself, of God and humanity.
('30', 376, 1, 5, 841930) But as I believe in God, as I believe in the fact that we are all met here together and as I believe also in humanity, because I see that in spite of all our differences, all our quarrels, humanity lives on, I believe also that the truth that I claim I represent for the time being, will impress itself upon my orthodox friends here.
('30', 376, 1, 6, 842264) I have made three sporting offers to these friends of mine.
('30', 376, 1, 7, 842324) In the name and on behalf of the satyagrahis of Vykom, those offers are binding on me, but I have left them free to reject or accept them.
('30', 376, 1, 8, 842463) I have pleaded with them that they should accept these offers even though it may be by way of trial.
('30', 376, 1, 9, 842564) I have not hesitated to enter into such unilateral contract because I believe in the truth that I implicitly believe and stand for.
('30', 376, 1, 10, 842696) For I have come not to precipitate and enhance the quarrel, but to bring about peace and goodwill between the orthodox section and those who are today trying to act in the name of humanity and justice.
('30', 376, 1, 11, 842898) Though I may seem at times to be fighting, my purpose is never to fight, nor have I undertaken a fight to prolong it, but to bring about peace at the shortest possible notice.
('30', 376, 1, 12, 843074) An English friend when I embarked upon non co operation, told me that my non co operation was only skin deep but that I was pining for co operation.
('30', 376, 1, 13, 843223) I immediately closed with him and I told him that he had read my heart correctly, and so it is with my orthodox friends, I assure them.
('30', 376, 1, 14, 843359) Satyagraha is there, but to be called off as soon as they wish it, it is for them to make a sporting offer and it will be accepted, only let them beware of murdering truth.
('30', 376, 1, 15, 843532) A satyagrahi has always his minimum and it is the minimum that is wanted in connection with this struggle.
('30', 376, 1, 16, 843639) The right of way is such a reasonable demand that it has only to be asked to be given.
('30', 376, 1, 17, 843726) Let it be understood, therefore, that there is no mental reservation behind this struggle.
('30', 376, 1, 18, 843817) I have repeatedly told the Hindus of India what the removal of untouchability means to me and to those who are today en gaged in that holy campaign.
('30', 376, 1, 19, 843966) It does not mean the breaking up of Varnashrama dharma.
('30', 376, 1, 20, 844022) It does not mean inter dining or inter marriages.
('30', 376, 1, 21, 844072) But it does mean the common relations between man and man that should exist in any civilized society.
('30', 376, 1, 22, 844174) It does mean that places of worship should be open if they are at all open to anybody, to all those who are considered Hindus.
('30', 376, 1, 23, 844301) But I grant that if there is a
('30', 377, 0, 1, 844332) 378 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 377, 1, 2, 844374) particular class, say, Brahmins, who want to build temples and exclude non Brahmins from them.
('30', 377, 1, 3, 844469) I say that it is their right to do so.
('30', 377, 1, 4, 844508) But if there is a temple which is open to non Brahmins also, then there is no such thing as a fifth caste which may be put out of that temple.
('30', 377, 1, 5, 844651) I see no warrant for such an exclusion in the Hindu Shastras.
('30', 377, 1, 6, 844713) Similarly I claim that public places such as schools should be open alike to the untouchables, if they are open to other classes.
('30', 377, 1, 7, 844843) So would it be with watering places such as wells, lakes and rivers.
('30', 377, 1, 8, 844912) That is the whole of my claim on behalf of those who are engaged in this campaign against untouchability and unapproachability.
('30', 377, 1, 9, 845040) Let me, however, clear the position a little so far as Vykom is concerned.
('30', 377, 1, 10, 845115) The present satyagraha is merely directed towards vindicating the right of the unapproachables to pass through the roads through which Christians and Mussalmans and caste Hindus are entitled to pass.
('30', 377, 1, 11, 845315) Satyagrahis today are not fighting for entry into temples.
('30', 377, 1, 12, 845374) They are not fighting—I do not know if there is any prohibition in the schools of Travancore—they are not fighting for admission in the schools, not that such is not their claim.
('30', 377, 1, 13, 845553) But I am presenting you today the implications of the present struggle.
('30', 377, 1, 14, 845625) Since satyagraha is a method of conversion and conviction, it seeks never to use the slightest coercion.
('30', 377, 1, 15, 845730) I therefore gladly endorse in its entirety the remarks made by the Dewan Sahib in his address 1 to the Travancore Assembly, and if I find the satyagrahis in Vykom in denial of their own faith use violence or any other method in order to put undue pressure upon the orthodox Hindus of Vykom, you will find me, on proof given to me, entirely dissociating myself from those satyagrahis so called.
('30', 377, 1, 16, 846124) But so long as satyagrahis keep within the terms of their contract, so long shall I consider it to be my bounden duty to give them all the assistance that a single, humble individual is capable of giving.
('30', 377, 1, 17, 846329) I plead, therefore, with all the force at my command that the orthodox Brahmins and non Brahmins of Vykom who may be opposed to this campaign study it in all its bearings, to apply their reason to bear upon the struggle and stand for justice and humanity; if they find that this struggle is just and the means adopted by the satyagrahis to vindicate the right of humanity are also fair, reasonable and non violent.
('30', 377, 1, 18, 846744) I am glad to be able to bear my testimony to the happy relations that have hitherto subsisted generally between the police authorities and the satyagrahis; they have shown how a decent gentlemanly battle can be carried on without any vexation, without any hard swearing
('30', 377, 2, 19, 847014) 1 Vide Appendix “Extract from Dewan of Travancore’s Speech on Vykom Satyagraha”, March 19, 1925.
('30', 378, 0, 1, 847111) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 379
('30', 378, 1, 2, 847157) and without violence.
('30', 378, 1, 3, 847179) I know that prejudices die hard.
('30', 378, 1, 4, 847212) Untouchability is an error of long standing.
('30', 378, 1, 5, 847257) I have, therefore, told my satyagrahi friends that they will have to exercise tremendous patience.
('30', 378, 1, 6, 847356) Time is always on the side of those who will wait upon it.
('30', 378, 1, 7, 847415) Public opinion, I hope, even of Vykom, is on their side.
('30', 378, 1, 8, 847472) Public opinion outside Vykom, I know, is on their side.
('30', 378, 1, 9, 847528) The world opinion is growing strong on their side and if the satyagrahis will only play the game well, have patience and will be able to endure silent and slow sufferings, I have no doubt that victory is theirs.
('30', 378, 1, 10, 847740) The Government of Travancore, so far as I can see from the address of the Dewan Sahib, has held the scales evenly between the two parties.
('30', 378, 1, 11, 847879) I know that my satyagrahi friends here shook their heads when I told them that the presentation by the Dewan was not open to exception.

('30', 378, 1, 13, 848259) The Dewan himself, so far as his own opinion is concerned, has told the orthodox people where his opinion lies.
('30', 378, 1, 14, 848371) He invites them to march with the times, to recognize the time spirit.
('30', 378, 1, 15, 848442) I hope my orthodox friends will listen to the sound advice given by him.
('30', 378, 1, 16, 848515) In any event, I give them my best assurance that no matter what they think of it, no matter how they behave, whether they accept my offers or reject them, I shall only do according to the behests of the Hindu religion as I know it.
('30', 378, 1, 17, 848747) I recognize no one as my enemy on the face of the earth.
('30', 378, 1, 18, 848804) I shall, therefore, love them in spite of differences between them and myself.
('30', 378, 1, 19, 848883) I shall ever pray to God that he may guide their steps in the right direction, open the eyes of their understanding, open their eyes to the writing on the wall and render justice to these down trodden countrymen of ours.
('30', 378, 1, 20, 849104) I am humble enough also to pray to God at the same time that if I have misread the Hindu Shastras, if I have misread humanity, and have erred in giving the advice that I have tendered to the satyagrahis, He will open my eyes also, show me my error and give me strength and the necessary courage to acknowledge my error and apologize to my orthodox friends.
('30', 378, 1, 21, 849461) One thing more and I have done.
('30', 378, 1, 22, 849493) When there is a difference between you and me on the question of untouchability, I hope there is no question of difference of opinion about another matter which also concerns the poorest of the land.
('30', 378, 1, 23, 849693) I refer to the spinning wheel and khaddar.

('30', 379, 0, 1, 849867) 380 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 379, 1, 2, 849909) wear the product of the spinning wheel and place a few coppers in the pockets of the poorest of your countrymen and countrywomen.
('30', 379, 1, 3, 850039) I shall not be satisfied as I have said repeatedly until the prince and the peasant, the Viceroy and his page, are clad from top to toe in khaddar, hand spun and hand made.
('30', 379, 1, 4, 850212) The third thing I need not mention to you, namely, the Hindu Muslim unity.
('30', 379, 1, 5, 850287) You have in this connection much to teach to the rest of India.
('30', 379, 1, 6, 850351) All the different races and communities belonging to different religions, I am happy to be able to know and testify, are living in perfect harmony and friendship in Travancore.
('30', 379, 1, 7, 850528) I hope that the rest of India will copy the admirable spirit which actuates you.
('30', 379, 1, 8, 850609) I thank you all for the very patient hearing you have kindly given to me and I now close with the hope and fervent prayer that the battle that is going on in Vykom may end in the only manner it should.

('30', 379, 2, 10, 850842) 232. TALK TO INMATES OF SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, VYKOM 1
('30', 379, 3, 11, 850893) [March 11, 1925] 2
('30', 379, 4, 12, 850912) (The following is almost a verbatim report of the quiet talk I gave to the inmates of the Satyagraha Ashram at Vykom.
('30', 379, 4, 13, 851030) The Ashram has at the present moment over fifty volunteers who stand or squat in front of the four barricades which are put up to guard the four entrances to the Vykom temple.
('30', 379, 4, 14, 851206) They spin whilst they are stationed there and remain there at a stretch for six hours.
('30', 379, 4, 15, 851293) They are sent in two relays.
('30', 379, 4, 16, 851322) I reproduce the talk as being of general interest and applicable to all satyagrahis.
('30', 379, 4, 17, 851407) M.K.G.) I am sorry that I shall be going away today without having a chat with you which I would regard as complete and satisfactory.
('30', 379, 4, 18, 851541) But it seems it is not possible to do more.
('30', 379, 4, 19, 851585) Those in charge of arrange ments about my programme are of opinion that I ought to see, in order to help the cause, more places than Vykom.
('30', 379, 4, 20, 851725) I have yielded to their advice but my own conviction based on past experience is that the success of the movement depends more on yourselves than on outside support.
('30', 379, 4, 21, 851891) If there is nothing in you, any amount of enthusiasm
('30', 379, 5, 22, 851944) 1 In Young India, this was published under the caption “Satyagrahi’s Duty”.
('30', 379, 5, 23, 852020) 2 From The Hindu, 14 3 1925
('30', 380, 0, 1, 852048) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 381
('30', 380, 1, 2, 852094) brought about by a passing visit like mine will be of no avail.
('30', 380, 1, 3, 852158) But if I had not come here and there had been no enthusiasm on the part of the public, and if you had been true to yourselves there would have been nothing wanting.
('30', 380, 1, 4, 852323) Your work would have commanded all the enthusiasm that might have been needed for a cause like this.
('30', 380, 1, 5, 852424) Therefore if I could have passed here a longer time than I have, it would have been more profitable.
('30', 380, 1, 6, 852525) However, that could not be done in face of the advice of friends who are guiding me.
('30', 380, 1, 7, 852610) But I want to tell you as briefly as I can what I expect of you.
('30', 380, 1, 8, 852675) I would ask you to forget the political aspect of the programme.
('30', 380, 1, 9, 852740) Political consequences of this struggle there are, but you are not to concern yourselves with them.
('30', 380, 1, 10, 852840) If you do, you will miss the true result and also miss the political consequences, and when the real heat of the struggle is touched you will be found wanting.
('30', 380, 1, 11, 853000) I am therefore anxious, even if it frightens you, to explain to you the true nature of the struggle.
('30', 380, 1, 12, 853101) It is a struggle deeply religious for the Hindus.
('30', 380, 1, 13, 853151) We are endeavouring to rid Hinduism of its greatest blot.
('30', 380, 1, 14, 853209) The prejudice we have to fight against is an age long prejudice.
('30', 380, 1, 15, 853274) The struggle for the opening of the roads round the temple which we hold to be public to the unapproachables is but a small skirmish in the big battle.
('30', 380, 1, 16, 853426) If our struggle was to end with the opening of the roads in Vykom you may be sure I would not have bothered my head about it.
('30', 380, 1, 17, 853552) If therefore you think that the struggle is to end with opening of the roads in Vykom to the unapproachables you are mistaken.
('30', 380, 1, 18, 853679) The road must be opened.

('30', 384, 3, 6, 863357) 233.NATIONAL EDUCATION
('30', 384, 4, 7, 863380) An Assistant Principal in a national institution writes:
('30', 384, 5, 8, 863437) In order to save the young generation from the slave mentality created in the Government schools, the national education movement was started on a large scale in the first decade of this century.
('30', 384, 5, 9, 863633) It only aimed at establishing schools where education was imparted “on national lines and under national control.”.
('30', 384, 5, 10, 863749) It undoubtedly produced a band of workers many of whom have taken a vigorous part in the struggle for freedom.
('30', 384, 5, 11, 863860) Nevertheless, it cannot be denied that as a purely educational movement, it had neither a separate source nor a separate existence .
('30', 384, 6, 12, 863993) The non co operation movement gave a second impetus—indeed a tremendous one– to the cause of national education.
('30', 384, 6, 13, 864106) Hundreds of mushroom schools sprang into existence all over the country.
('30', 384, 6, 14, 864179) Their object was also limited in scope.
('30', 384, 6, 15, 864219) They mainly aimed at accommodating the N.C.O. students for one year only.
('30', 384, 6, 16, 864293) The boys were to be made “Swaraj Soldiers”, i.e., workers to carry out the different items of N.C.O. Here again the educational movement had no existence separate from the political one.
('30', 384, 6, 17, 864480) When the latter lost its force, the former became feeble and infirm.
('30', 384, 7, 18, 864549) The result is that national education has always been given a secondary or subordinate place in the programme and no scientific and independent thought has ever been accorded to it by any leader.
('30', 384, 7, 19, 864745) It seems that with you it is not as dear as khaddar, or it may be that with you khaddar and national education mean one and the same thing!

('30', 386, 3, 15, 869206) 234. SOUTH AFRICA
('30', 386, 4, 16, 869224) Things are clearly going from bad to worse in South Africa and there is no telling where they will end.
('30', 386, 4, 17, 869328) In two separate measures, which have been put forward by the Government in power, “Asiatics” are discriminated against and classed with “Native”, as contrasted with the “Coloured”, people.
('30', 386, 4, 18, 869517) It is somewhat difficult for those who have never been to South Africa to understand clearly what such discrimination means.
('30', 386, 4, 19, 869642) What has to be realized is that the great bulk of the “Native” population is entirely uneducated.
('30', 386, 4, 20, 869740) On the other hand, the “Coloured” people (i.e., those who have a slight mixture of European blood in their veins) are on the whole a fairly literate community.
('30', 386, 4, 21, 869900) It appears that the policy of the new Government, under General Hertzog is to depress still further the “Asiatic” and to raise the status of the “Coloured” people.
('30', 386, 5, 22, 870064) A further measure is scheduled, whereby South African citizenship will be confined to the pure white population, which has been born and bred in South Africa.
('30', 386, 5, 23, 870223) An Englishman coming out straight from England will not have his citizenship in South Africa as an inherent right on account of his English birth and origin.
('30', 386, 5, 24, 870381) He will have to take out naturalization papers in South Africa.
('30', 386, 5, 25, 870445) Leading newspapers in South Africa suggest that a compact has been made between the Labour Party (which relies chiefly on the British labour
('30', 387, 0, 1, 870586) 388 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 387, 1, 2, 870628) vote) and the Nationalist Party (which relies chiefly on the Dutch vote) on the understanding that the Nationalist will support a strong anti Asiatic labour policy provided that the labourites will support a strong “burgher” policy.
('30', 387, 1, 3, 870861) In addition to this, we have the further news that a new segregation measure, of even more drastic character than the late “Class Areas Bill”, is already being prepared.
('30', 387, 1, 4, 871031) It will be remembered that the Municipal Franchise Act for Natal, depriving Indians in future of municipal franchise, has now been passed and sanctioned by the Governor General.
('30', 387, 1, 5, 871209) If a racial Segregation Act is also passed, it will be difficult to see what will still remain of “vested rights”, which were to be strictly observed under the Smuts Gandhi Agreement of 1914.
('30', 387, 2, 6, 871401) In the Transvaal, a picketing system and a boycott of all Indian trade has again been started.
('30', 387, 2, 7, 871496) This time, in the present inflamed atmosphere— it has met with some measure of success.
('30', 387, 2, 8, 871584) The repatriation of Indians in Natal by means of Government “recruiters” is still proceeding.
('30', 387, 2, 9, 871678) I have personally cross examined those in Madras who have returned.
('30', 387, 2, 10, 871746) They have told me that they have been unable to find employment in India.
('30', 387, 2, 11, 871820) They are therefore now to be found, after great misery and privation, entering the emigration depot for Malaya, asking to be sent out of India to the rubber plantations of the Federated Malaya States.
('30', 387, 2, 12, 872021) Truly the whole situation of Indians in South Africa has reached the lowest point where even stout hearts may find it difficult to look forward to the future with hope.
('30', 387, 2, 13, 872190) There is one redeeming feature, however, which continually meets us in every fresh information that reaches us in India.
('30', 387, 2, 14, 872311) The Hindu Muslim problem out there does not exist.
('30', 387, 2, 15, 872362) In face of common suffering Indians are one people—one in heart and soul as well as one in Indian birth.

('30', 387, 3, 17, 872630) The picketing referred to by Mr. Andrews is nothing but veiled coercion.
('30', 387, 3, 18, 872703) If with all the elaborate precautions it did not remain peaceful everywhere in India in 1921, how less likely it is to be peaceful in South Africa, only those who know its white population can realize.

('30', 389, 2, 13, 876739) 236. BIRTH CONTROL
('30', 389, 3, 14, 876758) It is not without the greatest hesitation and reluctance that I approach the subject.
('30', 389, 3, 15, 876844) The question of using artificial methods for birth control has been referred to me by correspondents ever since my return to India.
('30', 389, 3, 16, 876976) Though I have answered them personally, I have never hitherto dealt with the subject publicly.
('30', 389, 3, 17, 877071) My attention was drawn to the subject, now thirty five years ago, when I was a student in England.
('30', 389, 3, 18, 877170) There was then a hot controversy raging between a purist who would not countenance anything but natural means and a doctor who advocated artificial means.
('30', 389, 3, 19, 877325) It was at that early time in my life that I became, after leanings for a brief period towards artificial means, a convinced opponent of them.
('30', 389, 3, 20, 877467) I now observe that in some Hindi papers the methods are described in a revoltingly open manner which shocks one’s sense of decency.
('30', 389, 3, 21, 877599) I observe, too, that one writer does not hesitate to cite my name as among the supporters of artificial methods of birth control.
('30', 389, 3, 22, 877729) I cannot recall a single occasion when I spoke or wrote in favour of such methods.
('30', 389, 3, 23, 877812) I have seen also two distinguished names having been used in support.
('30', 389, 3, 24, 877882) I hesitate to publish them without reference to their owners.
('30', 389, 3, 25, 877944) There can be no two opinions about the necessity of birth 
('30', 390, 0, 1, 878003) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 391
('30', 390, 1, 2, 878049) control.
('30', 390, 1, 3, 878058) But the only method handed down from ages past is self control or brahmacharya.
('30', 390, 1, 4, 878138) It is an infallible sovereign remedy doing good to those who practise it.
('30', 390, 1, 5, 878212) And medical men will earn the gratitude of mankind, if instead of devising artificial means of birth control they will find out the means of self control.
('30', 390, 1, 6, 878367) The union is meant not for pleasure but for bringing forth progeny.
('30', 390, 1, 7, 878435) And union is a crime when the desire for progeny is absent.
('30', 390, 1, 8, 878495) Artificial methods are like putting a premium upon vice.
('30', 390, 1, 9, 878552) They make men and women reckless.
('30', 390, 1, 10, 878586) And respectability that is being given to the methods must hasten the dissolution of the restraints that public opinion puts upon one.
('30', 390, 1, 11, 878721) Adoption of artificial methods must result in imbecility and nervous prostration.
('30', 390, 1, 12, 878803) The remedy will be found to be worse than the disease.
('30', 390, 1, 13, 878858) It is wrong and immoral to seek to escape the consequences of one’s acts.
('30', 390, 1, 14, 878932) It is good for a person who overeats to have an ache and a fast.
('30', 390, 1, 15, 878997) It is bad for him to indulge his appetite and then escape the consequence by taking tonics or other medicine.
('30', 390, 1, 16, 879107) It is still worse for a person to indulge in his animal passions and escape the consequences of his acts.
('30', 390, 1, 17, 879213) Nature is relentless and will have full revenge for any such violation of her laws.
('30', 390, 1, 18, 879297) Moral results can only be produced by moral restraints.
('30', 390, 1, 19, 879353) All other restraints defeat the very purpose for which they are intended.
('30', 390, 1, 20, 879427) The reasoning underlying the use of artificial methods is that indulgence is a necessity of life.
('30', 390, 1, 21, 879525) Nothing can be more fallacious.
('30', 390, 1, 22, 879557) Let those who are eager to see the births regulated explore the lawful means devised by the ancients and try to find out how they can be revived.
('30', 390, 1, 23, 879703) An enormous amount of spade work lies in front of them.
('30', 390, 1, 24, 879759) Early marriages are fruitful source of adding to the population.
('30', 390, 1, 25, 879824) The present mode of life has also a great deal to do with the evil of unchecked procreation.
('30', 390, 1, 26, 879917) If these causes are investigated and dealt with, society will be morally elevated.
('30', 390, 1, 27, 880000) If they are ignored by impatient zealots and if artificial methods become the order of the day, nothing but moral degradation can be the result.
('30', 390, 1, 28, 880145) A society that has already become enervated through a variety of causes will become still further enervated by the adoption of artificial methods.
('30', 390, 1, 29, 880292) Those men therefore who are light heartedly advocating artificial methods cannot do better than study the subject afresh, stay their injurious activity and popularize brahmacharya both for the married and the unmarried.
('30', 390, 1, 30, 880512) That is the only noble and straight method of birth control.

('30', 397, 1, 2, 895146) 238. THE LOWLANDS OF KENYA 1
('30', 397, 2, 3, 895175) After a recent visit to Delhi, I feel it to be of the utmost importance to make plain, beyond any shadow of misunderstanding, how emphatically I should object to anyone being sent out from India officially to investigate an area in the Lowlands of Kenya in which large free grants of Crown lands should be given to Indians for colonization purposes.
('30', 397, 3, 4, 895525) In the first place, to accept even tentatively such an offer, or even to examine it with a view to approval, is to stultify the whole Indian position.
('30', 397, 3, 5, 895676) For the Indian claim is not to receive free grants of Crown lands anywhere, but to recover the legal rights of sale and purchase of land in the Highlands which have been illegally taken away after a solemn promise had been made that they should remain intact.
('30', 397, 3, 6, 895936) Indians are asking for an elementary right of citizenship.
('30', 397, 3, 7, 895995) They are asking to be placed on a basis of equality with other citizens in the eyes of the law.
('30', 397, 3, 8, 896091) It, therefore, can easily be seen, that if Indians even examine the proposal that they should be given grants in the Lowlands, it will be certainly understood as their final abandonment of legal rights elsewhere.
('30', 397, 3, 9, 896304) I do not think that it can be made too plain, that the very act of sending an Indian official to examine an area in the Lowlands will be interpreted as a giving up of Indian legal rights in the Highlands altogether.
('30', 397, 3, 10, 896520) In the second place, for Indians to use the British military force to take possession of a large area in the Lowlands, thus depriving the natives of still further territory, in addition to the 12,000 square miles of fertile soil that has been taken from them in the Highlands by the whites, is to commit an injustice.
('30', 397, 3, 11, 896838) It means that India, for the first time, by a definite act is prepared to enter upon a policy of imperial “grab”, wherever an opportunity occurs.
('30', 397, 3, 12, 896984) That the African Natives, as far as they have any voice or power, will most strongly object to any such policy of “grab”, on the part of India, goes without saying.
('30', 397, 3, 13, 897149) If they are voiceless and powerless, then the wrong done to them will be all the greater.
('30', 397, 3, 14, 897239) It must be remembered that Kenya is not an empty country, with no Native inhabitants.
('30', 397, 3, 15, 897325) It is a large territory, with only a very small fraction of good, well watered agricultural land.
('30', 397, 3, 16, 897423) If it had not been for the labour exploitation that has been going on, with its inevitable demoralization, the Native population would already have spread over the cultivable soil and occupied it.
('30', 397, 3, 17, 897620) Even today, in spite of the exploitation that has taken place, the Native “reserves” are already proving too small.
('30', 397, 3, 18, 897736) It would be an act of grave injustice, therefore, if Indians were to seize, under the cover of British and Indian bayonets, a great slice of the territory still remaining open for Native occupation.
('30', 397, 4, 19, 897935) 1 This was C. F. Andrews’ article to which Gandhiji appended a note.
('30', 398, 0, 1, 898004) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 399
('30', 398, 1, 2, 898050) In the third place, the Indian claim to free immigration into Kenya and Uganda is based entirely on the ground that Indians are helping and not hindering the Native advancement.
('30', 398, 1, 3, 898228) There is no other claim than this.
('30', 398, 1, 4, 898263) What is put forward is this, that for two thousand years the trade between East Africa and India has gone on.
('30', 398, 1, 5, 898373) Indians have come freely to East Africa and have been hospitably received because they came in peace and not for war; because the trade and the barter that they brought with them was mutually beneficial.
('30', 398, 1, 6, 898577) East Aricans have, from this side, been able to come freely to India in the same manner.
('30', 398, 1, 7, 898666) They have been hospitably received for the same reason.
('30', 398, 1, 8, 898722) Thus free emigration on both sides has been encouraged and has prevailed.
('30', 398, 1, 9, 898796) But if an entirely new relationship is advocated—the relationship (however decently veiled) of conquest and possession,—the whole aspect changes.
('30', 398, 1, 10, 898942) The Indian claim, to respect the Native and to benefit the Native, falls to the ground.
('30', 398, 1, 11, 899030) Indians become imperialistic invaders of Africa and are classed as such in the same category with the Europeans.
('30', 398, 1, 12, 899143) Though feeling the iron yoke of subjection themselves, they are ready to bring others into subjection.
('30', 398, 1, 13, 899246) They do not any longer stand out on the side of the oppressed, but themselves take the side of the oppressors and their own share of the spoils.
('30', 398, 1, 14, 899391) Any such action on the part of responsible Indians, on such a large scale as is now contemplated, is to me unthinkable.
('30', 398, 1, 15, 899511) I entirely endorse Mr. Andrews’ view that it would be wrong in every way to countenance the idea of Indians being excluded from the highlands and restricted to the lowlands especially if it is true that the lowlands have to be stolen from the native of the soil.

('30', 398, 3, 22, 900105) The caste system has in my opinion a scien tific basis.
('30', 398, 3, 23, 900161) Reason does not revolt against it.

('30', 414, 6, 13, 940626) The majority of diseases in towns were due to dirt, filth and filthy air.
('30', 414, 6, 14, 940700) He instanced the case of Trichinopoly where nuisance was committed on the banks of the Cauvery, the water of which was drunk by the people.
('30', 414, 6, 15, 940840) Though Trichinopoly was a big town, its water supply was so awfully neglected by its citizens, but in Trivandrum he was struck by its cleanliness.
('30', 414, 6, 16, 940987) People stifled themselves in big towns and cities in dungeons where no fresh air could be had and he was glad they lived in cottages in Travancore scattered all over the land.
('30', 414, 6, 17, 941163) As a lover of municipal life, he had studied the activities of many Corporations and considered it a misfortune that he had not been able to devote his lifetime to municipal service.

('30', 415, 4, 14, 943050) March 14, 1925 After paying a short visit to the Fort High School and the Mahila Mandiram, an association for women to which a hostel also is attached, Mahatma Gandhi came to the Law College where Mr. M. K. Govinda Pillai, Acting Principal of the College, received him.
('30', 415, 4, 15, 943320) An address was presented by the students to which Mahatmaji made a reply in the course of which he gave an account of his early education, his first voyage to England and his initiation into the bar 40 years ago when the profession was overcrowded.
('30', 415, 4, 16, 943569) He advised the students who took to law to have a complete mastery of facts, to understand human nature, to sift every case given to them, and if they found it a just cause that commended itself to them, to take it up or otherwise throw it overboard.
('30', 415, 4, 17, 943820) They as lawyers should not sell their conscience for a mess of pottage.
('30', 415, 4, 18, 943892) When they got a good case, they should identify themselves with the client and make the client’s case their own by asking for all the facts they wanted without being led by him.
('30', 415, 4, 19, 944070) You know how strongly I have spoken against lawyers and their ways—but who should speak if not I who knew all the intricacies of legal life, who knew all the spheres of a legal life—and so I took courage to deliver myself of what was within me in connection with the legal profession.
('30', 415, 5, 20, 944355) 1 In reply to an address of welcome presented by the students of the College
('30', 416, 0, 1, 944432) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 417
('30', 416, 1, 2, 944478) The late Sir Pherozeshah Mehta and Badruddin Tyabji 1 were not by any means the tallest among lawyers, but their services to the national cause were invaluable.
('30', 416, 1, 3, 944639) The late Mana Mohan Ghose 2 was a friend of the poor and he refused to charge fees when it was a poor man’s case.
('30', 416, 1, 4, 944753) He rendered invaluable services at the time of the Indigo riots in Bengal.
('30', 416, 2, 5, 944828) In asking them to study the lives of lawyers like Ghose, Mahatma Gandhi asked them not merely to be satisfied with the heritage those great lawyers had left for them, but wished the present generation to do better.
('30', 416, 2, 6, 945043) They should become the poor man’s friend in every sense and then alone would they be able to justify the legal profession.
('30', 416, 2, 7, 945166) Their end was not to get more than a decent livelihood or how to shine in life, but to serve humanity in order to serve the motherland.
('30', 416, 2, 8, 945302) They ought not to become lawyers in order to increase cases.
('30', 416, 2, 9, 945363) The education they received ought not to be prostituted to the base use of earning a livelihood, it ought to be used to promote moral growth to enable them to realize themselves, to understand that there was the Maker who saw everything and registered all thoughts, pure and impure, and the learning they derived should be dedicated to a vigorous self analysis and not prostituted.
('30', 416, 3, 10, 945745) Concluding, Mahatmaji gave the students the message of the spinning wheel and asked them to remember that not from the law books or platform oratory but only from the spinning wheel would they find the deliverance of India.
('30', 416, 4, 11, 945969) A purse of Rs.500 was given over to Mahatmaji as proceeds of collections made yesterday at the public meeting.

('30', 417, 1, 2, 946499) 248. IN SEARCH OF KNOWLEDGE
('30', 417, 2, 3, 946527) A French writer has written a story with the title "In Search of Knowledge".
('30', 417, 2, 4, 946604) The writer sends many learned men in this search to different continents.
('30', 417, 2, 5, 946678) One of them comes to India.
('30', 417, 2, 6, 946706) This seeker goes to those who have understood Brahman 1 to those who have learned the Shastras, to coutriers and others, but fails to get knowledge anywhere.
('30', 417, 2, 7, 946864) He is convinced that knowledge means the search for God.
('30', 417, 2, 8, 946921) Finally, he comes upon the home of an Antyaja.
('30', 417, 2, 9, 946968) Here he finds devotion at its best.
('30', 417, 2, 10, 947004) Here for the first time he experiences simplicity, innocence, and artlessness.
('30', 417, 2, 11, 947083) Here he comes face to face with God, and he reaches the conclusion that one who wishes to discover God easily must search for Him amongst the poor and the humble.
('30', 417, 2, 12, 947246) This is an imaginary story.
('30', 417, 2, 13, 947274) Our Shastras, however, bear witness to this very truth.
('30', 417, 2, 14, 947330) Sudama 1 readily found God.
('30', 417, 2, 15, 947358) Mirabai 2 found God when she ceased to be a queen.
('30', 417, 2, 16, 947409) Duryodhana 3, because he went and sat near Krishna’s head, got the latter’s army only.
('30', 417, 2, 17, 947496) God became the charioteer of Arjuna 4 who sat at His feet.
('30', 417, 2, 18, 947555) These thoughts have occurred to me because of the following letter: 5
('30', 417, 3, 19, 947625) It has been written by one who has a clear conscience.
('30', 417, 3, 20, 947680) The correspondent is in search of knowledge.
('30', 417, 3, 21, 947725) However, the more he seeks it, the more it evades him.
('30', 417, 3, 22, 947780) He is making vain efforts to grasp by reason something which is beyond reason.
('30', 417, 3, 23, 947859) Giving up the desire for the fruit of one’s action does not imply that no result will follow.
('30', 417, 3, 24, 947953) It implies that every action brings in its result and in the mysterious scheme of things, where fibres are so interwoven that the trunk is not distinguishable from the branches, who can identify the fruit of one man’s action amidst the complex of the collective acts of many persons?
('30', 417, 3, 25, 948237) What right have we to know this?
('30', 417, 3, 26, 948270) Even a king’s soldier has no right to know the result of his own action, why should we who are the servants of the people know the results of our particular actions?

('30', 419, 2, 9, 952019) 249. CONCERNING “NAVAJIVAN ”
('30', 419, 3, 10, 952048) A subscriber of Navajivan has written a long letter of complaint.
('30', 419, 3, 11, 952114) Its substance is as follows: 1. Navajivan has become like a monthly magazine because it contains uninteresting and depressing articles on the spinning wheel and khadi.
('30', 419, 3, 12, 952282) 2. Mahadev gives something like a diary of my tours in the Navajivan and goes on writing on the same theme.
('30', 419, 3, 13, 952390) 3. The supplement to Navajivan which is supposed to deal with education gives disheartening news regarding education; but it too has no plans for education.
('30', 419, 3, 14, 952547) 4. Other articles find no place in Navajivan.
('30', 419, 3, 15, 952593) This is indeed the limit.
('30', 419, 3, 16, 952619) 5. Perhaps no other weekly in the world is as expensive as Navajivan.
('30', 419, 3, 17, 952689) Moreover, although the prices of paper have gone down, the price of Navajivan remains the same.
('30', 419, 3, 18, 952785) There is some truth in these arguments.
('30', 419, 3, 19, 952825) The subscriber wishes me to discuss this matter in the paper.
('30', 419, 3, 20, 952887) I regard the subscribers as partners in Navajivan.
('30', 419, 3, 21, 952938) I insist on publishing it only as long as a certain minimum number of persons subscribe to it.
('30', 419, 3, 22, 953033) I also propose to meet its expenses through subscriptions alone and not through advertisements.
('30', 419, 3, 23, 953129) Hence its subscribers can, if they so desire, put an end to its publication.

('30', 420, 1, 2, 953252) It is indeed true that Navajivan is not a newspaper, but a paper intended to propagate certain views.
('30', 420, 1, 3, 953354) It tests these views in two ways: in the first place by bringing them up for discussion from time to time, and secondly, by finding out the number of people who support these views.
('30', 420, 1, 4, 953536) Navajivan searches for the means for securing swaraj and puts them before the public; hence it presents something new.
('30', 420, 1, 5, 953655) It does not attempt to do what other newspapers do.
('30', 420, 1, 6, 953707) What is not found in other newspapers constantly appears in Navajivan, and in this way the paper maintains its novelty and distinctiveness.
('30', 420, 1, 7, 953847) It does not propose to compete with other newspapers.
('30', 420, 1, 8, 953901) It is obvious that Navajivan is not as interesting as it used to be.
('30', 420, 1, 9, 953970) At one time its subscribers numbered about 40,000 as against only 6,000 today.
('30', 420, 1, 10, 954049) Swami Anand believes that the reason is that now a days I write more for Young India and less for Navajivan.
('30', 420, 1, 11, 954158) I do not think this is correct.
('30', 420, 1, 12, 954190) Young India is in the same pitiable plight today as Navajivan.
('30', 420, 1, 13, 954253) Its circulation, too, which had reached the figure of 30,000 is now almost the same as that of Navajivan.
('30', 420, 1, 14, 954359) Nevertheless, I still cherish the desire to write more in Navajivan.
('30', 420, 1, 15, 954428) God willing, it will be fulfilled, and then the Swami’s doubts will be resolved.
('30', 420, 1, 16, 954509) The fact is that what I am putting before the public now is neither intoxicating nor exciting.
('30', 420, 1, 17, 954604) Moreover, there is no hope of winning swaraj soon.
('30', 420, 1, 18, 954655) Navajivan does not put forward new means for securing swaraj but it rather attempts to place before the public the same old means in new ways.
('30', 420, 1, 19, 954798) It is interesting precisely because it is uninteresting.
('30', 420, 1, 20, 954855) As it promotes the cause of swaraj, it is only those who have faith in the spinning wheel and such other means that subscribe to it; this is enough to satisfy me.

('30', 422, 2, 7, 958863) 250. QUINTESSENCE OF NON VIOLENCE
('30', 422, 3, 8, 958897) A certain gentleman asks the following questions:
('30', 422, 4, 9, 958947) 1. Is it a fact that in the manufacture of foreign sugar, bones, blood and such other unclean things are added?
('30', 422, 5, 10, 959059) 2. Can anyone who observes the vow of non violence consume foreign sugar?
('30', 422, 6, 11, 959133) 3. Will thsoe who wear khadi as a matter of non violence continue to do so after securing swaraj or will they wear all kinds of cloth afterwards?
('30', 422, 7, 12, 959279) 4. Is Khadi related to non violence or is it a political matter?
('30', 422, 7, 13, 959344) As between [Indian] mill made cltoh and foreign cloth, which is worse from the standpoint of violence, considering that both are equally machine made?
('30', 422, 8, 14, 959495) 5. Can anyone who observes the vow of non violence drink tea?
('30', 422, 8, 15, 959557) If the answer is in the negative, how does it involve any violence?
('30', 422, 8, 16, 959625) I hesitate to answer such questions as they indicate ignorance.
('30', 422, 8, 17, 959689) Nevertheless, since readers frequently raise such doubts, it is proper that they should be resolved.
('30', 422, 8, 18, 959790) Moreover, while answering these questions, I wish to indicate the essence of non violence as I understand it.
('30', 422, 8, 19, 959900) It is not that foreign sugar contains bones and such other substances, but that these are said to be used in the process of refining sugar.
('30', 422, 8, 20, 960040) There is no reason to believe that Indian sugar is not subjected to this same.
('30', 422, 8, 21, 960119) process.
('30', 422, 8, 22, 960128) Hence, from the standpoint of non violence, the use of both kinds of sugar should, perhaps, be given up.
('30', 422, 8, 23, 960233) Or, if it has to be taken, the process of its manufacture should be ascertained.
('30', 422, 8, 24, 960314) Thus, foreign
('30', 423, 0, 1, 960328) 424 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 423, 1, 2, 960370) sugar has to be renounced solely for giving an impetus to swadeshi.
('30', 423, 1, 3, 960438) There is, however, a subtle non violent consideration for which all sugar might be given up.
('30', 423, 1, 4, 960531) Every process involves violence, hence the less an edible substance is processed, the better.
('30', 423, 1, 5, 960625) It is best to eat sugarcane, jaggery is next in order, and sugar is the worst of all.
('30', 423, 1, 6, 960711) I do not see any necessity for the common man to enter into such minute details.

('30', 423, 1, 8, 960919) The very same means by which we shall secure swaraj will enable us to preserve and strengthen it.

('30', 424, 5, 19, 964858) A teacher writes: 2
('30', 424, 6, 20, 964878) As this teacher has answered his own questions, my task is simplified.
('30', 424, 6, 21, 964949) What I had said could not possibly mean that ten teachers
('30', 424, 7, 22, 965007) 1 A medieval Gujarati saint poet 2 The letter is not translated here.
('30', 425, 0, 1, 965077) 426 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 425, 1, 2, 965119) or a single teacher should rest after teaching only one child.
('30', 425, 1, 3, 965182) My contention is that not merely ten but even twenty teachers should not forsake a solitary student or leave a school but should try to increase their number.
('30', 425, 1, 4, 965341) When plenty of students are available, the teacher should draw an allowance sufficient for his living, but his true test lies in his ability to accept nothing and starve to death if the need arises, and let his dependents also starve to death.
('30', 425, 1, 5, 965585) Such a teacher sacrifices his relations, his parents, his children, his all for his work.
('30', 425, 1, 6, 965675) What do those who practise other professions do when they incur heavy losses?
('30', 425, 1, 7, 965753) If a person does not find a job despite all possible efforts, he lets his dependents starve along with himself; this should be the case with the teachers in national schools.
('30', 425, 1, 8, 965928) This would make our dependents work for their livelihood.
('30', 425, 1, 9, 965986) When teachers are idle for want of students, they should, of course, take up some other activity, but even while doing so, they must try to revive the school.
('30', 425, 1, 10, 966145) Moreover, seeking out some other activity means that, in the absence of children, and during spare time, they should earn their living through the work of carding and weaving.

('30', 425, 2, 12, 966358) 252. SPEECH IN REPLY TO WELCOME ADDRESSES,
('30', 425, 3, 13, 966401) KOTTAYAM 1
('30', 425, 4, 14, 966412) March 15, 1925 It has given me pleasure to be able to come to a place which is the centre of Christian influence.
('30', 425, 4, 15, 966526) All the world over, I enjoy the privilege of having many Christian friends and I expect from Christians in India a great deal.
('30', 425, 4, 16, 966653) There is nothing in the programme that I have ventured to place before the nation in which a Christian cannot whole heartedly participate.
('30', 425, 4, 17, 966792) Indeed I go so far as to say, if I may do so in all humility, that a Christian is the less a Christian if he does not whole heartedly participate in this constructive programme.
('30', 425, 4, 18, 966970) Those who are born and bred in this land, and to whom this land is as much the motherland as it is to me, as it is to the Mussalmans, if these Christians do not promote the nation’s growth, to that extent, I venture to say, they are denying Christianity.
('30', 425, 4, 19, 967225) You cannot serve God and
('30', 425, 5, 20, 967250) 1 The addresses were presented by the Kottayam Municipality and the Hindi students.
('30', 426, 0, 1, 967334) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 427
('30', 426, 1, 2, 967380) refuse to serve your neighbours.
('30', 426, 1, 3, 967413) But he who passes over his neighbour, be he Hindu, Christian or Mussalman, denies his God.
('30', 426, 1, 4, 967504) I, therefore, suggest to my Christian friends that they should regard it as a special privilege, and therefore special duty, to serve India to the best of their ability.
('30', 426, 1, 5, 967674) We may have different religions, we may hold different views about our conception of God, we may have different views about salvation.
('30', 426, 1, 6, 967809) But there is one thing which binds all Indians to the soil.
('30', 426, 1, 7, 967869) There is one thing which binds all Indians, one to another, is an indissoluble tie and that is the spinning wheel and its product khaddar.
('30', 426, 1, 8, 968008) I harp upon khaddar and the spinning wheel in season and out of season beacause I know that in khaddar alone, in the spinning wheel alone, lies the economic salvation of India.
('30', 426, 1, 9, 968185) The spinning wheel is a symbol and a symbol of the binding tie between the masses and the classes.
('30', 426, 1, 10, 968284) The classes derive their sustenance from the labour of the masses and I beg the classes to make some small return to the masses for what they receive from them.
('30', 426, 1, 11, 968445) I, therefore, say to every Indian, also to every Englishman domiciled in India, or who derives his livelihood from India, let him adopt khaddar.
('30', 426, 1, 12, 968590) In his own home let him dress himself from top to toe in khaddar and make a return to the masses.
('30', 426, 1, 13, 968688) (Cheers.) I say to the women of Kottayam and the surrounding places and to the men: “If you will reinstate the spinning wheel in your homes, you will find that you have delivered to the famishing millions of India a message of hope and comfort.”
('30', 426, 2, 14, 968934) Referring to untouchability he said: Her Highness and the Dewan have assured me of their sympathy with the reformers and if I have understood them correctly I know that they are only waiting for an emphatic, unequivocal, disciplined and articulate expression of public opinion on the part of the savarna Hindus in order to do away with this disgrace and if the Hindus are true to their faith and will consider themselves as the custodians of the dignity of their religion, and if they feel as keenly as I do about this untouchability, they will not rest satisfied unless they have convinced the Maharani Regent and the Dewan that the whole public opinion of Travancore demands this reform.

('30', 427, 1, 2, 969687) 253. ALL INDIA COW PROTECTION SABHA
('30', 427, 2, 3, 969723) [March 15, 1925] 1
('30', 427, 3, 4, 969742) Readers will recall that among the many conferences held at Belgaum last December, there was one for the protection of cows.
('30', 427, 3, 5, 969867) Reluctantly I yielded to importunity and became its chairman.
('30', 427, 3, 6, 969929) I believe that the protection of cows is an important and necessary task in this age for those who believe in Hinduism.
('30', 427, 3, 7, 970049) I think I have been carrying on this work for many years in my own way.
('30', 427, 3, 8, 970121) The whole of India is aware that the protection of cows is one of the vital reasons for the friendship that I deliberately wish to cultivate with the Muslims.
('30', 427, 3, 9, 970280) However, I do not regard saving cows from Muslims as the most important aspect of cow protection.
('30', 427, 3, 10, 970378) The most important aspect is to make Hindus protect cows.
('30', 427, 3, 11, 970436) My definition of cow protection includes sparing cows and bullocks from the cruelty to which they are subjected.
('30', 427, 3, 12, 970549) However, I have taken little direct interest until today in this great task of protection.
('30', 427, 3, 13, 970640) I have practised penance in order to be worthy of taking such a part but have not yet attained such worthiness.
('30', 427, 3, 14, 970752) I was, therefore, hesitant to accept the chair, and yet I did accept it.
('30', 427, 3, 15, 970825) One of the resolutions of the conference related to establishing a permanent committee.
('30', 427, 3, 16, 970913) I had to take part in that too.
('30', 427, 3, 17, 970945) Hence, the committee nominated by the conference met in the last week of January 2 in Delhi.
('30', 427, 3, 18, 971038) At that meeting it was decided to establish an All India Cow protection Sabha; its constitution was framed and accepted by the committee.
('30', 427, 3, 19, 971176) The fact that this Sabha could progress so far is primarily due to the famous worker for the cause of the cows, Chaunde Maharaj, who comes from Wai.
('30', 427, 3, 20, 971325) I am being drawn to it by his earnestness and initiative.
('30', 427, 3, 21, 971383) The members of the committee included Dadasaheb Karandikar, Lala Lajpat Rai, Babu Bhagwandas 3, Shri Kelkar 4, Dr. Moonje 5, Swami Shraddhanandji 6 and others.

('30', 428, 1, 27, 974121) My pen shakes as I write this.

('30', 430, 1, 2, 976374) 255. LETTER TO W. H. PITT
('30', 430, 2, 3, 976400) ALWAI, March 18, 1925
('30', 430, 3, 4, 976422) DEAR MR. PITT 1 , With reference to the conversations 2 we have had as to the possibility and desirability of removing the barriers at Vykom and the picket which prevent satyagrahi volunteers from crossing the boundary line on the roads leading to the temple, the position as I understand is this.
('30', 430, 3, 5, 976720) It is common cause between Government and the reformers that the embargo upon the so called untouchables making use of the roads around the temple should be removed.
('30', 430, 3, 6, 976886) In your opinion the cause I have at heart will succeed earlier if I advise the satyagrahis to respect the boundary line pending final decision without the barricades and the picket.
('30', 430, 3, 7, 977068) You tell me that the orthodox opinion gathers strength from the presence of the barricades and the picket, because the orthodox people wrongly infer that the intention in putting up the barricades and keeping the pickets is to help them to maintain their position.
('30', 430, 3, 8, 977333) I have gathered from our conversations that it would be possible for you to have the existing orders withdrawn under which you are acting, if I undertake to respect the boundary line in the manner suggested by you.
('30', 430, 3, 9, 977548) Whilst I hesitate to believe that the action proposed by you, if taken by the satyagrahis, will soften the hearts of the orthodox people and weaken their position, I fully appreciate the motive that lies behind your suggestion.
('30', 430, 3, 10, 977776) I am, therefore, prepared to advise, by way of trial, adoption of the suggestion made by you.
('30', 430, 3, 11, 977870) After all, what the satyagrahis want is to create an active and overwhelming public opinion in their behalf.
('30', 430, 3, 12, 977979) Their object is not to irritate orthodoxy but to win it over to their side.
('30', 430, 3, 13, 978055) Their object moreover is in no way to embarrass the Government in the prosecution of the campaign but, so far as it is possible, to enlist its sympathy and support on their side.
('30', 430, 3, 14, 978234) I am therefore prepared to act upon your suggestion immediately on learning from you that the prohibitory order referred to herein is withdrawn.
('30', 430, 3, 15, 978379) The effect of this would be that a very small number, not larger than at present, will continue to march up to the boundary line by way of pleading their cause and stand or spin as they are now doing in front of the lines.
('30', 430, 4, 16, 978602) 1 Commissioner of Police, Trivandrum 2 The interview took place on March 10 at Trivandrum.
('30', 431, 0, 1, 978693) 432 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 431, 1, 2, 978735) They will not cross it on any account whatsoever whilst their agreement lasts and I expect that if it ever becomes necessary to challenge in a court of law the so called right or custom under which the so called untouchables are prohibited from making use of the roads round the temple the prosecution would be under the ordinary criminal law of Travancore.
('30', 431, 1, 3, 979093) But I am hoping, with the assistance of the Travancore Government, to formulate public opinion so that it becomes irresistible and that without recourse to law on either side the common right of using public or semi public roads is not denied to any class of people by reason of their birth.
('30', 431, 1, 4, 979385) I have already discussed with you the three proposals made by me, namely, referendum by taking the vote of the savarna Hindus in select areas; arbitration; or interpretation and examination of the authority of texts from Hindu Shastras supposed to be available to the orthodox in support of their contention as to the use of roads round certain temples.
('30', 431, 1, 5, 979739) It must be a very simple matter to adopt one or all of the suggestions.
('30', 431, 1, 6, 979811) In closing this letter I would place on record my sincere thanks for the perfect arrangement made by you during the whole of my sojourn in Travancore.
('30', 431, 2, 7, 979962) I am, Yours sincerely, From a microfilm: S.N. 13267
('30', 431, 3, 8, 980014) 256. SPEECH IN REPLY TO ADDRESSES, PARUR 2
('30', 431, 4, 9, 980057) March 18, 1925
('30', 431, 5, 10, 980072) Mahatmaji in his reply observed that it was in keeping with their traditions that they carried to the very letter whatever they resolved upon and hoped that the resolve, the Municipal Councillors had expressed that they would spin and wear khaddar hereafter, would be followed in earnest.
('30', 431, 5, 11, 980361) He regretted that untouchability and unapproachability prevailed in worst forms in Travancore and they owed it to the Motherland and Hinduism to eradicate them.
('30', 431, 5, 12, 980522) He observed that their tastes were so simple that neither men nor women considered it civilized to have multiplicity of clothing.
('30', 431, 5, 13, 980652) He considered it a matter of shame and humiliation to wear foreign or mill made clothes.
('30', 431, 5, 14, 980741) The Ezhavas 3 were weavers who at one time produced all their clothing.

('30', 432, 8, 16, 982276) But had I been a Sanskrit pundit, even then I would not have replied in Sanskrit, because unfortunately today we Hindus have neglected the study of Sanskrit and therefore the masses cannot be expected to understand that language.
('30', 432, 8, 17, 982506) But in order to be in tune with the Sanskrit atmosphere here, I would have spoken in Hindi, had it been possible to do so.

('30', 433, 0, 1, 983090) 434 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 433, 1, 2, 983132) our communication may be carried on in that language.
('30', 433, 1, 3, 983186) It is not a difficult thing, however, to start communicating in Hindi.
('30', 433, 1, 4, 983257) Your motto is, “One community, one religion, one God”.
('30', 433, 1, 5, 983312) I had discussions with Shri Narayan Guru Swami on this subject and since you have given the subject the first place in your welcome address, I am also obliged to mention it in my reply.
('30', 433, 1, 6, 983498) I feel that the attainment of what is implied by this motto is also beyond our powers.
('30', 433, 1, 7, 983585) I can understand the principle of one God.
('30', 433, 1, 8, 983628) In spite of our worshipping Him in a million different ways, our adoration finds its way to Him.
('30', 433, 1, 9, 983725) However, I feel that so long as the human race continues, differences of creeds and religions will indeed exist, since there are many minds and not one.
('30', 433, 1, 10, 983878) If we look at Nature, we shall find that it is full of diversities and it is through them that the one God becomes many.
('30', 433, 1, 11, 983999) To expect that at any stage in the history of the human race the world will have a single religion and a single creed is, I think, as good as wishing that the laws of Nature should become topsy turvy.
('30', 433, 1, 12, 984200) As a result of my limited reading, reflection and meditation, I feel that human society cannot do without the four fold divisions of varna and ashrama.
('30', 433, 1, 13, 984352) Hence, diverse religions and diverse creeds seem to be inevitable.
('30', 433, 1, 14, 984419) Tolerance should be our aim.
('30', 433, 1, 15, 984448) If all of us hold uniform views, where then is the scope for this generous virtue of tolerance?
('30', 433, 1, 16, 984544) However, this search for uniformity is as futile as looking for flowers in the sky.
('30', 433, 1, 17, 984628) Hence, the only possible alternative for us is to tolerate one antoher’s views.
('30', 433, 1, 18, 984708) According to my Muslim friends, I, a born idol worshipper, a believer in incarnation and rebirth, must necessarily cultivate tolerance for Muslims who do not believe in idol worship, who do not believe in incarnation and perhaps in rebirth.
('30', 433, 1, 19, 984949) I, a believer in incarnations, do not think that Christ alone was God, or that he alone was the son of God.
('30', 433, 1, 20, 985057) Nevertheless, I should tolerate the fact that my Christian friends look upon Christ as God and, similarly, Muslims and Christians should tolerate the fact that I bow in reverence to Kanyakumari and Jagannath.
('30', 433, 1, 21, 985266) I can see that the age of tolerance is dawning in my own lifetime, because tolerance is at the root of the dharma of ashimsa.
('30', 433, 1, 22, 985392) That very same tolerance is at the root of the dharma of truth.
('30', 433, 1, 23, 985456) Truth, like God, has a thousand diverse aspects.
('30', 433, 1, 24, 985505) I cannot therefore insist that my view about the nature of truth is the correct one, and those of others wrong.
('30', 433, 1, 25, 985617) That is why I feel we are fast approaching the age of mutual tolerance and mutual love.
('30', 433, 1, 26, 985705) If, therefore, I cannot persuade Shri Narayan Guru Swami to accept the ideal of tolerance, I shall content by understanding the ideal in my own way.
('30', 434, 0, 1, 985854) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 435
('30', 434, 1, 2, 985900) Leaving aside this abstract discussion, let us come to more concrete things.
('30', 434, 1, 3, 985977) While we cannot have before us the ideal of one caste, one religion and one creed, we can certainly have before us the ideal of performing one task daily and regularly for the good of the country.
('30', 434, 1, 4, 986174) When shall We learn to wear khadi and thereby establish a bond of union with the poorest of the poor?
('30', 434, 1, 5, 986276) We can learn this one mantra of making common cause with the poor.
('30', 434, 1, 6, 986343) Instead of talking of universal love, it would be enough if we give up the calico made in the mills of Ahmedabad, Japan or England and win instead the simple love of the poor by wearing cloth spun and woven by our own brothers and sisters.
('30', 434, 1, 7, 986583) Shri Narayan Guru Swami has assured me that he will himself take up spinning and forbid his followers from approaching him unless they are clad in khadi.
('30', 434, 1, 8, 986737) We have to practise the dharma of ahimsa and love in another matter as well.

('30', 435, 1, 5, 988483) But I was reminded only just now that there is also in this land the curse of invisibility, that the very sight of man offends.
('30', 435, 1, 6, 988611) If this is Hinduism I would renounce it today, but as a sanatani Hindu that I call myself, and one brought up in an orthodox family, I know that it is no part of Hinduism to have untouchability, unapproachability or invisibility as they are practised today.
('30', 435, 1, 7, 988869) But I shall be leaving this land in the hope that all those crowds that have attended such gatherings and all those crowds who have associated themselves in the sentiments expressed in the addresses which have censured this caste custom will see to it that this blot is removed from Travancore and Cochin.

('30', 435, 4, 23, 990307) VYKOM SATYAGRAHA
('30', 435, 5, 24, 990324) I offer no apology to the reader for giving much space in these pages to Vykom satyagraha by reproducing the whole of that portion
('30', 436, 0, 1, 990455) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 437
('30', 436, 1, 2, 990501) of the address 1 of the Dewan of Travancore to its Popular Assembly which deals with the Vykom satyagraha.
('30', 436, 1, 3, 990608) It enables the reader to understand and appreciate the nature of the brave struggle that is being carried on by a band of satyagrahis as also the importance of the cause for which satyagraha is being offered.
('30', 436, 1, 4, 990817) Vykom is a test case so far as Travancore and, for that matter, Malabar is concerned.
('30', 436, 1, 5, 990903) It affects the common rights of more than one sixth of the entire population of Travancore.
('30', 436, 1, 6, 990995) Those therefore who are interested in the removal of the curse of untouchability cannot but read the Dewan’s address with interest.
('30', 436, 1, 7, 991127) I do not propose to comment on it this week as it would be unfair to do so in view of the fact that I am to have the honour of meeting him before this will have been printed and in view of the further fact that I have not at the time of writing completed my investigations.
('30', 436, 1, 8, 991401) But I cannot help endorsing the remark of Dewan Bahadur T. Raghaviah that
('30', 436, 2, 9, 991475) there is a world of difference between satyagraha meant to be an educative force and satyagraha intended as an instrument for the coercion of the Government and through them of the orthodox Hindu.
('30', 436, 2, 10, 991672) What the satyagrahis should aim at is the conversion of the orthodox to whom untouchability is a part of their faith.
('30', 436, 2, 11, 991790) I make bold to state that from the very outset satyagraha at Vykom was intended to be an educative force and never an instrument of coercion of the orthodox.
('30', 436, 2, 12, 991948) It was for that reason that the fast against the orthodox was abandoned.
('30', 436, 2, 13, 992021) It was to avoid coercion of the Government by embarrassment that the barricades have been scrupulously respected.
('30', 436, 2, 14, 992135) It was for that reason that no attempt was made to dodge the police.
('30', 436, 2, 15, 992204) It has been recognized that what appears to the reformers as a gross and sinful superstition is to the orthodox a part of their faith.
('30', 436, 2, 16, 992339) The satyagrahi’s appeal has therefore been to the reason of the orthodox.
('30', 436, 2, 17, 992413) But experience has shown that mere appeal to the reason produces no effect upon those who have settled convictions.
('30', 436, 2, 18, 992529) The eyes of their understanding are opened not by argument but by the suffering of the satyagrahi.
('30', 436, 2, 19, 992628) The satyagrahi strives to reach the reason through the heart.
('30', 436, 2, 20, 992690) The method of reaching the heart is to awaken public opinion.
('30', 436, 2, 21, 992752) Public opinion for which one cares is a mightier force than that of gunpowder.
('30', 436, 2, 22, 992831) The Vykom satyagraha has vindicated itself in that it has drawn the attention of the whole of India to the cause and it has been instrumental in the Travancore

('30', 437, 1, 4, 993412) MAN’S INHUMANITY TO MAN In the midst of the incessant rush I am going through in this land of palms (Travancore) where I am writing these notes, I cannot resist noting down a never fading sight I had to witness at Cochin.
('30', 437, 1, 5, 993634) Cochin has imported from Japan numerous rickshaws which its well to do citizens use for their convenience.
('30', 437, 1, 6, 993741) These are drawn not by animals but by men.
('30', 437, 1, 7, 993784) I carefully noted as many of these carriers as passed.
('30', 437, 1, 8, 993839) Not one impressed me with his physique.
('30', 437, 1, 9, 993879) They had neither the calves nor the chest nor the arms well formed for the arduous task of carrying a burden in the hot sun and melting heat.
('30', 437, 1, 10, 994021) The rickshaws are built for carrying one passenger only.
('30', 437, 1, 11, 994078) In my opinion, it is bad enough for a healthy and full limbed man to be carried by man, but I was ashamed of my species and pained beyond measure to see two and even three passengers huddled together in some rickshaws.
('30', 437, 1, 12, 994297) It was no doubt wrong for the carrier not to refuse to carry more than one burden.
('30', 437, 1, 13, 994380) But what is one to say of the pair or the trio who in order to save a few coppers would not be ashamed to be carried by a member of their species who is hardly fit to carry even one of them.
('30', 437, 1, 14, 994571) I hope there is a law in Cochin prohibiting the carrying of more than one passenger in these rickshaws.
('30', 437, 1, 15, 994675) And if there is one, I hope the kindly citizens will see to it that it is strictly obeyed.
('30', 437, 1, 16, 994766) But if there is no such law, I hope that one would be passed making the carriage of more than one passenger an impossibility.
('30', 437, 1, 17, 994892) If I had the power I would abolish the rickshaw.
('30', 437, 1, 18, 994941) But that I know must remain a pious hope.
('30', 437, 1, 19, 994983) But is it too much to hope that men who ply these rickshaws will be subjected to a strict medical examination as to their fitness for the heavy work?
('30', 437, 1, 20, 995133) INTER DINING
('30', 437, 2, 21, 995146) A correspondent asks: “Should children belonging to different castes and living in one boarding house be made to dine together in a common dining room?” The question is not well put.
('30', 437, 2, 22, 995329) But the answer to the question as it is put would be that children cannot be made to inter dine.
('30', 437, 2, 23, 995426) If, however, it be urged that no boarding house keeper can make rules requiring all who care to join it to inter dine, it would be as unreasonable a demand as it would be to compel children who are
('30', 438, 0, 1, 995624) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 439
('30', 438, 1, 2, 995670) admitted without such stipulation as to inter dining to dine in company with children belonging to other castes.
('30', 438, 1, 3, 995783) In the absence of any rule to the contrary, I should imagine that the presumption would be that the usual rules for separate dining arrangements would apply.
('30', 438, 1, 4, 995941) This question of inter dining is a vexed one and in my opinion no hard and fast rules can be laid down.
('30', 438, 1, 5, 996045) Personally, I am not sure that inter dining is a necessary reform.
('30', 438, 1, 6, 996112) At the same time I recognize the tendency towards breaking down the restriction altogether.
('30', 438, 1, 7, 996204) I can find reasons for and against the restriction.
('30', 438, 1, 8, 996256) I would not force the pace.
('30', 438, 1, 9, 996284) I do not regard it as a sin for a person not to dine with another nor do I regard it as sinful if one advocates and practises inter dining.
('30', 438, 1, 10, 996424) I should, however, resist the attempt to break down the restriction in disregard of the feelings of others.
('30', 438, 1, 11, 996532) On the contrary I would respect their scruples in the matter.

('30', 446, 1, 6, 1015634) We even referred our differences to Hakim Saheb and Dr. Ansari for our guidance.
('30', 446, 1, 7, 1015715) Fortunatley, Pandit Motilalji was present at our discussion.

('30', 446, 1, 10, 1015919) We then decided to travel together a few hours to re examine ourselves and to see whether we could remodel our statements.
