('30', 446, 1, 14, 1016594) Our open acknowled gment of our differences will be an object lesson in mutual toleration.
('30', 446, 1, 15, 1016685) Let the public know that neither the Maulana Saheb nor I have spared pains to come near each other.
('30', 446, 1, 16, 1016785) But there was no desire for suppression of opinion.

('30', 446, 1, 20, 1017040) But beyond that the originals have not suffered material alterations.

('30', 446, 4, 23, 1017166) Maulana Shaukat Ali and I went to Rawalpindi on the 4th February to meet the Hindu refugees and the Mussalmans of Kohat to whom the Maulana had written and who were excepted to come to Rawalpindi.
('30', 446, 4, 24, 1017363) Lala Lajpat Rai followed a day later.

('30', 447, 1, 2, 1017533) of the time we were in Rawalpindi.
('30', 447, 1, 3, 1017568) Of the Mussalmans Maulvi Ahmad Gul and Pir Saheb Kamal were the principal parties whose evidence we took.
('30', 447, 1, 4, 1017674) The Hindus had their written and printed statements to which they had nothing to add.
('30', 447, 1, 5, 1017760) The Muslim Working Committee which is functioning in Kohat did not and would not come.
('30', 447, 1, 6, 1017847) They sent a wire to Maulana Saheb saying:
('30', 447, 2, 7, 1017889) A reconciliation has already been effected between Hindus and Muslims.
('30', 447, 2, 8, 1017960) In our opinion this question should not be reopened.
('30', 447, 2, 9, 1018013) The Muslims should therefore be excused for not sending their representatives to Rawalpindi.
('30', 447, 2, 10, 1018106) Maulvi Ahmad Gul and another gentleman who came to Rawalpindi with him were members of the Working Committee but they said they came not as such but as members of the Khilafat Committee.
('30', 447, 2, 11, 1018293) It was difficult to come to any conclusions on details without a thorough examination on the spot and without examining many more witnesses.
('30', 447, 2, 12, 1018434) This, however, we could not do.
('30', 447, 2, 13, 1018466) We could not go to Kohat nor was it our purpose to rake up the whole controversy again by going into minute details.
('30', 447, 2, 14, 1018583) Our purpose was to bring together the two parties if it was at all possible.
('30', 447, 2, 15, 1018660) We therefore confined ourselves to elucidating the main facts.
('30', 447, 2, 16, 1018723) As I am writing this without a detailed consultation with the Maulana Saheb, I state my own conclusions, leaving him either to confirm mine or to state his own.
('30', 447, 2, 17, 1018884) The causes of the events of the 9th September and after were many.
('30', 447, 2, 18, 1018951) Among these was the resentment felt by the Mussalmans over the resentment felt in their turn by the Hindus over the conversions (so called in my opinion) of Hindus—men and married women, and consequent steps taken by them, the Hindus.
('30', 447, 2, 19, 1019186) The desire of the parachas (Mussalman traders of Kohat) to oust the Hindus of Kohat was another.
('30', 447, 2, 20, 1019283) 1 The resentment felt over the alleged abduction by Sardar Makhan Singh’s son of a married Mussalman girl was the third.
('30', 447, 3, 21, 1019404) The cumulative effect of these causes was to create great tension between the two communities.
('30', 447, 3, 22, 1019499) The immediate cause that lighted the

('30', 448, 1, 2, 1019791) conflagration was a poem in the notorious pamphlet published by Mr. Jiwandas, Secretary, Sanatan Dharma Sabha at Rawalpindi, and imported by him into Kohat.
('30', 448, 1, 3, 1019948) It contained a number of bhajans or poems in praise of Shri Krishna and Hindu Muslim unity.
('30', 448, 1, 4, 1020040) But it also contained the one in question.
('30', 448, 1, 5, 1020083) It was a highly offensive poem, undoubtedly calculated to wound Muslim susceptibility.
('30', 448, 1, 6, 1020170) Mr. Jiwandas was not the author.
('30', 448, 1, 7, 1020203) He did not import the pamphlet in order to irritate the Mussalmans.
('30', 448, 1, 8, 1020271) As soon as the matter was brought to the notice of the Sanatan Dharma Sabha, it sent a written apology to the Mussal mans for the offending poem and removed it from the unsold copies.
('30', 448, 1, 9, 1020455) This might have satisfied the Mussalmans, but it did not.
('30', 448, 1, 10, 1020513) The unsold copies, over 500 according to Mussalman testimony and over 900 according to Hindu testimony, were brought to the Town Hall and publicly burnt in the presence of the Assistant Commissioner and a large concourse of Mussalmans.
('30', 448, 1, 11, 1020749) The cover of the pamphlet contained a portrait of Shri Krishna.
('30', 448, 1, 12, 1020813) Mr. Jiwandas was arrested.
('30', 448, 1, 13, 1020840) This took place on the 3rd September, 1924. He was to be brought before the Court on the 11th.
('30', 448, 1, 14, 1020935) The Hindus tried to avoid the Court proceedings and to settle the matter amicably.
('30', 448, 1, 15, 1021018) A Khilafat deputation, too, came from Peshawar for the purpose.
('30', 448, 1, 16, 1021082) The Mussalmans wanted to try Mr. Jiwandas according to Shariat.
('30', 448, 1, 17, 1021146) The Hindus declined but offered to submit to the award of the Khilafatists.
('30', 448, 1, 18, 1021222) The negotiations fell through.
('30', 448, 1, 19, 1021253) The Hindus, therefore, applied for discharge of Mr. Jiwandas.
('30', 448, 1, 20, 1021315) He was released on the 8th September under security and under instructions to leave Kohat.
('30', 448, 1, 21, 1021406) He did leave Kohat immediately.
('30', 448, 1, 22, 1021438) This anticipation of the date of trial enraged the Mussalmans.
('30', 448, 1, 23, 1021501) During the night of the 8th September they held an excited meeting at which fiery speeches were made.
('30', 448, 1, 24, 1021603) It was resolved to approach the Deputy Commissioner in a body and to demand the re arrest of Mr. Jiwandas and the arrest of certain other members of the Sanatan Dharma Sabha.
('30', 448, 1, 25, 1021778) Reprisals against the Hindus were threatened if the Deputy Commissioner did not listen to the demand.
('30', 448, 1, 26, 1021880) Messages were sent out to the neighbouring villages to join the assembly in the morning.
('30', 448, 1, 27, 1021969) About two thousand angry Mussalmans, according to Pir Kamal, marched to the Town Hall.
('30', 448, 1, 28, 1022056) The request of the Deputy Commissioner that a samll party from among the assembly should see him in the Town Hall was rejected and he was compelled to face the vast crowd outside.
('30', 448, 1, 29, 1022236) He yielded to the demand and the elated crowd dispersed.
('30', 448, 1, 30, 1022293) The Hindus had become nervous through fright during the preceding week.

('30', 449, 1, 6, 1022820) The latter still took no notice.
('30', 449, 1, 7, 1022853) There is a hot dispute as to what the crowd did after dispersal near the Town Hall.
('30', 449, 1, 8, 1022937) The Mussalman version is that the Hindus fired the first shot killing a Mussalman boy and wounding another, that this infuriated the mob resulting in the burning and looting that took place that day.
('30', 449, 1, 9, 1023137) The Hindu version is that the first shot was fired by the Mussalmans, that they, the Hindus, fired afterwards and in self defence and that the whole of the looting and burning was according to a pre arranged plan and after pre arranged signals.
('30', 449, 1, 10, 1023382) There is no direct evidence on the point and I am unable to reach a definite conclusion.
('30', 449, 1, 11, 1023471) The Mussalmans contend that no damage would have occurred if the Hindus had not fired the first shot.
('30', 449, 1, 12, 1023573) I am unable to accept the contention.
('30', 449, 1, 13, 1023611) In my opinion some damage was bound to be done, whether the Hindus had fired or not.
('30', 449, 1, 14, 1023696) It is certain to me that Sardar Makhan Singh’s suburban residence was burnt and its garden damaged by the crowd before the firing, no matter from which side it was begun.
('30', 449, 1, 15, 1023867) But there is no doubt that the Hindus did fire and kill or wound some Mussalmans at some stage or other.
('30', 449, 1, 16, 1023972) My opinion is that the crowd elated by its success dispersed itself in several directions and made hostile demonstrations in front of Hindu houses or shops.
('30', 449, 1, 17, 1024129) I should not be surprised if the Hindus who, as shown above, were already nervous and were expecting trouble, took fright at the demonstration and fired in order to scare away the mob.
('30', 449, 1, 18, 1024314) But such an attitude of resistance would infuriate the Mussalmans who were unused to resistance on the part of Hindus.
('30', 449, 1, 19, 1024433) For as Pir Kamal said, the Frontier Mussalmans regarded themselves as Nayaks (protectors) and the Hindus as Hamsayas (here meaning protected).
('30', 449, 1, 20, 1024576) The more, therefore, the Hindus showed resistance the greater became the fury of the mob.
('30', 449, 1, 21, 1024666) To me, then, who fired the first shot has not much significance for the purpose of the distribution of blame.
('30', 449, 1, 22, 1024776) No doubt, if the Hindus had not defended themselves at all or if they had not fired the first shot, assuming that they did, the Mussalman demonstration would have exhausted itself sooner.
('30', 449, 1, 23, 1024964) But such was not to be expected of the

('30', 450, 1, 4, 1025221) I am, however, certain that several Hindus died or were wounded on the 9th at the hands of the Mussalmans.
('30', 450, 1, 5, 1025328) It is difficult to give the total number.

('30', 450, 1, 9, 1025739) Destruction of life and property, in which the constabulary freely partook, which was witnessed by the officials and which they could have prevented, was general.
('30', 450, 1, 10, 1025902) Had not the Hindus been withdrawn from their places and taken to the Cantonment, not many would have lived.

('30', 457, 2, 3, 1042009) March 21, 1925
('30', 457, 3, 4, 1042024) FRIENDS, It gives me very great pleasure to be able to meet you all in this out of the way place, and on seeing the musical instruments here, I wished to hear some of your songs in your own natural way.
('30', 457, 3, 5, 1042227) I know that songs play an important part in the development of national life.
('30', 457, 3, 6, 1042305) But there is song and song and there is all the difference between different varieties.
('30', 457, 3, 7, 1042393) There is song that ennobles and there is song that degrades; and when you get a real, good song full of devotion and fervour, it ennobles.
('30', 457, 3, 8, 1042532) Such are some of our old songs all over India.
('30', 457, 3, 9, 1042579) In days of old, we had our own string instruments, but today the harmonium has displaced those noble instruments.
('30', 457, 3, 10, 1042693) I wish that we could revert to the stringed instruments.
('30', 457, 3, 11, 1042750) They produce a deeper melody and so far as I am concerned they have a far more soothing effect on me than a harmonium.
('30', 457, 3, 12, 1042869) When I look at all of you and all these sisters who have come here, I find the majority of them have foreign cloth on.
('30', 457, 3, 13, 1042988) Now I would like you for a few minutes to consider what the wearing of foreign cloth means.
('30', 457, 3, 14, 1043080) Not more than a hundred years ago, every one of our ancestors—men and women—had a spinning wheel in their homes.
('30', 457, 3, 15, 1043193) And just as toda we have got a kitchen and a cooking stove in every house, so had we a spinning wheel in every house at which the women spun.
('30', 457, 3, 16, 1043335) The village weavers wove the yarn that our sisters spun; and we clothed ourselves that way.
('30', 457, 3, 17, 1043427) Now if everyone spends for himself, say, Rs. 8 per year, for his clothing and supposing this village had a population of 5,000, we would have saved Rs. 40,000 a year.
('30', 457, 3, 18, 1043594) Today we are sending nearly Rs. 40,000 from our own village to Manchester or to Japan or to Bombay.
('30', 457, 3, 19, 1043694) In every case it is bad.
('30', 457, 3, 20, 1043719) In ancient times, we were doing what was right and what was good for our country and which kept our country away from hunger.
('30', 457, 3, 21, 1043845) Now we have changed it; the result is, when there is famine here we do not know what to do.
('30', 457, 3, 22, 1043937) I would like you, therefore, everyone to take a vow never henceforth to wear anything but khadi—hand spun and hand woven.
('30', 457, 3, 23, 1044059) I would ask you also, those of you who have not already introd uced a spinning wheel in your homes, to do so.
('30', 457, 3, 24, 1044169) That will be our Kamadhenu.

('30', 460, 1, 20, 1050911) And you can help in a variety of ways.
('30', 460, 1, 21, 1050950) Those of you who are fairly well to do and cannot spare much money can spare half an hour daily to spinning.
('30', 460, 1, 22, 1051059) You can learn carding and spinning at the Ashram here, take sufficient cotton from week to week, turn it into yarn and deliver that yarn free to the Ashram.
('30', 460, 1, 23, 1051216) That will enable Sjt.
('30', 460, 1, 24, 1051238) Rajagopalachariar to sell khadi at a lower cost than today.
('30', 460, 1, 25, 1051298) Those of you who cannot afford to give cotton may give cash.
('30', 460, 1, 26, 1051359) The Ashram is public property.
('30', 460, 1, 27, 1051390) You have a right to see it at any time you like.

('30', 460, 1, 29, 1051460) And so long as you find that its activity is a helpful activity and serves your district, it is your bounden duty to help it in every way.
('30', 460, 2, 30, 1051599) After the close of the address, Sjt.
('30', 460, 2, 31, 1051636) Rajagopalachariar invited the poor, who promised to boycott foreign cloth and wear only khaddar, to register their names at the Ashram, when they would be supplied with khaddar at a price cheaper than the bazaar price of mill cloth.

('30', 462, 5, 9, 1055144) FRIENDS, I thank you for all these addresses.
('30', 462, 5, 10, 1055190) I note that you endorse my activities in connection with khaddar.
('30', 462, 5, 11, 1055256) The more I think of the possibilities of the spinning wheel and khadi, the more certain I feel that it is the only thing which can solve the problem of the deep distress which has overtaken our land.
('30', 462, 5, 12, 1055456) And as I saw this morning at the Ashram, old women and old men streaming in, and as I saw old women being served with cotton, I felt millions of men and women like this had and could have no other occupation than the spinning wheel.
('30', 462, 5, 13, 1055689) If it were not for our self satisfaction with our own lot and happiness so called, the contemplation of the paupe rism of India would make life a terrible burden to us.
('30', 462, 5, 14, 1055858) Just picture to ourselves an India with a whole one tenth of her population living on merely one meal a day, living on a bread and a pinch of salt, and you will have some conception of the poverty prevailing in India.
('30', 462, 5, 15, 1056076) It is not a picture drawn from my imagination but it is a statement based on facts collected by the inexhaustible energy of the Grand Old Man of India, Dadabhai Naoroji.
('30', 462, 5, 16, 1056246) It was he who first introduced us to the statistics that were prepared by English administrators and from these statistics he showed that India was daily growing poorer and poorer.
('30', 462, 5, 17, 1056427) Now, the remedy for removing the distress lies in our own hands.
('30', 462, 5, 18, 1056492) We are responsible for the distress.
('30', 462, 5, 19, 1056529) We gave up the use of cloth

('30', 463, 1, 2, 1056755) that was woven by our own weavers out of yarn spun by millions of our own sisters.
('30', 463, 1, 3, 1056838) We chose to adopt the calico from Manchester, Japan and lately from Bombay and Ahmedabad.
('30', 463, 1, 4, 1056928) And in doing so, we did not care a straw as to what happened to our own neighbours.
('30', 463, 1, 5, 1057012) We did not stop to think that the use of calico from mills, no matter where they were situated, deprived the poor labourers who were devoted to agriculture of the profit they received from working during their spare hours.
('30', 463, 1, 6, 1057235) It was a crime for which we have paid heavily and we are still paying heavily.

('30', 463, 1, 8, 1057350) If only we will cease to be callous and indifferent to the sufferings of our own countrymen and countrywomen, we can adopt the remedy today and help to remove the poverty from our land.
('30', 463, 1, 9, 1057536) I have been visiting the khaddar centres in the South and I have been told that if the people of this Presidency were to patronize or rather do their duty by the people by buying khaddar, thousands of these men and women would get a few coppers more into their pockets.

('30', 463, 1, 14, 1058659) It is an incredibly simple and certain solution of the problem which has been engaging the attention of the best of our countrymen for a generation.
('30', 463, 1, 15, 1058808) You are unable now to complain of want of means to learn spinning or secure khaddar.

('30', 463, 1, 17, 1059063) You have but to walk there and you can have your spinning lessons for nothing, you can have good spinning wheels and you can have khaddar to your heart’s satisfaction.
('30', 463, 1, 18, 1059231) Equally important is the question of untouchability if we are to serve our religion.

('30', 465, 1, 2, 1061536) APPENDICES
('30', 465, 2, 3, 1061547) APPENDIX I
('30', 465, 3, 4, 1061558) M. N. ROY ON BOLSHEVISM
('30', 465, 4, 5, 1061582) Some of his American friends wrote Mahatma Gandhi that, in the name of religion, he was probably introducing Bolshevism into India.
('30', 465, 4, 6, 1061714) These gratuitous “friends” obviously taking their cue from the spokesmen of Anglo Saxon Imperialism (who often masquerade as pacifists), depict the revolt of the Moslem peoples as a menace to the world, because this revolt is supported by Bolshevik Russia.
('30', 465, 4, 7, 1061971) It should have been very simple for Mahatmaji to give a fitting reply to this impudent communication.
('30', 465, 4, 8, 1062073) He could have told his “responsibly (?) foreign friends” that the Moslem peoples have legitimate reason to revolt, and that any political doctrine or government supporting this revolt is to be considered favourably by all apostles of freedom.
('30', 465, 4, 9, 1062316) Besides, he could have requested his American friends to get busy at home, if they sincerely dreaded any menace to the world.
('30', 465, 4, 10, 1062442) What is menacing the world more today than American Imperialism?
('30', 465, 4, 11, 1062507) Is the revolt of the Moslem people more sinister than the Ku Klux Klan and the American Legion?
('30', 465, 4, 12, 1062603) Is Bolshevist atheism more godless than the anti Asiatic spirit of the American democracy?
('30', 465, 5, 13, 1062694) The Mahatma, however, did not give such a direct answer.
('30', 465, 5, 14, 1062751) He preferred to justify himself—to absolve himself from any possible suspicion of Bolshevist tendency.
('30', 465, 5, 15, 1062854) But the curious thing is, that although by his own confession he did not know anything about Bolshevism, nevertheless he was extremely solicitous to disown any leaning towards it, so sure is his instinctive antipathy for it.
('30', 465, 5, 16, 1063079) In an article in Young India he writes: “In the first place I must confess that I do not know the meaning of Bolshevism.” This is indeed a very damaging confession, in view of the fact that it is made by one standing at the head of a great popular movement.
('30', 465, 5, 17, 1063337) The Mahatma said in the same article that he knew that there were two opposite pictures of Bolshevism, “one painting it in the blackest colour, the other hailing it as a deliverance for the downtrodden masses all the world over.” But he does not know what to believe.
('30', 465, 5, 18, 1063605) Here again he could follow a simple human course.
('30', 465, 5, 19, 1063655) He could easily find out who paints the first picture.
('30', 465, 5, 20, 1063710) It is done by those who are ruling over the world with the policy of blood and iron.
('30', 465, 5, 21, 1063795) In deference to his scruples of impartiality, he might not believe those giving the second picture; but certainly Mahatmaji does need to be convinced that the first party is not the friend or deliverer of the human race.
('30', 465, 5, 22, 1064016) Therefore when they depict a thing in the blackest colour, the oppressed section of humanity can instinctively sense some sinister motive, they feel that the “blackest colour” is for deceiving them.
('30', 465, 5, 23, 1064215) By this unerring instinct, Indian nationalists during
('30', 466, 0, 1, 1064269) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 467
('30', 466, 1, 2, 1064315) the War used to read two German victories in the place of each allied victory cabled by Reuter, and the Mexican peon calls himself proudly a Bolshevik, for the simple reason that the American capitalists are so much against Bolshevism.
('30', 466, 1, 3, 1064551) But I suppose, the mentality of a Mahatma is too complicated an organism to admit of such a simple instinctive process.
('30', 466, 2, 4, 1064671) Since the deplorable ignorance of Bolshevism is not the Mahatma’s alone, but is shared by many in India, and since this ignorance does not preclude them from forming an opinion on the subject, it may not be uncalled for to say a few words about this “monstrous” doctrine.
('30', 466, 2, 5, 1064943) It is the more called for, in view of the fact that Bolshevism (which, by the way, is not the result, as is commonly believed, but the basic principle of the Russian Revolution of 1917) is the most dominant political factor of the contemporary world.
('30', 466, 2, 6, 1065194) Just as the great French Revolution of 1789 affected the political thought and life of Europe at that epoch, the Russian Revolution is bound to play the same role in our time, with the difference that the geographical situation of Russia, coupled with the principles of her revolution, will bring wider spheres, including Asia and Africa, under its sway.
('30', 466, 2, 7, 1065549) This is the case, despite the explicable apprehension and righteous indignation of the pacifically minded ladies and gentlemen, whose good faith is taken for granted by Mahatmaji, but is seriously doubted by more practical men of the world.
('30', 466, 3, 8, 1065790) Now, as far as Mahatmaji is concerned, the main principles of Bolshevism will not be anything new.
('30', 466, 3, 9, 1065889) He himself will think so.
('30', 466, 3, 10, 1065915) But principles become a bundle of dead formulas if they are not put into action.
('30', 466, 3, 11, 1065996) By his own declaration, the Mahatma desires to see the masses freed from the domination of capitalism.
('30', 466, 3, 12, 1066099) Well, Bolshevism does not propose anything more monstrous.
('30', 466, 3, 13, 1066158) The Bolsheviks are generally in agreement with Mahatmaji when he says, “the greatest menace to the world today is the growing, exploiting, irresponsible imperialism which is threatening the independent existence and expansion of the weaker races.” But the difference between Mahatmaji and the Bolsheviks is that in the hands of the former, this gospel of freedom loses all practical value, being subordinated to an intricate conception of morality, religion and God, while the latter do not permit their vision to be clouded by illusions, and deal with the world as it is.
('30', 466, 3, 14, 1066731) The result is, that while Bolshevism forges ahead, breaking one link after another of the mighty chain of time honoured servitude, in the face of united and determined Opposition of the powers that be, Gandhism gropes in the dark, spinning out ethical and religious dogmas, that only prevent the masses from developing the will to fight for freedom.
('30', 466, 4, 15, 1067081) It can be taken for granted that Mahatmaji is acquainted with the general principles of Socialism; not the Utopian brand of St. Simon, Thomas More, Tolstoy, etc., but that formulated on the basis of scientific knowledge and economic facts by Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels.
('30', 466, 4, 16, 1067355) The principles of Socialism are (1) to overthrow the
('30', 467, 0, 1, 1067408) 468 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 467, 1, 2, 1067450) capitalist system of production; (2) abolition of private property; (3) reorganization of the means of social production and distribution on the basis of communal ownership and (4) transformation of the class ridden society into a human fraternity.
('30', 467, 1, 3, 1067699) These are also the principles of Bolshevism, the latter being Socialism in its militant and initial stages of victory.
('30', 467, 2, 4, 1067818) The term “Bolshevism” which has come to be associated with bloodshed, destruction, terror and what not, is very harmless in its meaning.
('30', 467, 2, 5, 1067955) It is derived from the Russian word bolsheviki, which is the synonym for the adherents of the majority.
('30', 467, 2, 6, 1068059) The term was first used when the Russian Socialist Democratic Labour Party split in 1903 into two factions on the questions of programme and tactics.
('30', 467, 2, 7, 1068209) The programme and tactics advocated by the majority, led by Lenin together with others, came to be known as Bolshevism; and since the Russian proletariat scored the victory in October 1917, having fought according to the programme and tactics advocated by the majority of the party ever since 1903, the October Revolution is called a Bolshevist victory, which means the first triumph of Socialism.
('30', 467, 2, 8, 1068607) What are the concrete results of the Russian Revolution?
('30', 467, 2, 9, 1068664) (1) A corrupt, irresponsible despotism was overthrown.
('30', 467, 2, 10, 1068719) (2) The bourgeoisie, which under the guise of democracy, sought in conjunction with foreign powers to deprive the Russian masses of the benefits of the Revolution, was also overthrown.
('30', 467, 2, 11, 1068904) (3) The landed aristocracy, the mainstay of the Czarist despotism, was destroyed, land declared to be the property of the entire nation and distributed among the cultivators.
('30', 467, 2, 12, 1069079) (4) Large industries were nationalized.
('30', 467, 2, 13, 1069119) (5) Foreign trade made a State monopoly.
('30', 467, 2, 14, 1069160) (6) All legislative and administrative power was transferred to the overwhelming majority of the people, namely, the workers, peasants and soldiers, who exercised this power through their councils (soviets).
('30', 467, 2, 15, 1069368) (7) All right of private property and the class privilege accruing therefrom was abolished.
('30', 467, 2, 16, 1069460) These in general are the principles of Bolshevism, applied practically in Russia in consequence of the Revolution.
('30', 467, 2, 17, 1069575) Now that he knows what Bolshevism is, what is the attitude of the Mahatma towards it?
('30', 467, 2, 18, 1069661) It will be interesting for India, as well as the whole world, to know the reply.
('30', 467, 3, 19, 1069742) Now comes the thorny question.
('30', 467, 3, 20, 1069773) Mahatmaji might not take exception to these principles, but he would certainly make many a stipulation as to the method of realizing them.
('30', 467, 3, 21, 1069912) For him there is only one touch stone for everything.
('30', 467, 3, 22, 1069966) If Bolshevism is atheistic, he is against it.
('30', 467, 3, 23, 1070012) That is all.
('30', 467, 3, 24, 1070025) Well, there we have given him a definition of Bolshevism in a nutshell.
('30', 467, 3, 25, 1070097) It is for him to pronounce whether it is a negation of God or what.
('30', 467, 3, 26, 1070165) He cannot maintain that it is a negation of God, unless he holds private property and vested interests to be a divine ordinance, because Bolshevism is certainly a negation of private property and vested interests, which from the dawn of civilization, have been the curse of human society.
('30', 467, 3, 27, 1070454) In the practical programme of Bolshevism there is no question of God or religion.
('30', 467, 3, 28, 1070536) It is neither theistic nor
('30', 468, 0, 1, 1070563) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 469
('30', 468, 1, 2, 1070609) atheistic.
('30', 468, 1, 3, 1070620) It concerns the worldly life of man.
('30', 468, 1, 4, 1070657) The possible conflict with God and religion occurs only when the latter stands in the way; when the conception of God or religion clashes with this practical programme.
('30', 468, 1, 5, 1070826) In that case, Bolshevism does not hesitate to take up the challenge even of the supposed Almighty, and become atheistic, thus running the risk of forfeiting the approbation of the Mahatma.
('30', 468, 1, 6, 1071015) But by doing so, it not only becomes the champion of the material rights of the masses, but holds up as well the torch of intellectual and spiritual emancipation to dissipate the gloom of ignorance and superstition in which the masses have been kept for ages by the dominating class.
('30', 468, 2, 7, 1071299) The programme of Bolshevism, which Mahatmaji cannot deny to be humanitarian (unless he chooses to take up openly the cause of the upper class) is, however, not easily put into practice.
('30', 468, 2, 8, 1071485) The reign of terror and devastating civil war, that undeniably took place in Russia after the revolution, owe their origin to the fact that a brutal resistance was put up to prevent the realization of this programme.
('30', 468, 2, 9, 1071702) Not only the Russian aristocracy and bourgeoisie, who naturally frantically tried to regain their lost position, put up this resistance; they were openly backed by the international bourgeoisie, who saw in the Russian Revolution the first breach in their vital citadel.
('30', 468, 2, 10, 1071972) A part of this ceaseless campaign was the picturing of Bolshevism in the darkest colours, which did not altogether fail to impress even the Mahatma.
('30', 468, 2, 11, 1072121) Now what were the Bolsheviks to do in that situation?
('30', 468, 2, 12, 1072175) There were two alternatives: to call upon the Russian workers and peasants to be godfearing and meekly slip back into the bondage they had so heroically broken or to keep on fighting even against God anal religion, if they stood in the way, to protect and consolidate the freedom won.
('30', 468, 2, 13, 1072460) Bolshevism was obliged to accept the second alternative, because not only all available material forces were concentrated in order to force the Russian workers and peasants back under the capitalist and Czarist tyranny; all the arms of God and religion were also mobilized for the same purpose.
('30', 468, 2, 14, 1072755) Bolshevism is not a gospel of God: Bolshevists are not angels.
('30', 468, 2, 15, 1072818) But neither is Bolshevism the spirit of demons.
('30', 468, 2, 16, 1072866) The Mahatma proposes “to touch the masses through their hearts, their better nature” It is a fascinating proposition, to which Bolshvism would not object, had it been found workable in the practice of liberating the masses from class domination and imperialist oppression.
('30', 468, 2, 17, 1073139) His theory of “discipline” is also very questionable.
('30', 468, 2, 18, 1073193) It may be good for the spiritual well being of the masses; but it certainly weakens their will to fight for freedom.
('30', 468, 2, 19, 1073310) All these doctrines about “heart”, “better nature”, “discipline” and the like have been adumbrated from time immemorial by those who were the (perhaps unconscious) instruments of class domination.
('30', 468, 2, 20, 1073507) Bolshevism does not shirk any task, however disagreeable or difficult it may be.
('30', 468, 2, 21, 1073588) It challenges the existence of God and denounces all the codes of religion and ethics originating therefrom because in the struggle for freedom they are all found arrayed on the side of despotism, tyranny and oppression.
('30', 469, 0, 1, 1073809) 470 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 469, 1, 2, 1073851) Bolshevism is prepared to leave God alone, if He and His agents on earth agree not to meddle in things temporal.
('30', 469, 1, 3, 1073964) But if they do not agree to be satisfied with their super material position and seek to make trouble on earth, Bolshevism will preach atheism to liberate the masses from the snare of ignorance woven by religion.
('30', 469, 2, 4, 1074176) M. N. ROY Young India, 1 1 1925
('30', 469, 3, 5, 1074208) APPENDIX II
('30', 469, 4, 6, 1074220) EXTRACT FROM C. RAJAGOPALACHARI’S COMMENT ON CHARKHA
('30', 469, 5, 7, 1074273) No changers who feel that the salvation of the country, the permanent anchor of its hope, rests on the charkha, must not look up, on this side or that, but prayerfully carry the burden.
('30', 469, 5, 8, 1074459) There is no rest or fatigue for us.
('30', 469, 5, 9, 1074495) The wheel is our hope, our joy, our friend, our good angel.
('30', 469, 5, 10, 1074555) We must work for it in our waking hours, and dream about it when we sleep.
('30', 469, 5, 11, 1074630) I did not see fully the meaning of things at first.
('30', 469, 5, 12, 1074682) I therefore thought Mahatmaji went along paths where I saw no logic or light.
('30', 469, 5, 13, 1074760) But I now see things clearly, and hope all those who felt distracted by doubts like myself will also see.
('30', 469, 5, 14, 1074866) Spin, spin and spin and make others spin—this is our single mantra, our Gayatri.
('30', 469, 6, 15, 1074947) While I saw all this, I felt at the same time that there was some sort of unreality, some sort of political playing with truth, casting a shadow over all this plan of Satyagraha.
('30', 469, 6, 16, 1075126) But here I depend on judgement of the guru whose instinctive sense of Truth is so much greater than mine, and I feel at ease.
('30', 469, 7, 17, 1075252) C. R. Young India, 15 1 1925
('30', 469, 8, 18, 1075281) APPENDIX III
('30', 469, 9, 19, 1075294) EXTRACT FROM DEWAN OF TRAVANCORE’S SPEECH ON VYKOM SATYAGRAHA
('30', 469, 10, 20, 1075356) The third matter relates to the resolution that was moved by Mr. N. Kumaran recommending that the Government should throw open the roads around and in the vicinity of the Vykom temple to all classes.
('30', 469, 10, 21, 1075556) I propose to deal with this resolution at some length and explain the position of the Government.
('30', 469, 10, 22, 1075654) The custom prohibiting the use by certain communities of certain roads forms the basis of the Vykom satyagraha and has been the cause of considerable comment both in and outside Travancore.
('30', 469, 10, 23, 1075844) There are certain Hindu communities falling outside the fold of caste in Kerala, whose approach or touch has been, from time immemorial, unfortunately considered to carry pollution with it, both to the members of caste Hindu communities and to the deities
('30', 470, 0, 1, 1076100) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 471
('30', 470, 1, 2, 1076146) in the temples to which the latter communities have access.
('30', 470, 1, 3, 1076206) In consequence, these non caste Hindu communities have not been allowed the use of roads lying within a certain distance from some Hindu temples even though such roads are public in the sense that they are open to certain classes of the public.
('30', 470, 1, 4, 1076451) The existence of this custom is admitted by the non caste Hindus.
('30', 470, 1, 5, 1076517) The most important among the non caste Hindu communities, so far as Travancore is concerned, are the Ezhavas, who constitute one sixth of the entire population, and who have, within recent times, made rapid advance in education and in material prosperity.
('30', 470, 1, 6, 1076773) This community naturally feels that the prohibition is derogatory to its self respect and it is a feeling with which every right minded man is bound to sympathize.
('30', 470, 1, 7, 1076937) The case of the Ezhavas and their brethren has, as a matter of fact, secured a certain amount of sympathy from members of communities more fortunately circumstanced.
('30', 470, 2, 8, 1077103) The satyagraha movement at Vykom was started nearly a year ago by a band of Ezhavas and their sympathizers to get this disability removed.
('30', 470, 2, 9, 1077242) The modus operandi of the movement consisted in the attempt to break through the long established custom referred to above by entering the prohibited area, even though it meant wounding the religious susceptibilities of the caste Hindus, and by defying the orders of the local Magistracy forbidding entry into the prohibited area, such orders having had to be passed to preserve the public peace threatened by the action of the non caste Hindu communities.
('30', 470, 2, 10, 1077699) The aim of the satyagrahis is to force the hands of the Government to authorize by an executive order the violation of an established custom, which has received the recognition of the Travancore High Court in a series of decisions commencing with the case in 5 T.L.R. and which is therefore the present law of the land.
('30', 470, 3, 11, 1078019) It is not the intention of the Government to justify the existence of this custom.
('30', 470, 3, 12, 1078102) Some may call it prejudice and some superstition.
('30', 470, 3, 13, 1078152) But, by whatever name it may be called, the custom is there and has to be reckoned with.
('30', 470, 3, 14, 1078241) As I have already said, it is based upon religious belief; and, as you all know, such beliefs are dear to the people who hold them.
('30', 470, 3, 15, 1078373) Such customs based upon religious beliefs are not unknown in other parts of India.
('30', 470, 3, 16, 1078456) In the Madras Presidency, for example, non caste Hindus are not permitted to use some of the public streets inhabited by caste Hindus, and an attempt to violate this custom in the Salem District led, within the last few months, to a riot attended with murder and in the Malabar District, to a disturbance of the public peace.
('30', 470, 3, 17, 1078782) Even among the non caste communities, wells touched by some of them are not used by some others.
('30', 470, 3, 18, 1078879) In Upper India also similar customs are widely prevalent.
('30', 470, 3, 19, 1078937) It is the paramount duty of every Government not to interfere with the religious beliefs or usages based upon them, so long as they are not outrageously in human.
('30', 470, 3, 20, 1079100) It is also the duty to the Government to preserve the public peace, and maintain the status quo ante.
('30', 470, 3, 21, 1079202) Every Executive Government is bound to maintain and
('30', 471, 0, 1, 1079254) 472 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('30', 471, 1, 2, 1079296) carry out the laws as it exists and as it is interpreted by its courts of justice.
('30', 471, 1, 3, 1079379) This is what the Travancore Government have done, as pointed out by the Additional Head Sirkar Vakil at the discussion of the resolution in the Legislative Council and this is also the policy pursued by other Governments in India.
('30', 471, 2, 4, 1079610) Now let us examine the position at Vykom in some detail.
('30', 471, 2, 5, 1079667) The roads immediately surrounding the temple are the private property of the temple and are not public roads.
('30', 471, 2, 6, 1079777) Those that converge towards the temple are, on the contrary, public roads.
('30', 471, 2, 7, 1079852) But, according to admitted and immemorial custom, they are up to within a certain distance of the temple public in a qualified sense only, viz., that they are open to certain classes of the public alone and are not king’s highways open to all communities.
('30', 471, 2, 8, 1080108) There is no public institution necessitating the entry into them of the entire public.
('30', 471, 2, 9, 1080195) The only real material inconvenience occasioned by the prohibition of entry into this area is the necessity to take devious and more lengthy routes from one point of the town of Vykom to another.
('30', 471, 2, 10, 1080391) This inconvenience the Government promised to remove by opening new roads for the use of the entire public on the outskirts of the prohibited area.
('30', 471, 2, 11, 1080539) This offer was not accepted, so that the sole justification for the demand for the removal of the prohibition is a feeling of self respect or, in other words, sentiment.
('30', 471, 2, 12, 1080709) I grant that this feeling deserves to be respected; but I ask, is it possible for a Government to respect it if, in so doing, it is compelled to act in violation of a well recognized and well established legal position and, in defiance of the religious beliefs entertained by another community?
('30', 471, 3, 13, 1081004) It has been urged, in the course of the discussion on the resolution, that the Government having thrown open public institutions, public offices and the public service to these communities, they cannot now refuse to remove this disability which is derogatory to their self respect.
('30', 471, 3, 14, 1081286) It is true that the Gover nment have done their utmost to remove several disabilities under which these communities have laboured so long and to give them equal opportunities with the other communities as far as possible; but the grant of permission to enter areas considered sacred by certain other sections of the Hindu community is of quite a different, character, as it would violate established rights based on religious faith.
('30', 471, 4, 15, 1081719) It is a matter for deep regret that the Ezhavas and other non caste Hindus of Travancore should have greatly prejudiced their cause by the methods they have adopted.
('30', 471, 4, 16, 1081885) The policy of attempting to secure the recognition of their claims by the caste Hindus through pressure put upon them by the Executive Government will be neither lasting nor far reaching in its results.
('30', 471, 4, 17, 1082088) All settlements arrived at as the result of the exercise of force majeure are bound to be short lived.
('30', 471, 4, 18, 1082191) It should have been far better had the Ezhavas devoted their energies to methods of peaceful persuasion and the education of the caste communities to a realization of the fact that the custom of untouchability is as degrading to the latter as it is unjust to the former.
('30', 471, 4, 19, 1082462) There is a
('30', 472, 0, 1, 1082473) VOL. 30 : 27 DECEMBER, 1924 21 MARCH 1925 473
('30', 472, 1, 2, 1082519) world of difference between satyagraha meant to be an educative force and satyagraha intended as an instrument for the coercion of the Government and through them of the orthodox Hindus.
('30', 472, 1, 3, 1082706) What the sayagrahis should aim at is the conversion of the orthodox to whom untouchability is part of their faith.
('30', 472, 1, 4, 1082821) The results of such a course of action will, no doubt, be slow but being based on voluntary assent, will be permanent.
('30', 472, 2, 5, 1082940) A satisfactory solution of the question can be reached only through negotiations between the disputing communities and by a compromise acceptable to both.
('30', 472, 2, 6, 1083095) While the Government recognize the legal right of the caste Hindu communities to maintain the prohibition so long as the law is what it is, they cannot but feel that it would be wise for these communities not to insist too strongly on their legal rights but to recognize the time spirit and give up, as quickly as possible, religious beliefs and prejudices which militate against communal harmony, and to admit claims which the world has come to regard as irrefutable.
('30', 472, 2, 7, 1083564) The Government are prepared to do everything in their power to explore the avenues along which negotiations to this end may proceed and the needed rapprochement reached.
('30', 472, 2, 8, 1083734) More than this it is unreasonable to expect the Government to undertake and further persistence of both sides in this struggle, without change in their angle of vision, would only serve to further intensify class hatred and endanger the public peace.
('30', 472, 3, 9, 1083985) Young India, 19 3 1925
